CourseID: P CAS 110. Humanities College Scholars Colloquium. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduces fields in the humanities to freshman honors students. Faculty members discuss their research, the nature of their fields, and career opportunities. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 3 credits. Pre- or coreq: acceptance into the Society of College Scholars program.

CourseID: P CAS 120. Science College Scholars Colloquium. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduces fields in the sciences to freshman honors students. Faculty members discuss their research, the nature of their fields, and career opportunities. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 3 credits. Pre- or coreq: acceptance into the Society of College Scholars program.

CourseID: P CAS 130. Social Science College Scholars Colloquium. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduces fields in the social sciences to freshman honors students. Faculty members discuss their research, the nature of their fields, and career opportunities. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 3 credits. Pre- or coreq: acceptance into the Society of College Scholars program.

Descriptions: P HIST 326 Colonial and Postcolonial Africa

CourseID: P AFR 215. Introduction to African Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of African studies. Evaluates the social, cultural, political, economic and environmental diversity of and issues affecting historical and contemporary Africa and African peoples.

CourseID: P AFR 604. Internship: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P AFR 606. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P AFR 609. Supervised Tutoring. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P AEIS 101. Introductory Academic Oral Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on strategies to improve aural-oral academic communication through discussions, seminars, dialogue, videos, and lectures. Sequence with AEIS 102. Pre- or coreq: placement test.

CourseID: P AEIS 102. Advanced Academic Oral Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on strategies to improve aural-oral academic communication through discussions, seminars, dialogue, and presentations. Sequence with AEIS 101. Pre- or coreq: placement test or AEIS 101 with a grade of C– or better.

CourseID: P AEIS 107. Reading Academic Discourse. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on interactive reading of academic text, building reading strategies for better comprehension, speed, and confidence, and developing critical reading skills. Prereq: placement test.

CourseID: P AEIS 108. Advanced Reading Academic Discourse. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on interactive reading of academic text, reading strategies for better comprehension, speed, and confidence, and further development of critical, interpretive and evaluative reading. Sequence with AEIS 107 (optional). Prereq: placement test or AEIS 107 with a grade of C– or better.

CourseID: P AEIS 110. Introductory Academic Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces conventions of expository essay writing. Emphasizes clear, effective written communication and development of editing skills. Covers grammar in context. Sequence with AEIS 111, 112. Prereq: placement test.

CourseID: P AEIS 111. Intermediate Academic Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate writing for nonnative speakers of English. Critical analysis of academic texts leading to summary, paraphrase, essay-examination responses, and expository essays. Sequence with AEIS 110, 112. Prereq: placement test or C– or better or P in AEIS 110.

CourseID: P AEIS 112. Advanced Academic Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced writing for nonnative speakers of English. Critical reading of academic texts for response in various academic modes: reporting research, critical analysis, and argumentation. Sequence with AEIS 110,

CourseID: P WR 121 College Composition I 4 ANTH 145 Principles of Archaeology
Descriptions: P First term of first-year second-language sequence 4

CourseID: P MATH 105 University Mathematics I 4 WR 121 College Composition I
Descriptions: P MATH 106 University Mathematics II 4 WR 122 College Composition II

CourseID: P MATH 106 University Mathematics II 4 WR 122 College Composition II
Descriptions: P Credits Spring MATH 107 University Mathematics III ANTH 161 Introduction to Cultural Anthropology Multicultural course Group-satisfying course in social science

CourseID: P ANTH 114. Anthropology of Pirates and Piracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political and economic origins and legacies of piracy through 500 years of history in the Americas, Europe, and Africa.

CourseID: P ANTH 119. Anthropology and Aliens. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how anthropology and speculative fiction have mutually constituted each other historically as each explores culture and society, and what makes us human.

CourseID: P ANTH 145. Principles of Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to archaeology methods and interpretation.

CourseID: P ANTH 150. World Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to prehistoric societies and cultural change through the examination of archaeological case studies from around the world. Taught once or more per academic year.

CourseID: P ANTH 161. Introduction to Cultural Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A first look into the work of cultural anthropology and an introduction to the cultural diversity of the world.

CourseID: P ANTH 162. Introduction to Medical Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to medical anthropology focusing on health, illness and healing from a cross-cultural perspective.

CourseID: P ANTH 163. Origins of Storytelling. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of evolutionary thinking to the origins and function of literature.

CourseID: P ANTH 165. Sexuality and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines sexuality through the historical, cultural, economic, and political factors that contribute to the construction of sexual identities, relationships, and institutions.

CourseID: P ANTH 170. Introduction to Human Origins. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Homo sapiens as a living organism; biological evolution and genetics; fossil hominids.

CourseID: P ANTH 171. Introduction to Monkeys and Apes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolutionary biology of the primates: the fossil record and ecology in the age of mammals, primate anatomy, locomotor feeding adaptations, taxonomic relations, and primate ethology.

CourseID: P ANTH 173. Evolution of Human Sexuality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Includes basic genetics, physiology, and behavior. Evolution of sex, of the sexes, and of the role of sex in mammal, primate, and human behavior.

CourseID: P ANTH 175. Evolutionary Medicine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the application of evolutionary thinking to the study of human health and disease.

CourseID: P ANTH 176. Introduction to Forensic Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to human skeletal analysis and its application in a legal context, using biological and anthropological approaches to the recovery and identificationof human remains.

CourseID: P ANTH 220. Introduction to Nutritional Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Human nutrition from a biocultural anthropological perspective, including the relationship of food consumption patterns to evolution, contemporary issues relating to malnutrition, and diseases of nutrition.

CourseID: P ANTH 223. Anthropology of Chocolate. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course explores the impact and meaning that chocolate has had on cultures around the world and on the human body.

CourseID: P ANTH 224M. Introduction to Anthropology of the African Diaspora. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theoretical questions and methodological concerns framing an anthropology of the African diaspora. Multilisted with ES 224M.

CourseID: P ANTH 225. Evolution of Play. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores a range of human play behaviors as adaptations that evolved in a hunting-and-gathering context, functioning to develop physical, cognitive, and social capacities needed in adulthood.

CourseID: P ANTH 243. Island Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an in-depth understanding about the prehistory of various island regions in a comparative perspective as seen in the material culture and how islands help archaeologists decipher patterns of changing human behavior over time, including migration processes, settlement patterns, environmental interactions, and exchange systems.

CourseID: P ANTH 248. Archaeology of Wild Foods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how diet and early cooking affected human evolution, harvest-processing of wild Pacific Northwest foods, pre-Neolithic cooking technologies.

CourseID: P ANTH 250. Introduction to Middle East Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores national, familial, religious, and gendered identities in the Middle East as well as colonial histories, historical memory, politics, globalization, and world view.

CourseID: P ANTH 260. Domestic Animals. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores human relationships with domestic animals, examining the domestication process and the effects of animal domestication on human society.

CourseID: P ANTH 270. Introduction to Biological Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the biological aspects of the human species from comparative, ecological, and evolutionary perspectives. Explores theoretical and methodological issues in biological anthropology.

CourseID: P ANTH 274. Animals and People. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores contemporary and historical examples of human-animal interactions around the globe from a cross-cultural perspective. We analyze the influences of culture and biology on these interactions, explore perspectives, and engage in hypothesis testing.

CourseID: P ANTH 278. Scientific Racism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding past scientific attitudes on racial variation helps place modern concepts of human diversity and racial segregation in a broader anthropological and scientific context.

CourseID: P ANTH 280. Introduction to Language and Culture. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship and methodology of language and culture.

CourseID: P ANTH 284. Warfare in Human Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reviews current theories regarding when/why warfare emerged in human prehistory, examining evidence from animal behavior, cognitive psychology, and the fossil, archaeological, and ethnographic records.

CourseID: P ANTH 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P ANTH 310. Exploring Other Cultures: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ANTH 310. Exploring Other Cultures: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How anthropologists study and describe human cultures. Content varies; draws on fieldwork, famous ethnographies, specific ethnographic areas and their problems, and comparative study of selected cultures. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P ANTH 311. Anthropology of Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a wide range of issues related to economic, cultural, and ideological aspects of globalization. Prereq: ANTH 161.

CourseID: P ANTH 314. Gender in Cross-Cultural Perspective. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cross-cultural exploration of women's power in relation to political, economic, social, and cultural roles. Case studies from Africa, America, Asia, Europe, and the Middle East.

CourseID: P ANTH 315. Gender, Folklore, Inequality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cross-cultural exploration of the expressive and artistic realm of women's lives. Topics include life-cycle rituals, religion, healing, verbal arts, crafts, and music.

CourseID: P ANTH 320. Native North Americans. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interpretive approach to accomplishments, diversity, and survival of precontact, postcontact, and present-day American Indian peoples. Impact of Euro-American stereotypes on politics and identity. Prereq: ANTH 161.

CourseID: P ANTH 322. Anthropology of the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the culture and the political economy of the contemporary United States, with a particular focus on race, class, and gender relations. Pre or coreq: ANTH 161.

CourseID: P ANTH 326. Caribbean Societies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the legacy of processes that formed Caribbean culture— migration, slavery, and trade—in religious, popular, and scholarly contexts.

CourseID: P ANTH 328. New Guinea. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A look at the lifeways of New Guinea people; focuses on personhood, gender, exchange, Christianity, and development.

CourseID: P ANTH 329. Immigration and Farmworkers Political Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mexican farmworkers in the United States, their history and living and working conditions explored within the political culture of immigration. Introductory social science course recommended.

CourseID: P ANTH 330. Hunters and Gatherers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of contemporary hunter-gatherer societies. Foraging, decision-making, exchange, prestige, marriage, gender roles, parenting, history, and demography in an ecological and evolutionary perspective.

CourseID: P ANTH 331. Cultures of India and South Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of contemporary South Asia's religious and cultural diversity, issues of ethnic identity, gender construction, social conflict, and politics of poverty.

CourseID: P ANTH 332. Human Attraction and Mating Strategies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolutionary theory, experimental and real-world data illuminate what we find attractive in others, variation in who we are attracted to, and why.

CourseID: P ANTH 340. Fundamentals of Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods modern archaeology uses to reconstruct the past, including background research, field methods, laboratory analyses, and interpreting data. Prereq: ANTH 145 or ANTH 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 341. Food Origins. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological, ecological, and social dimensions of plant-animal domestication and the environmental impact of agriculture in the Late Pleistocene-Holocene epochs.

CourseID: P ANTH 342. Archaeology of Egypt and Near East. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The archaeology of ancient Egypt and the Near East.

CourseID: P ANTH 343. Pacific Islands Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archaeology and prehistoric cultural development of Pacific island peoples from earliest settlement through early Western contact. Emphasizes Southeast Asian cultural foundations and ecological adaptations. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 344. Oregon Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Native American cultural history of Oregon based on archaeological evidence. Environmental and ecological factors that condition human adaptations and contemporary cultural resource protection.

CourseID: P ANTH 345. Archaeology of East Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the evolution of diverse cultures and ethnic identities in East Asia during prehistoric and early historical times.

CourseID: P ANTH 347. Archaeology of Ancient Cities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The archaeology of ancient cities from around the world.

CourseID: P ANTH 349. Origins of Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines prehistoric and recent hunter-gatherer art to understand the role that art behavior played in ancestral human life.

CourseID: P ANTH 361. Human Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fossil evidence of human evolution; Homo sapiens' place among the primates; variability of populations of fossil hominids. Prereq: ANTH 170 or ANTH 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 362. Human Biological Variation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Genetic and biological structure of human populations; population dynamics and causes of diversity; analysis of genetically differentiated human populations and their geographic distribution. Prereq: one from ANTH 270, BI 213, or BI 283H.

CourseID: P ANTH 365. Food and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anthropological approach to the role of nutrients in human development (individual and group); cultural determinants and differences among populations; world food policy; applied nutritional anthropology.

CourseID: P ANTH 366. Human Osteology Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Human and nonhuman primate osteology and osteometry; fundamentals of dissection and primate anatomy. Prereq: one from ANTH 170, 270, BI 212, or HPHY 321.

CourseID: P ANTH 369. Human Growth and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines key issues in human and nonhuman primate growth and development; addresses genetic, social and ecological determinants of variation in growth.

CourseID: P ANTH 373. Psychoactive Substances in Ancient Societies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Global review of psychoactive substances in past human societies, including the paraphernalia, iconography, and residues of drugs found in the archaeological record. Prereq: ANTH 145 or ANTH 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 375. Primates in Ecological Communities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How do primates interact with other species at evolutionary and ecological scales? What factors influence differences and similarities in primate communities? Prereq: ANTH 170 or 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 376. Genomics and Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how genomic data are used to address anthropological questions concerning human and nonhuman primate biological variation, health, and evolution. Prereq: one course from ANTH 175, 270, BI 211, 282H.

CourseID: P ANTH 411. Politics, Ethnicity, Nationalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores relationship between ethnicity, politics, and nationalism from historical and anthropological perspectives; addresses the way nationalism and ethnic identity construct and reproduce each other. Prereq: junior standing in a social science.

CourseID: P ANTH 413. Culture and Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bridges anthropology and psychology to explore the relationship between the individual and culture; includes such topics as emotion, personality, mental illness, and sexuality.

CourseID: P ANTH 414. Activist Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how anthropologists link research with advocacy, public policy processes, activism, and public outreach.

CourseID: P ANTH 415. Human Life History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores evolution of key life history traits in comparative primatological, paleo-anthropological, behavioral ecology, and evolutionary psychology perspectives.

CourseID: P ANTH 417. Field Methods in Cultural Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques of participant observation, community definition and extension, nondirective interviewing, and establishing rapport. Provides theoretical perspectives and emphasizes investigator's ethical responsibilities. Prereq: 8 credits of upper-division cultural anthropology.

CourseID: P ANTH 419. Performance, Politics, and Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aesthetic, political, economic, and social dimensions of cultural performances examined in museums, heritage displays, folklore festivals, community celebrations, and tourist destinations. Pre- or coreq: 8 credits in cultural anthropology.

CourseID: P ANTH 420. Culture, Illness, and Healing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural foundations of illness and healing. Attempts to analyze illness experiences, looks at therapies cross-culturally, and examines the nature of healing. Prereq: ANTH 161.

CourseID: P ANTH 424. Feminist Methods in Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Seminar in feminist research design and methods in three subfields of anthropology: biological, sociocultural, archaeological. Examines case studies illustrating research ethics, collaboration, and activism. Prereq: 12 credits in ANTH or WGS courses.

CourseID: P ANTH 427M. Latino Roots I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Documents Latino history in the racial history of what is now Oregon since 1500 and teaches students to conduct oral history interviews. Multilisted with J 427M/527M. Sequence with ANTH 428M/528M Latino Roots II.

CourseID: P ANTH 428M. Latino Roots II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continuation of Latino Roots I, designed for producing a short documentary using oral history as the story. Covers basic theory and practice of digital film-video documentary production. Multilisted with J 428M/528M. Sequence with ANTH 427M/527M. Prereq: ANTH 427M.

CourseID: P ANTH 429. Jewish Folklore and Ethnology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traditional expressive culture of East European Jews; includes narrative, proverbs, jokes, folk beliefs, rituals, holidays, food, customs, music, gender, and immigrant folklore in the United States.

CourseID: P ANTH 431. Plants and People. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of issues in and research methods for understanding the cultural roles and uses of plants in past and present human societies.

CourseID: P ANTH 434. Native South Americans. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contact period and contemporary ethnography of native peoples; ecological adaptation, socioeconomic organization, and culture change. Prereq: ANTH 161.

CourseID: P ANTH 438. Race and Gender in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersecting systems of race, gender, ethnicity, and nationalism through 600 years of Latin American history, focusing on five countries in three regions.

CourseID: P ANTH 440. Old World Prehistory: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archaeology of prehistoric cultures in selected regions of the Middle East, Southeast Asia, or Africa, from first human cultures to historic periods. Repeatable when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 441. Recent Cultural Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of various cultural frameworks: Durkheimian, Marxian, feminist, transnationalism, Orientalism. Prereq: 8 credits in social science.

CourseID: P ANTH 442. Northwest Coast Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archaeological and prehistoric cultural development of peoples indigenous to the Northwest Coast of North America, from Alaska to northern California, from earliest settlement through Western contact. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 443. North American Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of interdisciplinary research applied to prehistoric cultures and environments in North America. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 444. Seacoast and Prehistory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Global review of the significance of coastal settlement and adaptations by humans in the ancient past. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 446. Practical Archaeobotany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates interactions between human-plant populations in the past; laboratory training of analyzing plant fossils in archaeologial contexts.

CourseID: P ANTH 449. Cultural Resource Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Objectives, legal background, operational problems, ethical and scholarly considerations in the management of prehistoric and historic cultural resources. Prereq: ANTH 145 or 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 450. The Anthropology Museum. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social, historical, ethical, and practical dimensions of the curation and exhibition of anthropological collections in museum contexts.

CourseID: P ANTH 453. African Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The archaeology of humans in Africa with an emphasis on the past 15,000 years.

CourseID: P ANTH 456. Peopling of the Americas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reviews anthropological methods of the Americas including biological, genetic, archaeological, and paleoenvironmental evidence. Prereq: ANTH 145 or ANTH 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 459. Advanced Evolutionary Medicine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores current research in the field of evolutionary medicine. Prereq: one from ANTH 175, ANTH 270, ANTH 468, BI 131, BI 380; ANTH 175 strongly suggested.

CourseID: P ANTH 462. Primate Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The fossil record and theoretical implications of the Cenozoic primates with special reference to their various adaptations: locomotion, special senses, dentition. Prereq: ANTH 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 463. Primate Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ecology and ethology of free-ranging primates. Classification, distribution, and ecological relationships of living primates; social structure and social organizations. Prereq: ANTH 171 or 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 466. Primate Feeding and Nutrition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evaluates primate feeding and foraging behavior, diet, and nutrition. Explores anatomical, physiological, and behavioral solutions to feeding challenges, both ecological and evolutionary. Prereq: ANTH 171 or 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 467. Paleoecology and Human Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship between ecology and comparative morphology as a basis for theories of hominid phylogeny; analysis of methods of paleoecological inference; current theories of hominid origins. Prereq: ANTH 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 468. Evolutionary Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a theoretical framework in evolutionary biology with which to explore human evolutionary history and aspects of modern human biology.

CourseID: P ANTH 470. Statistical Analysis of Biological Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The important methods in biometry (biological statistics) and their inherent assumptions, limitations, interpretations, and common uses (and misuses) as relevant to biological anthropology. Prereq: MATH 243, 425, or equivalent.

CourseID: P ANTH 471. Zooarchaeology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and interpretation of bone and shell animal remains from archaeological sites. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when the topic changes. Prereq: ANTH 145 or ANTH 150.

CourseID: P ANTH 472. Primate Conservation Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evaluates the conservation status of the order Primates. Explores biological-ecological issues and social-cultural influences on primate biodiversity, distribution, and abundance. Prereq: ANTH 171 or 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 473. Advanced Forensic Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaches theory and analysis of human remains for medico-legal professionals, including estimating biological parameters from skeletons and outdoor crime scene processing and testimony. Prereq: ANTH 176 with a grade of B– or better or ANTH 366 with a C– or better.

CourseID: P ANTH 479. Taphonomy: Bones, Bugs, and Burials. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of taphonomic studies in the fields of paleontology, archaeology, and forensic-medicolegal anthropology. Prereq: one from ANTH 170, ANTH 176, ANTH 270, ANTH 366, BI 212, or equivalent.

CourseID: P ANTH 481. Principles of Evolutionary Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates how understanding of our evolutionary history is used to further understanding of the human mind. Prereq: ANTH 170 or 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 487. Bioanthropology Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Laboratory-based introduction to research methods in biological anthropology, with an emphasis on research among living human populations. Prereq: ANTH 270.

CourseID: P ANTH 488. Foundations of Social Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Important early social theorists (Marx, Engels, Freud, Durkheim, Weber) and the historical conditions in which the study of society emerged in Western thought.

CourseID: P ANTH 493. Anthropology and Popular Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Popular culture offers insights into the conditions of the reproduction of social relations through the analysis of film, sport, television, advertising, folklore, fashion, and festivals.

CourseID: P ANTH 511. Politics, Ethnicity, Nationalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores relationship between ethnicity, politics, and nationalism from historical and anthropological perspectives; addresses the way nationalism and ethnic identity construct and reproduce each other.

CourseID: P ANTH 513. Culture and Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bridges anthropology and psychology to explore the relationship between the individual and culture; includes such topics as emotion, personality, mental illness, and sexuality.

CourseID: P ANTH 514. Activist Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how anthropologists link research with advocacy, public policy processes, activism, and public outreach.

CourseID: P ANTH 515. Human Life History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores evolution of key life history traits in comparative primatological, paleo-anthropological, behavioral ecology, and evolutionary psychology perspectives.

CourseID: P ANTH 517. Field Methods in Cultural Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques of participant observation, community definition and extension, nondirective interviewing, and establishing rapport. Provides theoretical perspectives and emphasizes investigator's ethical responsibilities.

CourseID: P ANTH 519. Performance, Politics, and Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aesthetic, political, economic, and social dimensions of cultural performances examined in museums, heritage displays, folklore festivals, community celebrations, and tourist destinations.

CourseID: P ANTH 520. Culture, Illness, and Healing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural foundations of illness and healing. Attempts to analyze illness experiences, looks at therapies cross-culturally, and examines the nature of healing.

CourseID: P ANTH 524. Feminist Methods in Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Seminar in feminist research design and methods in three subfields of anthropology: biological, sociocultural, archaeological. Examines case studies illustrating research ethics, collaboration, and activism.

CourseID: P ANTH 527M. Latino Roots I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Documents Latino history in the racial history of what is now Oregon since 1500 and teaches students to conduct oral history interviews. Multilisted with J 427M/527M. Sequence with ANTH 428M/528M Latino Roots II.

CourseID: P ANTH 528M. Latino Roots II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continuation of Latino Roots I, designed for producing a short documentary using oral history as the story. Covers basic theory and practice of digital film-video documentary production. Multilisted with J 428M/528M. Sequence with ANTH 427M/527M. Prereq: ANTH 527M.

CourseID: P ANTH 529. Jewish Folklore and Ethnology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traditional expressive culture of East European Jews; includes narrative, proverbs, jokes, folk beliefs, rituals, holidays, food, customs, music, gender, and immigrant folklore in the United States.

CourseID: P ANTH 531. Plants and People. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of issues in and research methods for understanding the cultural roles and uses of plants in past and present human societies.

CourseID: P ANTH 534. Native South Americans. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contact period and contemporary ethnography of native peoples; ecological adaptation, socioeconomic organization, and culture change.

CourseID: P ANTH 538. Race and Gender in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersecting systems of race, gender, ethnicity, and nationalism through 600 years of Latin American history, focusing on five countries in three regions.

CourseID: P ANTH 540. Old World Prehistory: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archaeology of prehistoric cultures in selected regions of the Middle East, Southeast Asia, or Africa, from first human cultures to historic periods. Repeatable when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: one course in archaeology or prehistory.

CourseID: P ANTH 541. Recent Cultural Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of various cultural frameworks: Durkheimian, Marxian, feminist, transnationalism, Orientalism. Prereq: 8 credits in social science.

CourseID: P ANTH 542. Northwest Coast Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archaeological and prehistoric cultural development of peoples indigenous to the Northwest Coast of North America, from Alaska to northern California, from earliest settlement through Western contact.

CourseID: P ANTH 543. North American Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of interdisciplinary research applied to prehistoric cultures and environments in North America.

CourseID: P ANTH 544. Seacoast and Prehistory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Global review of the significance of coastal settlement and adaptations by humans in the ancient past.

CourseID: P ANTH 546. Practical Archaeobotany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates interactions between human-plant populations in the past; laboratory training of analyzing plant fossils in archaeologial contexts.

CourseID: P ANTH 549. Cultural Resource Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Objectives, legal background, operational problems, ethical and scholarly considerations in the management of prehistoric and historic cultural resources.

CourseID: P ANTH 550. The Anthropology Museum. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social, historical, ethical, and practical dimensions of the curation and exhibition of anthropological collections in museum contexts.

CourseID: P ANTH 553. African Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The archaeology of humans in Africa with an emphasis on the past 15,000 years.

CourseID: P ANTH 559. Advanced Evolutionary Medicine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores current research in the field of evolutionary medicine.

CourseID: P ANTH 562. Primate Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The fossil record and theoretical implications of the Cenozoic primates with special reference to their various adaptations: locomotion, special senses, dentition.

CourseID: P ANTH 563. Primate Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ecology and ethology of free-ranging primates. Classification, distribution, and ecological relationships of living primates; social structure and social organizations.

CourseID: P ANTH 567. Paleoecology and Human Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship between ecology and comparative morphology as a basis for theories of hominid phylogeny; analysis of methods of paleoecological inference; current theories of hominid origins.

CourseID: P ANTH 568. Evolutionary Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a theoretical framework in evolutionary biology with which to explore human evolutionary history and aspects of modern human biology.

CourseID: P ANTH 570. Statistical Analysis of Biological Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The important methods in biometry (biological statistics) and their inherent assumptions, limitations, interpretations, and common uses (and misuses) as relevant to biological anthropology. Prereq: MATH 243, 425, or equivalent.

CourseID: P ANTH 571. Zooarchaeology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and interpretation of bone and shell animal remains from archaeological sites. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when the topic changes.

CourseID: P ANTH 572. Primate Conservation Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evaluates the conservation status of the order Primates. Explores biological-ecological issues and social-cultural influences on primate biodiversity, distribution, and abundance.

CourseID: P ANTH 573. Advanced Forensic Anthropology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaches theory and analysis of human remains for medico-legal professionals, including estimating biological parameters from skeletons and outdoor crime scene processing and testimony.

CourseID: P ANTH 579. Taphonomy: Bones, Bugs, and Burials. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of taphonomic studies in the fields of paleontology, archaeology, and forensic-medicolegal anthropology.

CourseID: P ANTH 581. Principles of Evolutionary Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates how understanding of our evolutionary history is used to further understanding of the human mind.

CourseID: P ANTH 587. Bioanthropology Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Laboratory-based introduction to research methods in biological anthropology, with an emphasis on research among living human populations.

CourseID: P ANTH 588. Foundations of Social Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Important early social theorists (Marx, Engels, Freud, Durkheim, Weber) and the historical conditions in which the study of society emerged in Western thought.

CourseID: P ANTH 593. Anthropology and Popular Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Popular culture offers insights into the conditions of the reproduction of social relations through the analysis of film, sport, television, advertising, folklore, fashion, and festivals.

CourseID: P ANTH 611. Ethnographic Research: Epistemology, Methods, Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Various techniques in ethnographic research. Examines the relationships between methods, theory, and ethics.

CourseID: P ANTH 615. Proseminar in Anthropology. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents the department's structure, program, and faculty; introduces research, writing, and funding resources.

CourseID: P ANTH 650. African Studies Seminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the ways researchers study Africa-related topics by surveying the types of data, analytical methods, and research questions asked in different subjects, from the natural sciences to the humanities.

CourseID: P ANTH 680. Basic Graduate Physical Anthropology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major subfields of physical anthropology; geochronology, primate classification, paleoprimatology, paleoanthropology, human biology and diversity, processes of evolution, and primate ethology.

CourseID: P ANTH 681. Archaeology and Anthropology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use by archaeologists of concepts drawn from anthropology; modifications and additions made necessary by the nature of archaeological data.

CourseID: P ANTH 683. Anthropological Linguistics. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include linguistic relativity; language, cognition, and social practice; distinctiveness of human language; role of reference in linguistic structures; creation of social and cultural forms.

CourseID: P ANTH 685. Professional Writing. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the basics of professional writing for grant proposals, journal articles, and papers presented at professional meetings. Requires short proposal, longer proposal or article, and workshop participation.

CourseID: P ANTH 688. Social Theory I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social theory survey organized around keywords: colonialismpostcolonialism, meaning, materiality-materialism, local-national-global, structure-agency-history, power, and difference.

CourseID: P ANTH 689. Social Theory II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social theory survey organized around keywords: colonialismpostcolonialism, meaning, materiality-materialism, local-national-global, structure-agency-history, power, and difference.

CourseID: P JPN 201 Second-Year Japanese 5 JPN 305 Introduction to Japanese Literature 4 General-education course in social science
Descriptions: P Credits 17 Winter JPN 202 Second-Year Japanese

CourseID: P JPN 301 Third-Year Japanese 5 ARH 209 History of Japanese Art
Descriptions: P 4 General-education course in science

CourseID: P ASIA 611 Perspectives on Asian Studies: [Topic] 1 ASIA 612 Theory and Methodology in Asian Studies: 3
Descriptions: P [Topic] Seminars or colloquia 8 Two courses in architecture, art history, literature, music, 8

CourseID: P ASIA 111. Great Books on Modern Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students learn about Asia and how knowledge about Asia is produced by reading and discussing four great books written by different authors in various writing genres and perspectives.

CourseID: P ASIA 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: freshman or new student.

CourseID: P ASIA 350. What Is Asia: Theoretical Debates. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An interdisciplinary seminar designed to introduce students to current theoretical debates about Asia, modernization, and area studies.

CourseID: P ASIA 403. Thesis. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: major honor's student.

CourseID: P ASIA 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Closely supervised participation in the activities of public or private organizations, institutes, and community service agencies.

CourseID: P ASIA 425. Asian Foodways. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores socio-cultural, political-economic and historical dimensions of food in China, Japan, Korea, Southeast Asia and India, including modernization, transnationalism, globalization. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ASIA 480. Chinese Economy: Transition, Development, Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive introduction to the Chinese economy: market transition; macroeconomic conditions and policies; key sectors such as industry, banking, finance, energy, export, technology, agriculture; globalization. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ASIA 525. Asian Foodways. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores socio-cultural, political-economic and historical dimensions of food in China, Japan, Korea, Southeast Asia and India, including modernization, transnationalism, globalization. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ASIA 580. Chinese Economy: Transition, Development, Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive introduction to the Chinese economy: market transition; macroeconomic conditions and policies; key sectors such as industry, banking, finance, energy, export, technology, agriculture; globalization. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ASIA 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Closely supervised participation in the activities of public or private organizations, institutes, and community service agencies.

CourseID: P ASIA 611. Perspectives on Asian Studies: [Topic]. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Explores the diverse perspectives that define Asian studies. Samples conflicts, controversies, and areas of consensus that characterize the field.

CourseID: P ASIA 612. Theory and Methodology in Asian Studies: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected Asian studies issues. Repeatable once when topic changes for maximum of 6 credits.

Descriptions: P or CH 224H– Honors General Chemistry

Descriptions: P or CH 237– Advanced General Chemistry Laboratory

Descriptions: P Organic Chemistry 28 CH 331 Organic Chemistry I CH 335 Organic Chemistry II

Descriptions: P or CH 224H– Honors General Chemistry

Descriptions: P or CH 237– Advanced General Chemistry Laboratory

Descriptions: P or BI 281H– Honors Biology I-III

Descriptions: P BI 282H Honors Biology II: Genetics and Molecular Biology

Descriptions: P BI 283H Honors Biology III: Evolution, Diversity and Ecology

Descriptions: P Course Title Credits Milestones

CourseID: P CH 223 General Chemistry III 4 Course Title Credits Milestones CH 221 General Chemistry I 4 Third Year CH 227 General Chemistry Laboratory 2
Descriptions: P Fall Credits 14 BI 214 General Biology IV: Mechanisms 4 Winter Upper-division course with BI subject code 4 BI 211 General Biology I: Cells

CourseID: P BI 213 General Biology III: Populations 4
Descriptions: P terms at or BI 214 or General Biology IV: Mechanisms

CourseID: P BI 100. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P BI 121. Introduction to Human Physiology. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P BI 121. Introduction to Human Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of body functions with emphasis on organs and systems. Cell function, genetics, nutrition, exercise; function of the gut, heart, vessels, glands, lungs, nerves, and muscles with practical applications. Lecture, laboratories.

CourseID: P BI 122. Introduction to Human Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts of genetics as they relate to humans. Blood groups, transplantation and immune reaction, prenatal effects, the biology of twinning, selection in humans, and sociological implications. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 123. Biology of Cancer. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comparison of cancer cells with normal cells; causes of cancer, including viral and environmental factors; biological basis of therapy. Lectures, laboratories.

CourseID: P BI 130. Introduction to Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The concept of an ecosystem; organismal energetics; biogeochemical cycles; succession; population growth; species interactions, species diversity; implications for human ecosystems. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 131. Introduction to Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Darwinian evolution; human-caused evolution, natural selection, speciation, extinction, and human evolution. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 132. Introduction to Animal Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Animal behavior, its evolutionary origins, and its neural mechanisms. Readings and films illustrate the adaptive nature of orientation, navigation, communication, and social behavior. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 140. Science, Policy, and Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the biology behind important topical issues such as stem cells, cloning, and genetically modified organisms. How policy decisions affect research in these areas. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 150. The Ocean Planet. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The diversity of marine life is introduced in the context of appreciating nature and using science in the solution of environmental problems. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 160. From Brains to Artificial Intelligence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts on how brains and artificial systems process information. Analysis of the similarities, differences, and complementarity between these systems.

CourseID: P BI 211. General Biology I: Cells. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How cells carry out functions of living organisms; genetic basis of inheritance; how genes and proteins work. Lectures, laboratories-discussions. Prereq: C- or better or P in CH 111 or CH 113 or CH 114 or CH 221 or CH 224H.

CourseID: P BI 212. General Biology II: Organisms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How cells develop and interact within complex organisms. Comparative anatomy and physiology of plants and animals. Lectures, laboratories-discussions. Prereq: C- or better or P in BI 211.

CourseID: P BI 213. General Biology III: Populations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How organisms interact with their environments and with each other; ecology, evolution, and behavior. Lectures, laboratories-discussions. Prereq: C- or better or P in BI 211.

CourseID: P BI 214. General Biology IV: Mechanisms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Protein structure and function; metabolism; DNA structure, replication, mutation, and repair; gene mapping and complementation; and gene regulation. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: C- or better or P in BI 212 and CH 223 or CH 226H.

CourseID: P BI 281H. Honors Biology I: Cells, Biochemistry and Physiology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the cellular structures and chemical reactions that allow cells to grow, to transform energy, and to communicate. Lectures, laboratories. Sequence with BI 282H, BI 283H. Prereq: MATH 111 or equivalent with B– or better or minimum AP/IB mathematics score of 4/5, and CH 221, CH 222, CH 223 or CH 224H, CH 225H, CH 226H with B– or better in all courses.

CourseID: P BI 282H. Honors Biology II: Genetics and Molecular Biology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P How living organisms store, replicate, and transmit their genetic information, and how this information directs the activities of the cell and organism. Lectures, laboratories. Sequence with BI 281H, BI 283H. Prereq: BI 281H with C- or better or P.

CourseID: P BI 283H. Honors Biology III: Evolution, Diversity and Ecology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P The genetic basis and ecological context of evolutionary change leading to an examination of the generation and major patterns of biodiversity. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Sequence with BI 281H, BI 282H. Prereq: BI 282H with grade of C– or better or P

CourseID: P BI 306. Pollination Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ecology and evolution of pollination biology: coevolution, mutualism, animal foraging behavior, plant breeding systems, biodiversity, and conservation issues associated with endangered species and introduced species. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 307. Forest Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of forested ecosystems emphasizing the Pacific Northwest. Interactions among trees, microorganisms, and animals; disturbance and recovery; forest management. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 309. Tropical Diseases in Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological and medical aspects of major infectious and parasitic diseases in Africa, including HIV/AIDS and malaria; socioeconomic issues in public health; case studies. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 212 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 320. Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Molecular mechanisms regulating control of gene expression. Topics include chromosome structure, transcription and processing of RNA, control of transcription, translational control, and genetic rearrangement. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 322. Cell Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Eukaryotic cell nuclear structure and exchange, protein trafficking, endocytosis, chaperones, cytoskeletal functions, intercellular junctions, extracellular materials, signaling, cell division mechanics and controls, aging and death. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H; CH 331 recommended.

CourseID: P BI 328. Developmental Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include genetic regulation, nucleocytoplasmic interactions, organogenesis, morphogenesis, pattern formation, cell differentiation, and neoplasia. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 330. Microbiology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biology of bacteria: photosynthetic, heterotrophic, and others. Cell structure and function, metabolism including anaerobic and O2-producing photosynthesis, nitrogen fixation, species interactions, and role in major geochemical cycles. Lectures. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 331. Microbiology Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Microbial diversity through laboratory projects involving enrichments, culture isolations, and partial characterizations. Two scheduled laboratories and one scheduled lecture per week; additional unscheduled time required. Laboratories. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H; pre- or coreq: BI 330.

CourseID: P BI 353. Sensory Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to physiology of the senses: cellular physiology of peripheral receptors through the computational mechanisms that are ultimately related to perception. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 356. Animal Physiology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Neurophysiology, endocrinology, muscle contraction, and homeostatic mechanisms of circulation, respiration, metabolism, ionic regulation, and excretion in mammals; comparison with those in other animals. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 281H.

CourseID: P BI 357. Marine Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ecology and physiology of marine plants and animals. Comparisons of various marine habitats. Human influences on marine systems. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H. Not open to students who have credit for BI 458 or BI 474.

CourseID: P BI 358. Investigations in Medical Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Human physiology with research and clinical medicine applications. Nervous system, addiction medicine, endocrinology, immunology, cardiology, digestion, nutrition, reproduction, infertility, pediatrics, and ophthalmology. Lectures, discussions, primary literature research. Human anatomy and physiology background preferred. Prereq: one from BI 214, BI 283H, HPHY 324.

CourseID: P BI 359. Plant Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A detailed introduction of the unique features of the biology of land plants, including ecology, physiology, developmental genetics, and evolutionary biology. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 211; BI 212; BI 213 or BI 281H; BI 282H; BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 360. Neurobiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Function of the nervous system from the single neuron to complex neural networks. Topics range from molecular and cellular neurobiological mechanisms to systems and behavioral analyses. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H.

CourseID: P BI 370. Ecology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship of organisms to their environment in space and time. Factors controlling the distribution and abundance of organisms, introductions to community systems, and ecosystems. Required fieldwork. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H. Calculus or statistics recommended.

CourseID: P BI 372. Field Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students learn to identify the plants and animals of Oregon, their adaptations and ecology. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered alternate years. Junior or Senior standing preferred.

CourseID: P BI 374. Conservation Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Global patterns of biological diversity; major threats to biodiversity; application of ecology, evolution, genetics, and other areas to protect and maintain biodiversity. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 375. Biological Diversity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Patterns of global biological diversity in space and time; major systematic groups of organisms and their ecological roles; historical and human effects on biological diversity. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 380. Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origin and maintenance of genetic variability. Historical and geographic patterns of variation. Application of population genetics to understanding evolutionary processes; modes of speciation. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: college algebra and BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 390. Animal Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How and why animals behave, and how animal behavior is studied. Mechanisms of behavior, behavioral ecology, and sociobiology. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: BI 212 and BI 213 and BI 214 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 402. Supervised College Teaching. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 9 credits.

CourseID: P BI 408. Laboratory Projects: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Special laboratory training in research methods. A fee may be charged for supplies and materials that become the property of the student.

CourseID: P BI 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: BI 212 and BI 213 and BI 214 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 421. Advanced Molecular Genetics Research Laboratory. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive multipart research project using fungus Neurospora; includes mutagenesis, genetic selection-screening, complementation testing, mapping, DNA purification, restriction analysis, polymerase chain reaction, Southern blotting. Five credits for BI 421, 4 credits for BI 521. Prereq: BI 320

CourseID: P BI 422. Protein Toxins in Cell Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms used by protein toxins to kill other organisms and how they have been used as molecular scalpels to dissect pathways in cell and neurobiology. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 322, BI 356, or BI 360.

CourseID: P BI 423. Human Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in genetics that relate to human development and disease. The human genome, sex determination, X chromosome inactivation, chromosomal abnormalities, trinucleotide repeat expansions, cancer. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320.

CourseID: P BI 424. Advanced Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of chromosomes with emphasis on unsolved genetic problems such as genomic imprinting, position effects, and gene silencing. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320.

CourseID: P BI 425. Advanced Molecular Biology Research Laboratory. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an intensive, structured research experience that incorporates molecular biology, genetics, and genomic methodologies. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: one from BI 320, BI 322, BI 328.

CourseID: P BI 426. Genetics of Cancer. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Genetic regulation of cancer. Topics include oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, signal transduction pathways, genetic animal models, and rationale treatment design. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 214 or BI 282H; one course from BI 320, BI 322.

CourseID: P BI 427. Molecular Genetics of Human Disease. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced discussions of heritable diseases from single-gene mutations such as cystic fibrosis to complex multigenetic diseases such as autism and schizophrenia. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320.

CourseID: P BI 428. Developmental Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Genetic regulation of development, including investigations of molecular mechanisms and studies of developmental mutants. Topics include molecular biology of eukaryotic chromosomes, genetic mosaics, and models of gene regulation. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320, BI 328.

CourseID: P BI 432. Mycology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiology, ecology, structure, and classification of fungi; emphasis on structural and physiological adaptations to saprophytic, parasitic, and symbiotic modes of existence. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 433. Bacterial-Host Interactions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines spectrum of interactions between bacteria and animals, from pathogenesis to symbiosis, focusing on the molecular and cellular bases of these interactions. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320 or BI 322 or BI 330.

CourseID: P BI 442. Systematic Botany. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of plant classification with emphasis on flowering plants, introduction to taxonomic theory and methods of biosystematics, collection and identification procedures, recognition of common families in native flora. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 448. Field Botany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of the regional flora; ecology and native uses; sight recognition of prominent species; field characteristics of principal plant families; identification using dichotomous keys. Lectures, field trips. Offered summer session only. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 451. Invertebrate Zoology. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative invertebrate groups with emphasis on marine forms; morphology, systematics, life history, and ecology. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 452. Insect Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy, physiology, systematics, and behavior of insects. Insect societies. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered summer session only. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 454. Estuarine Biology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P The biological and physical factors regulating abundance, distribution, production, and biodiversity within estuaries. Includes field trips to marshes, tidal flats and exploration of estuarine habitats. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 455. Marine Birds and Mammals. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of morphology, physiology, evolution, life history, and systematics as demonstrated through study of birds and mammals of the Oregon coast. Comparison of the fauna from the open sea to coastal waters. Lectures, laboratory, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 457. Marine Biology: [Topic]. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Content varies. Topics include comparative embryology, environmental issues, biology of fishes, and other subjects related to marine biology. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 212 & BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 458. Biological Oceanography. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines patterns of biological productivity and controlling physical and chemical mechanisms in the various environments of the world's oceans. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 461. Systems Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of organization of nervous systems with emphasis on vertebrate brain and spinal cord. Functional implications of synaptic organization and pattern of projections, and comparative aspects. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 353 or BI 360 or equivalent.

CourseID: P BI 463. Cellular Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiology of excitation, conduction, and synaptic transmission. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 360.

CourseID: P BI 464. Biological Clocks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological time keeping at ecological, evolutionary, behavioral, physiological, neurological, and molecular levels, with emphasis on daily and seasonal rhythmicity. Senior standing in Biology or Psychology required. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320 or BI 322.

CourseID: P BI 466. Developmental Neurobiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms underlying development of the nervous system. The genesis of nerve cells; differentiation of neurons; synaptogenesis and neuronal specificity; plasticity, regeneration, and degeneration of nervous tissue. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320, BI 328.

CourseID: P BI 468. Amphibians and Reptiles of Oregon. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Field identification and understanding of ecology, biogeography, and evolution of the common herpetofauna of four major physiographic regions of Oregon. Conservation biology issues addressed. Lectures, field trips. Offered summer session only. Prereq: one year of college biology or BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 471. Population Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical, experimental and applied aspects of growth, structure, and regulation of natural populations; population estimation; demographic analysis; life-history theory. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: MATH 247 or MATH 252; BI 370.

CourseID: P BI 472. Community Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Quantitative and conceptual approaches to the study of biological communities. Biodiversity measurement. Effect of climate and climate change on ecosystem structure and function. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 370.

CourseID: P BI 474. Marine Ecology. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Factors that influence the distribution, abundance, and diversity of marine organisms. Field emphasis on local intertidal and shallow-water communities. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology. Prereq: BI 213 or BI 283H.

CourseID: P BI 476. Terrestrial Ecosystem Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Flux of nutrients, carbon, water, and energy in the environment; interactions and consequences for organisms. Scale ranges from microbial to global. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 370.

CourseID: P BI 484. Molecular Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P General description of patterns of molecular variation within and between species, underlying mechanisms, and methods of analysis. Prereq: BI 320 or BI 380.

CourseID: P BI 485. Techniques in Computational Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to numerical techniques for modeling the nervous system from single neurons to neutral networks. Lectures, laboratories. Prereq: BI 360 or BI 461; MATH 247 or MATH 252 or higher.

CourseID: P BI 486. Population Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the genetic mechanisms of evolutionary change. Study of artificial and natural selection, mutation, migration, population structure, and genetic drift. Lectures. Prereq: BI 380; MATH 247 or MATH 252.

CourseID: P BI 488. Evolutionary Processes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical discussion of the ecological and evolutionary genetic processes associated with adaptation in natural populations; draws from topics in population, quantitative, and molecular genetics, molecular evolution, and statistics. Prereq: BI 380.

CourseID: P BI 493. Genomic Approaches and Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to experimental methods and analytical techniques for studying biological questions on a genome-wide scale. Lectures, discussions. Prereq: BI 320.

CourseID: P BI 508. Laboratory Projects: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Special laboratory training in research methods. A fee may be charged for supplies and materials that become the property of the student.

CourseID: P BI 521. Advanced Molecular Genetics Research Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive multipart research project using fungus Neurospora; includes mutagenesis, genetic selection-screening, complementation testing, mapping, DNA purification, restriction analysis, polymerase chain reaction, Southern blotting. Five credits for BI 421, 4 credits for BI 521.

CourseID: P BI 522. Protein Toxins in Cell Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms used by protein toxins to kill other organisms and how they have been used as molecular scalpels to dissect pathways in cell and neurobiology. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 523. Human Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in genetics that relate to human development and disease. The human genome, sex determination, X chromosome inactivation, chromosomal abnormalities, trinucleotide repeat expansions, cancer. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 524. Advanced Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of chromosomes with emphasis on unsolved genetic problems such as genomic imprinting, position effects, and gene silencing. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 525. Advanced Molecular Biology Research Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an intensive, structured research experience that incorporates molecular biology, genetics, and genomic methodologies. Lectures, laboratories.

CourseID: P BI 526. Genetics of Cancer. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Genetic regulation of cancer. Topics include oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, signal transduction pathways, genetic animal models, and rationale treatment design. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 527. Molecular Genetics of Human Disease. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced discussions of heritable diseases from single-gene mutations such as cystic fibrosis to complex multigenetic diseases such as autism and schizophrenia. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 528. Developmental Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Genetic regulation of development, including investigations of molecular mechanisms and studies of developmental mutants. Topics include molecular biology of eukaryotic chromosomes, genetic mosaics, and models of gene regulation. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 532. Mycology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiology, ecology, structure, and classification of fungi; emphasis on structural and physiological adaptations to saprophytic, parasitic, and symbiotic modes of existence. Lectures, laboratories.

CourseID: P BI 533. Bacterial-Host Interactions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines spectrum of interactions between bacteria and animals, from pathogenesis to symbiosis, focusing on the molecular and cellular bases of these interactions. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 542. Systematic Botany. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of plant classification with emphasis on flowering plants, introduction to taxonomic theory and methods of biosystematics, collection and identification procedures, recognition of common families in native flora. Lectures, laboratories, field trips.

CourseID: P BI 548. Field Botany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of the regional flora; ecology and native uses; sight recognition of prominent species; field characteristics of principal plant families; identification using dichotomous keys. Lectures, field trips. Offered summer session only.

CourseID: P BI 551. Invertebrate Zoology. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative invertebrate groups with emphasis on marine forms; morphology, systematics, life history, and ecology. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 552. Insect Biology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy, physiology, systematics, and behavior of insects. Insect societies. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered summer session only.

CourseID: P BI 554. Estuarine Biology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P The biological and physical factors regulating abundance, distribution, production, and biodiversity within estuaries. Includes field trips to marshes, tidal flats and exploration of estuarine habitats. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 555. Marine Birds and Mammals. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of morphology, physiology, evolution, life history, and systematics as demonstrated through study of birds and mammals of the Oregon coast. Comparison of the fauna from the open sea to coastal waters. Lectures, laboratory, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 557. Marine Biology: [Topic]. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Content varies. Topics include comparative embryology, environmental issues, biology of fishes, and other subjects related to marine biology. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 558. Biological Oceanography. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines patterns of biological productivity and controlling physical and chemical mechanisms in the various environments of the world's oceans. Lectures, laboratories, field trips. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 561. Systems Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of organization of nervous systems with emphasis on vertebrate brain and spinal cord. Functional implications of synaptic organization and pattern of projections, and comparative aspects. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 563. Cellular Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiology of excitation, conduction, and synaptic transmission. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 564. Biological Clocks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological time keeping at ecological, evolutionary, behavioral, physiological, neurological, and molecular levels, with emphasis on daily and seasonal rhythmicity. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 566. Developmental Neurobiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms underlying development of the nervous system. The genesis of nerve cells; differentiation of neurons; synaptogenesis and neuronal specificity; plasticity, regeneration, and degeneration of nervous tissue. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 568. Amphibians and Reptiles of Oregon. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Field identification and understanding of ecology, biogeography, and evolution of the common herpetofauna of four major physiographic regions of Oregon. Conservation biology issues addressed. Lectures, field trips. Offered summer session only.

CourseID: P BI 571. Population Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical, experimental and applied aspects of growth, structure, and regulation of natural populations; population estimation; demographic analysis; life-history theory. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 572. Community Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Quantitative and conceptual approaches to the study of biological communities. Biodiversity measurement. Effect of climate and climate change on ecosystem structure and function. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 574. Marine Ecology. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Factors that influence the distribution, abundance, and diversity of marine organisms. Field emphasis on local intertidal and shallow-water communities. Offered at Oregon Institute of Marine Biology.

CourseID: P BI 576. Terrestrial Ecosystem Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Flux of nutrients, carbon, water, and energy in the environment; interactions and consequences for organisms. Scale ranges from microbial to global. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 584. Molecular Evolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P General description of patterns of molecular variation within and between species, underlying mechanisms, and methods of analysis.

CourseID: P BI 585. Techniques in Computational Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to numerical techniques for modeling the nervous system from single neurons to neutral networks. Lectures, laboratories.

CourseID: P BI 586. Population Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the genetic mechanisms of evolutionary change. Study of artificial and natural selection, mutation, migration, population structure, and genetic drift. Lectures.

CourseID: P BI 588. Evolutionary Processes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical discussion of the ecological and evolutionary genetic processes associated with adaptation in natural populations; draws from topics in population, quantitative, and molecular genetics, molecular evolution, and statistics.

CourseID: P BI 593. Genomic Approaches and Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to experimental methods and analytical techniques for studying biological questions on a genome-wide scale. Lectures, discussions.

CourseID: P BI 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include neurobiology, developmental biology, ecology colloquium, genetics, molecular biology, and neuroscience. Repeatable.

CourseID: P BI 608. Special Topics: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lecture course devoted to advanced topics that reflect instructor's research interests. Repeatable.

CourseID: P BI 620. Molecular Genetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of modern genetic techniques to analyze gene function. Illustrates the use of model organisms including yeast, worms, flies, and mice. Covers forward genetics (function-driven gene discovery) and reverse genetics.

CourseID: P BI 621. Computational Methods in Genomic Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to Unix shell, Python, and R programming skills for analysis of biological data sets, specifically focusing on high-throughput sequencing data. Series with BI 622, BI 623, BI 624.

CourseID: P BI 622. Genomics Techniques. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students will be introduced to various genomics laboratory techniques, as well as trained in oral and written scientific communication. Series with BI 621, BI 623, BI 624.

CourseID: P BI 623. Advanced Topics in Genomics Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exposure to a variety of topics in genomics analysis including phylogenetics, transcriptome assembly, transcript quantification, and microbial community analysis. Series with BI 621, BI 622, BI 624.

CourseID: P BI 624. Genomics Research Lab. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Group research on high-throughput sequencing data. Series with BI 621, BI 622, BI 623.
