CourseID: P CH 111. Introduction to Chemical Principles. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to modern chemistry with emphasis on problem solving skills and critical thinking. Fundamental mathematical techniques and skills are incorporated to illustrate the quantitative aspects of chemistry. Prereq: MATH 101 or satisfactory placement test score; MATH 111 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 113. The Chemistry of Sustainability. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Illustrates how chemistry provides innovative materials, processes, and consumer products that support sustainable solutions related to energy utilization, global warming and pollution prevention. Prereq: MATH 101 or higher; high school chemistry.

CourseID: P CH 114. Green Product Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Illustrates how green chemistry, product design, advertising, and sustainable business practices are used to design greener consumer products and accelerate their adoption in the market.

CourseID: P CH 221. General Chemistry I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First term of the three-term university chemistry sequence: components of matter, quantitative relationships, atomic structure, thermochemistry, and major classes of chemical reactionsof the elements. Lectures. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 221 and CH 224H. Prereq: high school chemistry; MATH 101 or satisfactory placement test score. coreq: one from MATH 111, MATH 112. Concurrent CH 227 or CH 237 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 222. General Chemistry II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second term of the three-term university chemistry sequence: molecular structure, chemical bonding, gases and kinetic molecular theory, intermolecular forces, solutions and kinetics.Lectures. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 222 and CH 225H. Prereq: CH 221 or CH 224H; MATH 111 with grades of C- or better. coreq: MATH 112. Concurrent CH 228 or CH 238 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 223. General Chemistry III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third term of the three-term university chemistry sequence: thermodynamics, equilibrium, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry. Lectures. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 223 and CH 226H. Prereq: CH 222 or CH 225H; MATH 112 with grades of C- or better. Concurrent CH 229 or CH 239 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 224H. Honors General Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First-year university chemistry for students with excellent backgrounds in high school chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Chemical structure, reactions, stoichiometry, thermochemistry, and an introduction to quantum chemistry. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 221 and CH 224H. Prereq: high school chemistry; MATH 112 with a grade of C-. coreq: one from MATH 241, MATH 246, MATH 251, MATH 261. Concurrent with CH 237 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 225H. Honors General Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First-year university chemistry for students with excellent backgrounds in high school chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Chemical bonding, states of matter, solutions, kinetics, and nuclear chemistry. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 222 and CH 225H. Prereq: CH 221 or CH 224H; one from MATH 241, MATH 246, MATH 251, MATH 261 with grades of C- or better. coreq: one from MATH 242, MATH 247, MATH 252, MATH 262. Concurrent CH 238 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 226H. Honors General Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First-year university chemistry for students with excellent backgrounds in high school chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Chemical equilibrium, acid-base chemistry, thermodynamics, and electrochemistry. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 223 and CH 226H. Prereq: CH 222 or CH 225H; one from MATH 242, MATH 247, MATH 252, MATH 262 with grades of C- or better. coreq: one from MATH 243, MATH 247, MATH 253, MATH 263. Concurrent CH 239 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 227. General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P First term of the three-term laboratory sequence: basic laboratory skills, quantitative relationships, qualitative analysis, calorimetry. Prereq: MATH 111. Pre- or coreq: CH 221 or 224H.

CourseID: P CH 228. General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second term of the three-term laboratory sequence: graphical analysis, spectroscopy, spectrophotometry, gas laws, chromatography, kinetics. Prereq: CH 227 or CH 237; MATH 111 with grades of C- or better. coreq: CH 222 or 225H; MATH 112.

CourseID: P CH 229. General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third term of the three-term laboratory sequence: synthesis, equilibrium, acids and bases, volumetric analyses, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry. Prereq: CH 228 or CH 238; MATH 112 with grades of C- or better. coreq: CH 223 or CH 226H.

CourseID: P CH 237. Advanced General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P First-year university laboratory course for students with a strong high school laboratory experience. Projects in analytical and inorganic chemistry emphasize the use of quantitative glassware, gravimetric and volumetric analysis, acid-base and precipitation reactions. Prereq: MATH 112 with a grade of C- or better. coreq: CH 221 or CH 224H.

CourseID: P CH 238. Advanced General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Projects in inorganic and biochemistry with a focus on absorption spectroscopy, synthesis of coordination compounds, and measuring initial rates of reaction. Prereq: CH 227 or CH 237; one from MATH 241, MATH 246, MATH 251, MATH 261 with grades of C- or better. coreq: CH 222 or CH 225H.

CourseID: P CH 239. Advanced General Chemistry Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Projects in biochemistry and inorganic chemistry involving enzymology, mechanisms of reactions, kinetics, and visible absorption spectroscopy. Prereq: CH 228 or CH 238; one from MATH 242, MATH 247, MATH 252, MATH 262 with grades of C- or better. coreq: CH 223 or CH 226H.

CourseID: P CH 331. Organic Chemistry I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure, properties, and bonding of organic molecules. Prereq: CH 223 or 226H. Concurrent CH 337 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 335. Organic Chemistry II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reactions and mechanisms of organic chemistry. Prereq: CH 331 or 341. Concurrent CH 338 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 336. Organic Chemistry III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Organic chemistry of biomolecules with a focus on chemical aspects. Prereq: CH 335 or 342. Concurrent CH 339 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 337. Organic Chemistry Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and techniques of laboratory practice in organic chemistry. Prereq: CH 229 or 239; pre- or coreq: CH 331.

CourseID: P CH 338. Organic Chemistry Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and techniques of laboratory practice in organic chemistry. Prereq: CH 331 or 341, 337; pre- or coreq: CH 335.

CourseID: P CH 341. Majors Track Organic Chemistry I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure, properties, and bonding of organic molecules. Provides a rigorous foundation appropriate for chemistry and biochemistry majors as they become chemical practitioners. Sequence with CH 342, 343. Prereq: CH 223 or CH 226H. Concurrent CH 337 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 342. Majors Track Organic Chemistry II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on mechanisms and reactions of common organic functional groups. Sequence with CH 341, 343. Prereq: CH 331 (with grade of B– or better) or CH 341. Concurrent CH 348 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 343. Majors Track Organic Chemistry III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Incorporates topics from the recent chemistry literature. Sequence with CH 341, 342. Prereq: CH 335 (with grade of B– or better) or CH 342. Concurrent CH 349 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 348. Organic Chemistry Laboratory for Majors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Problem solving in the organic chemistry laboratory. Sequence with CH 337, 349. Prereq: CH 337; CH 331 or 341; coreq: CH 342.

CourseID: P CH 349. Organic Chemistry Lab for Majors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Organic chemistry laboratory projects. Two-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance techniques. Sequence with CH 337, 348. Prereq: CH 348; coreq: CH 343.

CourseID: P CH 360. Physiological Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P For preprofessional health science students. Topics include protein structure and function, enzyme mechanisms, central metabolism and bioenergetics, integration and regulation of metabolism by hormone action. Students cannot receive credit for both CH 360 and 462. Prereq: CH 336 or 343; BI 214 or 282H recommended.

CourseID: P CH 401. Research: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to methods of chemical investigation. For advanced undergraduates by arrangement with individual faculty members.

CourseID: P CH 403. Thesis. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Open to students eligible to work for a bachelor's degree with honors in chemistry or biochemistry. Prereq: Honors majors.

CourseID: P CH 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Biochemistry seminar for undergraduates who have completed or are enrolled in CH 461, 462, 463. No graduate credit.

CourseID: P CH 409. Special Laboratory Problems. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Nonresearch-oriented laboratory instruction and off-campus research and laboratory experience.

CourseID: P CH 411. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to chemical thermodynamics. Prereq: two years of college chemistry (except for physics majors), PHYS 201, 202, 203; MATH 253; MATH 256, 281, 282 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CH 412. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to statistical mechanics and rate processes. Prereq: two years of college chemistry (except for physics majors); CH 411; PHYS 201, 202, 203; MATH 253; MATH 256, 281, 282 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CH 413. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to quantum chemistry. Prereq: two years of college chemistry (except for physics majors), PHYS 201, 202, 203; MATH 253; MATH 256, 281, 282 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CH 417. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments in thermodynamics, modern electronic measurements, computer modeling, and data reduction. Pre or coreq: CH 411.

CourseID: P CH 418. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments in statistical mechanics, chemical kinetics, plasma chemistry, and mass spectrometry. Prerequisite CH 417; Pre or coreq: CH 412.

CourseID: P CH 419. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments molecular spectroscopy, quantum chemistry, and laser-excited chemical and physical processes to illustrate theoretical principles. Prereq: CH 417; pre or coreq: CH 413.

CourseID: P CH 420. Physical Organic Chemistry I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern physical organic chemistry including chemical bonding, acid-base chemistry, thermochemistry, noncovalent interactions, and introduction to computational chemistry. Sequence with CH 421/521. Prereq: CH 336.

CourseID: P CH 421. Physical Organic Chemistry II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern physical organic chemistry including tools to study reaction mechanisms, kinetic analysis, isotope effects, and qualitative molecular orbital theory. Sequence with CH 420/520. Prereq: CH 420/520.

CourseID: P CH 429. Instrumental Analysis. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of instrumental methods for quantitative determinations of unknown chemical samples. Prereq: CH 417.

CourseID: P CH 431. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to group theory for molecular symmetry; syntheses, structures, reactions, and reaction mechanisms of coordination complexes and organometallic complexes.

CourseID: P CH 432. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bioinorganic chemistry: metals in biological systems; coordination chemistry, reactions, spectroscopy, metalloclusters, and synthetic modeling. Prereq: CH 431 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 433. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Solid-state inorganic chemistry: solid-state structure and its determination; the electrical, magnetic, and mechanical properties of materials and their physical description. Prereq: CH 431 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 441. Quantum Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The principles of time-independent quantum mechanics and their application to model atomic and molecular systems. Prereq: CH 413 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 442. Quantum Chemistry and Spectroscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Molecular structure theory, perturbation theory, time-dependent quantum mechanics, theory of spectra, selection rules. Prereq: CH 441 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 443. Quantum Chemistry and Spectroscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experimental spectra of atomic and molecular systems and surfaces. Prereq: CH 442 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 444. Chemical Thermodynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The laws of thermodynamics and their applications, including those to nonideal chemical systems. Prereq: CH 413 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 445. Statistical Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Molecular basis of thermodynamics. Applications to the calculation of the properties of noninteracting and weakly interacting systems. Prereq: CH 413 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 446. Chemical Kinetics: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Description and interpretation of the time evolution of chemical systems. Prereq: CH 413 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 447. Computational Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to modern computational methods used to understand the properties of molecules. Prereq: CH 411, 412; or PHYS 353.

CourseID: P CH 451. Advanced Organic-Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of organic-inorganic reaction dynamics; kinetics and mechanisms, linear free-energy relationships, isotope effects, substitution reactions, dynamic behavior of reactive intermediates, electron transfer chemistry. Prereq: CH 336 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 452. Advanced Organic Chemistry—Stereochemistry and Reactions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and applications of stereochemistry; reagents and reactions, with mechanisms, used in contemporary organic synthesis; examples taken from the current literature.

CourseID: P CH 454. Advanced Electrochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in electrochemistry including fundamental concepts (thermodynamics, kinetics, transport) and applications (analytical techniques, electrolysis, batteries). Prereq: CH 411.

CourseID: P CH 461. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of macromolecules. Exposure to calculus and physical chemistry recommended. Prereq: CH 336 or 343.

CourseID: P CH 462. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Metabolism and metabolic control processes. Energy and sensory transduction mechanisms. Prereq: CH 461.

CourseID: P CH 463. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms and regulation of nucleic acid and protein biosynthesis. Other current topics in biochemical genetics. Prereq: CH 461/561; or CH 360 with a grade of B- or better.

CourseID: P CH 464. RNA Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the diverse field of RNA biochemistry. Prereq: CH 463.

CourseID: P CH 465. Physical Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical chemical properties of biological macromolecules; forces and interactions to establish and maintain macromolecular conformations; physical bases of spectroscopic, hydrodynamic, and rapid-reaction investigative techniques. Offered alternate years. Prereq: CH 461.

CourseID: P CH 466. Structural Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Protein and nucleic acid structures and energetics. Structure determination by x-ray crystallography and nuclear magnetic resonance. Computational methods for structural analysis. Offered alternate years. Prereq: CH 461.

CourseID: P CH 467. Biochemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of modern molecular biology and protein purification. Co-req: CH 461

CourseID: P CH 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Biochemistry seminar for undergraduates who have completed or are enrolled in CH 461, 462, 463. No graduate credit.

CourseID: P CH 511. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to chemical thermodynamics.

CourseID: P CH 512. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to statistical mechanics and rate processes.

CourseID: P CH 513. Physical Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of physics applied to chemical problems, including inorganic, organic, and biochemistry. Introduction to quantum chemistry.

CourseID: P CH 517. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments in thermodynamics, modern electronic measurements, computer modeling, and data reduction. Pre- or coreq: CH 411/511.

CourseID: P CH 518. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments in statistical mechanics, chemical kinetics, plasma chemistry, and mass spectrometry. Pre or coreq: CH 412/512.

CourseID: P CH 519. Physical Chemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments in molecular spectroscopy, quantum chemistry, and laser-excited chemical and physical processes to illustrate theoretical principles. Pre or coreq: CH 413/513.

CourseID: P CH 520. Physical Organic Chemistry I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern physical organic chemistry including chemical bonding, acid-base chemistry, thermochemistry, noncovalent interactions, and introduction to computational chemistry. Sequence with CH 421/521.

CourseID: P CH 521. Physical Organic Chemistry II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern physical organic chemistry including tools to study reaction mechanisms, kinetic analysis, isotope effects, and qualitative molecular orbital theory. Sequence with CH 420/520. Prereq: CH 420/520.

CourseID: P CH 531. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to group theory for molecular symmetry; syntheses, structures, reactions, and reaction mechanisms of coordination complexes and organometallic complexes.

CourseID: P CH 532. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bioinorganic chemistry: metals in biological systems; coordination chemistry, reactions, spectroscopy, metalloclusters, and synthetic modeling. Prereq: CH 531 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 533. Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Solid-state inorganic chemistry: solid-state structure and its determination; the electrical, magnetic, and mechanical properties of materials and their physical description. Prereq: CH 531 recommended.

CourseID: P CH 541. Quantum Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The principles of time-independent quantum mechanics and their application to model atomic and molecular systems. Prereq: CH 4/513 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 542. Quantum Chemistry and Spectroscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Molecular structure theory, perturbation theory, time-dependent quantum mechanics, theory of spectra, selection rules. Prereq: CH 4/541 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 543. Quantum Chemistry and Spectroscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experimental spectra of atomic and molecular systems and surfaces. Prereq: CH 4/542 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 544. Chemical Thermodynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The laws of thermodynamics and their applications, including those to nonideal chemical systems. Prereq: CH 4/513 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 545. Statistical Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Molecular basis of thermodynamics. Applications to the calculation of the properties of noninteracting and weakly interacting systems. Prereq: CH 413/513 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 546. Chemical Kinetics: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Description and interpretation of the time evolution of chemical systems. Prereq: CH 4/513 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 547. Computational Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to modern computational methods used to understand the properties of molecules.

CourseID: P CH 551. Advanced Organic-Inorganic Chemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of organic-inorganic reaction dynamics; kinetics and mechanisms, linear free-energy relationships, isotope effects, substitution reactions, dynamic behavior of reactive intermediates, electron transfer chemistry. Prereq: CH 336 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CH 552. Advanced Organic Chemistry—Stereochemistry and Reactions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and applications of stereochemistry; reagents and reactions, with mechanisms, used in contemporary organic synthesis; examples taken from the current literature.

CourseID: P CH 554. Advanced Electrochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in electrochemistry including fundamental concepts (thermodynamics, kinetics, transport) and applications (analytical techniques, electrolysis, batteries).

CourseID: P CH 561. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of macromolecules.

CourseID: P CH 562. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Metabolism and metabolic control processes. Energy and sensory transduction mechanisms. Prereq: CH 461/561.

CourseID: P CH 563. Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms and regulation of nucleic acid and protein biosynthesis. Other current topics in biochemical genetics. Prereq: CH 461/561.

CourseID: P CH 564. RNA Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the diverse field of RNA biochemistry.

CourseID: P CH 565. Physical Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical chemical properties of biological macromolecules; forces and interactions to establish and maintain macromolecular conformations; physical bases of spectroscopic, hydrodynamic, and rapid-reaction investigative techniques. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P CH 566. Structural Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Protein and nucleic acid structures and energetics. Structure determination by x-ray crystallography and nuclear magnetic resonance. Computational methods for structural analysis. Offered alternate years. Prereq: CH 561.

CourseID: P CH 567. Biochemistry Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of modern molecular biology and protein purification.

CourseID: P CH 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Seminars offered in biochemistry, chemical physics, materials science, molecular biology, neuroscience, organic-inorganic chemistry, and physical chemistry.

CourseID: P CH 613. Organic Chemistry: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include bioorganic and bioinorganic chemistry, computational chemistry, green chemistry, medicinal chemistry, natural products, organometallic chemistry, polymers, catalysis, molecular motors, and spectroscopic methods for structure determination. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P CH 623. Organic-Inorganic Chemistry Journal Club. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Preparation and delivery of colloquium-style lectures in organic-inorganic chemistry based on papers from the literature. Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P CH 624. Physical Chemistry Journal Club. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Preparation and delivery of colloquium-style lectures in physical chemistry based on papers from the literature. Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P CH 662. Advanced Biochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Detailed consideration of enzyme mechanisms, macromolecular structure, protein-nucleic acid interactions, and selected aspects of biological synthesis.

CourseID: P CH 667. Polymers: Synthesis, Characterization, Processing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of polymer synthesis and characterization; kinetics and mechanisms of the principal polymerization reactions. Introduction to mechanical properties and fabrication techniques.

CourseID: P CH 668. Physical Chemistry of Polymers and Coatings. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Statistical and thermodynamic models for the equilibrium configuration, conformation, structure, mechanical properties, and phase transitions of polymer solutions, dense melts, liquid crystals.

CourseID: P CH 669. Polymer Synthesis and Characterization Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Preparation and physical characterization of polymers; emphasis on polymers of commercial interest.

CourseID: P CH 670. Industrial Polymer Projects Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Polymer industry–focused projects with emphasis on formulation and optimization of adhesives, coatings, thermoplastics, thermosets, drug delivery systems, biopolymers, personal care products. Prereq: CH 667, CH 668, CH 669.

CourseID: P CH 677M. Semiconductor Device Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the theory behind semiconductors. Elementary theory of inorganic solids; electronic structures and transport properties. Basic theory of devices including diodes, transistors, mosfets, and optoelectronic devices. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 678M, PHYS 679M. Multilisted with PHYS 677M.

CourseID: P CH 678M. Semiconductor Processing and Characterization Technology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the techniques required to make semiconductors and test their properties. Solid-state and surface chemistry of inorganic semiconductors as it pertains to microelectronic devices. Offered only in summer. Multilisted with PHYS 678M. Prereq: CH 677M.

CourseID: P CH 679M. Device Processing and Characterization Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students use theory and techniques learned to design, fabricate, and test a device that performs a specific function, with an emphasis on wafer processing and device realization. Offered only in summer. Sequence with CH 677M, CH 678M. Multilisted with PHYS 679M. Prereq: CH 678M.

CourseID: P CH 680. Electronics and Vacuum Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to modern electronic components, circuits, basic vacuum theory, vacuum failure modes, measurement systems, and troubleshooting.

CourseID: P CH 681. Introduction to Electron Microscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and best practices for applying scanning electron (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in materials science.

CourseID: P CH 682. Electron Microprobe Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the theory and operation of instrumentation for electron microprobe analysis (EPMA) in materials science and geochemistry.

CourseID: P CH 683. Surface Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and best practices for surface analysis techniques (XPS and ToF-SIMS), with focus on applications for materials science.

CourseID: P CH 685. Advanced Transmission Electron Microscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced theory and practices for using transmission electron microscopy, as applied to materials science. Prereq: CH 681.

CourseID: P CH 686. Advanced Scanning Electron Microscopy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced theory and practices for using focused ion beam and scanning electron microscopy in research and nanofabrication. Prereq: CH 681.

CourseID: P CH 687. Advanced Surface Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced theory and practices for surface analysis spectroscopy, as applied to materials science. Prereq: CH 683.

CourseID: P CINE 110M. Introduction to Film and Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to film and media studies and various methods of critical analysis. Multilisted with ENG 110M.

CourseID: P CINE 111. How to Watch TV. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the critical analysis of television narrative, aesthetics, and reception.

CourseID: P CINE 151M. Introduction to Korean Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys Korean national cinema, from the earliest days of the medium to the present. Multilisted with KRN 151M.

CourseID: P CINE 230. Remix Cultures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of issues surrounding media production and consumption in relation to intellectual property laws in modern society. Open to all majors.

CourseID: P CINE 260M. Media Aesthetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the analysis of form and style in cinema and related media, focusing on narrative, mise-en-scène, cinematography, editing, and sound. Multilisted with ENG 260M.

CourseID: P CINE 265. History of the Motion Picture I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies the technological, artistic, and cultural histories of motion pictures in various national contexts, from precinema through the silent era. Series with CINE 266, CINE 267.

CourseID: P CINE 266. History of the Motion Picture II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies the technological, artistic, and cultural histories of motion pictures in various national contexts, from the transition to sound through the early 1960s. Series with CINE 265, CINE 267.

CourseID: P CINE 267. History of the Motion Picture III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies the technological, artistic, and cultural histories of motion pictures in various national contexts, from the 1960s through the present. Series with CINE 265, CINE 266.

CourseID: P CINE 268. United States Television History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analyzes the history of US television, from its roots in radio broadcasting to the latest developments in digital television.

CourseID: P CINE 270. Introduction to Narrative Cinema Production. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on basic theory and practice of digital video for narrative production. Prereq: ENG 260, J 201; two from ENG 265, 266, 267.

CourseID: P CINE 320. Beginning Screenwriting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the basics of writing for the screen. Provides students with an organized strategy for writing a feature film. Prereq: ENG 260, J 201; two from ENG 265, 266, 267; one from ARTD 256, CINE 270, J 208.

CourseID: P CINE 330. Film Festivals. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys histories of film festivals in relation to their forms, functions, operations, marketing, curatorial missions, and social impacts. Prereq: one from J 201, ENG 260, ENG 265, ENG 266, ENG 267.

CourseID: P CINE 335. Exhibition and Audiences. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the exhibition and reception of film and other media by audiences in various contexts.

CourseID: P CINE 340. Production Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the development of production practices and the lived realities of film and television production workers.

CourseID: P CINE 345. Stars. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An examination of how and why stars and celebrities are produced and marketed by entertainment industries.

CourseID: P CINE 350. Queer European Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines questions of gender and sexuality within the transnational and national contexts of Europe, including its diverse cinematic landscapes, traditions, and star imagery.

CourseID: P CINE 360. Film Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theoretical debates about film as a medium of artistic expression in a transhistorical and global framework.

CourseID: P CINE 362M. Contemporary Korean Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to contemporary South Korean film. Explores changes in film culture, practice, and industry in relation to social changes since the early 1990s. Offered alternate years. Multilisted with KRN 362M.

CourseID: P CINE 365. Digital Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the impact of digital media technologies on diverse dimensions of cinematic experience encompassing the production, delivery, and reception.

CourseID: P CINE 381M. Film, Media, and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of film and media as aesthetic objects shaped by a broad range of identity categories, reflecting communities identified by class, gender, race, ethnicity, and sexuality. Multilisted with ENG 381M.

CourseID: P CINE 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P CINE 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for a maximum of 12 credits; only 4 credits may count toward the cinema studies major.

CourseID: P CINE 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for a maximum of 12 credits; only 4 credits may count toward the cinema studies major.

CourseID: P CINE 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: One course from ARTD 252, ARTD 256, CINE 270, J 207, J 208.

CourseID: P CINE 410. Experimental Course. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: one from ENG 110, 260.

CourseID: P CINE 411M. US Film Industry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traces the past and present of the U.S. film industry. Multilisted with J 411M. Prereq: J 201 with a grade of mid-C or better.

CourseID: P CINE 415. Cinema Careers. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the values and strengths of cinema-oriented jobs in the humanities, industry, and otherwise. Resume, cover letter, portfolio, and interview assignments hone oral and written communication skills.

CourseID: P CINE 420. Advanced Screenwriting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides advanced screenwriting students with an organized strategy for writing a feature film screenplay. Sequence with CINE 320. Prereq: CINE 320 with grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CINE 425. Cinema Production: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of intermediate to advanced techniques used in cinema production—from music videos to digital sound recording to 16-millimeter film. Topics include Directing, Digital Single-Lens Reflex Camera Production, Music Video Production. Repeatable three times for a maximum of 16 credits when topic changes. Prereq: ENG 260, J 201; two from ENG 265, 266, 267; one from ARTD 256, CINE 270, J 208.

CourseID: P CINE 470. Postwar Cinema : [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how war has impacted film cultures across the globe and the relation between film industries and war. Develops analytical skills within an historical and national context. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when the topic changes.

CourseID: P CINE 486M. New Media and Digital Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of emerging media forms and techniques, such as digital cinema, video games, viral videos, and interactive media. Offered alternate years. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Multilisted with ENG 486M.

CourseID: P CINE 511M. US Film Industry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traces the past and present of the U.S. film industry. Multilisted with J 511M.

CourseID: P CINE 586M. New Media and Digital Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of emerging media forms and techniques, such as digital cinema, video games, viral videos, and interactive media. Offered alternate years. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Multilisted with ENG 586M.

CourseID: P HIST 414 Ancient Rome: [Topic] ANTH 310 Exploring Other Cultures: [Topic] or ANTH or World Archaeology 150 or Fundamentals of Archaeology or ANTH or Zooarchaeology: [Topic] 340 or ANTH
Descriptions: P 471 Upper-division elective course Elective course

CourseID: P CLAS 110. Classical Mythology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the world of Greek and Roman mythology with an emphasis on the issues of personal and social identity.

CourseID: P CLAS 188. Introduction to Classical Archaeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the archaeology and material culture of the Ancient Greeks and Romans.

CourseID: P CLAS 201. Greek Life and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the literature, history, and art of ancient Greece. Students develop an appreciation for Greek culture and its similarities to and differences from American culture.

CourseID: P CLAS 202. Roman Life and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines Roman civilization from the founding of Rome in the 8th century BC to the victory of Constantine and his religion early in the 4th century AD.

CourseID: P CLAS 301. Greek and Roman Epic. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the heroic tradition and epic themes in the Homeric poems, the works of Hesiod, and the Aeneid. Emphasis on literary criticism and intellectual history.

CourseID: P CLAS 302. Greek and Roman Tragedy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, and perhaps Seneca from the viewpoint of literary criticism and intellectual history.

CourseID: P CLAS 303. Classical Greek Philosophers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the philosophies of Plato and/or Aristotle from the viewpoint of Greek intellectual history.

CourseID: P CLAS 310. Early China, Ancient Greece. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between knowledge and wisdom in literature produced by two different ancient civilizations, Greece and China, from c. 1000 BCE to 86 CE. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P CLAS 311. Death and Rebirth in Greece and India. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores Greco-Roman and Indian conceptions of the soul and beliefs concerning the afterlife, particularly those of reincarnation and soul transmigration. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P CLAS 314. Gender and Sexuality in Antiquity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to construction of the categories of norms of Western sexuality through study of Greek and Roman attitudes toward gender roles, homo- and heterosexuality, the family, and privacy.

CourseID: P CLAS 330. Greek and Roman Archaeology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A course of variable content focusing on issues and methods of Mediterranean archaeology from the Bronze Age to Late Antiquity. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when the topic changes.

CourseID: P CLAS 503. Thesis. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: second-year proficiency in Greek or Latin.

CourseID: P CLAS 611. Introduction to Philological Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces graduate students to methodological approaches for the study of antiquity, employing faculty expertise in literary criticism, ancient art, historiography, epigraphy, ancient philosophy, and paleography.

CourseID: P GRK 101. First-Year Greek. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of the Attic Greek language; readings in Attic Greek and in koine.

CourseID: P GRK 102. First-Year Greek. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of the Attic Greek language; readings in Attic Greek and in koine. Prereq: GRK 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GRK 103. First-Year Greek. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of the Attic Greek language; readings in Attic Greek and in koine. Prereq: GRK 102 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GRK 301. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Greek: selections from major Greek authors, either Plato or Lysias, with focus on reading and syntax. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P GRK 302. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Greek: selections from Euripides, with focus on reading and syntax. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P GRK 303. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Greek: selections from Homer or Hesiod, with focus on reading and syntax. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P GRK 411. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Each term devoted to a different author or literary genre: Euripides, Sophocles, Aeschylus, Plato, Aristotle, Demosthenes, Herodotus, Aristophanes, lyric poetry, comedy, pastoral. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GRK 511. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Each term devoted to a different author or literary genre: Euripides, Sophocles, Aeschylus, Plato, Aristotle, Demosthenes, Herodotus, Aristophanes, lyric poetry, comedy, pastoral. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P LAT 101. First-Year Latin. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of Latin grammar; selected readings from classical and medieval authors.

CourseID: P LAT 102. First-Year Latin. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of Latin grammar; selected readings from classical and medieval authors. Prereq: LAT 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P LAT 103. First-Year Latin. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of Latin grammar; selected readings from classical and medieval authors. Prereq: LAT 102 or equivalent.

CourseID: P LAT 301. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Latin: selections from Caesar, with focus on reading and syntax. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P LAT 302. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Latin: selections from Virgil's Aeneid, with focus on reading and syntax. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P LAT 303. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second-year Latin: selections from major Roman authors with focus on reading and syntax. Recent authors are Cicero, Terence, Tibullus. Repeatable when reading material changes.

CourseID: P LAT 411. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Each term devoted to a different author or literary genre: Catullus, Tacitus, Juvenal, Pliny, Ovid, Lucretius, comedy, philosophy, elegy, epic, satire. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P LAT 511. Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Each term devoted to a different author or literary genre: Catullus, Tacitus, Juvenal, Pliny, Ovid, Lucretius, comedy, philosophy, elegy, epic, satire. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P COLT 103 Introduction to Comparative Literature First Year: 4 language one lower proficiency
Descriptions: P division COLT General education courses 8

CourseID: P COLT 101. Introduction to Comparative Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the comparative study of literature. Emphasis on literary genre, world literature, historical period.

CourseID: P COLT 102. Introduction to Comparative Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the comparative study of literature. Emphasis on world literature in its social and political contexts.

CourseID: P COLT 103. Introduction to Comparative Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of visual culture from around the world.

CourseID: P COLT 211. Comparative World Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores literature from a global standpoint. Examines movement of literary forms (e.g., genres, motifs, rhetorical modes) from one culture, region, historical epoch to the next.

CourseID: P COLT 212. Comparative World Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the principles of comparative analysis, exploring the aesthetic, ideological, and socio-economic exchanges between national cinematic traditions. Themes vary by instructor. Recent themes include Melodrama, Zombies, Queer Cinema.

CourseID: P COLT 231. Literature and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of literature in relation to society and politics. Draws on perspectives from political science, law, sociology, and related fields.

CourseID: P COLT 232. Literature and Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of literature and film. Draws on perspectives from cinema studies, media aesthetics, and related fields.

CourseID: P COLT 301. Approaches to Comparative Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and methods in comparative literature, with some attention to the history and problems of the discipline.

CourseID: P COLT 302. Theories of Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the study of poetry and poetic form from a world perspective. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P COLT 303. Theories of the Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the study of narrative and the novel from a world perspective. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P COLT 304. Theories of Drama. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the study of drama and performance from a world perspective. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P COLT 305. Cultural Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of cultural discourses and practices.

CourseID: P COLT 360. Gender and Identity in Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the study of gender in literature, from Asia to Europe to the Americas, and from the classics to the late 20th century.

CourseID: P COLT 370. Comparative Comics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines genre of narrative from a comparative and global standpoint, reviewing the impact of comics and other visual media on questions of national, regional, and ethnic identity. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P COLT 380. Comparative Media: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical analysis of a range of media from a transnational and/or intercultural perspective. Taught as a hybrid course blending face-toface and online learning. Recent topics include Tokyo Cyberpunk, Asian Horror, Listening to Cinema. Repeatable thrice for a maximum of 16 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 415. Capstone Seminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Senior seminar for all comparative literature students includes development and presentation of an original research project.

CourseID: P COLT 440. Studies in Genre: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of specific literary genres, modes, or both (e.g., lyric poetry, comedy, allegory). Repeatable when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 450. Comparative Studies in Cinema: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced consideration of the aesthetic (including literary) and cultural contexts of world film. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 460. Major Theorists: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concentrates on the work of a single literary or cultural theorist (e.g., Walter Benjamin, Jacques Derrida, Gayatri Spivak). Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 461. Studies in Contemporary Theory: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Identifies issues in literary or cultural theory for close examination. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 462. Cultural Intersections: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies designated issues between literatures and societies remote from one another, e.g., "minor" and "major" cultures, Asia and the West. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 470. Studies in Identity: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of gender, ethnicity, and other identity formations in literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 490. Literature and Philosophy: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Establishes a dialogue between philosophy and literature—as disciplines, as historical constructions, as value systems. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 540. Studies in Genre: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of specific literary genres, modes, or both (e.g., lyric poetry, comedy, allegory). Repeatable when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 550. Comparative Studies in Cinema: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced consideration of the aesthetic (including literary) and cultural contexts of world film. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 560. Major Theorists: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concentrates on the work of a single literary or cultural theorist (e.g., Walter Benjamin, Jacques Derrida, Gayatri Spivak). Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 561. Studies in Contemporary Theory: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Identifies issues in literary or cultural theory for close examination. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 562. Cultural Intersections: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies designated issues between literatures and societies remote from one another, e.g., "minor" and "major" cultures, Asia and the West. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 570. Studies in Identity: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of gender, ethnicity, and other identity formations in literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered every two to three years.

CourseID: P COLT 590. Philosophical Problems and Literary Contexts: [Topic]. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Establishes a dialogue between philosophy and literature—as disciplines, as historical constructions, as value systems. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P COLT 613. Graduate Studies in Translation. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Approaches to literary translation in its theoretical, practical and pedagogical dimensions.

CourseID: P COLT 614. Graduate Studies in Comparative Literature. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the state of the discipline. Treats historical and theoretical developments in literary studies including philology and cultural studies; reconsiders the place of comparative literature in a global, pluralistic curriculum.

CourseID: P COLT 615. Graduate Studies in Comparative Literature. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of contemporary literary theory.

CourseID: P COLT 616. Transmedial Aesthetics. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Approaches to the analysis of film, photography, video, and new media. Emphasis on intersections between comparison and media theory.

CourseID: P CIS 105. Explorations in Computing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of basic ideas and areas of computer science: includes algorithms, hardware, machine organization, programming languages, networks, artificial intelligence, and associated ethical issues. Prereq: MATH 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CIS 110. Fluency with Information Technology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to information technology (IT), the study of computer-based information systems. Basics of the Internet and World Wide Web. Students create websites using XHTML and CSS.

CourseID: P CIS 111. Introduction to Web Programming. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Project-based approach to learning computer programming by building interactive web pages using JavaScript and XHTML. Programming concepts including structured and object-oriented program design. CIS 110 recommended preparation. Prereq: MATH 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CIS 115. Multimedia Web Programming. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate web programming with an emphasis on HTML5 multimedia: two-dimensional graphics, image processing, animation, video, user interaction, geolocation. Continuing JavaScript, DOM, Ajax, and JSON use, programming fundamentals, and debugging techniques. Prereq: CIS 111.

CourseID: P CIS 122. Introduction to Programming and Problem Solving. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Computational problem solving, algorithm design, data structures, and programming using a multi-paradigm programming language. Introduces techniques for program design, testing, and debugging. Prereq: MATH 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CIS 210. Computer Science I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts and practices of computer science. Topics include algorithmic problem solving, levels of abstraction, object-oriented design and programming, software organization, analysis of algorithm and data structures. Sequence. Prereq: MATH 112. Prior programming experience strongly encouraged.

CourseID: P CIS 211. Computer Science II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts and practices of computer science. Topics include algorithmic problem solving, levels of abstraction, object-oriented design and programming, software organization, analysis of algorithm and data structures. Sequence. Prereq: CIS 210.

CourseID: P CIS 212. Computer Science III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts and practices of computer science. Topics include algorithmic problem solving, levels of abstraction, object-oriented design and programming, software organization, analysis of algorithm and data structures. Sequence. Prereq: CIS 211.

CourseID: P CIS 313. Intermediate Data Structures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design and analysis of data structures as means of engineering efficient software; attention to data abstraction and encapsulation. Lists, trees, heaps, stacks, queues, dictionaries, priority queues. Prereq: CIS 210, CIS 211, CIS 212, MATH 231, MATH 232 with grades of B- or better.

CourseID: P CIS 314. Computer Organization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to computer organization and instruction-set architecture-digital logic design, binary arithmetic, design of central processing unit and memory, machine-level programming. Prereq: CIS 210, CIS 211, CIS 212, MATH 231 with grades of B- or better.

CourseID: P CIS 315. Intermediate Algorithms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Algorithm design, worst-case and average-behavior analysis, correctness, computational complexity. Prereq: CIS 313.

CourseID: P CIS 322. Introduction to Software Engineering. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A project-intensive introduction to software engineering intended to build skills, knowledge, and habits of mind that prepare students for 400-level computer science courses, internships, and other software. Prereq: CIS 210, CIS 211, CIS 212 with grades of B- or better.

CourseID: P CIS 330. C/C++ and Unix. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical software design and programming activities in a C/C++ and Unix environment, with emphasis on the details of C/C++ and good programming style and practices. Prereq: CIS 314.

CourseID: P CIS 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P CIS 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Opportunity to study in greater depth specific topics arising out of other courses.

CourseID: P CIS 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P The student assists other students who are enrolled in introductory programming classes. For each four hours of scheduled weekly consulting, the student is awarded 1 credit. Repeatable for maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P CIS 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P CIS 413. Advanced Data Structures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Complex structures, storage management, sorting and searching, hashing, storage of texts, and information compression. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 415. Operating Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of operating system design. Process and memory management, concurrency, scheduling, input-output and file systems, security. Prereq: CIS 313, CIS 330.

CourseID: P CIS 420. Automata Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a mathematical basis for computability and complexity. Models of computation, formal languages, Turing machines, solvability. Nondeterminism and complexity classes. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 422. Software Methodology I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Technical and nontechnical aspects of software development, including specification, planning, design, development, management and maintenance of software projects. Student teams complete projects. Prereq: CIS 313.

CourseID: P CIS 423. Software Methodology II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of concepts and methodologies covered in CIS 422/522. Student teams complete a large system design and programming project. Final system specification, test plan, user documentation, and system walk throughs. Prereq: CIS 422 with a B- or better.

CourseID: P CIS 425. Principles of Programming Languages. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Syntax and semantics. Scope rules, environments, stores, denoted and expressed values, procedures, and parameters. Definitional interpreters. Types, overloading, parametric polymorphism, and inheritance. Varieties of abstraction. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 427. Introduction to Logic. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic notions of logic: propositional logic, first-order logic, Hilbert systems, sequent calculus, natural deduction. Soundness, completeness, undecidability. Current research in logic frameworks, automated deduction, Curry-Howard isomorphism. Prereq: CIS 315; CIS 425 recommended pre or co-req.

CourseID: P CIS 429. Computer Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P RISC (reduced instruction-set computer) and CISC (complex instruction-set computer) design, storage hierarchies, high-performance processor design, pipelining, vector processing, networks, performance analysis. Prereq: CIS 330.

CourseID: P CIS 431. Introduction to Parallel Computing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Parallel architecture, theory, algorithms, and programming with emphasis on parallel programming, focusing on models, languages, libraries, and runtime systems. Prereq: CIS 330.

CourseID: P CIS 432. Introduction to Networks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of computer network design. Link technologies, packet switching, routing, inter-networking, reliability. Internet protocols. Programming assignments focus on protocol design. Prereq: CIS 330. CIS 415 recommended.

CourseID: P CIS 433. Computer and Network Security. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Security for various aspects of computers and networks. Elementary cryptography, program security, trusted operating systems, network security, privacy, and legal and ethical issues. Prereq: CIS 415.

CourseID: P CIS 441. Introduction to Computer Graphics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the hardware, geometrical transforms, interaction techniques, and shape representation schemes that are important in interactive computer graphics. Programming assignments using contemporary graphics hardware and software systems. Prereq: CIS 330.

CourseID: P CIS 443. User Interfaces. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to user interface software engineering. Emphasis on theory of interface design, understanding the behavior of the user, and implementing programs on advanced systems. Prereq: CIS 313.

CourseID: P CIS 445. Modeling and Simulation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical foundations and practical problems for the modeling and computer simulation of discrete and continuous systems. Simulation languages, empirical validation, applications in computer science. Prereq: CIS 315, 330.

CourseID: P CIS 451. Database Processing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental concepts of DBMS. Data modeling, relational models and normal forms. File organization and index structures. SQL, embedded SQL, and concurrency control. Prereq: CIS 313, 314.

CourseID: P CIS 452. Database Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers central database issues such as access methods, security, tuning, and concurrency control. Examines alternative database models. Prereq: CIS 451.

CourseID: P CIS 453. Data Mining. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Databases, machine learning, artificial intelligence, statistics, and data visualization. Examines data warehouses, data preprocessing, association and classification rule mining, and cluster analysis. Prereq: CIS 451/551.

CourseID: P CIS 454. Bioinformatics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to bioinformatics from a computer science perspective covering algorithms for basic operations such as sequence comparison and phylogenetic inference on existing databases.

CourseID: P CIS 461. Introduction to Compilers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lexical analysis, parsing, attribution, code generation. Prereq: CIS 314, 425. CIS 420 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CIS 471. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic themes, issues, and techniques of artificial intelligence, including agent architecture, knowledge representation and reasoning, problem solving and planning, game playing, and learning. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 472. Machine Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A broad introduction to machine learning and its established algorithms. Topics include concept learning, decision trees, neural network. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 473. Probabilistic Methods for Artificial Intelligence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental techniques for representing problems as probability distributions, performing inference, and learning from data. Topics include Bayesian and Markov networks, variable elimination, loopy belief propagation, and parameter. Prereq: CIS 315.

CourseID: P CIS 490. Computer Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses ethical issues and social impacts of computing. Topics include crime, hacking, intellectual property, privacy, software reliability, employment, and worldwide networks.

CourseID: P CIS 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Opportunity to study in greater depth specific topics arising out of other courses.

CourseID: P CIS 513. Advanced Data Structures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Complex structures, storage management, sorting and searching, hashing, storage of texts, and information compression.

CourseID: P CIS 520. Automata Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a mathematical basis for computability and complexity. Models of computation, formal languages, Turing machines, solvability. Nondeterminism and complexity classes.

CourseID: P CIS 522. Software Methodology I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Technical and nontechnical aspects of software development, including specification, planning, design, development, management and maintenance of software projects. Student teams complete projects.

CourseID: P CIS 523. Software Methodology II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Student teams complete a large system design and programming project. Final system specifications, test plan, user documentation, and system walk-through. Prereq: CIS 522

CourseID: P CIS 527. Introduction to Logic. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic notions of logic: propositional logic, first-order logic, Hilbert systems, sequent calculus, natural deduction. Soundness, completeness, undecidability. Current research in logic frameworks, automated deduction, Curry-Howard isomorphism.

CourseID: P CIS 529. Computer Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P RISC (reduced instruction-set computer) and CISC (complex instruction-set computer) design, storage hierarchies, high-performance processor design, pipelining, vector processing, networks, performance analysis.

CourseID: P CIS 531. Introduction to Parallel Computing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Parallel architecture, theory, algorithms, and programming with emphasis on parallel programming, focusing on models, languages, libraries, and runtime systems.

CourseID: P CIS 532. Introduction to Networks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of computer network design. Link technologies, packet switching, routing, inter-networking, reliability. Internet protocols. Programming assignments focus on protocol design.

CourseID: P CIS 533. Computer and Network Security. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Security for various aspects of computers and networks. Elementary cryptography,program security, trusted operating systems, network security, privacy, and legal and ethical issues.

CourseID: P CIS 541. Introduction to Computer Graphics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the hardware, geometrical transforms, interaction techniques, and shape representation schemes that are important in interactive computer graphics. Programming assignments using contemporary graphics hardware and software systems.

CourseID: P CIS 543. User Interfaces. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to user interface software engineering. Emphasis on theory of interface design, understanding the behavior of the user, and implementing programs on advanced systems.

CourseID: P CIS 545. Modeling and Simulation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical foundations and practical problems for the modeling and computer simulation of discrete and continuous systems. Simulation languages, empirical validation, applications in computer science.

CourseID: P CIS 551. Database Processing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental concepts of DBMS. Data modeling, relational models and normal forms. File organization and index structures. SQL, embedded SQL, and concurrency control.

CourseID: P CIS 552. Database Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers central database issues such as access methods, security, tuning, and concurrency control. Examines alternative database models. Prereq: CIS 4/551.

CourseID: P CIS 553. Data Mining. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Databases, machine learning, artificial intelligence, statistics, and data visualization. Examines data warehouses, data preprocessing, association and classification rule mining, and cluster analysis. Prereq: CIS 451/551.

CourseID: P CIS 554. Bioinformatics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to bioinformatics from a computer science perspective covering algorithms for basic operations such as sequence comparison and phylogenetic inference on existing databases.

CourseID: P CIS 561. Introduction to Compilers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lexical analysis, parsing, attribution, code generation. Prereq: CIS 314 or equivalent, 624. CIS 420/520 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CIS 571. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic themes, issues, and techniques of artificial intelligence, including agent architecture, knowledge representation and reasoning, problem solving and planning, game playing, and learning.

CourseID: P CIS 572. Machine Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A broad introduction to machine learning and its established algorithms. Topics include concept learning, decision trees, neural network.

CourseID: P CIS 573. Probabilistic Methods for Artificial Intelligence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental techniques for representing problems as probability distributions, performing inference, and learning from data. Topics include Bayesian and Markov networks, variable elimination, loopy belief propagation, and parameter.

CourseID: P CIS 590. Computer Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses ethical issues and social impacts of computing. Topics include crime, hacking, intellectual property, privacy, software reliability, employment, and worldwide networks.

CourseID: P CIS 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Research topics are presented.

CourseID: P CIS 609. Final Project. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Final project for master's degree without thesis.

CourseID: P CIS 621. Algorithms and Complexity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design and analysis of algorithms, strategies for efficient algorithms, introduction to complexity theory including NP-completeness. Prereq: CIS 420/520 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P CIS 624. Structure of Programming Languages. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to axiomatic, operational, and denotational semantics. Environments, stores, and continuations. Type theory, subtypes, polymorphism, and inheritance. Functional and logic programming.

CourseID: P CIS 630. Distributed Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of distributed computer systems: interprocess communication, distributed file systems, distributed timing and synchronization, distributed programming, transactions, process scheduling, distributed shared memory. Prereq: CIS 415 or equivalent, CIS 429/529.

CourseID: P CIS 631. Parallel Processing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in parallel processing including massively parallel computer architecture, supercomputers, parallelizing compiler technology, performance evaluation, parallel programming languages, parallel applications. Prereq: CIS 529, CIS 531.

CourseID: P CIS 632. Computer Networks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced issues in computer networks, focusing on research to extend the services offered by the Internet. Prereq: CIS 432/532.

CourseID: P CIS 633. Advanced Network Security. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Classic and state-of-the-art research topics in network security; threats and attacks, defense algorithms and mechanisms, measurement and evaluation of both security problems and solutions. Offered alternate years. Prereq: CIS 533.

CourseID: P CIS 650. Software Engineering. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines recent models and tools in software engineering including modifications to the traditional software life-cycle model, development environments, and speculative view of the future role of artificial intelligence.

CourseID: P CIT 281. Web Applications Development I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of web application development using open-source software tools and technologies (Unix, Git), client-side frameworks, server-side programming (Node.js, PHP), model-view-controller pattern, data storage and APIs, cloud hosting. Prereq: CIS 111 with a B- or higher.

CourseID: P CIT 381. Database Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to database systems, emphasis on database design and access. Database concepts, data modeling, SQL, connecting database to web. Prereq: CIT 281.

CourseID: P CIT 382. Web Applications Development II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Server- and client-side technologies and their interaction for database-driven web applications: application frameworks, single-page applications, cloud platforms, and open-source software stacks—MEAN (MongoDB, ExpressJS, AngularJS, Node.js) versus LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP). Prereq: CIT 381.

CourseID: P CIT 383. Networking Fundamentals. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of data communication and networks. Network management and security. Prereq: CIT 382.

CourseID: P CRWR 225. Kidd Tutorial I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to an intensive, yearlong sequence devoted to the study and practice of poetry, fiction, and nonfiction.

CourseID: P CRWR 230. Introduction to Poetry Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to forms and techniques of writing poetry.

CourseID: P CRWR 235. Kidd Tutorial II: Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second in a yearlong sequence devoted to the study and practice of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction, including the development of an individual line of inquiry project. Prereq: CRWR 225 with a grade of B- or above.

CourseID: P CRWR 240. Introduction to Fiction Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to forms and techniques of writing fiction.

CourseID: P CRWR 245. Kidd Tutorial II: Fiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second in a yearlong sequence devoted to the study and practice of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction, including the development of an individual line of inquiry project. Prereq: CRWR 225 with a grade of B- or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 330. Intermediate Poetry Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level study of poetry writing. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: one from CRWR 230, CRWR 235 with a grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 335. Kidd Tutorial III: Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third in a yearlong sequence, culminating in a Kidd Tutorial student anthology, a portfolio of poetry, and the completion of an individual line of inquiry project. Prereq: CRWR 235 with a Grade of B- or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 336. Intermediate Creative Writing: Literary Nonfiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level study of literary nonfiction writing. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: one from CRWR 240, CRWR 244, CRWR 245 with a grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 340. Intermediate Fiction Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level study of fiction writing. Repeatable when topic changes. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: one from CRWR 240, CRWR 244, CRWR 245 with a grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 345. Kidd Tutorial III: Fiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third in a yearlong sequence, culminating in a Kidd Tutorial student anthology, a portfolio of original fiction, and the completion of an individual line of inquiry project. Prereq: CRWR 245 with a Grade of B- or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 413. Literature for Poets. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced discourse on issues and principles related to the craft of poetry. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: one from CRWR 330, CRWR 335 with a grade of B– or better. Students majoring in English, journalism, or comparative literature may also enroll with instructor approval.

CourseID: P CRWR 414. Literature for Fiction Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced discourse on issues and principles related to the craft of fiction. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: One from CRWR 336, CRWR 340, CRWR 345 with a grade of B– or better. Students majoring in English, journalism, or comparative literature may also enroll with instructor approval.

CourseID: P CRWR 435. Advanced Poetry Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced workshop in the writing of poetry. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: One from CRWR 330, CRWR 335 with a grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 445. Advanced Fiction Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced workshop in the writing of fiction. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: One from CRWR 336, CRWR 340, CRWR 345 with a grade of B– or better.

CourseID: P CRWR 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected seminars offered each year. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P CRWR 609. Terminal Creative Project: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P CRWR 610. Experimental Course [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

CourseID: P CRWR 610. Experimental Course [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P CRWR 635. MFA Poetry Workshop. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concentration on student writing in a workshop setting. Open only to students admitted to creative writing master of fine arts program in poetry. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 36 credits.

CourseID: P CRWR 645. MFA Fiction Workshop. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concentration on student writing in a workshop setting. Open only to students admitted to creative writing master of fine arts program in fiction. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 36 credits.
