CourseID: P GEOL 101. Exploring Planet Earth. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Plate tectonics, mantle flow, and magmatism. Volcanoes, earthquakes, mountain building, generation of Earth's crust; rocks and minerals; Earth's internal structure. Comparison with other planets. Laboratory, lecture.

CourseID: P GEOL 102. Exploring Earth’s Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Landforms, surface processes, and interactions between humans and the environment. Weathering, erosion, sedimentation, ground water, streams, glaciers, deserts, oceans, and coastlines; geologic hazards. Laboratory, lecture. Roering.

CourseID: P GEOL 103. Exploring Earth History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of the Earth. Geologic time, sedimentary environments; oceans, mountains, and climate through time; stratigraphic history of North America; evolution of plants and animals. Laboratory, lecture.

CourseID: P GEOL 110. People, Rocks, and Fire. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigation of topics in geology, ecology, and anthropology relevant to contemporary global energy debates; current energy policy issues investigated through term projects.

CourseID: P GEOL 137. Mountains and Glaciers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the geological processes that both create and destroy mountain ranges around the world, and an introduction to geological science.

CourseID: P GEOL 156M. Scientific Revolutions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys several major revolutions in our views of the natural and technological world, focusing on scientific concepts and methodological aspects. For nonscience majors. Multilisted with PHYS 156M.

CourseID: P GEOL 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Studies of geologic topics combine background lectures with guided field trips to areas of geologic interest.

CourseID: P GEOL 201. Dynamic Planet Earth. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Processes that cause earthquakes, volcanism, mountain building, and plate tectonics. Includes Earth's origin and internal structure, rocks and minerals, gravity and magnetics. Weekly lectures, two-hour laboratory. Series with GEOL 202, GEOL 203.

CourseID: P GEOL 202. Earth's Surface and Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Earth materials, the rock record, human interactions with surface environment. Sedimentary rocks and environments, chemical and physical weathering, mineral and energy resources, hydrogeology, ground-water contamination, surface processes, human impacts. Weekly lectures, two-hour laboratory. Series with GEOL 201, GEOL 203.

CourseID: P GEOL 203. History of Life. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origin, history, and physical evolution of the Earth; geologic time scales, development of the global stratigraphic section. Weekly lectures, two-hour laboratory. Series with GEOL 201, GEOL 202.

CourseID: P GEOL 213. Geology of National Parks. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines selected geologic features in United States national parks and the processes that form them. Focuses on parks in the western states.

CourseID: P GEOL 304. The Fossil Record. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origin of life in Precambrian; evolution of plants and invertebrate animals; evolution of early chordates, fish, amphibians, reptiles, dinosaurs, birds, and mammals; speciation and extinction. Intended for junior and senior nonmajors but also open to geological sciences majors.

CourseID: P GEOL 305. Dinosaurs. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the past and present biodiversity of vertebrate animals, including ourselves, dinosaurs, and what ruled the ocean when dinosaurs roamed the land.

CourseID: P GEOL 306. Volcanoes and Earthquakes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms that cause earthquakes and volcanoes, relation to plate tectonics, associated hazards, examples in Oregon and the western United States.

CourseID: P GEOL 307. Oceanography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Characteristics and physical, chemical, and biological processes of the world's oceans. Includes sections on origin of the oceans, plate tectonics, and human use and misuse of oceans.

CourseID: P GEOL 308. Geology of Oregon and the Pacific Northwest. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The region's geologic and tectonic history and the plate tectonic processes responsible for its evolution.

CourseID: P GEOL 310. Earth Resources and the Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Geology of energy, mineral, and water resources and environmental issues related to their use. Topics include fossil fuels, metals, nuclear waste disposal, and water pollution.

CourseID: P GEOL 311. Earth Materials. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chemical and mineralogical composition of rocks, sediment, and soil. Properties of common minerals; origin of rocks; microscopic study of rock textures; environmental issues. Prereq: GEOL 101, 102 or 201, 202; coreq CH 221 or 224.

CourseID: P GEOL 315. Earth Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physics of basic Earth processes; application of physics to plate tectonics and lithospheric deformation. Topics include forces, deformation, gravity, and seismology. Taught once or more per academic year. Prereq: MATH 252, PHYS 201.

CourseID: P GEOL 316. Introduction to Hydrogeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the role of water in geologic and environmental processes. Topics include the water cycle, groundwater flow, and contaminant transport. Pre- or coreq: MATH 252, PHYS 201.

CourseID: P GEOL 318. Introduction to Field Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geologic mapping and related field skills, rock descriptions, cross sections, and structures. Lectures, laboratories, mandatory field trips. Prereq: GEOL 101–103 or GEOL 201–203.

CourseID: P GEOL 331. Mineralogy. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Crystal chemistry, systematic study of rock-forming silicate, and selected other minerals, mineral optics, and x-ray diffraction. Lab work with hand samples and petrographic microscopes. Prereq: GEOL 201, 202 or GEOL 101, 102; coreq: CH 221 or 224.

CourseID: P GEOL 332. Introduction to Petrology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origin and classification of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks. Microscopic study of rocks in thin section. Prereq: GEOL 331.

CourseID: P GEOL 334. Sedimentology and Stratigraphy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Sedimentary processes; characteristic properties of sedimentary rocks and their use in interpreting depositional environments; principles of lithostratigraphy and sequence stratigraphy. Prereq: GEOL 101–103 or GEOL 201–203; pre- or coreq: GEOL 311 or

CourseID: P GEOL 350. Structural Geology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Description, analysis, and origin of geologic structures including faults, folds, and tectonites. Focus on kinematic and dynamic analysis of deformation of earth materials. Prereq: GEOL 318; GEOL 311 or 332.

CourseID: P GEOL 351. Structural Geology Problems. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Exercises in solving structural geology problems using orthographic and stereographic projection techniques. Problems emphasize calculating stress and strain from structural markers. Coreq: GEOL 350.

CourseID: P GEOL 352. Structural Geology Laboratory and Field. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Collection and interpretation of field and map data for structural analysis. Includes field trips, map and cross-section generation, and some computer-based exercises. Coreq: GEOL 350.

CourseID: P GEOL 353. Geologic Hazards. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines geologic hazards, including both the physical processes that cause them and society's attempt to mitigate them. Prereq: GEOL 101 or 201.

CourseID: P GEOL 363. MATLAB for Earth Scientists. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to MATLAB (Matrix Laboratory) software package, providing data analysis, mathematical modeling, and computer visualization tools and techniques vital to the work of Earth scientists. Pre- or coreq: MATH 251.

CourseID: P GEOL 403. Thesis. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable thrice for maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: earth sciences honors or senior thesis students only.

CourseID: P GEOL 414. Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced principles of igneous and metamorphic petrogenesis. Gibbs phase rule, phase diagrams, mineral thermodynamics; magma geochemistry and rheology; metamorphic facies, geothermometry and geobarometry. Johnston. Prereq: GEOL 332; CH 223 or 226H.

CourseID: P GEOL 415. Field Geophysics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geophysical methods for subsurface investigation, useful for exploration, geotechnical engineering, and characterization of subsurface groundwater and environmental conditions. Prereq: MATH 112 or PHYS 201.

CourseID: P GEOL 418. Earth and Environmental Data Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tools-based instruction in data analysis for earth and environmental scientists. Topics include descriptive statistics, visualization, uncertainty analysis, hypothesis testing, regression, time series, and directional data. Prereq: MATH 246 or 251.

CourseID: P GEOL 420. Geocommunication. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Scientific writing and presentations for the geological sciences. Focus on writing scientific papers and proposals, preparing oral and visual presentations.

CourseID: P GEOL 425. Geology of Ore Deposits. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Porphyry copper-molybdenum, epithermal, massive sulfides in volcanic rocks, and base and precious metals in sedimentary rocks. Geologic setting, alteration and ore mineral assemblages, and geochemistry of ore formation. Prereq: CH 223; GEOL 332.

CourseID: P GEOL 431. Paleontology I: Paleozoic Marine Fossils. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biostratigraphy, evolution, and paleoecology of life on earth: Paleozoic and some Mesozoic marine invertebrates. Laboratory exercises on fossil specimens. Prereq: GEOL 103 or 203.

CourseID: P GEOL 433. Paleobotany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution and ecology of plants and microbes from the origin of life to global warming. Laboratory exercises and field trip to collect plant fossils. Pre- or coreq: GEOL 103 or 203.

CourseID: P GEOL 434. Vertebrate Paleontology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of vertebrates, including ourselves, based on fossil evidence. Physical and other evolutionary constraints are addressed, and lab exercises provide practical experience. Prereq: GEOL 103 or 203.

CourseID: P GEOL 435. Paleopedology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Soil formation; mapping and naming fossil soils; features of soils in hand specimens and petrographic thin sections; interpretations of ancient environments from features of fossil soils. Prereq: GEOL 311 or 332.

CourseID: P GEOL 438. Geobiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies how microorganisms interact with geological environments at scales from enzymes to global element cycles.

CourseID: P GEOL 440. Sedimentary Basin Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of sedimentary basins, emphasizing tectonic controls on basin formation and filling. Interpretation of subsidence mechanisms and sedimentary processes through analysis of the stratigraphic record. Prereq: GEOL 334, GEOL 350.

CourseID: P GEOL 441. Hillslope Geomorphology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hillslope processes and landforms; includes hillslope hydrology, overland flow erosion, weathering and soil formation, soil creep, landslides and related hazards, glacial and periglacial processes, effects of land-use practices and fire, and landscape evolution.

CourseID: P GEOL 451. Hydrogeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the origin, motion, and physical and chemical properties of ground water. Emphasizes quantitative analysis of flow and interaction with geologic materials. Prereq: CH 222 or CH 225H; GEOL 316.

CourseID: P GEOL 452. Neotectonics and Quaternary Geology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interpretation of active structures from deformed quaternary sediments and surfaces using case histories. Field project uses air photos and field techniques. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: GEOL 334, GEOL 350.

CourseID: P GEOL 453. Tectonics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tectonic processes and examples. Global kinematics of plates and the forces that drive them. Continental deformation in compressional, shear, and extensional settings. Prereq: GEOL 350 and calculus.

CourseID: P GEOL 454. Fluid Dynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the continuum theory of fluid dynamics, focusing on the Navier-Stokes equations of motion including common simplified limits and extensions. Applications are drawn from Earth and Planetary Science, Biology, and Physics. Prereq: PHYS 252, MATH 252.

CourseID: P GEOL 455. Mechanical Earth. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to continuum mechanics. Includes stress and strain, friction, elasticity, viscous fluids, constitutive laws, equations of motion, and deformation of the Earth. Prereq: GEOL 315, PHYS 202, or equivalent; MATH 256.

CourseID: P GEOL 462. Environmental Geomechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of fluid and solid mechanics to understanding processes in the earth and environmental sciences. Offered alternate years. Prereq: GEOL 455.

CourseID: P GEOL 463. Computational Earth Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical techniques for scientific computing. Topics include root finding, curve fitting, interpolation, integration and differentiation, optimization, differential equations. Prereq: MATH 253; GEOL 363 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GEOL 467. Fault Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The physics of faulting throughout the earthquake cycle. Topics include fault friction, seismic rupture, earthquake triggering, and other fault zone processes. Offered alternate years. Prereq: GEOL 315, MATH 253.

CourseID: P GEOL 468. Introduction to Seismology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to observational, theoretical, and computational seismology. Includes review of earth structure, source representation, ray theory, and seismic wave phenomena. Prereq: MATH 256, GEOL 455.

CourseID: P GEOL 471. Thermodynamic Geochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geologic application of classical chemical thermodynamics. Gibbs free energy and its temperature, pressure, and composition derivatives; fugacity, activity, and chemical potential. Solutions, ideal and nonideal. Prereq: GEOL 311 or 332, CH 223, MATH 253.

CourseID: P GEOL 472. Aqueous-Mineral-Gas Equilibria. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aqueous chemistry applied to natural waters (geothermal, diagenetic, continental brines). Equilibrium calculations applied to aqueous-mineralgas systems. Prereq: CH 223; MATH 252.

CourseID: P GEOL 473. Isotope Geochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to nuclear physics and isotope systematics; techniques of isotope analysis; applications of stable and radioactive isotopes in geochronology and as tracers of geological processes.

CourseID: P GEOL 514. Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced principles of igneous and metamorphic petrogenesis. Gibbs phase rule, phase diagrams, mineral thermodynamics; magma geochemistry and rheology; metamorphic facies, geothermometry and geobarometry. Johnston.

CourseID: P GEOL 515. Field Geophysics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geophysical methods for subsurface investigation, useful for exploration, geotechnical engineering, and characterization of subsurface groundwater and environmental conditions.

CourseID: P GEOL 518. Earth and Environmental Data Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tools-based instruction in data analysis for earth and environmental scientists. Topics include descriptive statistics, visualization, uncertainty analysis, hypothesis testing, regression, time series, and directional data. Prereq: MATH 246 or 251.

CourseID: P GEOL 520. Geocommunication. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Scientific writing and presentations for the geological sciences. Focus on writing scientific papers and proposals, preparing oral and visual presentations.

CourseID: P GEOL 525. Geology of Ore Deposits. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Porphyry copper-molybdenum, epithermal, massive sulfides in volcanic rocks, and base and precious metals in sedimentary rocks. Geologic setting, alteration and ore mineral assemblages, and geochemistry of ore formation.

CourseID: P GEOL 531. Paleontology I: Paleozoic Marine Fossils. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biostratigraphy, evolution, and paleoecology of life on earth: Paleozoic and some Mesozoic marine invertebrates. Laboratory exercises on fossil specimens.

CourseID: P GEOL 533. Paleobotany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution and ecology of plants and microbes from the origin of life to global warming. Laboratory exercises and field trip to collect plant fossils.

CourseID: P GEOL 534. Vertebrate Paleontology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of vertebrates, including ourselves, based on fossil evidence. Physical and other evolutionary constraints are addressed, and lab exercises provide practical experience.

CourseID: P GEOL 535. Paleopedology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Soil formation; mapping and naming fossil soils; features of soils in hand specimens and petrographic thin sections; interpretations of ancient environments from features of fossil soils.

CourseID: P GEOL 538. Geobiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies how microorganisms interact with geological environments at scales from enzymes to global element cycles.

CourseID: P GEOL 540. Sedimentary Basin Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of sedimentary basins, emphasizing tectonic controls on basin formation and filling. Interpretation of subsidence mechanisms and sedimentary processes through analysis of the stratigraphic record.

CourseID: P GEOL 541. Hillslope Geomorphology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hillslope processes and landforms; includes hillslope hydrology, overland flow erosion, weathering and soil formation, soil creep, landslides and related hazards, glacial and periglacial processes, effects of land-use practices and fire, and landscape evolution.

CourseID: P GEOL 551. Hydrogeology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the origin, motion, and physical and chemical properties of ground water. Emphasizes quantitative analysis of flow and interaction with geologic materials.

CourseID: P GEOL 552. Neotectonics and Quaternary Geology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interpretation of active structures from deformed quaternary sediments and surfaces using case histories. Field project uses air photos and field techniques. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P GEOL 553. Tectonics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tectonic processes and examples. Global kinematics of plates and the forces that drive them. Continental deformation in compressional, shear, and extensional settings.

CourseID: P GEOL 554. Fluid Dynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the continuum theory of fluid dynamics, focusing on the Navier-Stokes equations of motion including common simplified limits and extensions. Applications are drawn from Earth and Planetary Science, Biology, and Physics.

CourseID: P GEOL 555. Mechanical Earth. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to continuum mechanics. Includes stress and strain, friction, elasticity, viscous fluids, constitutive laws, equations of motion, and deformation of the earth.

CourseID: P GEOL 562. Environmental Geomechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of fluid and solid mechanics to understanding processes in the earth and environmental sciences. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P GEOL 563. Computational Earth Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical techniques for scientific computing. Topics include root finding, curve fitting, interpolation, integration and differentiation, optimization, differential equations.

CourseID: P GEOL 567. Fault Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The physics of faulting throughout the earthquake cycle. Topics include fault friction, seismic rupture, earthquake triggering, and other fault zone processes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P GEOL 568. Introduction to Seismology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to observational, theoretical, and computational seismology. Includes review of earth structure, source representation, ray theory, and seismic wave phenomena.

CourseID: P GEOL 571. Thermodynamic Geochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geologic application of classical chemical thermodynamics. Gibbs free energy and its temperature, pressure, and composition derivatives; fugacity, activity, and chemical potential. Solutions, ideal and nonideal.

CourseID: P GEOL 572. Aqueous-Mineral-Gas Equilibria. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aqueous chemistry applied to natural waters (geothermal, diagenetic, continental brines). Equilibrium calculations applied to aqueous-mineralgas systems. Prereq: CH 223; MATH 252.

CourseID: P GEOL 573. Isotope Geochemistry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to nuclear physics and isotope systematics; techniques of isotope analysis; applications of stable and radioactive isotopes in geochronology and as tracers of geological processes.

CourseID: P GEOL 606. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Geologic fieldwork principally in connection with graduate thesis or dissertation. Emphasis on individual problems.

CourseID: P GEOL 620. Advanced Igneous Petrology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ingeous rocks of the ocean basins, continental margins, and stable continental interior including basalts, calcalkaline series, and granites. Content varies according to research interests. Prereq: GEOL 414/514, 471/571 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GEOL 692. Volcanology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Products and processes of volcanism, origin of magmas, eruptive mechanisms, and relation of volcanism to orogeny and tectonic processes.

CourseID: P CHN 420/520 Intermediate Language Strategies 4 CHN 421/521 Intermediate Language Strategies 4 CHN 422/522 Intermediate Language Strategies 4 CHN 439/539 Chinese Academic Writing 4 CHN 445/545 Advanced Chinese: [Topic] 4 CHN 480/580 Chinese Linguistics 4
Descriptions: P Flagship courses as well as content courses taught in Chinese in other departments expose students to the language and content of a broad range of disciplines, including business, journalism, social sciences, sciences, and the humanities. These courses prepare students to pursue a wide variety of careers in Chinese-speaking environments. Students do not need to be Chinese majors to enroll in Chinese Flagship courses or the program. Those interested in either Flagship-level courses or formally enrolling in the program should visit chineseflagship.uoregon.edu.

CourseID: P CHN 480 Chinese Linguistics
Descriptions: P Upper-division language courses must be taken at the University of Oregon or through an Oregon University System program in China. Lower-division courses must be passed with grades of C– or better or P; upper-division courses must be passed with grades of C– or better.

Descriptions: P Introduction to popular Chinese cultures in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the United States. Discussion focuses on nationalism, globalization, identity, and gender. No background in Chinese necessary; taught in English.

CourseID: P CHN 305. History of Chinese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey ranging from early Confucian and Daoist classics through Tang and Song poetry, short fiction and novels, the 1919 May Fourth Movement writers, and into the contemporary period. Readings in English. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CHN 306. History of Chinese Literature. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P CHN 308. Literature of Modern Taiwan. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the literature of Taiwan from the postwar era to the present. Discussion focuses on national identity, gender, class, modernization, and globalization. Taught in English. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CHN 350. Gender and Sexuality in Traditional Chinese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the changing constructions of gender and sexuality in premodern China. Topics include arranged marriage and concubinage, attitudes toward the body and transgender identities. No background in Chinese necessary; readings in English. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CHN 351. Gender and Sexuality in Modern Chinese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Primary and secondary works about women, sexuality, and changing gender roles in republican, socialist, and post-Mao China. Readings in English. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P CHN 380. Self and Society in Traditional Chinese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the role of the self in premodern Chinese society through reading some of the most important works in traditional Chinese literature. Taught in Chinese. Prereq: Proficiency in modern Chinese as confirmed by instructor.

CourseID: P JPN 437. Classical Japanese Literary Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the basic principles and forms of classical Japanese literary language--style, syntax, and textuality. Selected readings of texts in classical Japanese from Nara through Edo periods. Prereq: JPN 303.

CourseID: P JPN 455. Japanese Business Culture and Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides extensive training in communication skills in all formats (oral and visual) in a business setting. The goal is a successful interview of local Japanese business people conducted in Japanese. Prereq: JPN 303 or equivalent.

CourseID: P JPN 471. The Japanese Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major filmmakers and works are introduced. Comparative analysis of Japanese cinema as narrative form and artists' efforts to grapple with the Japanese experience of modernity. Readings, films, and discussions in English.

CourseID: P JPN 480. Early Modern Comics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on comic books in 18th and 19th century Japan and their place in the "floating world" of popular culture.

CourseID: P JPN 490. Translation and Japanese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theory and practice of translation as it relates to Japanese literature. Students produce their own translations and critique existing translations. Prereq: JPN 412 or 416 or JPN 303.

CourseID: P JPN 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies and projects in Japanese literature or linguistics. Sources are in Japanese, English, or both. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P JPN 511. Fourth-Year Spoken Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of speaking and listening skills related to concrete and abstract topics. Emphasis on sociolinguistic skills. Prereq: JPN 303 or equivalent.

CourseID: P JPN 512. Fourth-Year Spoken Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of speaking and listening skills related to concrete and abstract topics. Emphasis on sociolinguistic skills. Prereq: JPN 411/511.

CourseID: P JPN 513. Fourth-Year Spoken Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of speaking and listening skills related to concrete and abstract topics. Emphasis on sociolinguistic skills. Prereq: JPN 412/512.

CourseID: P JPN 514. Fourth-Year Reading and Writing Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading skills, vocabulary, and knowledge of kanji. Writing exercises include message writing, letter writing, and short essays. Prereq: JPN 303 or equivalent.

CourseID: P JPN 515. Fourth-Year Reading and Writing Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading skills, vocabulary, and knowledge of kanji. Writing exercises include message writing, letter writing, and short essays. Prereq: JPN 414/514.

CourseID: P JPN 516. Fourth-Year Reading and Writing Japanese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading skills, vocabulary, and knowledge of kanji. Writing exercises include message writing, letter writing, and short essays. Prereq: JPN 415/515.

CourseID: P JPN 525. Modern Japanese Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates topics relevant to Japanese literary studies in a comparative context. Recent topics include suicide and literature East and West, nations and resistance, atomic bomb literature. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P JPN 534. Advanced Readings in Japanese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading modern Japanese literature in Japanese. Students acquire proficiency in reading, writing, and translation as well as knowledge of literature. Prereq: JPN 416/516.

CourseID: P JPN 535. Advanced Readings in Japanese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading modern Japanese literature in Japanese. Students acquire proficiency in reading, writing, and translation as well as knowledge of literature. Prereq: JPN 434/534.

CourseID: P JPN 536. Advanced Readings in Japanese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading modern Japanese literature in Japanese. Students acquire proficiency in reading, writing, and translation as well as knowledge of literature. Prereq: JPN 435/535.

CourseID: P JPN 537. Classical Japanese Literary Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the basic principles and forms of classical Japanese literary language--style, syntax, and textuality. Selected readings of texts in classical Japanese from Nara through Edo periods. Prereq: JPN 303 or equivalent.

CourseID: P JPN 571. The Japanese Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major filmmakers and works are introduced. Comparative analysis of Japanese cinema as narrative form and artists' efforts to grapple with the Japanese experience of modernity. Readings, films, and discussions in English.

CourseID: P JPN 580. Early Modern Comics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on comic books in 18th and 19th century Japan and their place in the "floating world" of popular culture.

CourseID: P JPN 590. Translation and Japanese Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theory and practice of translation as it relates to Japanese literature. Students produce their own translations and critique existing translations. JPN 512 or 516

CourseID: P JPN 605. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable as approved by the faculty.

CourseID: P JPN 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies and projects in Japanese literature, linguistics, or pedagogy. Sources in Japanese, English, or both. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P JPN 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 18 credits.

CourseID: P KRN 101. First-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to basic Korean grammar, syllabary, conversation, and characters. Offered annually with KRN 201, 202, 203.

CourseID: P KRN 102. First-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to basic Korean grammar, syllabary, conversation, and characters. Prereq: KRN 101.

CourseID: P KRN 103. First-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to basic Korean grammar, syllabary, conversation, and characters. Prereq: KRN 102.

CourseID: P KRN 151M. Introduction to Korean Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys Korean national cinema, from the earliest days of the medium to the present. Multilisted with CINE 151M.

CourseID: P KRN 201. Second-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of skills in speaking, reading, and writing Korean. Introduction of additional characters. Offered annually with KRN 101, 102, 103. Prereq: KRN 103 or equivalent.

CourseID: P KRN 202. Second-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of skills in speaking, reading, and writing Korean. Introduction of additional characters. Prereq: KRN 201.

CourseID: P KRN 203. Second-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of skills in speaking, reading, and writing Korean. Introduction of additional characters. Prereq: KRN 202.

CourseID: P KRN 301. Third Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills in Korean with focus on literary and cultural texts, writing, and oral skills. Sequence with KRN 302, 303. Prereq: KRN 203

CourseID: P KRN 302. Third-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills in Korean with focus on literary and cultural texts, writing, and oral skills. Sequence with KRN 301, 303. Prereq: KRN 301.

CourseID: P KRN 303. Third-Year Korean. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills in Korean with focus on literary and cultural texts, writing, and oral skills. Sequence with KRN 301, 302. Prereq: KRN 302.

CourseID: P KRN 309. Languages and Cultural Formation in Korea. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the roles that languages and literacies played in the formation of Korean culture from a socio-historical linguistic perspective.

CourseID: P KRN 315. Introduction to Korean Linguistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys general characteristics of the Korean language and places them in their cultural and historical context. Prereq: KRN 103.

CourseID: P KRN 361. Korean Popular Culture and Transnationalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores contemporary South Korean popular culture in a global frame and key issues in cultural transnationalization.

CourseID: P KRN 362M. Contemporary Korean Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to contemporary South Korean film. Explores changes in film culture, practice, and industry in relation to social changes since the early 1990s. Offered alternate years. Multilisted with CINE 362M.

CourseID: P KRN 403. Thesis. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P KRN 411. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 412, 413. Prereq: KRN 303.

CourseID: P KRN 412. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 411, 413. Prereq: KRN 411.

CourseID: P KRN 413. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 411, 412. Prereq: KRN 412.

CourseID: P KRN 511. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 512, 513.

CourseID: P KRN 512. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 511, 513. Prereq: KRN 511.

CourseID: P KRN 513. Fourth-Year Korean. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of advanced language skills and cultural sensitivity. Sequence with KRN 511, 512. Prereq: KRN 512.

CourseID: P KRN 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 18 credits.

The courses, which must be completed within a standard ten-week term, are open to enrolled and community-education students and to high school students who want accredited university course work.

CourseID: P EC 201 Introduction to Economic Analysis:
Descriptions: P MATH 241 Calculus for Business and Social or MATH Science I 251 or Calculus I MATH 4 112 or sufficient placement test score required for MATH 251; students considering graduate work in economics should take MATH 251 and 252 to enable them to take upper-division mathematics courses

CourseID: P MATH 241 Calculus for Business and Social or MATH Science I 251 or Calculus I MATH 4 112 or sufficient placement test score required for MATH 251; students considering graduate work in economics should take MATH 251 and 252 to enable them to take upper-division mathematics courses
Descriptions: P General-education course in arts and letters
P Econometrics (or equivalent) 1 12 EC 511 4
P Econometrics (or equivalent) 1 12 EC 511 4

CourseID: P EC 101. Contemporary Economic Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines contemporary public policy using economic principles. Topics may include balanced budgets and tax reform, unemployment, health care, poverty and income redistribution, environmental policy, and international trade policy.

CourseID: P EC 201. Introduction to Economic Analysis: Microeconomics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how consumers, firms, and governments make decisions when facing scarce resources and how those decisions affect market outcomes, such as prices and output. MATH 111 recommended.

CourseID: P EC 202. Introduction to Economic Analysis: Macroeconomics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the aggregate activity of a market economy, the problems that arise, such as inflation and unemployment, and how the government can use macroeconomic policy to address these problems. EC 201 recommended.

CourseID: P EC 311. Intermediate Microeconomic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Consumer and firm behavior, market structures. General equilibrium theory, welfare economics, collective choice, rules for evaluating economic policy. Students cannot receive credit for both EC 311 and FIN

CourseID: P EC 313. Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Determination of aggregate income, employment, and unemployment; evaluation of macroeconomic policies. Prereq: EC 202, MATH 111; EC 311 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P EC 320. Introduction to Econometrics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of classical statistical techniques of estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression to economic models. Includes laboratory section in Social Science Instructional Laboratory. Prereq: MATH 242, 243.

CourseID: P EC 327. Introduction to Game Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory course in game theory. Develops game-theoretic methods of rational decision making and equilibriums, using many in-class active games. Ellis. Prereq: one from EC 101, 201.

CourseID: P EC 330. Urban and Regional Economic Problems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include urban and metropolitan growth, land use, race and poverty, education systems, slums and urban renewal, transportation, crime, and pollution and environmental quality. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 333. Resource and Environmental Economic Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic analysis of replenishable and nonreplenishable natural resources; environmental issues and policies. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 340. Issues in Public Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and problems of government financing. Expenditures, revenues, debt, and financial administration. Production by government versus production by the private sector. Tax measures to control externalities. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 350. Labor Market Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include the changing structure of employment, the minimum wage, the dual labor market hypothesis, collective bargaining, discrimination, and health and safety regulation. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 360. Issues in Industrial Organization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include analysis of market power, trends in industrial structure, the role of advertising, pricing policies and inflation, impact of social regulation (e.g., OSHA, EPA), and international comparisons. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 370. Money and Banking. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Operations of commercial banks, the Federal Reserve System, and the Treasury that affect the United States monetary system. Prereq: EC 202.

CourseID: P EC 380. International Economic Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exchange across international boundaries, theory of comparative advantage, balance of payments and adjustments, international financial movements, exchange rates and international financial institutions, trade restrictions and policy. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 390. Problems and Issues in the Developing Economies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include the role of central planning, capital formation, population growth, agriculture, health and education, interaction between economic and cultural change, and the "North-South debate." Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P EC 404. Internship. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P EC 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable only when the topic changes. Yearly offerings vary depending on interests and needs of students and on availability of faculty members.

CourseID: P EC 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable only when the topic changes. Prereq: EC 311; EC 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 411. Advanced Microeconomic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced theory of consumer and firm behavior, market structures. Prereq: one from MATH 253, MATH 263.

CourseID: P EC 413. Advanced Macroeconomic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced theory about the determination of aggregate income, employment, unemployment; evaluation of macroeconomic policies. Prereq: one from MATH 253, MATH 263.

CourseID: P EC 418. Economic Analysis of Community Issues I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hands-on experience applying economic analysis and econometrics to problems that face local community nonprofits and government agencies. Prereq: EC 311, EC 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 419. Economic Analysis of Community Issues II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hands-on experience applying economic analysis and econometrics to problems that face local community nonprofits and government agencies. Prereq: EC 311,320.

CourseID: P EC 421. Introduction to Econometrics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of classical statistical techniques of estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression to economic models. Prereq: one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 422. Economic Forecasting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic techniques of economic forecasting that are typically used in a business environment. Prereq: one from EC 320, EC 423; coreq: one from EC 421, EC 424.

CourseID: P EC 423. Econometrics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory topics in probability theory and statistical inference; regression problems of autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, multicollinearity, and lagged dependent variables; special single-equation estimating techniques; the identification problem in a simultaneous equation setting; development of simultaneous equation estimating procedures. Prereq: MATH 281, 341; MATH 282 and 461 strongly recommended.

CourseID: P EC 424. Econometrics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory topics in probability theory and statistical inference; regression problems of autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, multicollinearity, and lagged dependent variables; special single-equation estimating techniques; the identification problem in a simultaneous equation setting; development of simultaneous equation estimating procedures. Prereq: one from EC 423, EC 523.

CourseID: P EC 425. Econometrics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory topics in probability theory and statistical inference; regression problems of autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, multicollinearity, and lagged dependent variables; special single-equation estimating techniques; the identification problem in a simultaneous equation setting; development of simultaneous equation estimating procedures. Prereq: one from EC 424, EC 524.

CourseID: P EC 427. Games and Decisions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Game-theoretic methods of decision-making. Topics may include extensive-form games, noncredible threats, subgame perfect equilibrium, strategic-form games, undominated strategies, Nash equilibrium, coalitional games, and the core. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 428. Behavioral and Experimental Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates the "rational choice" model and behavioral alternatives, using laboratory experiments. Topics may include altruism, auctions, bargaining, behavioral finance, hyperbolic discounting, and decision-making under uncertainty. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 430. Urban and Regional Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Location theory; urbanization and metropolitan growth; regional analysis; intraurban rent, location and land use, size distribution of urban areas; welfare economics, political economy, and urban problems. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 432. Economy of the Pacific Northwest. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Locational factors influencing development of the region's major industries; recent changes in income and population; problems and governmental policies in the areas of taxation, environment, and planning. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 434. Environmental Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the field that includes theoretical environmental policy, issues in environmental regulation, and empirical techniques used by practitioners. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 435. Natural Resource Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applications of economic theory and empirical methods to natural resources problems: ecosystems and renewable resources (land, water, fisheries, forests); exhaustible resources (energy, minerals). Prereq: EC 311, EC 320.

CourseID: P EC 440. Public Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory of public goods and their optimal provision. Collective choice versus private choice and implications for resource allocation and efficiency. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 441. Public Economics: Taxation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory of taxation, analysis of tax policy, and theory of government debt and budget deficits. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 443. Health Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Includes moral hazard and adverse selection; incentives faced by health care providers through reimbursement, managed care, and malpractice; rationale for government intervention in the health care sector. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 448. Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the economic problems that arise when the government is a self-interested actor in the economy. We study political agency, voting, the economic origins of political institutions and the size and number of nations. Prereq: EC 311, EC 313, EC 320.

CourseID: P EC 450. Labor Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supply and demand for labor, wage determination under various market structures, minimum wage and worker exploitation, human capital investments, labor market signaling and sorting, discrimination, uncertainty, and job matching. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 451. Issues in Labor Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include the determination of wages, employment, and unemployment; globalization and immigration; income inequality; internal labor markets; the role of unions; human capital, education, and schools. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 460. Theories of Industrial Organization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories, quantitative measures, and institutional descriptions of the structure, conduct, and results that characterize American industry. Emphasis is on the determinants and consequences of market power. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 461. Industrial Organization and Public Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major policy instruments that have been developed to cope with social problems created by market power. The two principal instruments are antitrust and income policies. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 462. Economics of Transportation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines economic transportation issues and models, including regulation, demand-cost modeling, productivity analysis, random utility and choice modeling, and spatial economics. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 470. Monetary Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Federal Reserve System strategies and methods of monetary and credit control. Effects of federal policies on prices, output, and employment. Prereq: EC 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 471. Monetary Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Money creation, deficit finance, and taxation in monetary economies. Topics may include the government budget constraint, causes and consequences of inflation, Richardian equivalence, and seigniorage. Prereq: EC 311, 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 480. International Finance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foreign exchange markets, interaction between spot and forward markets, speculation and interest arbitrage, balance-of-payments accounting, measures of deficits and surpluses, "open-economy" macroeconomic issues. Prereq: EC 311, 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 481. International Trade. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories of international trade, direction of trade flows, determination of prices and volumes in international trade, tariffs, quotas, customs unions, free versus restricted trade. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 482. Economics of Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applications of economic theories and empirical methods to globalization issues: market integration of goods and factors, international labor and environmental standards, economic growth and income inequality, financial stability, global governance. Prereq: EC 311, EC 320.

CourseID: P EC 484. Multinational Corporations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economist's perspective of multinational corporations. Explores the policies governments use to influence corporate behavior and patterns of investment; taxation as a tool for implementing public policy. Prereq: EC 311; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 490. Economic Growth and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experience of developed countries and theories of development. Analysis of specific development programs, role of agriculture, sources of investment, techniques and strategies of investment planning. Prereq: EC 311, 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 491. Issues in Economic Growth and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic issues in developing countries, including use of central planning or markets, capital formation, agriculture, population growth, health and education systems, and the "North-South debate." Prereq: EC 311, 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

CourseID: P EC 493. The Evolution of Economic Ideas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic thought from the ancient world to the 20th century. Major schools of economic thought and their relationship to other social ideas of their times. Prereq: EC 311, 313; one from EC 320, EC 423.

Descriptions: P Repeatable only when the topic changes. Yearly offerings vary depending on interests and needs of students and on availability of faculty members.

CourseID: P EC 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

Descriptions: P Federal Reserve System strategies and methods of monetary and credit control. Effects of federal policies on prices, output, and employment.

CourseID: P EC 571. Monetary Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Money creation, deficit finance, and taxation in monetary economies. Topics may include the government budget constraint, causes and consequences of inflation, Richardian equivalence, and seigniorage.

CourseID: P EC 580. International Finance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foreign exchange markets, interaction between spot and forward markets, speculation and interest arbitrage, balance-of-payments accounting, measures of deficits and surpluses, "open-economy" macroeconomic issues.

CourseID: P EC 581. International Trade. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories of international trade, direction of trade flows, determination of prices and volumes in international trade, tariffs, quotas, customs unions, free versus restricted trade.

CourseID: P EC 582. Economics of Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applications of economic theories and empirical methods to globalization issues: market integration of goods and factors, international labor and environmental standards, economic growth and income inequality, financial stability, global governance.

CourseID: P EC 584. Multinational Corporations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economist's perspective of multinational corporations. Explores the policies governments use to influence corporate behavior and patterns of investment; taxation as a tool for implementing public policy.

CourseID: P EC 590. Economic Growth and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experience of developed countries and theories of development. Analysis of specific development programs, role of agriculture, sources of investment, techniques and strategies of investment planning.

CourseID: P EC 591. Issues in Economic Growth and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic issues in developing countries, including use of central planning or markets, capital formation, agriculture, population growth, health and education systems, and the "North-South debate."

CourseID: P EC 593. The Evolution of Economic Ideas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic thought from the ancient world to the 20th century. Major schools of economic thought and their relationship to other social ideas of their times.

CourseID: P EC 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics are Econometrics, Game Theory, Labor Economics, and Public Finance.

CourseID: P EC 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Graduate teaching fellows may earn 3 credits a term; available to other graduate students with department head's consent.

CourseID: P ENG 200
Descriptions: P Public Speaking as a Liberal Art 2

CourseID: P WR 122 College Composition II
Descriptions: P 4 or WR 123 or College Composition III Second term of first-year second-language sequence

CourseID: P ENG 205 Genre: [Topic] Student 4 should have completed the UO writing requirement
Descriptions: P Third term of first-year second-language sequence

Descriptions: P Theory Second term of second-year second-language sequence

CourseID: P ENG 436 Advanced Shakespeare
Descriptions: P General-education course in arts and letters 4 General-education course in science 4 Course on women writers chosen in consultation with

CourseID: P ENG 690 Introduction to Graduate Studies in English
Descriptions: P Select one of the following: Pre-1500 course 1500-1660 course 1660–1800 course

CourseID: P ENG 104. Introduction to Literature: Fiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Works representing the principal literary genres.

CourseID: P ENG 105. Introduction to Literature: Drama. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Works representing the principal literary genres.

CourseID: P ENG 106. Introduction to Literature: Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Works representing the principal literary genres.

CourseID: P ENG 107. World Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading and analysis of selected works in a global survey of ancient literatures, 2500 BCE–1500 CE.

CourseID: P ENG 108. World Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading and analysis of selected works in a global survey of the early modern period to the industrial revolution, 1500 CE–1789 CE.

CourseID: P ENG 109. World Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reading and analysis of selected works in a global survey from the industrial revolution onward, 1789 CE–present.

CourseID: P ENG 110M. Introduction to Film and Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to film and media studies and various methods of critical analysis. Multilisted with CINE 110M.

CourseID: P ENG 200. Public Speaking as a Liberal Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study and practice of public speaking as grounded in the five rhetorical canons of invention, arrangement, style, delivery, and memory. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ENG 205. Genre: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traces the historical development and transformations of key genres for the study of English and American literature and culture, including canonical and popular literary as well as media forms. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: P ENG 207. Shakespeare. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The major plays in chronological order with emphasis on the early and middle plays through "Hamlet."

CourseID: P ENG 208. Shakespeare. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The major plays in chronological order with emphasis on the later plays beginning with "Twelfth Night."

CourseID: P ENG 209. The Craft of the Sentence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of basic sentence mechanics, grammatical terminology, and the conventions of punctuation. Includes some historical background on the development of English grammar. Students cannot receive credit for both ENG 209 and LING 494.

CourseID: P ENG 216. Survey of American Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P American literature from 1850 to the present.

CourseID: P ENG 225. Age of King Arthur. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the literature of the Middle Ages set against the backdrop of medieval culture.

CourseID: P ENG 230. Introduction to Environmental Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to literature that examines the human place in the natural world. Consideration of how writers understand environmental crises and scientific ideas of their generation.

CourseID: P ENG 240. Introduction to Disability Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to central concepts and essential texts in disability studies and applies them to literary and cultural texts, with a focus on racial diversity and learning directly from writers and scholars who experience a wide spectrum of bodymind variabilities.

CourseID: P ENG 241. Introduction to African American Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P African American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts.

CourseID: P ENG 242. Introduction to Asian American Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Asian American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts.

CourseID: P ENG 243. Introduction to Chicano and Latino Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chicano and Latino literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts.

CourseID: P ENG 244. Introduction to Native American Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Native American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts.

CourseID: P ENG 245. Introduction to Ethnic American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P American ethnic literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts. Repeatable once when topic changes for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ENG 250. Literature and Digital Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course will focus on the intersection of digital culture and literary studies. Students will learn how to use digital tools to study literature. Simultnaeously, they will use literary analysis approaches to study contemporary digital culture.

CourseID: P ENG 260M. Media Aesthetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the analysis of form and style in cinema and related media, focusing on narrative, mise-en-scène, cinematography, editing, and sound. Multilisted with CINE 260M.

CourseID: P ENG 280. Introduction to Comic Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the art of comics and the methodologies of comics studies.

CourseID: P ENG 300. Introduction to Literary Criticism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Various techniques and approaches to literary criticism (e.g., historical, feminist, formalist, deconstructionist, Freudian, Marxist, semiotic) and their applications. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 301. Foundations of the English Major: Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chronological study of literary and media works in English, beginnings to the present, emphasizing their cultural and historical contexts. Series with ENG 302, ENG 303. Prereq: ENG 205.

CourseID: P ENG 302. Foundations of the English Major: Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chronological study of literary and media works in English, beginnings to the present, emphasizing disciplinary history and theoretical debates. Series with ENG 301, ENG 303. Prereq: ENG 205.

CourseID: P ENG 303. Foundations of the English Major: Text. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chronological study of literary and media works in English, beginnings to the present, emphasizing analytic reading and writing skills. Series with ENG 301, ENG 303. Prereq: ENG 301 or ENG 302.

CourseID: P ENG 313. Teen and Children's Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Books for young readers, their social implications and historical context, from the 19th century to the present. This is a service learning course, which explores the interplay between the classroom experience and the co-requisite internship volunteering with youth at K-12 schools and nonprofit agencies. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 316. Women Writers' Forms: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Women's writing in a particular genre or form (prose, fiction, drama, poetry, autobiography, folksong) examined in the context of current feminist literary theories. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 321. English Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rise of the novel from Defoe to Austen.

CourseID: P ENG 322. English Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rise of the novel from Scott to Hardy.

CourseID: P ENG 323. English Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rise in the novel from Conrad to the present.

CourseID: P ENG 325. Literature of the Northwest. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of significant Pacific Northwest literature as set against the principles of literary regionalism. Offered alternate years. Prereq: Sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 330. Oral Controversy and Advocacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth study of the habits of research, reasoning, selection, and presentation necessary for ethical and effective oral advocacy on contested topics. Not open to freshmen. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ENG 335. Inventing Arguments. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and use of patterns of reasoning derived from the disciplines of rhetoric, informal logic, cognitive science, and the theory of argumentation. Prereq: WR 122 or WR 123.

CourseID: P ENG 340. Jewish Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Forms and varieties of fiction, poetry, and drama by Jewish writers from the 19th century to the present.

CourseID: P ENG 360. African American Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the origins and development of African American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 361. Native American Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the origins and development of Native American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts. Course will be taught once or more per academic year. Prereq: Sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 362. Asian American Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the origins and development of Asian American literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts. Course will be taught once or more per academic year. Prereq: Sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 363. Chicano and Latino Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the origins and development of Chicano and Latino literature and culture in relevant intellectual, social, and historical contexts. Course will be taught once or more per academic year. Prereq: Sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 364. Comparative Ethnic American Literatures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comparative examination of major issues in African, Asian, Chicano, and Native American literatures and cultures in relevant contexts. Course will be taught once or more per academic year. Prereq: Sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 380. Film, Media, and History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the history of institutions and industries that shape production and reception of film and media.

CourseID: P ENG 381M. Film, Media, and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of film and media as aesthetic objects shaped by a broad range of identity categories, reflecting communities identified by class, gender, race, ethnicity, and sexuality. Multilisted with CINE 381M.

CourseID: P ENG 385. Graphic Narratives and Cultural Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of 20th- and 21st- century graphic novels in the context of cultural theory. Sophomore standing required. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ENG 386. Bodies in Comics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines questions and representations of bodily identity in comics through the lenses of disability studies and gender theory.

CourseID: P ENG 391. American Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the American novel from its beginnings to 1900.

CourseID: P ENG 392. American Novel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the American novel from 1900 to present.

CourseID: P ENG 394. 20th-Century Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern literature from American, British, and European cultures, 1890 to 1945. Significant works of poetry, fiction, drama, and nonfiction in relation to intellectual and historical developments.

CourseID: P ENG 395. 20th-Century Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern literature from American, British, and European cultures, 1945 to present. Significant works of poetry, fiction, drama, and nonfiction in relation to intellectual and historical developments.

CourseID: P ENG 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ENG 401. Research: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 403. Thesis. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P On- or off-campus internship in a variety of writing or literacy-related settings in connection with designated courses. Repeatable. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected seminars offered each year.

CourseID: P ENG 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected topics offered each year. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 412. Literary Editing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of principles and practices of editing contemporary literature. Prepares the student for work in the trade.

CourseID: P ENG 413. Theories of Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Approaches to literacy through literary theory, rhetoric and cultural studies. Examines issues involved with school and community literacy. Pre- or coreq: ENG 404 Internship: Community Literacy; junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 420. The Art of the Sentence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of English grammar and style in literary and academic contexts. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 423. The Age of Beowulf. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A reading of Anglo-Saxon literature and culture as the intersection of Germanic, Celtic, and Christian traditions. Readings include Irish epic, Welsh romance, Norse mythology, and Icelandic saga. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 425. Medieval Romance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of selected romances in the context of European intellectual and social history. May include elementary linguistic introduction to Middle English. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 427. Chaucer. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Close textual study of selected Canterbury Tales in Middle English; instruction in the grammar and pronunciation of Chaucer's language. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 428. Old English I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Old English language. Sequence with ENG 429, 430. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 429. Old English II: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of Old English prose or poetry in the original language. Sequence with ENG 428, 430. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: ENG 428.

CourseID: P ENG 430. Old English III: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of Beowulf or works by other major Old English authors in the original language. Sequence with ENG 428, 429. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: ENG 429

CourseID: P ENG 434. Spenser. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the works of Edmund Spenser. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 436. Advanced Shakespeare. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Detailed study of selected plays, poetry, or both. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 442. Milton. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P "Paradise Lost," "Paradise Regained," and "Samson Agonistes." Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 448. Restoration and 18th-Century Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Johnson and his circle; classic to romantic; relations between England and the Enlightenment in France.

CourseID: P ENG 452. 19th-Century British Fiction: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Close study of selected novels. Repeatable once when topic changes for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ENG 454. English Romantic Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Romantic thought and expression. The first generation including Blake, Coleridge, Dorothy and William Wordsworth. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 455. English Romantic Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Romantic thought and expression. The second generation including Byron, Keats, Mary and Percy Shelley. Junior standing required.

CourseID: P ENG 461. American Literature to 1800. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in American poetry, nonfiction prose, drama, and fiction. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 467. American Literature, 1900-Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in American poetry, nonfiction prose, drama, and fiction. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 469. Literature and the Environment: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth study of various topics related to literature and the environment including Bioart/Bioethics, Biosemiotics, Critical Animal Studies, Food Culture, Ideas of Wilderness, Rhetoric of Nature Writing, Virtual Ecologies. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 470. Technologies and Texts Capstone. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course examines the way humanities disciplines use digital technologies to forge a new role in the public sphere, exploring how digital and print cultures (re)shape forms of cultural expression and knowledge production. Students will create their own digital projects in this course. Prereq: ENG 250 with a grade of C.

CourseID: P ENG 479. Major Authors: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth study of one to three major authors from medieval through modern periods. Repeatable. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 480. Modern American Superhero. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the path of the American comic book superhero and an exploration of the ways in which that journey reflects large processes of social change.

CourseID: P ENG 485. Television Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of television's institutional contents and representational practices, including such television genres as serials, news, and reality TV. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ENG 486M. New Media and Digital Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of emerging media forms and techniques, such as digital cinema, video games, viral videos, and interactive media. Offered alternate years. Repeatable twice for a maximum for 12 credits. Multilisted with CINE 486M.

CourseID: P ENG 488. Race and Representation in Film: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Screening, interpretation, and analysis of films from developing non-European cultures and by people of color. Mechanisms of racism in dominant U.S. media. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 491. Rhetoric and Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigation of historical and contemporary theories of ethical rhetoric in both written and oral arguments. Prereq: WR 122 or 123.

CourseID: P ENG 492. History of Rhetoric and Composition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of rhetoric as related to the theory and practice of writing, relations between rhetoric and poetics, and rhetorical criticism through the 19th century. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 493. Modern Rhetorical Criticism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical topics addressed by 20th-century rhetorical critics. Varieties of rhetorical interpretation, from neo-Aristotelian to reader-response, postmodernist views of metaphor. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ENG 494. Reasoning, Speaking, Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of advanced study in argumentation theory, particularly procedural standards of rationality developed in recent argumentation studies, to selected public policy controversies.

CourseID: P ENG 496. Feminist Film Criticism: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical analysis of film and television texts from a feminist perspective. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: Junior standing.

Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected seminars offered each year.

CourseID: P ENG 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected topics offered each year.

CourseID: P ENG 529. Old English II: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of Old English prose or poetry in the original language. Sequence with ENG 528, 530. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: ENG 4/528.

Descriptions: P Study of Beowulf or works by other major Old English authors in the original language. Sequence with ENG 528, 529. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: ENG 4/529.

Descriptions: P Investigation of historical and contemporary theories of ethical rhetoric in both written and oral arguments. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

Descriptions: P History of rhetoric as related to the theory and practice of writing, relations between rhetoric and poetics, and rhetorical criticism through the 19th century.

Descriptions: P Critical analysis of film and television texts from a feminist perspective. Repeatable when topic changes.

Descriptions: P Repeatable. On- or off-campus internship in a variety of writing or literacy-related settings.
