Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected seminars offered each year.

CourseID: P ENG 609. Terminal Project. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P ENG 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

CourseID: P ENG 611. Composition Graduate Teaching Fellow Seminar I. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Issues in pedagogy related to the university's writing requirement.

CourseID: P ENG 612. Composition Graduate Teaching Fellow Seminar II. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discussions designed to increase the effectiveness of first-year graduate teaching fellows as teachers of courses that fulfill the university's writing requirement.

CourseID: P ENG 613. Graduate Teaching Fellow Composition Apprenticeship. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised practical experience in all aspects of teaching WR 121, 122. Prereq: ENG 611 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ENG 614. Introduction to Literary and Cultural Theory. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a number of the most important and influential developments in 20th-century literary and cultural theory. Graduate seminar.

CourseID: P ENG 615. Advanced Studies in Literary Theory: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of one to three major theorists or a significant theoretical problem. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 620. Medieval Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent offerings include Chaucer's Troilus and Criseyde, Humor and Vulgarity in Medieval Literature. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 630. Renaissance Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent offerings include Hamlet, Jacobean Potboilers, Renaissance Irrationalities. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 645. 18th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of one to three major authors or selected topics from the 18th century. Recent offerings include Enlightenment and Revolution. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 650. 19th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent topics include Scottish Fiction and Cultural Nationalism, Heroine and the English Novel. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 660. American Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent offerings include African American Women Writers, Evolutionary Theories and Narrative, Sentimental Novel, V. Deloria and Native American Cultural Values. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 670. Modern Literature: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent offerings include H. James, Modernist Politics, Environmental Humanities, Postmodernism. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 690. Introduction to Graduate Studies in English. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of selected professional, methodological, and theoretical issues.

CourseID: P ENG 691. Composition Theory: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of topics related to rhetorical theory and the teaching of writing. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENG 695. Film Studies: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of selected topics related to film studies and literature. Recent topics include Introduction to Film Theory; Feminism, Comedy, and the Carnivalesque; Melodrama. Repeatable.

CourseID: P WR 121. College Composition I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Written reasoning as discovery and inquiry. Frequent essays explore relationship of thesis to structure and audience. Strong focus on the process of revising. Regular work on editing. Prereq: SAT Reading and Writing scores both below 37, or SAT verbal score below 710 if taken before March 2016, or ACT verbal score below 32, or equivalent.

CourseID: P WR 122. College Composition II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Written reasoning as a process of argument. Developing and supporting theses in response to complex questions. Attention to critical reading in academic setting. Continuing focus on revising and editing. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P WR 123. College Composition III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Written reasoning in the context of research. Practice in writing documented essays based on the use of sources. Continuing focus on revising and editing. Prereq: WR 121 or equivalent.

CourseID: P WR 195. Writing Tutorial. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides students concurrently enrolled in WR 121 with one-on-one tutoring. Enrollment priority based on entrance exam (SAT or ACT) scores. Repeatable once. Coreq: WR 121.

CourseID: P WR 198. Independent Writing Project. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Supervised writing projects in nonfiction prose. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

CourseID: P WR 312. Principles of Tutoring Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The practice and ethics of tutoring writing in the context of writing in various academic disciplines. Theories of teaching, tutoring techniques, and assessment of writing.

CourseID: P WR 320. Scientific and Technical Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on form, function, and style of scientific, professional, and technical writing; weekly writing assignments include proposals, reports, definitions, instructions, summaries. Use of documentation in publication. Prereq: completion of university writing requirement; junior standing.

CourseID: P WR 321. Business Communications. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practice in writing and analyzing internal and external messages common to business, industry, and professions. Suggested for business and management students. Prereq: completion of university writing requirement; junior standing.

Descriptions: P Emphasis on critical thinking skills and rhetorical strategies for advanced written reasoning in different academic disciplines. Prereq: Completion of University Writing Requirement; junior standing.

Descriptions: P Supervised writing projects in nonfiction prose. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ENVS 201. Introduction to Environmental Studies: Social Sciences. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contributions of the social sciences to analysis of environmental problems. Topics include human population, the relationship between social institutions and environmental problems, and appropriate political, policy, and economic processes.

CourseID: P ENVS 202. Introduction to Environmental Studies: Natural Sciences. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contributions of the natural sciences to analysis of environmental problems. Topics include biological processes, ecological principles, chemical cycling, ecosystem characteristics, and natural system vulnerability and recovery.

CourseID: P ENVS 203. Introduction to Environmental Studies: Humanities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contributions of the humanities and arts to understandings of the environment. Emphasis on diverse ways of thinking, writing, creating, and engaging in environmental discourse.

CourseID: P ENVS 225. Introduction to Food Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An exploration of the field of "food studies" and examination of the role of food in historical and contemporary life in the US and around the world.

CourseID: P ENVS 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P ENVS 335. Allocating Scarce Environmental Resources. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ENVS 335. Allocating Scarce Environmental Resources. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Considerations for the design of environmental and natural resources policies and regulations: balancing society's preferences and the costs of environmental protection and resource conservation. Prereq: MATH 105 or higher.

CourseID: P ENVS 345. Environmental Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Key concepts and various moral views surveyed; includes anthropocentrism, individualism, ecocentrism, deep ecology, and ecofeminism. Exploration includes case studies and theory.

CourseID: P ENVS 350. Ecological Footprint of Energy Generation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Detailed study of the ecological consequences of all forms of energy generation including fossil fuels and alternative energy sources. Open to environmental science, environmental studies, and planning, public policy and management majors only. Prereq: ENVS 201, MATH 112.

CourseID: P ENVS 375. Oregon Seminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students broaden and deepen their understanding of the materials presented in three linked courses: BI 372 Field Biology, GEOL 308 Geology of Oregon and the Pacific Northwest, and HIST 473 American Environmental History: [Topic]. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior or senior standing.

CourseID: P ENVS 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: Instructor's approval.

CourseID: P ENVS 411. Environmental Issues: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In depth examination of a particular environmental topic such as global warming, ecosystem restoration, energy alternatives, geothermal development, public lands management, or environmental literature. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: junior or senior standing.

CourseID: P ENVS 425. Environmental Education Theory and Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Learning theories, environmental literacy, and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of environmental education programs. Development of teaching materials in collaboration with a community partner for group project. Prereq: instructor's approval.

CourseID: P ENVS 427. Environmental and Ecological Monitoring. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory, design, and practice of monitoring sampling mapping, field techniques, data collection, management, analysis and presentation methods, local case studies.

CourseID: P ENVS 429. Environmental Leadership: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Partnering with governmental agencies, nonprofit organizations, public schools and local businesses, students develop service learning projects. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: instructor's approval.

CourseID: P ENVS 435. Environmental Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Environmental justice and its impact on current decisions. Focus on civil rights law, perception of risk, and relation of sustainability and equity. Prereq: ENVS 201.

CourseID: P ENVS 450. Political Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how social relations and economic, social, and cultural control of natural resources shape human interactions with the environment. Theory and case studies. Prereq: ENVS 201.

CourseID: P ENVS 455. Sustainability. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the evolution of the concept of sustainability and its complex and sometimes problematic uses among scholars, policymakers, environmentalists, and businesses. Pre- or coreq: ENVS 201; junior or senior standing.

CourseID: P ENVS 465. Wetland Ecology and Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines management, law, and policies related to wetlands in an ecological framework; includes wetland type definitions, classification, distribution, formation and development, and restoration. Prereq: BI 307 or BI 370 or GEOG 360.

CourseID: P ENVS 467. Sustainable Agriculture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines sustainability issues in agricultural production and current food systems. Focuses on environmental aspects of seed, water, soil, energy, and pest management. Prereq: ENVS 201 or 202.

CourseID: P ENVS 477. Soil Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chemical and physical characteristics and classification of soils, field soil identification, soil degradation. Prereq: CH 111 or 221 or 224H.

CourseID: P ENVS 493M. Passive Cooling. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conceptual and quantitative investigations of passive cooling design and performance, including precedents, shading, natural ventilation, evaporative cooling, use of thermal mass, radiant cooling assisted by cold night skies, and control scheduling, supported by field investigations and introductory energy modeling. Multilisted with ARCH 493M. Prereq: ARCH 491.

CourseID: P ENVS 494M. Passive Heating. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conceptual and quantitative investigations of passive solar heating design and performance, including precedents, solar resource evaluation, glazing selection and orientation, thermal mass materials and positioning, movable insulation, and control scheduling, supported by solar site surveys and modeling in EnergyPlus. Multilisted with ARCH 494M. Prereq: ARCH 491.

CourseID: P ENVS 511. Environmental Issues: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth examination of a particular environmental topic such as global warming, ecosystem restoration, energy alternatives, geothermal development, public lands management, or environmental literature. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P ENVS 525. Environmental Education Theory and Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Learning theories, environmental literacy, and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of environmental education programs. Development of teaching materials in collaboration with a community partner for group project.

CourseID: P ENVS 535. Environmental Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Environmental justice and its impact on current decisions. Focus on civil rights law, perception of risk, and relation of sustainability and equity.

CourseID: P ENVS 550. Political Ecology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how social relations and economic, social, and cultural control of natural resources shape human interactions with the environment. Theory and case studies.

CourseID: P ENVS 555. Sustainability. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the evolution of the concept of sustainability and its complex and sometimes problematic uses among scholars, policymakers, environmentalists, and businesses.

CourseID: P ENVS 565. Wetland Ecology and Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines management, law, and policies related to wetlands in an ecological framework; includes wetland type definitions, classification, distribution, formation and development, and restoration.

CourseID: P ENVS 567. Sustainable Agriculture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines sustainability issues in agricultural production and current food systems. Focuses on environmental aspects of seed, water, soil, energy, and pest management.

CourseID: P ENVS 577. Soil Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chemical and physical characteristics and classification of soils, field soil identification, soil degradation.

CourseID: P ENVS 593M. Passive Cooling. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conceptual and quantitative investigations of passive cooling design and performance, including precedents, shading, natural ventilation, evaporative cooling, use of thermal mass, radiant cooling assisted by cold night skies, and control scheduling, supported by field investigations and introductory energy modeling. Multilisted with ARCH 593M. Prereq: ARCH 591.

CourseID: P ENVS 594M. Passive Heating. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conceptual and quantitative investigations of passive solar heating design and performance, including precedents, solar resource evaluation, glazing selection and orientation, thermal mass materials and positioning, movable insulation, and control scheduling, supported by solar site surveys and modeling in EnergyPlus. Multilisted with ARCH 594M. Prereq: ARCH 591.

CourseID: P ENVS 604. Internship: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P ENVS 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Interdisciplinary Capstone Project.

CourseID: P ENVS 631. Environmental Studies Theory and Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to various disciplinary perspectives that contribute to environmental studies, including their research methods, vocabularies, and core concepts.

CourseID: P ENVS 632. Environmental Studies Research Methodology. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Identifying a clear and concise research problem, developing methodology to address that problem, and the process of developing a thorough knowledge of relevant literature.

CourseID: P ENVS 633. Environmental Studies Thesis Development. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interdisciplinary readings in environmental studies focused on topics chosen by each student in consultation with instructor. Preparation for presentations at the Joint Campus Conference.

CourseID: P ES 100. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P ES 101. Introduction to Ethnic Studies. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ES 101. Introduction to Ethnic Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Multidisciplinary study focuses on Americans of African, Asian, Latino, and Native American descent. Topics include group identity, language in society and culture, forms of resistance, migration, and social oppression.

CourseID: P ES 196. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: approval of program administrators.

CourseID: P ES 224M. Introduction to Anthropology of the African Diaspora. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theoretical questions and methodological concerns framing an anthropology of the African Diaspora. Multilisted with ANTH 224M.

CourseID: P ES 250. Introduction to African American Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on historical, cultural, and social issues in African America and surveys scholarship in African American studies.

CourseID: P ES 252. Introduction to Asian American Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on historical, cultural, and social issues in Asian America and surveys scholarship in Asian American studies.

CourseID: P ES 254. Introduction to Chicano and Latino Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on historical, social, and cultural issues in Chicano and Latino communities and surveys scholarship in Chicano and Latino studies.

CourseID: P ES 256. Introduction to Native American Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on historical, social, and cultural issues in Native America and surveys scholarship in Native American studies.

CourseID: P ES 258. Introduction to Pacific Islander Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on historical, social, and cultural issues in Pacific Islander communities and surveys scholarship in Pacific Island Studies.

CourseID: P ES 301. Theoretical Perspectives in Ethnic Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to contemporary theoretical frameworks in the discipline of ethnic studies. Offered fall term only. Prereq: ES 101; one from ES 250, 252, 254, or 256.

CourseID: P ES 310. Race and Popular Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the interface between race and popular culture, surveying the historical development, political significance, and social influence ofpopular culture in the United States. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 20 credits when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ES 330. Women of Color: Issues and Concerns. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contemporary social issues and feminism among women of color in the United States. Prereq: ES 101 recommended.

CourseID: P ES 345M. Music, Politics, and Race. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines a variety of musical forms and their relationship to histories of racial and social justice, inequality, and political movements. Offered alternate years. Multilisted with MUS 345M.

CourseID: P ES 350. Native Americans and the Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical issues in Native American environmentalism.

CourseID: P ES 352. Social Equity and Criminal Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical issues related to police, prisons, criminal justice, and racial and gender inequalities.

CourseID: P ES 354. Environmental Racism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores environmental justice as both a field of scholarship and organizing framework that links power, justice, and inequality to environmental issues. Special attention is given to the specific forms of racism which produce environmental injustice.

CourseID: P ES 356. Race and Social Movements. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical significance of self-asserted racial distinctions and explores the ideological diversity of ethno-racial identities produced in tandem with 20th century U.S. social justice movements.

CourseID: P ES 370. Race, Ethnicity, and Cinema: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the history and politics of race, ethnicity, and indigenousness in relation to film, including questions of production, distribution, and reception in the United States. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 20 credits when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ES 380. Race, Migration, and Rights. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines historical and contemporary politics in race, immigration, and migration.

CourseID: P ES 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent topics include Caribbean Migrations; Asian American Women; Critical Whiteness Studies; Native Americans and Film; Asian Diasporas; Race and Resistance in United States History.

CourseID: P ES 401. Research: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: majors or minors only.

Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: majors or minors only.

CourseID: P ES 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: majors or minors only.

CourseID: P ES 440. Race, Literature, and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines race, literature, and culture from an interdisciplinary perspective. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 20 credits when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ES 442. Caribbean Literature and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discusses how Caribbean diaspora literature employs themes of colonialism, sexuality, racism, migration, state violence, nationalism, and identity.

CourseID: P ES 450. Race and Incarceration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces several key questions necessary for understanding the crisis of prisons and incarceration in the United States, with an emphasis on race, gender, and class.

CourseID: P ES 452. Race and Ethnicity and the Law: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses issues of social justice and the participation of Asian Americans, African Americans, Chicanos and Latinos, and Native Americans in the legal system. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P ES 456. History of Native American Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical conflict between traditional culture and knowledge transmission among Native Americans and the assimilationist educational system and practices of Euro-American culture. Offered alternative years.

CourseID: P ES 460. Race, Culture, Empire: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how racial discourses have informed United States domestic and foreign policy, with special attention on cultural representations of

CourseID: P ES 498. Interdisciplinary Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares majors for independent research in ethnic studies. Examines interdisciplinary methods for research on race and ethnicity. Offered winter term only. Prereq: completion of required courses for ethnic studies major, except ES 499; majors or minors only.

CourseID: P ES 499. Ethnic Studies Proseminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Capstone seminar. Focuses on concluding work and experience in ethnic studies through independent research, preparation and presentation of research paper. Offered spring term only. Prereq: ES 498; majors only.

CourseID: P ES 540. Race, Literature, and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines race, literature, and culture from an interdisciplinary perspective. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 20 credtis when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ES 542. Caribbean Literature and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discusses how Caribbean diaspora literature employs themes of colonialism, sexuality, racism, migration, state violence, nationalism, and identity.

CourseID: P ES 550. Race and Incarceration. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ES 614. Colloquium: Professional Development. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Professional development, teaching skills, and mentorship for first year Ethnic Studies PhD students. Repeatable twice for a total of three credits.

CourseID: P ES 615. Theoretical Foundations in Ethnic Studies. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the theoretical foundations and debates in Ethnic Studies scholarship.

CourseID: P ES 616. Interdisciplinary Research Methods in Ethnic Studies. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to interdisciplinary methodologies in the various fields of ethnic studies, with an eye towards developing interdisciplinary competence and students applying it to their own work.

CourseID: P ES 617. Genealogies of Ethnic Studies. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the emergence and evolution of the discipline of Ethnic Studies, including major intellectual shifts in the field, particularly as they relate to changes in the social science and humanities; and the state of the discipline today.

CourseID: P ES 620. Race, Space, and Power: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course questions the variety of ways that social constructions of race and space are inextricable from one another and constitute, as much as they are constituted by, modern power relations. Repeatable once for a maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P ES 621. Cultural Production: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Graduate introduction to the theories and methods utilized within Cultural Studies scholarship with attention to race, gender, nation, sexuality and indigeneity. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P ES 622. Resistance and Dissent: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys historical and contemporary methods people of color have used to subvert and challenge white power and privilege in the United States. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P EURO 415. European Union History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, institutions, and policy landmarks of European integration since the end of World War II. Introduction to documents and research on history of European communities.

CourseID: P EURO 515. European Union History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, institutions, and policy landmarks of European integration since the end of World War II. Introduction to documents and research on history of European communities.

CourseID: P FLR 225. Voices of Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Novels, music, dance, dress, paintings, films, and cartoons serve as a primary sources from which to learn about the diversity and vivacity of contemporary African peoples.

CourseID: P FLR 235. Folklore and the Supernatural. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the study of beliefs about the supernatural by examining diverse approaches to the description and analysis of belief traditions and religious culture.

CourseID: P FLR 236. Magic in the Middle Ages. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how medieval culture defined magic and how the exploration of magic led to the beginnings of science. Analyzes the practices of medieval western Europe, particularly Britain.

CourseID: P FLR 245. Folklore and the Pacific Northwest. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A survey exploring cultural expression of customary, verbal, and material folklore found in the Pacific Northwest, with a consideration of ethnic and geographical variation.

CourseID: P FLR 250. Introduction to Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The process and genres of traditional (i.e., folk) patterning; the relations between these forms of expression and other arts, especially English and American literature.

CourseID: P FLR 255. Folklore and United States Popular Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the relationship between folklore and popular culture, with special emphasis on the analysis of legends, myths, icons, stereotypes, heroes, celebrities, rituals, and celebrations.

CourseID: P FLR 320. Car Cultures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines car customizing and tuning as forms of vernacular art; studies the environmental impacts of automobiles, the history of the industry, and the peculiarities of drivers' behavior. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P FLR 350. Folklore and the Bible. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies readings of the Judeo-Christian Bible in connection with mythological and traditional contexts and meanings from ancient times to the present. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P FLR 365. Folklore Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Archival and library research skills augmented with fieldwork skills including observation, participation, documentation, interviewing, transcription, and presentation of findings.

CourseID: P FLR 370. Folklore and Sexuality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersections of folklore and sexuality as entry points for discussing social issues of sexual and gender identity, intolerance, and resistance. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P FLR 411. Folklore and Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the role of folklore in people's religious lives with particular emphasis on narrative, beliefs, rituals, celebrations, pilgrimage, and ecstatic states.

CourseID: P FLR 413. Folk Art and Material Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the research by folklorists on contemporary folk art, material culture, and the aesthetic impulse in everyday life.

CourseID: P FLR 414. Mythology and Modern Fantasy Fiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the folklore and literary sources that inspired writers such as

CourseID: P FLR 415. Folklore and Foodways. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines food traditions from a folkloristic perspective, looking at issues such as identity, performance, community, creativity, and innovation. Prereq: junior standing. Offered every second or third year.

CourseID: P FLR 416. African Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines folklore forms across the African continent to analyze themes of history, identity, aesthetics, gender, class, politics, and globalization. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P FLR 418. Folklore and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersections of folklore and gender and the resulting issues of creativity, social dynamics, feminism, identity politics, and negotiations of power. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P FLR 450. Folklore in the Public Sector. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates the history of the field of public folklore as well as training students in contemporary practices including fieldwork methods, grant writing, and project development.

CourseID: P FLR 483. Folklore and Mythology of the British Isles. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic folk traditions in the British Isles (e.g., ballads, folktales, legends, myths) and their treatment in the written literature of major British authors.

CourseID: P FLR 485. Film and Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The developmental use of film by folklorists. Folklore genres, theories, and fieldwork methods as related to filmmakers' techniques. Analysis includes documentary and ethnodocumentary films.

CourseID: P FLR 491. Anglo-American Ballad and Folk Song. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of popular ballads in the Anglo-American tradition--styles, origins, forms, content, and dissemination. History and influence of popular media.

CourseID: P FLR 511. Folklore and Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the role of folklore in people's religious lives with particular emphasis on narrative, beliefs, rituals, celebrations, pilgrimage, and ecstatic states.

CourseID: P FLR 513. Folk Art and Material Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the research by folklorists on contemporary folk art, material culture, and the aesthetic impulse in everyday life.

CourseID: P FLR 514. Mythology and Modern Fantasy Fiction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the folklore and literary sources that inspired writers such as

CourseID: P FLR 515. Folklore and Foodways. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines food traditions from a folkloristic perspective, looking at issues such as identity, performance, community, creativity, and innovation. Prereq: junior standing. Offered every second or third year.

CourseID: P FLR 516. African Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines folklore forms across the African continent to analyze themes of history, identity, aesthetics, gender, class, politics, and globalization.

CourseID: P FLR 518. Folklore and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersections of folklore and gender and the resulting issues of creativity, social dynamics, feminism, identity politics, and negotiations of power. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P FLR 550. Folklore in the Public Sector. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates the history of the field of public folklore as well as training students in contemporary practices including fieldwork methods, grant writing, and project development.

CourseID: P FLR 583. Folklore and Mythology of the British Isles. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic folk traditions in the British Isles (e.g., ballads, folktales, legends, myths) and their treatment in the written literature of major British authors.

CourseID: P FLR 585. Film and Folklore. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The developmental use of film by folklorists. Folklore genres, theories, and fieldwork methods as related to filmmakers' techniques. Analysis includes documentary and ethnodocumentary films.

CourseID: P FLR 591. Anglo-American Ballad and Folk Song. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of popular ballads in the Anglo-American tradition--styles, origins, forms, content, and dissemination. History and influence of popular media.

CourseID: P FLR 681. History and Theory of Folklore Research. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines nature of scholarly inquiry, research questions, and techniques. Historic orientation with emphasis on ideological development of folkloristics from its beginnings to the present.

CourseID: P FLR 684. Folklore Fieldwork Seminar. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students conceptualize and execute a fieldwork project while developing practical skills in proposal writing, observation, interviewing, analysis, documentation, and presentation.

CourseID: P GEOG 141. The Natural Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The earth's physical landscapes, vegetation patterns, weather, and climate; emphasis on the dynamic interactions among climate, landforms, vegetation, and soils.

CourseID: P GEOG 142. Human Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The spatial organization of humans and their activities on Earth’s surface. Cultural, political, and economic influences shaping places and their interconnections.

CourseID: P GEOG 181. Our Digital Earth. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploring the emergence of geospatial data and technologies that are pervasive in our everyday lives and how they are shaping society.

CourseID: P GEOG 201. World Regional Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the world's cultural regions. Study of the cultural and environmental factors that make different parts of the world distinct.

CourseID: P GEOG 202. Geography of Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical and cultural processes that have shaped the rural and urban landscapes of Europe.

CourseID: P GEOG 204. Geography of Russia and Neighbors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Natural regions, major population groups, and the economic development of the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

CourseID: P GEOG 205. Geography of Pacific Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical, cultural, and economic processes that have shaped the rural and urban landscapes of Pacific Asia.

CourseID: P GEOG 208. Geography of the United States and Canada. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical and geographical analysis of the physical and human geography of the U.S. and Canada. Topics include physical regions, settlement patterns, economic development, and urbanization. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P GEOG 209. Geography of the Middle East and North Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical and cultural processes that have shaped the rural and urban landscapes of the Middle East and North Africa.

CourseID: P GEOG 214. Geography of Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical, cultural, and economic processes that have shaped the rural and urban character of Latin America.

CourseID: P GEOG 281. The World and Big Data. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores technical foundations and social and economic applications of big data along the “5V” dimensions of volume, variety, velocity, veracity, and visualization.

CourseID: P GEOG 285. Mapping With Drones. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding and applying the technologies, theories, and skills needed to acquire and convert drone photography into mapping applications.

CourseID: P GEOG 321. Climatology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Energy and moisture in the atmosphere, atmospheric circulation, controls of regional and microclimates, applied climatology, climatic variations, past and future climates. Prereq: GEOG 141.

CourseID: P GEOG 322. Geomorphology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Landforming processes with emphasis on mass movements, rivers, eolian, glacial, and coastal processes. Special fee. Prereq: GEOG 141 or GEOL 102 or 202.

CourseID: P GEOG 323. Biogeography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relation of plants and animals to the environment, distribution of individual species, historical changes in plant distribution. Prereq: one from GEOG 141, GEOL 103, 203, BI 370.

CourseID: P GEOG 341. Population and Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Patterns of population growth over history and place, current policies and programs, and impacts and trends in United States and international contexts. Includes method and theory.

CourseID: P GEOG 342. Geography of Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical and geographical dimensions of globalization; emphasizes economic and social factors. Topics include multinationals, trade agreements, sustainability, global inequalities, and racial and gender divisions of labor.

CourseID: P GEOG 343. Society, Culture, and Place. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines ways in which geographical context reflects and shapes cultural and social processes. Importance of place and territory in human affairs.

CourseID: P GEOG 360. Watershed Science and Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical and biological processes of watersheds; problems of land use, water quality, riparian zones, aquatic ecology; scientific basis of watershed management and policy. Special fee. Prereq: GEOG 141, or GEOL 102 or 202, or BI 130 or 213.

CourseID: P GEOG 361. Global Environmental Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Natural and human-induced environmental changes and their impact on different environmental systems. Not available to those who have taken GEOG 143. Prereq: GEOG 141.

CourseID: P GEOG 391. Social Science Inquiry and Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding scientific inquiry, the scientific method and learning to critique social science research. Readings and discussion focus on the questions, methods, conclusions and outcomes of research.

CourseID: P GEOG 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are listed in the class schedule each term.

CourseID: P GEOG 419. Professional Geographer. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the geographical perspective on world cultures and global issues, and prepares students how to articulate a spatial perspective and effectively communicate geographic training and skills to broader audiences.

CourseID: P GEOG 421. Advanced Climatology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in climatology, including physical climatology, dynamic and synoptic climatology, and paleoclimatology. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: GEOG 321.

CourseID: P GEOG 423. Advanced Biogeography: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics in biogeography including relation of plants and animals to their environment, historical changes in plant distribution, and palynological analysis. Special fee. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: GEOG 323.

CourseID: P GEOG 425. Hydrology and Water Resources. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on surface water including precipitation, evapotranspiration, surface runoff, and stream flow. Understanding and analysis of processes. Management for water supply and quality. Special fee. Prereq: GEOG 321 or 322; MATH 111.

CourseID: P GEOG 427. Fluvial Geomorphology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hydraulics and hydrology of stream channels; channel morphology and processes; drainage network development; fluvial deposits and landforms; field and analytical methods. Required field trips. Special fee. Prereq: MATH 112; one from GEOG 322, GEOG 425, GEOL 334.

CourseID: P GEOG 430. Long-Term Environmental Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of the physical landscape during the Quaternary period. Elements of paleoclimatology, paleoecology, and geomorphology. Required field trips. Special fee. Prereq: GEOG 321, 322, or 323.

CourseID: P GEOG 433. Fire and Natural Disturbances. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Wildfire and other landscape disturbance processes, historical and current patterns of fire, use and management of fire. Offered alternate years. Prereq: BI 307 or GEOG 323 or BI 370.

CourseID: P GEOG 441. Political Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Spatial perspectives on global political patterns and processes. Relationship of political territories to resources, ethnic patterns, and ideological communities. Impact of political arrangements on landscapes. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 442. Urban Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Urbanization throughout the world, the structure of urban settlements; cities as regional centers, physical places, and homes for people; geographic problems in major urban environments. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 444. Cultural Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Patterns of culture as a force in human affairs. Dynamics of identity, place, and power. The creation of culture at different scales.

CourseID: P GEOG 445. Culture, Ethnicity, and Nationalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship of ethnic groups and nationality to landscapes, perception, and cultural geographic phenomena. Distribution of ethnic and national groups. Junior standing required.

CourseID: P GEOG 448. Tourism and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tourism-related concepts and practices associated with tourism planning, development, marketing, and impacts in different geographic contexts.

CourseID: P GEOG 461. Environmental Alteration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Human alterations of the earth's major ecosystems. Consequences of human activity at different times and places with respect to soils, atmosphere, vegetation, landforms, and water. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 463. Geography, Law, and the Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Values underlying American legal approaches to environmental issues; the role of laws in reflecting and shaping human understanding and use of the environment. Special fee. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 465. Environment and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical analysis of development concepts. Economic activity and environmental impacts. Sustainable development. Development projects and landscapes in the industrializing world. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 467. International Water Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines problems in water policy and governance in a global context. Draws on interdisciplinary perspectives, compares case studies, and analyzes institutions.

CourseID: P GEOG 468. Contemporary Food Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores contemporary food systems at local, national, and global scales. Emphasis on the political economy and sociocultural dynamics linking agriculture, food industries, and consumption.

CourseID: P GEOG 471. North American Historical Landscapes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the origin and evolution of cultural landscapes in North America through historical and contemporary sources, and draws upon the local region for student projects. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P GEOG 475. Advanced Geography of Non-European-American Regions: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Examination of the settlement patterns, regional economies, political organization, and character of the landscapes of selected major regions of the non-European and American world. Repeatable when region changes.

CourseID: P GEOG 481. GIScience I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geographic information science, geographic information systems (GIS), the current population survey (CPS), remote sensing, and cartography. Sequence with GEOG 482/582, 491/591.

CourseID: P GEOG 482. GIScience II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Spatial data collection, spatial data models, database design, data editing, geographic information system (GIS) project management, and advanced topics in geographic information science. Sequence with GEOG 481/581, 491/591, 493/593. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 485. Remote Sensing I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to remote sensing science including its physical basis, instruments, platforms, data, processing methods, and applications. Sequence with GEOG 486/586. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 486. Remote Sensing II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The use of digital electromagnetic data for classification, mapping, and monitoring biologic, hydrologic, atmospheric, geologic, and human processes and environmental change. Sequence with GEOG 485/585. Prereq: GEOG 485.

CourseID: P GEOG 490. GIScience: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Advanced topics on geographic information systems science including spatial analysis and modeling, data visualization, cartography, volunteered geographic information, GIS programming. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: GEOG 481 or GEOG 311.

CourseID: P GEOG 491. Advanced Geographic Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Automated processing of geospatial data using Python scripting language. Programming for spatial analysis such as 3-D and network modeling; processing of big data (satellite imagery, climate data, demographic information). Sequence with GEOG 481/581, 482/582. Prereq: GEOG 482.

CourseID: P GEOG 493. Advanced Cartography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Map design and production methods; use of color, cartographic visualization, graphing, data graphics theory, and integration of geographic information systems (GIS) and graphics tools. Sequence with GEOG 481/581, 482/582. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 494. Spatial Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to a variety of spatial analysis techniques that can be used for understanding and modeling geographic phenomena. Series. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 495. Geographic Data Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and display of geographical data by traditional data-analytical methods and by scientific-visualization approaches. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 496. Location-Aware Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores technical fundamentals of location-aware systems, such as location models and location-based services, as well as challenges such as user privacy. Prereq: GEOG 281.

CourseID: P GEOG 497. Qualitative Methods in Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores conceptual and practical dimensions of qualitative research. Includes linking theory and method; research question formulation; project design; ethics; data gathering, analysis, and presentation. Prereq: GEOG 341, 342, or 343.

CourseID: P GEOG 498. Geospatial Project Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to methods for designing and implementing professional projects involving geospatial data, technologies, and analytical methods. Prereq: GEOG 481.

CourseID: P GEOG 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are listed in the class schedule each term.

Descriptions: P Topics in climatology, including physical climatology, dynamic and synoptic climatology, and paleoclimatology. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GEOG 597. Qualitative Methods in Geography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores conceptual and practical dimensions of qualitative research. Includes linking theory and method; research question formulation; project design; ethics; data gathering, analysis, and presentation.

CourseID: P GEOG 598. Geospatial Project Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to methods for designing and implementing professional projects involving geospatial data, technologies, and analytical methods.

CourseID: P GEOG 611. Theory and Practice of Geography I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to professional practice in geography and the development of geographic concepts and theories from Ancient times through the mid-twentieth century. Sequence with GEOG 612, 613.

CourseID: P GEOG 612. Theory and Practice of Geography II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The development of geographic concepts and theories from the mid-20th century to the present. Students learn to refine effective geographic research questions. Sequence with GEOG 611 and 613. Prereq: GEOG 611.

CourseID: P GEOG 613. Research Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines main components of research design, including research questions, methodological approach, institutional review boards, funding programs, proposal writing, and application. Sequence with GEOG 611 and 612. Prereq: GEOG 612.

CourseID: P GEOG 631. Progress in Physical Geography. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Recent developments in climatology, geomorphology, hydrology, and biogeography. Lectures, readings, and presentation of faculty and student works in progress. Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P GEOG 632. Progress in Human Geography. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Recent developments in cultural, economic, environmental and political geography. Lectures, readings, and presentation of faculty and student works in progress. Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P GEOG 633. Progress in Geographic Information Science. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Recent developments in cartography, GIS, remote sensing, data analysis, and visualization. Lectures, readings, and presentation of faculty and student works in progress. Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P GER 101. First-Year German. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a thorough grammatical foundation and an elementary reading knowledge of German as well as an understanding of the spoken language. Sequence.

CourseID: P GER 102. First-Year German. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a thorough grammatical foundation and an elementary reading knowledge of German as well as an understanding of the spoken language. Prereq: GER 101 or GER 104.

CourseID: P GER 103. First-Year German. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a thorough grammatical foundation and an elementary reading knowledge of German as well as an understanding of the spoken language. Prereq: GER 102.

CourseID: P GER 201. Second-Year German. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Grammar and composition, reading selections from representative authors, conversation. Sequence. Prereq: GER 103 or 105 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GER 202. Second-Year German. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Grammar and composition, reading selections from representative authors, conversation. Prereq: GER 201 or GER 204.

CourseID: P GER 203. Second-Year German. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Grammar and composition, reading selections from representative authors, conversation. Prereq: GER 202.

CourseID: P GER 206. Law in Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to German literature and key concepts of Germany's legal tradition with a focus on the connection between legal codes and their representations in fiction.

CourseID: P GER 220M. From Kierkegaard to Kafka. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the existential tradition in German and Scandinavian literature, philosophy, drama, and film. Historical and conceptual developments are considered, from Kierkegaard to Kafka. Taught in English. Multilisted with SCAN 220M.

CourseID: P GER 221. Postwar Germany: Nation Divided. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to literary and cultural movements of public dissent, including 1960s student revolutions, in postwar Germany. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P GER 222. Voices of Dissent in Germany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Key debates in German culture, including the adequate representation of the Holocaust, literature in society, and the roles of ethnic and gender identities within the nation. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P GER 223. Germany: A Multicultural Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the multiethnic complexities of German, Austrian, and/or Swiss societies through the writings of African, Turkish, or Jewish Germans. Period of focus varies. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P GER 250. The Culture of Money. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores ideas about money, value, and exchange in German-speaking cultures from selected moments in modern history through readings of literature, philosophy, and the arts. Series with GER 251, GER 252.

CourseID: P GER 251. Sexuality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines discourses on sexuality (e.g., sexual norms, gender roles, and divergences from them) in modern German, Austrian, and Swiss-German contexts through literature, essays, and films. Series with GER 250, GER

CourseID: P GER 252. War, Violence, Trauma. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines works of literature, thought, art, music, and film on subjects of war, violence, and trauma in German and Austrian cultural history during one or more selected postmedieval epochs. Series with GER 250, GER

CourseID: P GER 311. Intermediate Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extensive practice in speaking and writing German; complex grammatical structures in writing. Prereq: GER 203, GER 205, or equivalent.

CourseID: P GER 312. Intermediate Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extensive practice in speaking and writing German; complex grammatical structures in writing. Prereq: GER 203, GER 205, or equivalent.

CourseID: P GER 313. Intermediate Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extensive practice in speaking and writing German; complex grammatical structures in writing. Option during 313 to take the Zertifikat Deutsch exam. Prereq: GER 312.

CourseID: P GER 317. Study in Germany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive grammar review in preparation for German exchange programs and upper-division German courses. Introduces contemporary ideas about German culture, history, architecture through journals and magazines. Pre- or coreq: GER 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P GER 340. Introduction to German Culture and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Writings by such figures as Kant, Marx, Freud, and Weber. The emergence of Germany as a cultural and political entity explored through literature, film, and art. Readings, discussion, and written assignments in German. Offered alternate years. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 341. Introduction to German Culture and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Writings by such figures as Kant, Marx, Freud, and Weber. The German crisis of modernization.Readings, discussion, and written assignments in German. Offered alternate years. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 350. Genres in German Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies on such genres in German literature as Novelle, 20th-century drama, political poetry. No knowledge of German required; readings and discussions in English.

CourseID: P GER 351. Diversity in Germany. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the social construction of identity in German literature and culture. Addresses topics of plural voices and tolerance in German-speaking cultures. Topics vary. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P GER 352. Authors in German Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative works by writers such as Lessing, Schiller, Hoffmann, Brentano, Droste-Hulshoff, Kafka, Fleisser, Brecht, and Nietzsche. No knowledge of German required; readings and discussions in English.

CourseID: P GER 354. German Gender Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Student oral presentations and written papers on such topics as men and women writers of German romanticism, mothers and daughters in German literature, comparison of men and women dramatists. No knowledge of German required; readings and discussions in English.

CourseID: P GER 355. German Cinema: History, Theory, Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth analysis of various facets of German cinema. Topics include film and the Third Reich, cinema and technology, German filmmakers in American exile, German New Wave. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P GER 356. German Fairy Tales. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The German fairy tale in historical and theoretical context, from the Brothers Grimm and romantic tales to adaptations by Tchaikovsky and Sendak. Taught in English.

CourseID: P GER 357. Nature, Culture, and the Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the contributions German writers, philosophers, scientists, and artists have made to changing notions of nature and its supposed opposition toculture. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P GER 360. Introduction to German Literature: Poetry, Plays, Prose. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to textual analysis--poetry, plays, and prose from 1800 to the present--in the context of major literary movements (romanticism, realism, modernism) and their social determinants. Focus on genre: poetry, plays, and prose. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 361. Introduction to German Literature: Literary Movements. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to textual analysis--poetry, plays, and prose from 1800 to the present--in the context of major literary movements (romanticism, realism, modernism) and their social determinants. Focus on literary movements. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 362. Introduction to German Literature: Interpretive Models. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to textual analysis--poetry, plays, and prose from 1800 to the present--in the context of major literary movements (romanticism, realism, modernism) and their social determinants. Focus on interpretive models. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 366. Themes in German Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Significant literary texts organized by theme--crime and society, travels and explorations, nature and technology, relationships between the sexes, the Nazi past. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 367. Themes in German Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Significant literary texts organized by theme--crime and society, travels and explorations, nature and technology, relationships between the sexes, the Nazi past. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 368. Themes in German Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Significant literary texts organized by theme--crime and society, travels and explorations, nature and technology, relationships between the sexes, the Nazi past. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P New topics or approaches appropriate for third-year German proficiency level. Content varies; focus may be on various aspects of German language, literature, or culture and civilization. Repeatable when topic changes. Coreq: GER 311.

CourseID: P GER 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Experimental Poetry.

CourseID: P GER 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics are Doppelganger and Nietzsche.

CourseID: P GER 411. Advanced Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Constant practice in speaking and writing with emphasis on complex syntactic structures as well as idiomatic nuances in German. Grammar. Prereq: GER 311, 312, 313.

CourseID: P GER 412. Advanced Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Constant practice in speaking and writing with emphasis on complex syntactic structures as well as idiomatic nuances in German. Writing. Prereq: GER 311, 312, 313.

CourseID: P GER 413. Advanced Language Training. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Constant practice in speaking and writing with emphasis on complex syntactic structures as well as idiomatic nuances in German. Speaking. Prereq: GER 311, 312, 313.

CourseID: P GER 425. Play Performance: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extensive practice in effective oral communication with emphasis on correct pronunciation. Reading of the play and scene rehearsals in class; public performance at end of term. Repeatable. Prereq: GER 203, GER 205, or equivalent.

CourseID: P GER 440. German Culture and Society: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural and sociopolitical aspects of Germany. Typical topics are the cultural history of the German forest, gender and terrorism, women and German film, peace movements. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: one upper-division course GER literature or culture.

CourseID: P GER 460. German Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative writers (e.g., Lessing, Heine, Kafka, Brecht, Bachmann, or Wolf) or pervasive themes (e.g., peace movements, art and illusion, family and society, history and literature, the political imagination). Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: one upper-division course GER literature or culture.

CourseID: P GER 470. German for Reading Knowledge I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the reading of German, introducing most of the major grammatical categories and providing substantial basic and advanced vocabulary training. Students translate passages in their chosen fields. Sequence with GER 471.

CourseID: P GER 471. German for Reading Knowledge II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Completes the overview of German grammar, reviews selected grammatical points, expands knowledge of vocabulary, and enhances capacity to read and translate. Sequence with GER 470. Prereq: GER 470.

CourseID: P GER 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Experimental Poetry.

CourseID: P GER 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics are Doppelganger and Nietzsche.

CourseID: P GER 540. German Culture and Society: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural and sociopolitical aspects of Germany. Typical topics are the cultural history of the German forest, gender and terrorism, women and German film, peace movements. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 560. German Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative writers (e.g., Lessing, Heine, Kafka, Brecht, Bachmann, or Wolf) or pervasive themes (e.g., peace movements, art and illusion, family and society, history and literature, the political imagination). Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: one upper-division course GER literature or culture.

CourseID: P GER 570. German for Reading Knowledge I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the reading of German, introducing most of the major grammatical categories and providing substantial basic and advanced vocabulary training. Students translate passages in their chosen fields. Sequence with GER 571.

CourseID: P GER 571. German for Reading Knowledge II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Completes the overview of German grammar, reviews selected grammatical points, expands knowledge of vocabulary, and enhances capacity to read and translate. Sequence with GER 570. Prereq: GER 570.

CourseID: P GER 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Weimar Modernisms.

CourseID: P GER 621. Narrative. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and theory of narrative texts. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 622. Drama. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and theory of dramatic texts. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 623. Lyric. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and theory of lyric texts. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 624. Critical and Philosophical Prose. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines important aspects of German philosophy. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 625. Translations-Transformations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents the theory and practice of translation and other transformation media (e.g., the sister arts, literature into film). Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P GER 690. Literary Studies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research methods, literary theory, history of German literature, and advanced methodology. Typical topics include contemporary theory, major German critics, literature and nonliterary forms. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P SCAN 220M. From Kierkegaard to Kafka. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the existential tradition in German and Scandinavian literature, philosophy, drama, and film. Historical and conceptual developments are considered, from Kierkegaard to Kafka. Taught in English. Multilisted with GER 220M.

CourseID: P SCAN 251. Text and Interpretation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to textual analysis; explores the relationship between experience, description, and identity through the reading and viewing of Scandinavian literature and film. Taught in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 259. Vikings through the Icelandic Sagas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the social, political, and cultural expressions of Viking society through the Sagas, the unique prose narratives of medieval Iceland. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 315. Nordic Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines cinematic culture in the Nordic countries of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden. Includes works by Ingmar Bergman and the Danish group Dogma 95. Taught in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 316. History of Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A survey of Nordic cinema from the silent era to the present. Films will be viewed and analyzed within their aesthetic and historical contexts. Taught in English. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SCAN 317. Directors, Movements, and Manifestos. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A directed study of specific directors, movements, and manifestos from the Nordic cinematic tradition. Taught in English. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SCAN 325. Constructions versus Constrictions of Identity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the notion of regional, ethnic, gender, and class identity in Scandinavian texts and culture. Topics include immigrant-emigrant experience, lore of the Arctic, folklore, Finland-Swedish writing. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 341. Revisions of the Scandinavian Dream. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines development of Scandinavian countries from impoverished kingdoms on the European periphery to modern, multicultural welfare societies. Analyzes patterns in the arts, social and political structures, ecological issues. Taught in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 343. Norse Mythology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical evaluation of the religious beliefs in Scandinavia from prehistory through the Viking Age. Taught in English. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SCAN 344. Medieval Hero and Monster. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of medieval Scandinavian and Germanic literature addressing the remarkably fine line drawn between the heroes and monsters depicted. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SCAN 351. Periods in Scandinavian Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Possible topics are modern breakthrough and modernism in Scandinavian literature. Student discussion, oral presentations, and written papers. Readings and discussions in English.

CourseID: P SCAN 353. Scandinavian Women Writers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines social issues, especially gender, in literature written by women from Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden. Primary emphasis on 19th- and 20th-century texts.

CourseID: P SCAN 354. Genres in Scandinavian Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent topics include short narrative fiction and Scandinavian drama. Student discussion, oral presentations, and written papers. Readings and discussions in English.

CourseID: P SWED 101. First-Year Swedish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thorough grammatical foundation in idiomatic Swedish with emphasis on both reading and speaking. Sequence.

CourseID: P SWED 102. First-Year Swedish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thorough grammatical foundation in idiomatic Swedish with emphasis on both reading and speaking. Prereq: SWED 101.

CourseID: P SWED 103. First-Year Swedish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thorough grammatical foundation in idiomatic Swedish with emphasis on both reading and speaking. Prereq: SWED 102.

CourseID: P SWED 201. Second-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of grammar; composition, conversation. Readings from contemporary texts in Swedish. Sequence. Prereq: SWED 103.

CourseID: P SWED 202. Second-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of grammar; composition, conversation. Readings from contemporary texts in Swedish. Prereq: SWED 201.

CourseID: P SWED 203. Second-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of grammar; composition, conversation. Readings from contemporary texts in Swedish. Prereq: SWED 202.

CourseID: P SWED 301. Third-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of Sweden, reading of modern Swedish texts, spoken and written practice. Sequence. Prereq: SWED 203.

CourseID: P SWED 302. Third-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of Sweden, reading of modern Swedish texts, spoken and written practice. Prereq: SWED 301.

CourseID: P SWED 303. Third-Year Swedish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of Sweden, reading of modern Swedish texts, spoken and written practice. Prereq: SWED 302.
