CourseID: P HIST 101. Western Civilization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of the Western world; major changes in value systems, ideas, social structures, economic institutions, and forms of political life. Ancient and medieval societies.

CourseID: P HIST 102. Western Civilization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of the Western world; major changes in value systems, ideas, social structures, economic institutions, and forms of political life. From the Renaissance to Napoleon.

CourseID: P HIST 103. Western Civilization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of the Western world; major changes in value systems, ideas, social structures, economic institutions, and forms of political life. From Napoleon to the present.

CourseID: P HIST 104. World History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of world cultures and civilizations and their actions. Includes study of missionary religions, imperialism, economic and social relations. Ancient societies.

CourseID: P HIST 105. World History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of world cultures and civilizations and their actions. Includes study of missionary religions, imperialism, economic and social relations. Early modern.

CourseID: P HIST 106. World History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of world cultures and civilizations and their actions. Includes study of missionary religions, imperialism, economic and social relations. Modern.

CourseID: P HIST 121. Women in World History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the history of women and gender. A comparative survey of women from prehistory to the present.

CourseID: P HIST 186. Cultures of India. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the historical study of culture in the Indian subcontinent.

CourseID: P HIST 190. Foundations of East Asian Civilizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to traditional China and Japan; Confucianism, Buddhism, Daoism; floating worlds; family and gender; traditional views of the body; literati class; samurai; Mongols and Manchus.

CourseID: P HIST 191. China, Past and Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Chinese culture. Explores meanings of past and present in 20th-century efforts to modernize China. Chronological and topical inquiry into politics, literature, social structure, gender, art, economy.

CourseID: P HIST 192. Japan, Past and Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Japanese culture. Explores myth, tradition, modernity, and postmodernity with one eye trained on the future. Examples from personal experience.

CourseID: P HIST 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Problem-oriented course designed for students interested in history who might or might not become majors. Repeatable.

CourseID: P HIST 201. Inventing America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the North American continent socially, economically, politically, culturally. Native America, European colonization, colonial development, origins of slavery, Revolution, early Republic.

CourseID: P HIST 202. Building the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creation and development of the United States and its social, economical, political, and cultural consequences. Jacksonian era, expansion, commercial and industrial revolution, slavery, Civil War, Reconstruction.

CourseID: P HIST 203. American Century. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creation and development of the so-called "American Century" socially, economically, politically, culturally. Imperialism, progressivism, modernity, the 1920s, Depression and New Deal, world wars and Cold War, 1960s, and recent developments.

CourseID: P HIST 205. Ancient Sports. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of sports and athletics in ancient societies: examines intersections of class, social status, race, gender, and sexuality. Includes study of organizational, political, religious, and ideological dimensions.

CourseID: P HIST 211. Reacting to the Past. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Centers on complex, exciting role-playing simulations of decisive historical events and the development of key analytical skills in close readings of classic texts.

CourseID: P HIST 215. Food in World History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the development of eating practices, tastes, foodstuffs, and culinary philosophies from early human history to the present in diverse parts of the world.

CourseID: P HIST 221. Sex in History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the history of sexuality. Comparative overview of sexual politics, ethics, and identities in diverse societies from the ancient world to the present.

CourseID: P HIST 239. Classical and Medieval Warfare. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines war and armies in the ancient Mediterranean and in medieval Europe. Series with HIST 240, HIST 241.

CourseID: P HIST 240. War in the Modern World I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of the conduct of war in the 19th and 20th centuries as a reflection of social, political, and technological developments.

CourseID: P HIST 241. War in the Modern World II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys changes in the nature and conduct of warfare in light of social, political, and technological developments from 1945 to present.

CourseID: P HIST 245. Russia, America, and the World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The United States and Russia share historical experiences that extend far beyond diplomacy, trade, and international adversity or alliance. Includes frontier expansion, revolution, industrialization, imperialism, world view.

CourseID: P HIST 248. Latinos in the Americas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores historical experiences of Latino groups, emphasizing Mexican and Caribbean migrations. Lectures in English; readings and discussions in English, Spanish, and Spanglish. Two years of high school Spanish or SPAN 103 with a grade of C or better recommended.

CourseID: P HIST 250. African American History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The African background, development of slavery, abolitionism, the Civil War and Reconstruction.

CourseID: P HIST 251. African American History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The 20th-century African American experience including the great migration, World War II, the Civil Rights Movement, post-1970 African America.

CourseID: P HIST 273. Introduction to Environmental History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to concepts, concerns, and methods of environmental history.

CourseID: P HIST 286. Cities in India and South Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course examines the economic, cultural and social dimensions of cities in the subcontinent of India with comparisons from other Asian and North American cities.

CourseID: P HIST 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P HIST 301. Modern Europe. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HIST 301. Modern Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, cultural, intellectual, and economic trends from the 18th century to the present. 18th century. McCole.

CourseID: P HIST 302. Modern Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, cultural, intellectual, and economic trends in the 19th century.

CourseID: P HIST 303. Modern Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, cultural, intellectual, and economic trends in the 20th century.

CourseID: P HIST 308. History of Women in the United States I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the diverse experiences of American women from 1600 to 1870.

CourseID: P HIST 309. History of Women in the United States II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the diverse experiences of American women from 1870 to present.

CourseID: P HIST 319. Early Middle Ages in Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emergence, from the remains of the late Roman Empire, of a uniquely medieval Christian culture in the Germanic kingdoms of northern Europe between the 4th and 9th centuries.

CourseID: P HIST 320. High Middle Ages in Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changes that swept Europe from 1000 to 1225, including the rise of towns and universities, new spiritual and artistic visions, and varieties of religious and social reform.

CourseID: P HIST 321. Late Middle Ages in Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A survey of Europe, 1250-1430, the age of Dante and the Black Death, when breakthroughs alternated with disasters in the realms of politics, economics, and religion.

CourseID: P HIST 322. The Crusades. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the idea and practice of Christian holy war—not only in Palestine, but within Europe. From the First Crusade in 1096 through early 13th Century.

CourseID: P HIST 325. Precolonial Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of African history to the mid-19th century, analyzing processes of state formation, regional and long-distance trade, religion, oral tradition, and systems of slavery.

CourseID: P HIST 326. Colonial and Postcolonial Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of African history from the late 1800s to the turn of the 21st century. Emphasis is on the internal dynamics of change as well as the effects of colonialism and global interaction.

CourseID: P HIST 332. British History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P British history from the Celts to the 21st century—economic, political, religious, and social change. McGowen. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 336. France. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ancient regime, 1789–1870—French Revolutions of 1789, 1830, and 1848; Napoleonic Empire; monarchy, republicanism, and dictatorship; society and culture in post-Revolutionary France. Birn, Sheridan.

CourseID: P HIST 337. France. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P 1870 to the present—the Paris Commune and Third Republic; the Dreyfus affair; popular front, fall of France and Resistance; Algeria, de Gaulle, the 1968 student movement.

CourseID: P HIST 340. US Military History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of US military history from the colonial period to the present with a focus on the organization, operations, and strategy of the US Army in wartime.

CourseID: P HIST 342. German History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Middle Ages to the end of the 20th century. I: Middle Ages and Reformation (1410–1648). II: Germany in the Old Regime and Age of Revolution (1648–1848). III: Modern Germany (1848–present). Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 345. Early Russia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Kievan Rus and Byzantium; Christianization; Mongol dominance; rise of Moscow and two Ivans, one Great, one Terrible; crisis of modernization and subsequent religious dissent.

CourseID: P HIST 346. Imperial Russia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Siberian and North American expansion; Peter the Great; Catherine the Great; abolition of serfdom; industrialization; Silver Age culture and revolution; World War I and collapse.

CourseID: P HIST 347. Soviet Union and Contemporary Russia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the rise, development, and collapse of the Soviet Union, the world's first communist regime. Topics include the Russian Revolution, Stalinism, war, culture, and society.

CourseID: P HIST 350. American Radicalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Motives, strategies, successes, and failures of radical movements and their significance for American society. American Revolution, slave revolts, abolitionism, women's rights.

CourseID: P HIST 351. American Radicalism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Motives, strategies, successes, and failures of radical movements and their significance for American society. Workers' movements, socialism, communism, African American freedom struggle, nationalist movements of people of color, feminism, student activism.

CourseID: P HIST 352. The United States in the 1960s. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of a watershed era: civil rights, student activism, educational crisis, Vietnam War, gender revolution, environmentalism.

CourseID: P HIST 361. Early Modern Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the subject, practive, and social place of science in the early modern world.

CourseID: P HIST 363. American Business History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P American businesses from their colonial origins to the present. Interaction between the political, social, economic, and ideological environment and the internal structure and activities of business enterprises.

CourseID: P HIST 368. American West in Popular Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the idea of the West in the American imagination as expressed in popular literature, captivity narratives, dime novels, travel literature, art, Wild West shows, films, and television.

CourseID: P HIST 378. American Environmental History to 1890. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Considers how humans and their natural environments have interacted and reshaped each other through time from 1491 to 1890.

CourseID: P HIST 379. American Environmental History, 1890-Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on environmental change and the rise of environmental politics from the Progressive Era to the present.

CourseID: P HIST 380. Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major economic, political, and cultural trends and continuities. Pre-Columbian and Iberian history, the colonial period up to 1750. Prereq: Sophomore standing recommended.

CourseID: P HIST 381. Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major economic, political, and cultural trends and continuities. Transition from late colonial mercantilism to political independence and national definition, 1750–1910. Prereq: Sophomore standing recommended.

CourseID: P HIST 382. Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major economic, political, and cultural trends and continuities. Reform and revolution in modern Latin American history, 1910 to the present. Prereq: sophomore standing recommended.

CourseID: P HIST 383. Soccer and Society in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploring the complexities of Latin American societies using soccer as a historical, cultural, and sociological window to issues of race, class, gender, and national identity.

CourseID: P HIST 385. South Asia: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to South Asian history in the modern period—South Asia I (1757–1971); South Asia II (1930 to the present). Repeatable once when topic changes for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 386. India. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course will survey the history of the Indian subcontinent as both a colony of Britain and then as a cluster of independent countries in the 20th and 21st centuries.

CourseID: P HIST 387. Early China. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey from the beginnings to the 10th century focuses on the development of Chinese thought and religion and the growth of the imperial state and bureaucracy.

CourseID: P HIST 388. Vietnam War and the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Vietnamese society and history: the First Indochina War, origins and escalation of United States involvement in Vietnam; de-escalation and defeat.

CourseID: P HIST 396. Samurai in Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the image of Japan's warrior class, the most prominent social group in Japan for over seven centuries. Combines films, readings, and lectures.

CourseID: P HIST 404. Internship. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent topics include History of Los Angeles, Modern Japanese Culture, Rethinking America in the 1960s, and Stalinism. Repeatable.

CourseID: P HIST 408. Colloquium: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Current topics include Southeast Asia Interpretations. Repeatable.

CourseID: P HIST 409. Supervised Tutoring. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable four times for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 411. Advanced Reacting to the Past: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive exploration of historical events through interactive games. Possible topics include U.S. Constitutional Convention, French Revolution, Democracy in Athens, India 1947. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: P HIST 412. Ancient Greece: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, cultural, and intellectual history of ancient Greece; emphasis on urban culture. I: Classical Greece. II: Hellenistic World. III: Greek Science. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 414. Ancient Rome: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, cultural, and intellectual history of ancient Rome from its foundation to late antiquity; emphasis on urban culture. I: Roman Republic. II: Roman Empire. III: Roman Society. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 415. Advanced World History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced intensive study of selected issues in world history. Possible topics include biology and ecology, ancient empires, or intercultural encounters. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P HIST 416. Advanced Women's History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of select issues in women's history. Emphasis on the construction of their diverse identities; the framework for political, social, and economic empowerment; the historical development of gendered categories. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HIST 417. Society and Culture in Modern Africa: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explorations in various topics with attention to class, gender, and generational and political struggles. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 419. African Regional Histories: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historiography of specific nations or regions. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 420. The Idea of Europe. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The concept and experience of Europe explored creatively throughout history from multiple disciplinary perspectives.

CourseID: P HIST 425. Economic History of Modern Europe: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Industrial revolution, economic transformation, growth, and integration in political and social contexts. Focuses on Britain, France, Germany, and Russia. I: European Economies to 1914. II: European Economies in the 20th Century. Repeatable once when topic changes for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 427. Intellectual History of Modern Europe: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major thinkers and movements include classical liberalism, utopian socialism, political economy, Marxism, aestheticism, Nietzsche, classical sociology, psychoanalysis, radical conservatism, Keynesian economics, intellectuals and political engagement, and Western Marxism. I: German Intellectual History. II: Ideas and Society, 19th Century. III: Ideas and Society, 20th Century. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 428. Europe in the 20th Century: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P War, revolution, social change, political transformation, and related intellectual and cultural developments in Europe from the Great War of 1914–18 through the present. I: European Fascism. II: Jews in Modern Europe. III: Eastern Europe since World War I. IV: Europe since 1945. Repeatable when chronological or thematic topic changes.

CourseID: P HIST 436. Medieval Central Europe: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics in the political, cultural, religious and economic history of Germany and neighboring peoples during the Middle Ages, from the eighth through 13th centuries. Repeatable when topic changes. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HIST 437. Medieval Spain. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A study of two related aspects of medieval Iberian history: Spain as a frontier society and Spain as a multicultural, multireligious society.

CourseID: P HIST 441. 16th-Century European Reformations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of religious, personal, and institutional reforms. Includes late medieval reform movements and the ideas of Erasmus, Luther, Calvin, Ignatius Loyola, and Teresa of Avila.

CourseID: P HIST 442. Early Modern German History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include peasant society, the foundations of absolutism, the German Enlightenment, protoindustrialization. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 443. Modern Germany: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include class formation, revolutionary movements, the socialist tradition, the Third Reich. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P HIST 444. The Holocaust. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys history of Nazi genocide, focusing on terror and complicity in formation of racial policy; and on perceptions of Nazi anti-Semitism as the Holocaust was occurring.

CourseID: P HIST 446. Modern Russia: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores topics such as the intellectual and cultural history of Russia from the revolution to recent times. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 449. Race and Ethnicity in the American West. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the growth of communities of color in western cities of the United States, with particular reference to competition and cooperation between groups.

CourseID: P HIST 450. The Iraq War. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A history of the Iraq War including the US decision to invade, the subsequent civil war, the rise and fall of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS), and beyond.

CourseID: P HIST 451. American Foreign Relations: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chronological and thematic topics in American foreign relations. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P HIST 455. Colonial American History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Native Americans; motives, methods, implications of European colonization; origins of American slavery; interaction of diverse peoples in shaping colonial North American societies, economies, landscapes, politics.

CourseID: P HIST 456. Revolutionary America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origins, consequences, meanings of American Revolution; changing social, economic, and political contexts; intellectual, religious, and ideological trends; Constitution; institutional, social, and cultural legacy.

CourseID: P HIST 457. 19th-Century United States: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, economic, and cultural history. I: Jacksonian Era. II: Civil War. III: Reconstruction. IV: Gilded Age. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 461. American Medical History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores nine major subjects in the social history of medicine and health in the United States. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HIST 463. American Economic History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Varying topics on the economic development of the United States as a preindustrial, industrial, and postindustrial society. I: The Great Depression. II: Industrialization. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 466. The American West. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social, political, and cultural history. Peoples of the American West and the expansion of the United States in the 19th century.

CourseID: P HIST 467. The American West. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social, political, and cultural history. 20th-century immigration, urban growth, economic development; social and political institutions; politics of race, ethnicity, and gender in a multicultural region.

CourseID: P HIST 468. The Pacific Northwest. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Regional history to the mid-20th century. How the Pacific Northwest mirrors the national experience and how the region has a distinctive history and culture.

CourseID: P HIST 469. American Indian History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Variable chronological, thematic, and regional topics, including Indian history to 1860; 1860 to the present; Indians and colonialism; Indians and environments; Indians and gender; regional histories. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 470. African American History to 1877: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HIST 471. African American History since 1877: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth exploration of specific topics in African American history from the late 19th century to the present. Repeatable twice when the topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits. Series with HIST 470.

CourseID: P HIST 473. American Environmental History: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Variable topics examine the social, cultural, economic, and political history of the American landscape; how Americans have understood, transformed, degraded, conserved, and preserved their environments.

CourseID: P HIST 480. Mexico. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mexican history from pre-Hispanic times to the present. Special attention to nationhood, economic development, church-state relations, the Mexican identity, and the Revolution of 1910.

CourseID: P HIST 482. Aztecs and Incas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Impact of Iberian conquest and settlement on the lives of the indigenous peoples of the Caribbean, Mexico, Central America, and South America.

CourseID: P HIST 483. Latin America: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HIST 487. China: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

Foundations and transformations of state and society; popular rebellions; impact of imperialism; issues of modernity; state building; political, cultural, and social revolutions. I: Song and Yuan. II: Ming and Qing. III: Late Qing. IV: Republican China. V: China since 1949. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits.

CourseID: P HIST 490. Japan: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Political, social, and cultural history from ancient through contemporary. Origins, aristocratic society, medieval age, Zen, warrior class, urban growth, modernization, imperialism, Pacific war, postwar society.

CourseID: P HIST 491. Medicine and Society in Premodern Japan. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HIST 611. Field Readings. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Independent study designed to ground students in major works and issues of their chosen field. Intensive study, based on a substantial reading list, requiring substantial written work.

CourseID: P HIST 612. Historical Methods and Writings. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the historical profession; includes historical questions, methods, and theories, and historiographic debates. Sequence.

CourseID: P HIST 615. Professional Development. 1 Credit.

Descriptions: P Designed to build on work from HIST 612 and 615 courses. Promotes understanding of history profession, standards, protocols; plan and host conference. Offeredonce per academic year.

Descriptions: P Independent readings with faculty members to discuss a predetermined reading list in preparation for PhD comprehensive examination.

CourseID: P HIST 619. Dissertation Prospectus. 5 Credits.

CourseID: P HUM 101. Introduction to the Humanities I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ideas and modes of vision Western culture has inherited from the classical period. Readings and discussions focus on literature, philosophy, history, the arts, and religion.

CourseID: P HUM 102. Introduction to the Humanities II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ideas and modes of vision Western culture has inherited from the medieval to the Renaissance periods. Readings and discussions focus on literature, philosophy, history, the arts, and religion.

Descriptions: P An interdisciplinary introduction to the global humanities in the modern period.

CourseID: P HUM 240. Medical Humanities. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HUM 245. Food, Art, and Literature. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HUM 355. The American City. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P HPHY 103. Exercise and Performance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Structure and function of the human body including movement analysis. Topics include training and exercise responses; sport, daily living, and workplace performance; and injury adaptations.

CourseID: P HPHY 105. Principles of Nutrition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the fundamentals of nutrition and its application to culture, lifestyle, and health as they relate to humans across the lifespan. Course will be taught once or more per academic year.

CourseID: P HPHY 111. The Science of Sex. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The anatomy and physiology of sex, with assignments and discussion designed to develop scientific literacy.

CourseID: P HPHY 112. The Science of Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines and assesses current health claims and controversies.

CourseID: P HPHY 211. Medical Terminology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explore and develop skills in language and terminology specific to the medical sciences with an emphasis on derivation, meaning, and pronunciation.

CourseID: P HPHY 212. Evidence, Inference, and Biostatistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how data is used as evidence in research and inferred from experiments, and how statistics are used to inform us about human physiology.

CourseID: P HPHY 321. Human Anatomy I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the human body and histology; nerves; central, autonomic, and peripheral nervous systems; cranial nerves; regional anatomy of the head; special senses. Includes cadaver laboratory. Sequence with HPHY 322, 323, 324, 325. Prereq: HPHY 211; BI 211 or BI 281H; BI 212 or BI 282H; CH 221 or CH 224H; CH 222 or CH 225H; CH 223 or CH 226H; MATH 246 or MATH

CourseID: P HPHY 322. Human Physiology I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Neuro- and muscular physiology: action potentials; synapses and receptors; skeletal muscle; central, peripheral, and autonomic nervous systems; special senses. Includes human-based laboratory. Sequence with HPHY 321, 323, 324, 325. Prereq: HPHY 212; BI 211 or BI 281H; BI 212 or BI 282H; CH 221 or CH 224H; CH 222 or CH 225H; CH 223 or CH 226H; MATH 246 or MATH

CourseID: P HPHY 323. Human Anatomy II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Heart, lungs, and vasculature in addition to regional exploration of the musculosketetal system. Includes cadaver laboratory. Sequence with HPHY 321, 322, 324, 325. Prereq: HPHY 321. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 324. Human Physiology II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cardiovascular system; respiratory system; immunology. Includes human-based laboratory. Sequence with HPHY 321, 322, 323, 325. Prereq: HPHY 212, HPHY 321, HPHY 322. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 325. Human Anatomy and Physiology III. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy and physiology of the digestive, reproductive, and renal systems; endocrinology. Includes combination of cadaver laboratory and human-based laboratory. Sequence with HPHY 321, 322, 323, 324. Prereq: HPHY 323, HPHY 324. Must be passed with a grade of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 333. Motor Control. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the processes of control and coordination in the performance of motor skills. Neurophysiological, mechanical, and cognitive bases of motor skill acquisition. Prereq: HPHY 321, HPHY 322; or PSY 304. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 337. Clinical Pharmacology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion), pharmacodynamics, therapeutic considerations and adverse effects of select prototypes from within major clinically relevant drug families. Prereq: HPHY 325. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 362. Tissue Injury and Repair. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of the physiology of injury and trauma. Emphasis on inflammation and healing of connective tissue injury, tissue biomechanics, mechanisms of injury, and clinical orthopedic evaluation techniques. Prereq: HPHY 323, HPHY 324. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 371. Physiology of Exercise. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiology of exercise, physical conditioning, and training; mechanisms and significance of these effects for health and performance. Prereq: HPHY 323, HPHY 324. Must be passed with a grade of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 375. Metabolism and Nutrition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of cellular, tissue, and whole body integrated metabolic processes as the basis of physiologic function. Integrating the metabolism of macronutrients at the cellular, tissue, and whole body systems level in the context of human growth, function, and disease. Prereq: HPHY 325, HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 381. Biomechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of physics applied to the analysis of human movement. Emphasis on developing abilities to analyze human movement quantitatively. Prereq: HPHY 323, PHYS 201. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: HPHY 325 or HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 403. Thesis. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P For honors students during the terms in which they conduct research or write a thesis.

CourseID: P HPHY 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Field experience in an agency, institution, or business. Practice knowledge from courses: planning, organizing, directing, evaluating, and developing professional competence.

CourseID: P HPHY 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Reading and assignments in connection with other courses for extra credit. Honors readings.

CourseID: P HPHY 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are offered regularly in such areas as health sciences, motor control, biomechanics, and physiology.

CourseID: P HPHY 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Assist students learning anatomy or physiology in either the lecture or lab courses.

CourseID: P HPHY 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: HPHY 325 or HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 411. Scientific Teaching. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P For students currently completing the Advanced Placement core sequence; focuses on how people learn, evidence-based teaching practices, and strategies to improve student inclusion and representation.

CourseID: P HPHY 412. Sleep Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of sleep and how physiology is affected by sleep. Prereq: HPHY 325 with a C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 413. Muscle Structure, Function, and Plasticity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiologic basis for skeletal muscle adaptation to increased and decreased use and injury. Emphasizes how structure dictates function relevant to rehabilitation. Prereq: HPHY 323, HPHY 324. Must be passed with a grade of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 414. Muscle Metabolism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Metabolic basis for skeletal muscle adaptation to increased and decreased use, and injury models. Emphasizes interorgan communication; uses clinical models. Prereq: HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 420. Human Anatomy Dissection. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dissection of one region of a preserved donated human cadaver and preparation of the specimen for the HPHY 321/HPHY 323/HPHY 325 laboratory experience. Students are accepted by application, which are due early February. Prereq: HPHY 323. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 422. Physiology of Obesity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores potential causes of the obesity epidemic, cellular mechanisms linking obesity to insulin resistance and metabolic diseases, and interventions in treatment of metabolic disease and obesity. Prereq: HPHY 325, HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 423. Physiology of Aging. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines changes that occur to cells and organs in old age and the causes of age-related disease and dysfunction (cardiovascular disease, diabetes, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s); interventions to increase longevity. Prereq: HPHY 325 with a C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 433. Neurophysiology of Concussion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigate diagnosis, deficits, and treatment of mild traumatic brain injury and neurophysiological effects. Prereq: HPHY 325, HPHY 333. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 434. Movement Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discusses the clinical manifestations and underlying physiological mechanisms of selected movement disorders. Emphasizes the role of scientific experiment in diagnosis and treatment. Prereq: HPHY 325, HPHY 333. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 435. Physiology of Fatigue. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates neuromuscular function and fatigue and how the underlying physiology can contribute to fatigability discrepancies with respect to extraneous and pathophysiological factors. Prereq: HPHY 325, HPHY 333. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 444. Clinical Anatomy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Through case-based learning, students have the opportunity to apply the knowledge of anatomy and physiology in the context of clinical practice and diagnosis. Prereq: HPHY 325. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 462. Therapeutic Techniques. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Clinical application of therapeutic techniques including modalities and rehabilitation for soft-tissue orthopedic injuries. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 362. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 470. Environmental Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of physiological adaptations to acute and chronic exposure to extreme heat, cold, and high altitude. Prereq: HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 472. Science of Athletic Performance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical basis and practical application of modern physiological testing of cardiovascular and respiratory function with a focus on exercise and performance. Prereq: HPHY 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 473. High Altitude Physiology and Medicine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major physiologic responses to high altitude (hypoxia), both adaptive and maladaptive, from systems to molecular level, as well as pathophysiologic conditions at high altitude. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 325 and 371. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 480. Technology Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a foundation in principles of intellectual property and technology transfer, critical to technology development in clinical and sport industries. Prereq: HPHY 371, HPHY 381. Prereq: HPHY 323, HPHY 324. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 486. Orthopedic Biomechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of musculoskeletal biomechanics relating to concepts in surgical and nonsurgical orthopedics. Course is beneficial to those pursuing careers in medicine and health sciences. Prereq: HPHY 381. Must be passed with grades of C or better.

CourseID: P HPHY 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are offered regularly in such areas as health sciences, motor control, biomechanics, and physiology.

CourseID: P HPHY 512. Sleep Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of sleep and how physiology is affected by sleep.

CourseID: P HPHY 513. Muscle Structure, Function, and Plasticity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiologic basis for skeletal muscle adaptation to increased and decreased use and injury. Emphasizes how structure dictates function relevant to rehabilitation.

CourseID: P HPHY 514. Muscle Metabolism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Metabolic basis for skeletal muscle adaptation to increased and decreased use, and injury models. Emphasizes interorgan communication; uses clinical models.

CourseID: P HPHY 520. Human Anatomy Dissection. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dissection of one region of a preserved donated human cadaver and preparation of the specimen for the HPHY 321/HPHY 323/HPHY 325 laboratory experience. Students are accepted by application, which are due early February.

CourseID: P HPHY 522. Physiology of Obesity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores potential causes of the obesity epidemic, cellular mechanisms linking obesity to insulin resistance and metabolic diseases, and interventions in treatment of metabolic disease and obesity.

CourseID: P HPHY 523. Physiology of Aging. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines changes that occur to cells and organs in old age and the causes of age-related disease and dysfunction (cardiovascular disease, diabetes, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s); interventions to increase longevity.

CourseID: P HPHY 533. Neurophysiology of Concussion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigate diagnosis, deficits, and treatment of mild traumatic brain injury and neurophysiological effects.

CourseID: P HPHY 534. Movement Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discusses the clinical manifestations and underlying physiological mechanisms of selected movement disorders. Emphasizes the role of scientific experiment in diagnosis and treatment.

CourseID: P HPHY 535. Physiology of Fatigue. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates neuromuscular function and fatigue and how the underlying physiology can contribute to fatigability discrepancies with respect to extraneous and pathophysiological factors.

CourseID: P HPHY 570. Environmental Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of physiological adaptations to acute and chronic exposure to extreme heat, cold, and high altitude.

CourseID: P HPHY 573. High Altitude Physiology and Medicine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major physiologic responses to high altitude (hypoxia), both adaptive and maladaptive, from systems to molecular level, as well as pathophysiologic conditions at high altitude. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HPHY 580. Technology Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a foundation in principles of intellectual property and technology transfer, critical to technology development in clinical and sport industries.

CourseID: P HPHY 586. Orthopedic Biomechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of musculoskeletal biomechanics relating to concepts in surgical and nonsurgical orthopedics. Course is beneficial to those pursuing careers in medicine and health sciences. Prereq: HPHY 381 or equivalent

CourseID: P HPHY 606. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Selected problems in the field of human physiology.

CourseID: P HPHY 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-9 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are offered regularly in such areas as health sciences, motor control, biomechanics, and physiology.

CourseID: P HPHY 611. Professional Skills I: Effective Teaching. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Development of professional skills for academic careers related to human physiology. Sequence with HPHY 612, 613.

CourseID: P HPHY 612. Professional Skills II: Responsible Research. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Development of professional skills for academic careers related to human physiology. Sequence with HPHY 611, 613.

CourseID: P HPHY 613. Professional Skills III: Career Development. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Development of professional skills for academic careers related to human physiology. Sequence with HPHY 611, 612.

CourseID: P HPHY 621. Systems Physiology I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced overview of neural physiology, neural control of human movement, and the biomechanical constraints underlying that control. Sequence with 622, 623.

CourseID: P HPHY 622. Systems Physiology II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced overview of cardiovascular physiology and skeletal muscle cell physiology and metabolism. Series with HPHY 621, 623.

CourseID: P HPHY 623. Systems Physiology III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced overview of renal and respiratory physiology. Series with HPHY 621, 622.

CourseID: P HPHY 631. Human Performance and Sports Products. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of sciences of human performance: physiology and kinesiology, which inform the sports product industry at the level of product development, product design, and marketing. Available to nonmajors only.

CourseID: P HPHY 660. Basic Science in Clinical Decisions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Literature-based investigation into the basic science and clinical research underlying clinical decisions in athletic medicine.

CourseID: P HPHY 661. Manual Therapy: Movement Patterns, Core Stability. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced skills in proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) movement patterns, and both pilates principles and manual therapy to improve core stability. For certified athletic trainers. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HPHY 662. Manual Therapy: Spine, Lower Quadrant. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced skills in muscle energy, mobilization, and trigger-point release techniques for the spine and lower quadrant. For certified athletic trainers. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P HPHY 669. The Female Athlete. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Literature-based investigation of the unique anatomy and physiology, as well as social-cultural issues, of the female athlete related to sports medicine.

CourseID: P HPHY 670. Advanced Respiratory Physiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores advanced concepts in respiratory physiology; includes exercise adaptations and examples of pathophysiology. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 623.

CourseID: P HPHY 671. Therapeutic Restoration of Biomotor Abilities. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of advanced rehabilitation techniques for athletic trainers, including advanced program design, evaluation, and movement-sport analysis. Pre- or coreq: certification as an athletic trainer or physical therapist.

CourseID: P HPHY 676. Human Cardiovascular Control. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cardiovascular physiology, including central control of blood pressure and flow regulation. An integrative approach toward how the cardiovascular system is coordinated with overall body function. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 623.

CourseID: P HPHY 684. Kinematics of Human Movement. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and application of kinematic analysis of human motion. Emphasis on 2D and 3D kinematics, including data collection, analysis and modeling. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 621.

CourseID: P HPHY 685. Kinetics of Human Movement. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experimental methods and mechanical theories associated with the analysis of joint forces and movements during human motion. Offered alternate years. Prereq: HPHY 621.

CourseID: P INTL 101. Introduction to International Issues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of major political, economic, and cultural themes in international studies through in-class debates on key contemporary issues.

CourseID: P INTL 240. Perspectives on International Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major ideologies, theories, historical processes, and contemporary challenges in international development. Galvan.

CourseID: P INTL 250. Value Systems in Cross-Cultural Perspective. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to value systems of various cultures, focusing on how values relate to religion, forms of social organization, group affiliation, and patterns of conflict resolution.

CourseID: P INTL 260. Culture, Capitalism, and Globalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural and historical perspectives on the development of capitalism as a way of life and its relationship to contemporary global issues and imbalances.

CourseID: P INTL 280. Global Environmental Issues and Alternatives. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines root causes of "environmental problems" at local, regional, national, and global scales. Critically compares approaches to addressing international environmental challenges.

CourseID: P INTL 323. Islam and Global Forces. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses interactions between global forces and processes in historical and modern Muslim societies and the salience of Islam in contemporary global arenas. Sequence with INTL 423. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P INTL 340. Global Health and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major issues in global health, their causes and possible solutions, with a focus on the poor in developing countries.

CourseID: P INTL 345. Africa Today: Issues and Concerns. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to current challenges facing African peoples today. Extends survey of Africa courses, and prepares students for more advanced study regarding the African continent.

CourseID: P INTL 360. International Cooperation and Conflict. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Utilizes case studies and selected themes to examine the root causes, stakeholder perspectives, and attempts to resolve international conflicts.

CourseID: P INTL 370. International Human Rights. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of human rights, examining diverse perspectives on the concept, practice, and implementation of human rights and human rights regimes.

CourseID: P INTL 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Special topics in international studies.

CourseID: P INTL 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Closely supervised participation in the activities of public or private organizations, institutes, and community service agencies.

CourseID: P INTL 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Africa: Development and Social Change. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P INTL 420. Global Community Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to communitarian theory and local-level grass-roots development practices. Comparison across North-South divide of efforts to alleviate poverty, promote sustainability, and ensure mobilization and cohesion. Prereq: INTL 240.

CourseID: P INTL 421. Gender and International Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the changing roles, opportunities, and expectations of Third World women as their societies undergo social upheavals associated with the problematic effects of development. Prereq: INTL 240.

CourseID: P INTL 422. Aid to Developing Countries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the history and current dynamics of international bilateral and multilateral development assistance, the possibilities and constraints of aid, and other related issues. Prereq: INTL 240.

CourseID: P INTL 423. Development and the Muslim World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to discourse on current development in various Muslim societies. Focuses on North Africa, the Middle East, South Asia, and Southeast Asia. Weiss.

CourseID: P INTL 424. United Nations Intervention in Global Crises. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theory and practice of humanitarian aid, peace-building, and development during or after violent conflict. Focuses on work of international organizations in conflict areas or on issues of conflict.

CourseID: P INTL 425. Global Food Security. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores explanations for, and solutions to, persistent inequities in food access. Considers the political, agricultural, economic and humanitarian aspects of the global food system.

CourseID: P INTL 431. Cross-Cultural Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on skills and insights needed by professionals working in cross-cultural settings. Considers values, development, education, politics, and environment as central to cross-cultural understanding.

CourseID: P INTL 432. Indigenous Cultural Survival. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores case studies of global indigenous peoples who are facing cultural survival issues and developing strategies and institutions to deal with this complex process.

CourseID: P INTL 433. Childhood in Cross-Cultural Perspective. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the experience of childhood around the world and examines how this experience is shaped by beliefs about who and what children are and by local conditions and contingencies.

CourseID: P INTL 434. Language Issues for International Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the influence of language on policy issues in societies around the world relative to nationalism, identity, multilingualism, education, human rights globalization, and language spread and loss.

CourseID: P INTL 442. South Asia: Development and Social Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the vast social changes and development issues confronting the South Asian subcontinent.

CourseID: P INTL 445. Development and Social Change in Sub-Saharan Africa. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces theoretical and practical aspects of development and social change in sub-Saharan Africa, with focus on key issues in African development during the post-colonial era.

CourseID: P INTL 446. Development and Social Change in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores development challenges, debt cycles, urban growth, neoliberalism, populism, socialism, gender, the environment, U.S.–Latin American relations, ecotourism, and drug geographies in the region.

CourseID: P INTL 448. Bollywood's Lens on Indian Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores Indian society through film, focusing on critical social issues; depicted vs. the historical reality; and ongoing transformations of social orientations and values.

CourseID: P INTL 463. Population Displacement and Global Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores health and mental health problems affecting displaced (migrant and refugee) communities and considers underdevelopment as a fundamental cause of displacement and health problems. Offered once per academic year.

CourseID: P INTL 465. Global Reproductive Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of issues in global reproductive health, including politics, economics, historical and cultural factors. Implications for international health and development programs reviewed. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P INTL 467. Global Mental Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of global mental health from a critical, anthropological, and historical perspective, with attention to cross-cultural differences in illness experience and treatment options.

CourseID: P INTL 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Special topics in international studies.

CourseID: P INTL 510. Experimental Course: [Topic). 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Africa: Development and Social Change. Repeatable when topic changes.

Descriptions: P Analysis of the changing roles, opportunities, and expectations of Third World women as their societies undergo social upheavals associated with the problematic effects of development.

CourseID: P INTL 548. Bollywood’s Lens on Indian Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores Indian society through film, focusing on critical social issues; depicted vs. the historical reality; and ongoing transformations of social orientations and values.

CourseID: P INTL 563. Population Displacement and Global Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores health and mental health problems affecting displaced (migrant and refugee) communities and considers underdevelopment as a fundamental cause of displacement and health problems. Offered once per academic year.

CourseID: P INTL 565. Global Reproductive Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of issues in global reproductive health, including politics, economics, historical and cultural factors. Implications for international health and development programs reviewed. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P INTL 567. Global Mental Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of global mental health from a critical, anthropological, and historical perspective, with attention to cross-cultural differences in illness experience and treatment options.

CourseID: P INTL 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Closely supervised participation in the activities of public or private organizations, institutes, and community service agencies.

CourseID: P INTL 655. International Studies Graduate Core Seminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Graduate introduction to the field of International Studies, including exploration of development, culture, communication, and research methods, design, and ethics.

CourseID: P INTL 656. Research and Writing in International Studies. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Focus on conceptualizing research topics; accessing bibliographic databases; writing grant applications, reports, and theses.

CourseID: P INTL 657. Proseminar: Proposal Writing. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to thesis proposal writing for first-year graduate students in international studies.

CourseID: P ANTH 429 Jewish Folklore and Ethnology 4 ENG 340 Jewish Writers 4 ENG 380 Film, Media, and History 4 FLR 411 Folklore and Religion 4 GER 368 Themes in German Literature 4 HIST 415 Advanced World History: [Topic] 4 HIST 428 Europe in the 20th Century: [Topic] 4 JDST 330 American Jewish Cultures 4 JDST 340 Israelis and Palestinians 4 PHIL 320 Philosophy of Religion 4 REL 318 Women in Judaism 4
Descriptions: P A list of approved courses is available from the program director preceding each term; it also appears in the online class schedule and the program website.

CourseID: P HBRW 111. Biblical Hebrew I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares students to read biblical and postbiblical Hebrew texts. Emphasis on classical Hebrew grammar, vocabulary, and syntax.

CourseID: P HBRW 112. Biblical Hebrew II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares students to read biblical and postbiblical Hebrew texts. Emphasis on classical Hebrew grammar, vocabulary, and syntax. Prereq: HBRW 111.

CourseID: P HBRW 113. Biblical Hebrew III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares students to read biblical and postbiblical Hebrew texts. Emphasis on classical Hebrew grammar, vocabulary, and syntax. Prereq: HBRW 112.

CourseID: P HBRW 311. Biblical Narrative. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in extended narrative prose passages from the Hebrew Bible; emphasis on reading, translation, vocabulary formation, and Hebrew syntax. Taught in Hebrew. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: HBRW 113 or equivalent.

CourseID: P HBRW 312. Biblical Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in poetic passages from the Hebrew Bible; focus on reading, translation, vocabulary formation, Hebrew syntax, and biblical poetics. Taught in Hebrew. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: HBRW 113 or equivalent.

CourseID: P HBRW 313. Postbiblical Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in postbiblical Hebrew texts of various genres from late antiquity and the Middle Ages, including legal writings, narratives, and poetry. Taught in Hebrew. Repeatable twice when topic changes. Prereq: HBRW 113 or equivalent.

CourseID: P JDST 212. Medieval and Early Modern Judaism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interdisciplinary introduction to Jewish life, literature, religion, culture, and thought in the Middle Ages and early modern times in both Muslim and Christian environments.

CourseID: P JDST 213. The Jewish Encounter with Modernity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of Jewish encounters with modernity outside the Americas from 1700 to 1948; concentrates on transformations in political status, national identity, Jewish culture, and religious self-definition.

CourseID: P JDST 330. American Jewish Cultures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P American Jewish culture, ritual, identity, institutions from 1880s to the present. Examines pluralism within American Jewish community and relationships with other religious and ethnic groups.

CourseID: P JDST 340. Israelis and Palestinians. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines political struggle between Israelis and Palestinians over past century and related human, societal, and cultural issues. Explores contemporary attempts at resolution.

CourseID: P LAS 200. Introduction to Latin American Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the history, peoples, and cultures of Latin America and of the Latino population in the United States.

CourseID: P LAS 211. Latin American Humanities: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the comparative study of Latin American cultural and intellectual traditions. Introduces scholarship in the humanities about Latin American and U.S. Latinos. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: P LAS 212. Latin American Social Sciences: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses various issues related to the historical, political, cultural, and economic development of Latin America from a social science perspective. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.
