CourseID: P ASTR 121. The Solar System. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Naked-eye astronomy, development of astronomical concepts, and the solar system.

CourseID: P ASTR 122. Birth and Death of Stars. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The structure and evolution of stars.

CourseID: P ASTR 321. Topics in Astrophysics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Problem solving of the orbits, kinematics, and dynamics of astronomical systems, structure and evolution of stars and galaxies. Pre- or coreq: MATH 252; PHYS 252 or equivalents.

CourseID: P PHYS 101. Essentials of Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental physical principles. Mechanics.

CourseID: P PHYS 102. Essentials of Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental physical principles. Heat, waves, and sound; electricity and magnetism.

CourseID: P PHYS 152. Physics of Sound and Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the wave nature of sound; hearing; musical instruments and scales; auditorium acoustics; and the transmission, storage, and reproduction of sound.

CourseID: P PHYS 153. Physics of Light, Color, and Vision. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Light and color, their nature, how they are produced, and how they are perceived and interpreted.

CourseID: P PHYS 155. Physics behind the Internet. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How discoveries in 20th-century physics mesh to drive modern telecommunications. Topics include electron mobility in matter, the development of transistors and semiconductors, lasers, and optical fibers.

CourseID: P PHYS 156M. Scientific Revolutions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys several major revolutions in our views of the natural and technological world, focusing on scientific concepts and methodological aspects. For nonscience majors. Multilisted with GEOL 156M.

CourseID: P PHYS 161. Physics of Energy and Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical study of energy generation and environmental impact, including energy fundamentals, fossil fuel use, global warming, nuclear energy, and energy conservation.

CourseID: P PHYS 162. Solar and Other Renewable Energies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include photovoltaic cells, solar thermal power, passive solar heating, energy storage, geothermal energy, and wind energy.

CourseID: P PHYS 171. The Physics of Life. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how physical laws guide the structure, function, and behavior of living organisms, and examines the physical properties of biological materials. Topics span microscropic and macroscopic scales.

CourseID: P PHYS 181. Quantum Mechanics for Everyone. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to quantum mechanics, a set of sometimes counterintuitive scientific principals describing atoms and light, along with the modern technologies it makes possible.

CourseID: P PHYS 201. General Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory series. Mechanics and fluids. Prereq: MATH 112 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 202. General Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory series. Thermodynamics, waves, optics. Prereq: PHYS 201.

CourseID: P PHYS 203. General Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory series. Electricity, magnetism, modern physics. Prereq: PHYS 201.

CourseID: P PHYS 204. Introductory Physics Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Sequence. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 201.

CourseID: P PHYS 205. Introductory Physics Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 202.

CourseID: P PHYS 206. Introductory Physics Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 203.

CourseID: P PHYS 251. Foundations of Physics I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Newtonian mechanics; units and vectors; one-dimensional motion; Newton’s laws; work and energy; momentum and collisions. Sequence. Coreq: MATH 251; Prereq MATH 112 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 252. Foundations of Physics I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Vibrations and waves; oscillations; wave mechanics; dispersion; modes; introductory optics. Prereq: PHYS 251; coreq: MATH 252 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 253. Foundations of Physics I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Electricity and magnetism; charge and electric field; electric potential; circuits; magnetic field; inductance. Prereq: PHYS 252; coreq: MATH 253 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 290. Foundations of Physics Laboratory. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to laboratory measurements, reports, instrumentation, and experimental techniques. Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits. Coreq: PHYS 251, 252 or 253.

CourseID: P PHYS 301. Physicists' View of Nature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Illustrates physics concepts through the work of prominent physicists. The classical view--mechanics, electrical science, thermal physics. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 351. Foundations of Physics II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to relativity and quantum physics with applications to atomic, solid-state, nuclear, and astro-particle systems Prereq: MATH 253, PHYS 253; coreq: MATH 256 or 281.

CourseID: P PHYS 352. Foundations of Physics II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thermodynamic systems; first and second laws; kinetic theory of gases; entropy. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 351; coreq: MATH 281.

CourseID: P PHYS 353. Foundations of Physics II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thermal radiation; Maxell-Boltzmann statistics; Fermi and Bose gases; phase transitions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 352; coreq: MATH 282.

CourseID: P PHYS 362. Biological Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physical principles governing biological systems. Topics include molecular machines, DNA and other macromolecules, signaling and information transfer, entropic forces, and physical mechanisms of self-organization. Prereq: PHYS 351 or 353.

CourseID: P PHYS 391. Physics Experimentation Data Analysis Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical aspects of physics experimentation, including data acquisition, statistical analysis, and introduction to scientific programming, and use of Fourier methods for data analysis.

CourseID: P PHYS 411. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Only nonmajors may earn graduate credit. Prereq: MATH 282.

CourseID: P PHYS 412. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Prereq: MATH 281.

CourseID: P PHYS 413. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Prereq: PHYS 412.

CourseID: P PHYS 414. Quantum Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planck's and de Broglie's postulates, the uncertainty principle, Bohr's model of the atom, the Schroedinger equation in one dimension, the harmonic oscillator, the hydrogen atom, molecules and solids, nuclei and elementary particles. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 413.

CourseID: P PHYS 415. Quantum Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planck's and de Broglie's postulates, the uncertainty principle, Bohr's model of the atom, the Schroedinger equation in one dimension, the harmonic oscillator, the hydrogen atom, molecules and solids, nuclei and elementary particles. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 414.

CourseID: P PHYS 417. Topics in Quantum Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Perturbation theory, variational principle, time-dependent perturbation theory, elementary scattering theory. Prereq: PHYS 415.

CourseID: P PHYS 421M. Partial Differential Equations: Fourier Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to PDEs with a view towards applications in physics. Wave and heat equations, classical Fourier series on the circle, Bessel and Legendre series. Multilisted with MATH 421M. Prereq: MATH 253; one from MATH 256, MATH 281.

CourseID: P PHYS 422. Electromagnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of electromagnetic waves. Topics include Maxwell's equations, wave equation, plane waves, guided waves, antennas, and other related phenomena. Prereq: PHYS 413.

CourseID: P PHYS 424. Classical Optics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Geometrical optics, polarization, interference, Frauenhofer and Fresnel diffraction. Prereq: PHYS 353.

CourseID: P PHYS 425. Modern Optics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Special topics in modern applied optics such as Fourier optics, coherence theory, resonators and lasers, holography, and image processing. Prereq: PHYS 424.

CourseID: P PHYS 431. Analog Electronics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Passive and active discrete components and circuits. General circuit concepts and theorems. Equivalent circuits and black box models. Integrated circuit operational amplifiers. Prereq: PHYS 203 or equivalent; knowledge of complex numbers; MATH

CourseID: P PHYS 432. Digital Electronics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Digital electronics including digital logic, measurement, signal processing and control. Introduction to computer interfacing. Prereq: PHYS 203 or equivalent; MATH 253.

CourseID: P PHYS 481. Design of Experiments. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applies statistics to practical data analysis, data-based decision making, model building, and the design of experiments. Emphasizes factorial designs.

CourseID: P PHYS 491. Research Project I. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 391 or PHYS 399.

CourseID: P PHYS 492. Research Project II. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 491.

CourseID: P PHYS 493. Research Project III. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 492.

CourseID: P PHYS 517. Topics in Quantum Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Perturbation theory, variational principle, time-dependent perturbation theory, elementary scattering theory. Only nonmajors may earn graduate credit. Prereq: PHYS 415/515.

CourseID: P PHYS 521M. Partial Differential Equations: Fourier Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to PDEs with a view towards applications in physics. Wave and heat equations, classical Fourier series on the circle, Bessel and Legendre series. Multilisted with MATH 521M.

CourseID: P PHYS 581. Design of Experiments. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applies statistics to practical data analysis, data-based decision making, model building, and the design of experiments. Emphasizes factorial designs.

CourseID: P PHYS 604. Internship: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Coreq: good standing in applied physics master's degree program.

CourseID: P PHYS 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Astrophysics and Gravitation, Biophysics, Condensed Matter, High Energy Physics, Physics Colloquium, Theoretical Physics.

CourseID: P PHYS 611. Theoretical Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, small oscillations, rigid bodies. Sequence.

CourseID: P PHYS 612. Theoretical Mechanics. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, small oscillations, rigid bodies. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 611.

CourseID: P PHYS 613. Statistical Physics. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, kinetic theory, application to gases, liquids, solids, atoms, molecules, and the structure of matter. Sequence.

CourseID: P PHYS 614. Statistical Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, kinetic theory, application to gases, liquids, solids, atoms, molecules, and the structure of matter. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 613.

CourseID: P PHYS 622. Electromagnetic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Microscopic form of Maxwell's equations, derivation and solution of the wave equation, Lorentz covariant formulation, motion of charges in given fields, propagation and diffraction, radiation by given sources, coupled motion of sources and fields, the electromagnetic field in dense media.

CourseID: P PHYS 623. Electromagnetic Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Microscopic form of Maxwell's equations, derivation and solution of the wave equation, Lorentz covariant formulation, motion of charges in given fields, propagation and diffraction, radiation by given sources, coupled motion of sources and fields, the electromagnetic field in dense media. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 622.

CourseID: P PHYS 626. Physical Optics with Labs. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of applied geometric and wave optics theory, reinforced through homework assignments, and explored in experiments conducted with lasers and optical components. Sequence with PHYS 627, PHYS

CourseID: P PHYS 627. Optical Materials and Devices. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of quantum mechanics and solid-state physics relating to material properties of optoelectronic devices with corresponding laboratories teaching how to operate and characterize these devices. Sequence with PHYS 626, PHYS 628. Prereq: PHYS 626 with B- or better grade.

CourseID: P PHYS 628. Laser and Nonlinear Optics with OpticStudio. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the nature of laser and nonlinear optics and the practical systems that utilize these phenomena with computational simulations using Zemax OpticStudio software. Sequence with PHYS 626, PHYS

CourseID: P PHYS 631. Quantum Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of fundamentals, central force problems, matrix mechanics. Sequence.

CourseID: P PHYS 632. Quantum Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Approximation methods, scattering. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 631.

CourseID: P PHYS 633. Quantum Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rotation symmetry, spin, identical particles. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 632.

CourseID: P PHYS 634. Advanced Quantum Mechanics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Time-dependent formulation of scattering, relativistic equations and solutions, hole theory, symmetry properties, second quantization, Fock space.

CourseID: P PHYS 661. Elementary Particle Phenomenology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Classification and quantum numbers of elementary particles; elements of group theory, Lorentz group and spin; discrete and continuous symmetries; phenomenology of weak, electromagnetic, and strong interactions; quark model of hadron structure. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 633.

CourseID: P PHYS 662. Elementary Particle Phenomenology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Classification and quantum numbers of elementary particles; elements of group theory, Lorentz group and spin; discrete and continuous symmetries; phenomenology of weak, electromagnetic, and strong interactions; quark model of hadron structure. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 661.

CourseID: P PHYS 665. Quantum Field Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Canonical quantization, path integral formulation of quantum field theory, Feynman rules for perturbation theory, quantum electrodynamics, renormalization, gauge theory of the strong and electroweak interactions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 634.

CourseID: P PHYS 666. Quantum Field Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Canonical quantization, path integral formulation of quantum field theory, Feynman rules for perturbation theory, quantum electrodynamics, renormalization, gauge theory of the strong and electroweak interactions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 665.

CourseID: P PHYS 671. Solid State Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Crystallography; thermal, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of solids; band theory; metals, semiconductors, and insulators; defects in solids. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 633.

CourseID: P PHYS 672. Solid State Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Crystallography; thermal, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of solids; band theory; metals, semiconductors, and insulators; defects in solids. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 671.

CourseID: P PHYS 674. Theory of Condensed Matter. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics include quantum and statistical description of many-particle systems, electronic structure, elementary excitations in solids and fluids, critical phenomena, statics and dynamics of soft condensed matter. Topics and emphasis vary. Prereq: PHYS 673.

CourseID: P PHYS 675. Theory of Condensed Matter. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics include quantum and statistical description of many-particle systems, electronic structure, elementary excitations in solids and fluids, critical phenomena, statics and dynamics of soft condensed matter. Topics and emphasis vary. Prereq: PHYS 674.

CourseID: P PHYS 677M. Semiconductor Device Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the theory behind semiconductors. Elementary theory of inorganic solids; electronic structures and transport properties. Basic theory of devices including diodes, transistors, mosfets, and optoelectronic devices. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 678M, PHYS 679M. Multilisted with CH 677M.

CourseID: P PHYS 678M. Semiconductor Processing and Characterization Technology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the techniques required to make semiconductors and test their properties. Solid-state and surface chemistry of inorganic semiconductors as it pertains to microelectronic devices. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 677M, PHYS 679M. Multilisted with CH 678M. Prereq: PHYS 677M.

CourseID: P PHYS 679M. Device Processing and Characterization Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students use theory and techniques learned to design, fabricate, and test a device that performs a specific function, with an emphasis on wafer processing and device realization. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 677M, PHYS 678M. Multilisted with CH 679M. Prereq: PHYS 678M.

CourseID: P PHYS 684. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 354 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PHYS 685. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 684; coreq PHYS 631.

CourseID: P PHYS 686. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 685; coreq: PHYS 632.

CourseID: P MATH 107 University Mathematics III
Descriptions: P or WR 123 or College Composition III 100-level course with PS subject code

CourseID: P PS 100. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P PS 102. Thinking Like a Social Scientist. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P PS 102. Thinking Like a Social Scientist. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Illustrates how the ways social scientists think—using quantitative, qualitative, and interpretive methods—help to sharpen thinking for many contexts and careers.

CourseID: P PS 106. Power, Politics, and Inequality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines power and politics through the lens of inequality, focusing on the constant struggle between the haves and the have-nots.

CourseID: P PS 109. Politics, Science, and the Body. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An interdisciplinary examination of the scientific and biological explanations of poverty and social inequality in the United States, historically and in the present day.

CourseID: P PS 111. Introduction to Political Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offers students the tools to think for themselves about politics: multiple ideological and analytical viewpoints on varying political arrangements around the world.

CourseID: P PS 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics vary from year to year. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P PS 201. United States Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical introduction to American institutions, political doctrines, and ideology as these affect the course of politics and public policy in the United States.

CourseID: P PS 205. Introduction to International Relations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theoretical and methodological tools for the analysis of world politics.

CourseID: P PS 208. Introduction to the Tradition of Political Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected issues in political theory such as political obligation, rationality, diversity, and relativism. Covers contemporary and classical theories.

CourseID: P PS 260. Public Policy and Democracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how American political ideals, interests, institutions, and history shape public policy, focusing on issues such as education, immigration, welfare, and civil liberties.

CourseID: P PS 275. Legal Process. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the United States legal system. Covers a range of sociolegal writing and provides a context for the legal system under which the U.S. operates.

CourseID: P PS 297. Introduction to Environmental Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P United States environmental policy and alternative environmental political futures.

CourseID: P PS 302. States’ Rights (and Wrongs). 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the division among U.S. federal, state and municipal power through the lens of our nation’s most contentious and most critical political and policy debates. Examines how elected officials, judges, and activists influence fights over federalism.

CourseID: P PS 304. Democracy, Dictators, and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines key questions in political science like why some countries are rich while others are poor, why some countries are democratic and others are authoritarian, how these different political systems work, and which are best equipped to address ethno-nationalist conflict and economic development.

CourseID: P PS 308. United States Political Thought. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of United States political thought from the Revolution through the 20th century. Includes writings of Jefferson, Paine, Madison, Tocqueville.

CourseID: P PS 309. Political Ideologies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ideology is a more-or-less coherent lens through which a person views the world in order to process information and direct action. The course examines how the world looks different for those holding liberal, conservative, communist, fascist, or anarchist world views.

CourseID: P PS 310. Roots of Democracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines modern conceptions of democracy, citizenship, legality, virtue, equality, and political order, which grew out of ideas initially developed in ancient Greek city-states. Special attention given to ideas of active citizenship.

CourseID: P PS 311. Sovereignty and Revolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines contemporary conceptions of politics springing from European debates about the power of kings, law, and the people. Considers key textual moments in the process by which modern conceptions of democracy emerged.

CourseID: P PS 312. Shadows of Modernity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the distinct critiques of modernity offered by John Stuart Mill, Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche, Michel Foucault, and Sigmund Freud. Concepts explored include liberalism, capitalism, power, morality, and the unconscious.

CourseID: P PS 316. Black Lives Matter and American Democracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the ideological origins and contemporary politics of the Black Lives Matter movement. Modules include the demands of/on democracy, race and the criminal justice system, and the politics of protest.

CourseID: P PS 320. International Organization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies efforts by states to cooperate in an effort to avoid or resolve conflict in the realms of security, trade, human rights, and the environment.

CourseID: P PS 321. Introduction to Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Systematic comparison of markets and political processes and their outcomes.

CourseID: P PS 324. European Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the formation and current dynamics of national politics in Western Europe.

CourseID: P PS 326. United States Foreign Policy I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts underlying the formulation and implementation of United States foreign policy; relationships between American society and foreign policy; the relationship of the U.S. to its international environment.

CourseID: P PS 330. Governments and Politics in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social, political, and economic developments in Latin America; causes and consequences of revolutions, democratization, economic politics; examples from Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Cuba, Guatemala, Venezuela. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 337. The Politics of Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents alternative perspectives on key north-south issues: trade, aid, foreign investment, debt, and the environment. Includes such institutions as the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and World Trade Organization.

CourseID: P PS 340. International Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Links between economics and politics in the international system. Basic concepts include power, dependence, inequality, imperialism, and development. EC 201, 202, or PS 205 recommended preparation.

CourseID: P PS 342. Politics of China. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the politics of the People's Republic of China. Emphasis on political sociology and group conflict: elites, ideology, social change, and organization.

CourseID: P PS 345. Southeast Asian Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys major themes in contemporary Southeast Asian politics, including nation-state building, economic development, authoritarianism and democracy, and religious and ethnic politics.

CourseID: P PS 346. Terrorism and Weapons Proliferation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines causes and control of terrorism, especially preventing terrorist use of weapons of mass destruction; theories and policies of nonproliferation and arms control.

CourseID: P PS 347. Political Power, Influence, and Control. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the use of the concept of power in the social sciences, stressing diverse theoretical perspectives and empirical studies of political institutions.

CourseID: P PS 348. Women and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political role of women and questions of equality in the

CourseID: P PS 349. Mass Media and American Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The role of the mass media in contemporary American politics; the effect of the media on such institutions as political parties, elections, and the presidency.

CourseID: P PS 350. Politics and Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political relevance of films and their role as a medium for illustrating, defending, and challenging political ideas.

CourseID: P PS 351. Democratic Dilemmas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Core course for the Wayne Morse Scholars Program, exploring significant political and policy challenges confronting our representative democracy.

CourseID: P PS 352. Political Parties and Elections. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of current developments in political parties and interest groups in the United States.

CourseID: P PS 355. Oregon Government and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Current political issues in Oregon with particular attention to political races and ballot measures before the Oregon electorate as well as the state's major political institutions.

CourseID: P PS 367. Science and Politics of Climate Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding the causes, impacts, policies, and politics of global climate change from natural and social science perspectives.

CourseID: P PS 368. Gender in the Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the role courts have played in framing and shaping policies where gender is a central feature with a focus on reproductive rights, pregnancy and abortion, domestic violence, rape, family issues, prostitution, and sexual harassment. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 369. Southern Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the economic, social, and political aspects of life in the 20thcentury US South.

CourseID: P PS 371. United States Congress. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of Congress as an institution: congressional elections, the committee system, and the internal distribution of influence; relations with the president and the Supreme Court.

CourseID: P PS 374. Politics of the Middle East. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an overview of current political developments in the Middle East.

CourseID: P PS 375. Race, Politics, and the Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the development and transformation of race-based domination and resistance in the United States by examining the intersection of policy and law.

CourseID: P PS 378. Games in Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Politics viewed as strategic interactions among politicians, voters, and countries; focuses on how to model these interactions using tools of game theory.

CourseID: P PS 380. Gender and Politics in Developing Countries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines gender politics in the developing world and efforts to help women. Topics include female genital cutting, violence against women, economic development, microfinance, migration, trafficking. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 386. United States Social Movements and Political Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Causes and consequences of American social movements. Considers theoretical perspectives. Topics may include agrarian populism, labor movement, civil rights movement, the women's movement, and identity politics.

CourseID: P PS 390. American Indian Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the political and constitutional status of American Indian tribes in the United States, with some comparison to Canada. Focus on history, current policy, and potential futures.

CourseID: P PS 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics vary from year to year. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P PS 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable once for a maximum of four credits.

CourseID: P PS 406. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P PS 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offerings vary from year to year, depending on student need and faculty interests. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P PS 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when title changes.

CourseID: P PS 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offerings vary from year to year, depending on student need and faculty interests. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P PS 411. Honors Thesis Prospectus. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Prepares students for writing the senior honors thesis in political science. Provides guidance in framing a suitable topic, conducting preliminary research, and writing a prospectus. Prereq: majors with honors standing.

CourseID: P PS 433. Marxism and Radical Thought. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys utopian socialist thought, anarchism, Marxism, and Leninism. Central themes include the nature of radical theory, the role of the state, human nature and the new society.

CourseID: P PS 440. Causes and Prevention of War. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys theories of causes of war; focuses on major theories of prevention; case studies from World War I, World War II, and other wars.

CourseID: P PS 445. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to quantitative analysis, concepts and methods of empirical research, applied statistical data analysis in political science. Methods include descriptive statistics, bivariate correlation, and regression techniques.

CourseID: P PS 446. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of multivariate model building for political analysis. Multiple regression, discrete-variable techniques, recursive systems, and cross-level analysis. Application of these techniques to concrete political problems. Prereq: PS 445/545.

CourseID: P PS 449. Racial Politics in the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Considers how race has interacted with political development in the U.S. from the New Deal to the present.

CourseID: P PS 455. Theories of International Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Competing theories of international relations and strategies for testing the theories.

CourseID: P PS 458. Feminist Political Theories. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between feminism, gender, and the state. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 460. Political Economy of East Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political economy of East Asia, with a focus on states, markets, and social classes during economic transformation. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 465. LGBT Rights in the Courts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analyzes the role of legal advocates and the courts in advancing and curtailing lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender rights with a focus on relationship recognition, parenting, employment, housing, military, education, and health care. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 466. Civil Rights in Post-Warren Era. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analyzes development in civil rights advocacy in the United States since the heyday of the Warren Court. Focuses primarily on developments in race, gender, disability, and sexuality. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 467. The United States Presidency. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An ambivalent view of the presidency as the key institution in the United States political system: source of great good but also of great harm.

CourseID: P PS 470. Constitutional Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys how the U.S. Constitution works as a structure for government. Addresses how the federal courts interact within the U.S. system of government.

CourseID: P PS 471. Intergenerational Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the ethical and legal obligations that exist between earlier and later generations within a political society.

CourseID: P PS 472. Matters of Life and Death. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the right to life from political, legal, and philosophical perspectives. Considers abortion, capital punishment, assisted suicide, just-war theory, and animal rights.

CourseID: P PS 475. Politics of the European Union. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the historical development and current workings of the European Union’s major institutions and policies. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 477. International Environmental Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How nations solve international environmental problems. Explores major problems, processes, and current debates. Evaluates existing treaties through case studies.

CourseID: P PS 479. U.S. Interventions in Developing Nations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines theories of intervention: security, economic imperialism, humanitarian intervention, spreading democracy, domestic politics; over thirty-seven U.S. interventions since 1898 are surveyed.

CourseID: P PS 480. Introduction to Rational Choice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the paradigm of rational choice and game theory that is of special significance to politics.

CourseID: P PS 484. United States Supreme Court. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The Supreme Court as a political body; the judicial role in the context of the economic, political, social, and psychological factors that influence the court's decisions.

CourseID: P PS 485. Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the role of rights in the United States legal system. Particular emphasis on the role of freedom and equality in a federal system.

CourseID: P PS 491. Politics of Everyday Life. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how we try to influence each other's behaviors in the course of everyday life. Readings from several disciplines.

CourseID: P PS 495. United States Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines United States political-economic institutions from a comparative and historical perspective. Topics include rise and fall of mass production, labor and the law, and regional development.

CourseID: P PS 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year, depending on student needs and faculty interests.

CourseID: P PS 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offerings vary from year to year, depending on student needs and faculty interests. Repeatable when topic changes.

Descriptions: P Examines theories of intervention: security, economic imperialism, humanitarian intervention, spreading democracy, domestic politics; over thirty-seven U.S. interventions since 1898 are surveyed.

CourseID: P PS 584. United States Supreme Court. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The Supreme Court as a political body; the judicial role in the context of the economic, political, social, and psychological factors that influence the court's decisions.

CourseID: P PS 585. Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the role of rights in the United States legal system. Particular emphasis on the role of freedom and equality in a federal system.

CourseID: P PS 595. United States Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines United States political-economic institutions from a comparative and historical perspective. Topics include rise and fall of mass production, labor and the law, and regional development.

CourseID: P PS 612. Qualitative Methods. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of rationales for qualitative methods in the social sciences and the main conceptual and practical issues raised in qualitative research. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PS 617. Political Behavior. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an overview of the important literature in the subfield of political behavior in U.S. politics.

CourseID: P PS 618. American Political Institutions. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P One of three required seminars for PhD students planning to take a comprehensive examination in American politics. Explores how political science approaches the study of institutional contributions to political and policy developments.

CourseID: P PS 619. United States Political Culture. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P In this course we examine the different ways that scholars study the relationship between politics and culture, and then focus on the United States as our case.

CourseID: P PS 620. State of the Discipline. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to trends in the political science profession and to the faculty at the University of Oregon.

CourseID: P PS 622. Political Theory. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of major works in the field of classical and contemporary political theory.

CourseID: P PS 624. International Relations. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of major works in the field of international relations.

CourseID: P PS 625. Public Policy. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of major works in the field of public policy.

CourseID: P PS 626. International Political Economy. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P One of two required seminars for PhD students planning to take a comprehensive examination in international relations. Explores how politics and economics interact in shaping economic relations among states.

CourseID: P PS 627. Formal Theory and Methodology. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reviews basic formal theory as developed in political science since 1957.

CourseID: P PS 628. States and State-Society Relations. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how scholars have studied the state and its relationship to society. Students develop a comparative perspective of contentious politics ranging from peasant rebellions to revolutions to transnational social movements.

CourseID: P PS 629. Comparative Political Economy. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Doctoral-level survey of how political factors explain variations in national or regional trajectories of economic development, including industrialization, wealth, growth, and inequality.

CourseID: P PS 630. States and Regimes. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the major issues, theories, concepts, and arguments about states and regimes in comparative politics. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P PSY 201. Mind and Brain. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to perception, memory, learning, and cognition.

CourseID: P PSY 202. Mind and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to topics in clinical, personality, social, and developmental psychology.

CourseID: P PSY 301. Scientific Thinking in Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals in the empirical study of human behavior, including hypothesis formation, experiment design, behavioral data basics, and critical evaluation of scientific claims. Sequence with PSY 302, PSY 303. Students may not register for PSY 301 after completing PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 302. Statistical Methods in Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Probability and statistics applied in psychological research. Topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation, regression, and design of experiments. With laboratory. Sequence with PSY 301, PSY 303. Prereq: MATH 243 or one from MATH 241, MATH 246, MATH 251; PSY 301, WR 121; Pre- or coreq: PSY 201, 202.

CourseID: P PSY 303. Research Methods in Psychology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical experience designing, conducting, analyzing, and communicating original research about human behavior. Sequence with PSY 301, PSY 302. Repeatable once for a total of 8 credits when the topic changes. Prereq: PSY 201, PSY 202, PSY 301, PSY 302; one from WR 122, WR

CourseID: P PSY 304. Biopsychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationships between brain and endocrine activity and behavior. Topics include sensation, perception, sexual behavior, drug effects, eating, drinking, sleeping, dreaming, and learning. Prereq: PSY 201.

CourseID: P PSY 305. Cognition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major topics addressed in this class include perception, attention, memory, language, reasoning, and decision-making. Prereq: PSY 201.

CourseID: P PSY 306. Social Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Processes underlying social perception and social interaction. Topics include aggression, the self-concept, stereotyping and prejudice, conformity, persuasion, attraction, and helping. Prereq: PSY 202.

CourseID: P PSY 307. Personality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and methods for studying human traits, including personality tests and measures. Current research in personality. Studies of age, gender, culture, and relation to emotion and motivation. Prereq: PSY 202.

CourseID: P PSY 308. Developmental Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of cognitive, social-emotional, and personality development in infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood. Prereq: PSY 202.

CourseID: P PSY 309. Psychopathology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major descriptive and theoretical approaches to etiological, developmental, and social factors in emotion and personality disorders. Includes assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and special topics. Prereq: PSY 202.

CourseID: P PSY 348. Music and the Brain. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the neural correlates of our perception of tonality, harmony, melody, and rhythm and how these relate to neurobiology, brain damage, and cognitive neuroscience.

CourseID: P PSY 366. Culture and Mental Health. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Role of culture in the definition and maintenance of mental health and the definition and treatment of mental illness.

CourseID: P PSY 380. Psychology of Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical analysis of evidence for sex differences, gender roles, and the effect of gender on traditional issues in psychology. Topics include parenthood, violence, and sexual orientation.

CourseID: P PSY 383. Psychoactive Drugs. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Physiological and behavioral effects of psychoactive drugs such as alcohol, opiates, barbiturates, and excitants. The psychology of use and overuse; therapies for correcting drug problems.

CourseID: P PSY 388. Human Sexuality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The nature of human sexuality; hormonal, instinctual, and learned factors in sexuality; psychosexual development; sexual orientation; frequency and significance of various types of sexual behavior; sexual inadequacy; sexual deviation.

CourseID: P PSY 412. Applied Data Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level practical data analysis and interpretation. Topics include experimental design, analysis of variance, multiple regression, exploratory data analysis. Extensive computer use. Honors only. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 420. Psychology and Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to topics of concern to both psychology and the law. Includes eyewitness identification, legal decision-making, criminal defenses, profiling, polygraphy, and mental-health law. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 433. Learning and Memory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Processes underlying learning and memory, including evolution. Topics range from simple forms of behavior change to the acquisition, retention, forgetting, and retrieval of symbolic information. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 304, PSY 305.

CourseID: P PSY 436. Human Performance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Motor and intellectual capacities; analysis of the flow of information within the nervous system; applications of performance principles to human-machine systems. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 305.

CourseID: P PSY 438. Perception. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics covered are color, size, shape, depth, distance, and movement. Examines the relationships between stimuli and perception, stimuli and the neural response, and the neural response and perception. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 304.

CourseID: P PSY 440. Psycholinguistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Processes and structures underlying language use. Methods of studying language processing. Relationships between psycholinguistic data and observations from linguistics and neurophysiology. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 305.

CourseID: P PSY 445. Brain Mechanisms of Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Organization of the mammalian brain. Structure and function of the neuronal systems underlying vision, perception, motivation, coordinated movement, sleep-wakefulness, learning and memory, and affective disorders. Prereq: PSY 303, 304.

CourseID: P PSY 449. Cognitive Neuroscience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Integrative neural mechanisms of normal and abnormal processes in systems (e.g., selective attention, language, memory, object recognition, and emotion). Prereq: PSY 303, 304.

CourseID: P PSY 450. Hormones and Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationships among the brain, endocrine systems, and behavior. Developmental effects of hormones on the brain, puberty, sexuality, aggression, stress. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 304.

CourseID: P PSY 457. Group Dynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in small-group dynamics, including decision-making, conflict, and changes over time in group structure and behavior. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 458. Decision-Making. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Psychological processes involved in judgment and decision-making. Normative theories of ideal behavior contrasted with descriptive analysis of actual behavior. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 459. Cultural Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines interdependence between mind and culture in substantive domains such as social cognition, motivation, emotion, and psychopathology. Cultural pluralism, collective identities, tolerance, and diversity considered. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 468. Motivation and Emotion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Adaptive human behavior; considers biological processes involved in emotions, how emotions interact with cognition, and social influences. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 472. Psychology of Trauma. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cognitive, neuropsychological, developmental, social, and clinical approaches to understanding trauma. Includes analysis of childhood trauma, sexual assault, domestic violence, terrorism, combat, and natural disasters. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 473. Intimate Relationships. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Adult intimacy and love relationships. Clinical-counseling approaches: assessment, couple and family therapies, and evaluation. Models of relationship functioning and the empirical study of interpersonal relationships. Prereq: PSY 303.

CourseID: P PSY 475. Cognitive Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intellectual development in children from infancy to adolescence with a focus on early childhood. Topics covered include perception, attention, memory, reasoning, conceptual structure, social cognition. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 305, PSY 308.

CourseID: P PSY 476. Language Acquisition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How children acquire language from the earliest speech sounds to full sentences. Topics include babbling, first words, word combinations, the relationship between cognition and language development. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 305, PSY 308.

CourseID: P PSY 478. Social Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical issues and empirical studies of social-emotional development. Topics may include attachment, temperament, moral development, family interaction, self-image, aggression, and sex-role development. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 306, PSY 307, PSY 308.

CourseID: P PSY 479. Infancy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms and processes that underlie and promote rapid changes in physical, cognitive, and linguistic capabilities, from birth to 24 months. Covers innovative methodologies and cultural attitudes toward infants. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 308, PSY 376.

CourseID: P PSY 480. Development and Psychopathology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological and environmental factors that shape normal and abnormal development. Analysis of how family functioning affects psychopathology and resilience in children and adolescents. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 308, PSY 309.

CourseID: P PSY 490. Honors in Psychology. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Reading and conference. Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits each. Prereq: Honors psychology majors only.

CourseID: P PSY 491. Honors is Psychology. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Reading and conference. Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits each. Prereq: Honors psychology majors only.

CourseID: P PSY 492. Honors in Psychology. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Reading and conference. Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits each. Prereq: Honors psychology majors only.

CourseID: P PSY 512. Applied Data Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level practical data analysis and interpretation. Topics include experimental design, analysis of variance, multiple regression, exploratory data analysis. Extensive computer use.

CourseID: P PSY 520. Psychology and Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to topics of concern to both psychology and the law. Includes eyewitness identification, legal decision-making, criminal defenses, profiling, polygraphy, and mental-health law.

Descriptions: P Integrative neural mechanisms of normal and abnormal processes in systems (e.g., selective attention, language, memory, object recognition, and emotion).

CourseID: P PSY 550. Hormones and Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationships among the brain, endocrine systems, and behavior. Developmental effects of hormones on the brain, puberty, sexuality, aggression, stress.

CourseID: P PSY 557. Group Dynamics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in small-group dynamics, including decision-making, conflict, and changes over time in group structure and behavior.

CourseID: P PSY 558. Decision-Making. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Psychological processes involved in judgment and decision-making. Normative theories of ideal behavior contrasted with descriptive analysis of actual behavior.

CourseID: P PSY 559. Cultural Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines interdependence between mind and culture in substantive domains such as social cognition, motivation, emotion, and psychopathology. Cultural pluralism, collective identities, tolerance, and diversity considered.

CourseID: P PSY 568. Motivation and Emotion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Adaptive human behavior; considers biological processes involved in emotions, how emotions interact with cognition, and social influences.

CourseID: P PSY 572. Psychology of Trauma. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cognitive, neuropsychological, developmental, social, and clinical approaches to understanding trauma. Includes analysis of childhood trauma, sexual assault, domestic violence, terrorism, combat, and natural disasters.

CourseID: P PSY 573. Intimate Relationships. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Adult intimacy and love relationships. Clinical-counseling approaches: assessment, couple and family therapies, and evaluation. Models of relationship functioning and the empirical study of interpersonal relationships.

CourseID: P PSY 575. Cognitive Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intellectual development in children from infancy to adolescence with a focus on early childhood. Topics covered include perception, attention, memory, reasoning, conceptual structure, social cognition.

CourseID: P PSY 576. Language Acquisition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How children acquire language from the earliest speech sounds to full sentences. Topics include babbling, first words, word combinations, the relationship between cognition and language development.

CourseID: P PSY 578. Social Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical issues and empirical studies of social-emotional development. Topics may include attachment, temperament, moral development, family interaction, self-image, aggression, and sex-role development.

CourseID: P PSY 579. Infancy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mechanisms and processes that underlie and promote rapid changes in physical, cognitive, and linguistic capabilities, from birth to 24 months. Covers innovative methodologies and cultural attitudes toward infants.

CourseID: P PSY 580. Development and Psychopathology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Biological and environmental factors that shape normal and abnormal development. Analysis of how family functioning affects psychopathology and resilience in children and adolescents.

CourseID: P PSY 611. Data Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to probability, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance with applications. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory.

CourseID: P PSY 612. Data Analysis II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Multiple regression and advanced topics in analysis of variance. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory. Prereq: PSY 611.

CourseID: P PSY 613. Data Analysis III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Multivariate techniques including MANOVA, factor analysis, principal components. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory. Prereq: PSY 612.

CourseID: P PSY 620. Psychopathology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Definition, measurement, and diagnosis of deviant behavior; includes critical reviews of research on the etiology, intervention, and outcome of major mental disorders. Prereq: major standing.

CourseID: P PSY 621. Clinical Psychobiology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and theory from the neurosciences applied to clinical problems and biological therapies. Prereq: major standing.

CourseID: P ARB 253. Introduction to Arabic Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A survey of the linguistic, geographic, social, cultural, religious, political, and artistic aspects of the contemporary Arab world.

CourseID: P ARB 301. Language and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 302, 303. Prereq: ARB 203.

CourseID: P ARB 302. Language and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 301, 303. Prereq: ARB 301.

CourseID: P ARB 303. Language and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 301, 302. Prereq: ARB 302.

CourseID: P ARB 331. Reading Classical Arabic. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Improves students' abilities to work with classical Arabic texts; serves as a gateway to other classical Arabic text courses. Prereq: ARB 202 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ARB 353. Arab Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Arab cinema and culture through an examination of the development of cinema in Arabic-speaking countries. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P REL 101. World Religions: Asian Traditions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to related religious traditions of Asia, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Daoism, Confucianism and Shinto. Readings in sacred texts and scholarlary literature. Lecture, discussion.

CourseID: P REL 102. World Religions: Near Eastern Traditions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the Abrahamic religions of Judaism, Christianity, Islam and to related traditions such as the Zoroastrian, Manichaean, Mandean, Baha'i. Lecture, discussion.

CourseID: P REL 211. Early Judaism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the Jewish religion from its earliest existence until the Christian era.

CourseID: P REL 222. Introduction to the Bible I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Content and organization of the Hebrew scriptures (Old Testament); examination of scholarly methods and research tools used in biblical studies.

CourseID: P REL 223. Introduction to the Bible II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the written traditions of early Christianity with an emphasis on the New Testament.

CourseID: P REL 233. Introduction to Islam. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Islamic religious tradition, beginnings to present. Pre-Islamic Arabia, Prophet Muhammed, pillars of Islam, ethics and piety, Sunni-Shiite divide, reform and renewal movements.

CourseID: P REL 302. Chinese Religions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prehistoric roots of Chinese religion, Confucius and his followers, philosophical Taoism, Han Confucianism, religious Taoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism, religion in China today.

CourseID: P REL 303. Japanese Religions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Early Shinto and its developments, Japanese Buddhism, transformation of Taoism and Confucianism, medieval Shinto, religion in the Tokugawa period, Nationalistic Shinto, folk religion, new religions.

CourseID: P REL 304. Religions of India. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to the major religious traditions of the Indian subcontinent: Hinduism and Buddhism, and more briefly Sikhism and Jainism.

CourseID: P REL 317. Jesus and the Gospels. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Considers early evidence for Jesus, including canonical and noncanonical gospels, in light of critical scholarship and historical reconstructions.

CourseID: P REL 318. Women in Judaism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Women and their roles in Judaism; emphasis on early modern and contemporary eras. Texts read include historical, literary, and theoretical documents.

CourseID: P REL 321. History of Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers the ancient period, from the Apostolic Fathers to the Islamic conquests (90–650).

CourseID: P REL 322. History of Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers medieval Western Christianity, from the Germanic invasions to the Reformation (400–1500).

CourseID: P REL 323. History of Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers modern Western Christianity, from the Reformation to the present (1500 to the present).

CourseID: P REL 324. History of Eastern Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Byzantine Christianity from the founding of the Christian Roman Empire to the Fall of Constantinople in the 15th century.

CourseID: P REL 325. History of Eastern Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The Eastern churches from the 15th century to the present.

CourseID: P REL 335. Introduction to the Qur'an. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to the nature of the Qur'an and the various ways it has been interpreted throughout history by both Muslims and non-Muslims.

CourseID: P REL 353. Dark Self, East and West. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comparative examination of selfhood in Eastern and Western religious thought and cultural contexts. Focus on dark side or problematic dimensions of Buddhist, Christian, Daoist, Jewish, and other thought.

CourseID: P REL 355. Mysticism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The experiential or mystical dimensions of the three major Abrahamic faiths. Exploration of the original writings of men and women from each spiritual tradition.

CourseID: P REL 357. War, Terrorism, and Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offers an examination of the theme of war, terrorism, and religion, focusing on cases of religiously motivated acts of violence in the contemporary era.

CourseID: P REL 359. Religion After Atheism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Atheist critiques of religion, analyses of secularism from multiple disciplinary perspectives, and responses to atheism and secularism by modernist Christian, Muslim, and Buddhist writers.

CourseID: P REL 411. Making Sense of Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of the study of religion, from the late 19th century to the present, as an expression of society, agent of oppression, psychological experience, symbolic system, and Western concept. Junior standing required.

CourseID: P REL 412. Dead Sea Scrolls: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of the Dead Sea Scrolls literature. Focus on either biblical texts and the development of the Hebrew Bible or nonbiblical texts and sectarian Judaism. Repeatable once when topic changes for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P REL 414. Biblical Book: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Close reading of one or more books of the Judeo-Christian Bible in literary, historical, and cultural contexts; history of interpretation; and critical scholarship. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P REL 418. Martyrdom. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of themes of sacrifice and martyrdom in ancient and medieval literatures of the Abrahamic traditions. Comparative approach to development of concepts within and across religious boundaries.

CourseID: P REL 424. Early and Medieval Christian Heresy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of various heretical beliefs from early medieval Christian history; examines alternative visions of Christian truth, and the formation from heterodoxy of orthodoxy.

CourseID: P REL 426. Sex and Gender in Early Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of how and why certain early Christians sought, successfully, to normalize certain interrelated cultural constructions of gender, the body, and sexuality.

CourseID: P REL 432. Islamic Mysticism: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Inner dimensions of Islamic piety and righteousness, from the Koranic and prophetic foundations to principal thinkers in the medieval Arabic and Persian Sufi traditions. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P REL 435. Advanced Study of the Qur’an: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Close reading of a section of the Qur’an in terms of its literary, historical, and cultural contexts, history of interpretation, and critical scholarship. Sequence with REL 335. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: P REL 440. Readings in Buddhist Scriptures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Readings in representative scriptures in English translation. Selection based on their import in development of Indian Buddhist philosophy and their impact on evolution of East Asian forms of Buddhism.

CourseID: P REL 444. Medieval Japanese Buddhism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Medieval Japanese Buddhism of the 12th and 13th centuries. Examination of religious thought and cultural history including Zen and Pure Land.

CourseID: P REL 511. Making Sense of Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of the study of religion, from the late 19th century to the present, as an expression of society, agent of oppression, psychological experience, symbolic system, and Western concept.

CourseID: P FR 101. First-Year French. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to French stressing the development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills through a communicative approach. Sequence. Conducted in French.

CourseID: P FR 102. First-Year French. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to French stressing the development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills through a communicative approach. Sequence. Conducted in French. Prereq: FR 101.

CourseID: P FR 103. First-Year French. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to French stressing the development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills through a communicative approach. Sequence. Conducted in French. Prereq: FR 102.

CourseID: P FR 111. Intensive Beginning French. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study for experienced language learners; introduction to French culture. Sequence. Cannot be combined with FR 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year French. Prereq: previous study of French or competence in another Romance language.

CourseID: P FR 112. Intensive Beginning French. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study for experienced language learners; introduction to French culture. Cannot be combined with FR 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year French. Prereq: FR 111.

CourseID: P FR 150. Cultural Legacies of France. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P French civilization in France and beyond. Possible topics are the Francophone world; premodern, early modern, and modern France; French film, architecture, and painting. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P FR 201. Second-Year French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading, writing, and speaking skills; study of short literary and cultural texts; considerable attention paid to oral use of the language. Sequence. Prereq: first-year language competence.

CourseID: P FR 202. Second-Year French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading, writing, and speaking skills; study of short literary and cultural texts; considerable attention paid to oral use of the language. Sequence. Prereq: FR 201.

CourseID: P FR 203. Second-Year French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of reading, writing, and speaking skills; study of short literary and cultural texts; considerable attention paid to oral use of the language. Sequence. Prereq: FR 202.

CourseID: P FR 301. Culture et langage: la France contemporaine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Training in language and culture of modern France using newspapers, short stories, poetry and film. Vocabulary enrichment activities. Conducted in French. Prereq: FR 203.

CourseID: P FR 302. Culture et langage: Le monde francophone contemporain. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Training in language and cultures of the French-speaking world using literary texts, websites, videos. Grammar review and vocabulary enrichment. Prereq: FR 203.

CourseID: P FR 307. Oral Skills. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Practice in improving oral, comprehension, and listening skills in French. Communicative activities in class in addition to language laboratory work. Repeatable once for maximum of 4 credits. Prereq: FR 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P FR 312. French Survey: Francophone Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major authors and texts of the French-speaking world outside of France. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 317. French Survey: Medieval and Renaissance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major themes and ideas in French literature from the medieval and Renaissance periods through the reading of representative texts. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 318. French Survey: Baroque and Enlightenment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major themes and ideas in French literature from the 17th and 18th centuries through the reading of representative texts. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 319. French Survey: 19th and 20th Centuries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative literary works from the 19th and 20th centuries with attention to literary analysis and literary history. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 320. Intensive French Grammar Review. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Promotes linguistic competency in French through intensive review and refinement of French grammar while introducing basic vocabulary and linguistic concepts. Prereq: FR 203.

CourseID: P FR 330. French Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Poems from the Middle Ages to the 20th century, literary movements, introduction to textual analysis and modern critical approaches. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 331. French Theater. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores important aspects of French theater. Reading plays from different periods. Emphasizes formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 333. French Narrative. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers important aspects of French narrative. Reading texts from different periods. Emphasis on formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 361. French Cinema for Nonmajors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to the major movements of French cinema for nonmajors. No prior knowledge of film studies or French culture required. Taught in English.

CourseID: P FR 362. French Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the differences between American culture and French and Francophone cultures. Addresses a sensitive issue exemplified by the attitude of the international movie industry. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include French Novel and World War II, Writers and Painters, Medievalism, Francophone Caribbean, Gide and Sartre. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 416. Advanced Writing in French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extended written production; writing for specific purposes and audiences. Advanced grammar review and composition; study of specialized vocabulary. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 425. French-English Translation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offers an overview of translation theory and practice from English to French and French to English. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: P FR 450. 17th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 17th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 451. Baroque Theater: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of representative plays by Moliere, Racine, or Corneille with emphasis on modern criticism. Repeatable when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 460. 18th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 18th-century French literature. A recent topic is Being Modern in the 18th century. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 480. 19th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 19th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 490. 20th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 20th-century French literature. Recent topics include African Identities, The French Novel in 2000, Postcolonial Africa. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 492. Francophone Studies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of literary works representative of the Francophone world. Topics may include Francophone African Literature, Quebec Literature, Writing the Haitian Revolution. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 497. Francophone Women's Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Developments in literature by women from areas such as Maghreb, the Caribbean, Sub-Saharan Africa, Quebec, the Indian Ocean, and Europe. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: P FR 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include French Novel and World War II, Writers and Painters, Medievalism, Francophone Caribbean, Gide and Sartre.

CourseID: P FR 516. Advanced Writing in French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extended written production; writing for specific purposes and audiences. Advanced grammar review and composition; study of specialized vocabulary.

CourseID: P FR 550. 17th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 17th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P FR 551. Baroque Theater: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P FR 560. 18th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 18th-century French literature. A recent topic is Being Modern in the 18th century. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P FR 580. 19th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 19th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P FR 590. 20th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 20th-century French literature. Recent topics include African Identities, The French Novel in 2000, Postcolonial Africa. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P FR 592. Francophone Studies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of literary works representative of the Francophone world. Topics may include Francophone African Literature, Quebec Literature, Writing the Haitian Revolution. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits.

CourseID: P FR 597. Francophone Women's Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Developments in literature by women from areas such as Maghreb, the Caribbean, Sub-Saharan Africa, Quebec, the Indian Ocean, and Europe.

CourseID: P ITAL 152. Desire and Resistance: Italian Cinema. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The theories and works of the major Italian filmmakers; topics in Italian history and culture; introduction to film analysis.

CourseID: P ITAL 201. Second-Year Italian. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ITAL 202. Second-Year Italian. 4 Credits.
