CourseID: P ITAL 252. The Italian-American Experience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the Italian-American experience investigating the process of assimilation of Italians into American life through the analysis of different cultural artifacts.

CourseID: P ITAL 301. Cultura e lingua: l'Italia contemporanea. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of Italian history and society since the unification of Italy through the readings of a short novel. Vocabulary enrichment activities and grammar review. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 303. Cultura e lingua: societa, economia, politica. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of Italian society, its economy and politics from 1950 to present. Readings of short stories and magazine articles, viewing of films. Vocabulary enrichment activities and grammar review. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 305. Cultura e lingua: arte, musica, i mass media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Artistic expressions over time and the influence of the mass media on the social structures and language. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 307. Oral Skills. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practice in improving listening, comprehension, and oral skills in Italian. Communicative activities in class in addition to language laboratory work. Repeatable twice for maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: ITAL 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ITAL 317. Italian Survey: Medieval and Renaissance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major themes and ideas in Italian literature and art from the medieval and Renaissance periods. Conducted in Italian. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 318. Italian Survey: Baroque and Enlightenment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major themes and ideas in Italian literature from the baroque and Enlightenment periods through the reading of representative texts. Conducted in Italian. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 319. Italian Survey: 19th and 20th Centuries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative literary works from the 19th and 20th centuries with attention to literary analysis and literary history. Conducted in Italian. Prereq: ITAL 203.

CourseID: P ITAL 320. Intensive Italian Grammar Review. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bridges second- and third-year culture and literature courses. Provides review, synthesis, consolidation, and elaboration of linguistic knowledge gained from lower-division courses. Prereq: ITAL 203.

Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Il canzoniere, Italian Folktales, Italian Epic, Pirandello, Literary Analysis. Prereq: one from ITAL 317, ITAL 318, ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Special group activities such as production of Italian plays.

CourseID: P ITAL 441. Medieval Italian Culture: [Topic]. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural productions of 13th- and 14th-century Italy (e.g., translating Dante, rewriting Boccaccio, chivalric romance) and the history of their interpretation. Conducted in Italian. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ITAL 317 or ITAL 318 or ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 444. Medieval and Renaissance Literature: [Topic]. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on a topic from 13th- to 16th-century Italy (e.g., medieval foundations of the Renaissance, Petrarch and Petrarchism, representations of otherness, Boccaccio and his influence). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ITAL 317 or ITAL 318 or ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 449. Humanism and the Renaissance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers authors who exemplify learning, aesthetics, and ideology of Renaissance Italy (e.g., Ariosto, Castiglione, Colonna, Franco, Leonardo, Machiavelli, Michelangelo, Tasso). Includes essays in criticism and theory. Conducted in Italian. Prereq: ITAL 317 or ITAL 318 or ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 481. 19th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics concerning issues or authors in 19th-century Italian literature (e.g., Irony and Novel, Leopardi and Italian Romanticism). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: ITAL 317 or ITAL 318 or ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 491. 20th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics about issues or figures in 20th-century Italian literature (e.g., Modern Lyric Poetry, Postmodern Narrative). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: ITAL 317 or ITAL 318 or ITAL 319.

CourseID: P ITAL 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Il canzoniere, Italian Folktales, Italian Epic, Pirandello, Literary Analysis.

CourseID: P ITAL 508. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Special group activities such as production of Italian plays. Prereq: ITAL 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ITAL 541. Medieval Italian Culture: [Topic]. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cultural productions of 13th- and 14th-century Italy (e.g., translating Dante, rewriting Boccaccio, chivalric romance) and the history of their interpretation. Conducted in Italian. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P ITAL 544. Medieval and Renaissance Literature: [Topic]. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on a topic from 13th- to 16th-century Italy (e.g., medieval foundations of the Renaissance, Petrarch and Petrarchism, representations of otherness, Boccaccio and his influence). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P ITAL 549. Humanism and the Renaissance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers authors who exemplify learning, aesthetics, and ideology of Renaissance Italy (e.g., Ariosto, Castiglione, Colonna, Franco, Leonardo, Machiavelli, Michelangelo, Tasso). Includes essays in criticism and theory. Conducted in Italian. Prereq: work in literature.

CourseID: P ITAL 581. 19th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics concerning issues or authors in 19th-century Italian literature (e.g., Irony and Novel, Leopardi and Italian Romanticism). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: previous work in literature.

CourseID: P ITAL 591. 20th-Century Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics about issues or figures in 20th-century Italian literature (e.g., Modern Lyric Poetry, Postmodern Narrative). Conducted in Italian. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: previous work in literature.

CourseID: P PORT 101. First-Year Portuguese. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Brazilian Portuguese language and culture, with emphasis on speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills. Sequence with PORT 102, 103.

CourseID: P PORT 102. First-Year Portuguese. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Brazilian Portuguese language and culture, with emphasis on speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills. Sequence with PORT 101, 103. Prereq: PORT 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PORT 103. First Year Portuguese. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Brazilian Portuguese language and culture, with emphasis on speaking, reading, writing and listening comprehension skills. Sequence with PORT 101, 102. Prereq: PORT 102 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PORT 111. Intensive Beginning Portuguese. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P PORT 111 is the first part of a two-quarter sequence (PORT 111, PORT 112) and is an accelerated introductory course, appropriate for students with a high aptitude for language learners and/or for learners who already have some proficiency in another Romance language. Cannot be combined with PORT 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Portuguese.

CourseID: P PORT 111 is the first part of a two-quarter sequence (PORT 111, PORT 112) and is an accelerated introductory course, appropriate for students with a high aptitude for language learners and/or for learners who already have some proficiency in another Romance language. Cannot be combined with PORT 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Portuguese.
Descriptions: P PORT 112. Intensive Beginning Portuguese. 5 Credits.

CourseID: P PORT 112. Intensive Beginning Portuguese. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P PORT 112 is the second part of a two-quarter sequence (PORT 111, PORT 112) and is an accelerated introductory course, appropriate for students with a high aptitude for language learners and/or for learners who already have some proficiency in another Romance language. Cannot be combined with PORT 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Portuguese. Prereq: PORT 111.

CourseID: P PORT 112 is the second part of a two-quarter sequence (PORT 111, PORT 112) and is an accelerated introductory course, appropriate for students with a high aptitude for language learners and/or for learners who already have some proficiency in another Romance language. Cannot be combined with PORT 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Portuguese. Prereq: PORT 111.
Descriptions: P PORT 150. Lusofonia: The Portuguese-Speaking World. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P PORT 150. Lusofonia: The Portuguese-Speaking World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in the history and contemporary cultures of the regions where Portuguese is spoken (Portugal, Brazil, Africa, Asia, and North America).

CourseID: P PORT 201. Second Year Portuguese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of Brazilian Portuguese speaking, reading, writing and comprehension; study of short literary and cultural materials. Sequence with PORT 202, 203. Prereq: PORT 103

CourseID: P PORT 202. Second-Year Portuguese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of Brazilian Portuguese speaking, reading, writing, and comprehension; study of short literary and cultural materials. Sequence with PORT 201, 203. Prereq: PORT 201 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PORT 203. Second-Year Portuguese. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of Brazilian Portuguese speaking, reading, writing, and comprehension; study of short literary and cultural materials. Sequence with PORT 201, 202. Prereq: PORT 202 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PORT 301. Cultura e Lingua: Expressoes Artisticas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills through the study of key representations in Brazilian art, literature, film, and music. Taught in Portuguese. Prereq: PORT 203 or equivalent. Offered alternate years. Prereq: PORT 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PORT 305. Cultura e lingua: Brasil ontem e hoje. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Brazilian history and culture. Topics include geography; indigenous, European, and African presence; trends of authoritarianism and democratization; issues in migration and urbanization; racial and ethnic identities; women’s roles. Taught in Portuguese. Prereq: PORT 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: P RL 404. Bilingual Internship. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Bilingual internship opportunity in area schools or community agencies for students of French or Spanish. Repeatable in another term. Prereq: third-year language competence.

CourseID: P RL 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Changing topics on issues relevant to study in two or more Romance languages. Recent topics include Travel Writing, Testimonial Writing, Caribbean Women Writers. Pre-req: One 300-level literature course in any Romance language.

CourseID: P RL 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Changing topics on issues relevant to study in two or more Romance languages. A recent topic is Travel Literature.

CourseID: P RL 604. Bilingual Internship. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P A bilingual internship opportunity in area schools or community agencies for students of French or Spanish. Repeatable in another term. Prereq: third-year language competence.

CourseID: P RL 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaching Methods offered fall term only. Other workshops may be offered. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P RL 620. Graduate Study in Romance Languages. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Discussion of purposes, problems, and methods of graduate study in Romance languages. Elements of critical method, research techniques, scholarly writing, and professional development.

CourseID: P RL 623. Romance Languages Colloquium: [Topic]. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Seminar organized around a series of speakers exposes students to critical and theoretical issues central to the study of Romance languages and literatures. Repeatable for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 101. First-Year Spanish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on the development of speaking, reading, and writing skills; introduction to Hispanic culture. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish.

CourseID: P SPAN 102. First-Year Spanish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on the development of speaking, reading, and writing skills; introduction to Hispanic culture. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 101.

CourseID: P SPAN 103. First-Year Spanish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on the development of speaking, reading, and writing skills; introduction to Hispanic culture. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 102.

CourseID: P SPAN 111. Intensive Beginning Spanish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study for experienced language learners; introduction to Hispanic culture. Prereq: evidence of placement. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Cannot be combined with SPAN 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Spanish. Prereq: previous study in Spanish or competence in another Romance language.

CourseID: P SPAN 112. Intensive Beginning Spanish. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study for experienced language learners; introduction to Hispanic culture. Prereq: evidence of placement. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Cannot be combined with SPAN 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 111.

CourseID: P SPAN 150. Cultures of the Spanish-Speaking World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Each term, this topics course treats a different aspect of the rich cultural heritage of the Spanish-speaking world. Check the Class Schedule extended description for the current offering. Past topics include: dialects of Spanish; Jewish; Arabic, and Christian relations in medievel Iberia; Hispanic experience in the United States. Conducted in English.

CourseID: P SPAN 201. Second-Year Spanish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of Spanish-language skills; emphasis on diversity of Hispanic cultures. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Prereq: first year language competence.

CourseID: P SPAN 202. Second-Year Spanish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of Spanish-language skills; emphasis on diversity of Hispanic cultures. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 201.

CourseID: P SPAN 203. Second-Year Spanish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continued development of Spanish-language skills; emphasis on diversity of Hispanic cultures. Sequence. Conducted in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 202.

CourseID: P SPAN 218. Latino Heritage I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for heritage learners—students who grew up with Spanish in their community and want to build communication skills in Spanish. Content focuses on personal experiences in U.S. Latino communities.Cannot be combined with SPAN 201, 202, 203 for more than 15 credits of second-year Spanish. Prereq: placement through self-identification or placement by Spanish heritage language placement test.

CourseID: P SPAN 228. Latino Heritage II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for heritage learners—students who grew up with Spanish in their community and want to continue developing communication skills in Spanish. Content focuses on personal experiences in U.S. Latino communities. Cannot be combined with SPAN 201, 202, 203 for more than 15 credits of second-year Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 218 or placement by Spanish heritage language placement test.

CourseID: P SPAN 238. Spanish Around the World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to language variation (dialects) through the study of the places, peoples, history, and social differences that make the Spanish language what it is today. Prereq: SPAN 103 or SPAN 112 or equivalent proficiency in Spanish language.

CourseID: P SPAN 248. Spanglish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates the history and social impact of language contact between English and Spanish in what is now the United States. Taught in English, Spanish, and Spanglish. Prereq: SPAN 103 or SPAN 112. Prereq: SPAN 103 or SPAN 112

CourseID: P SPAN 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P SPAN 301. Cultura y Lengua: Identidades Hispanas. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 301. Cultura y Lengua: Identidades Hispanas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills through analysis of major historical influences in the cultures of Spanish-speaking regions: Spain, Latin America, and the United States. Taught in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 303. Cultura y lengua: expresiones artisticas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills through the study of cultural products (e.g., art, literature, film, music) in Spanish-speaking societies. Taught in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 305. Cultura y lengua: cambios sociales. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced language skills through the investigation of major currents of change in modern Spanish-speaking societies; gender issues, technology, revolution and counter-revolution.Taught in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 307. Oral Skills. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practice in improving listening, comprehension, and oral skills in Spanish. Communicative activities in class in addition to language laboratory work. Repeatable once when content changes for maximum of 4 credits. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 308. Cultura y lengua: comunidades bilingues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for heritage learners—students who grew up with Spanish in their community and want to continue developing communication skills in Spanish. Explores socio-linguistic dynamics of communities in which Spanish is in contact with another language. Open to all students. Taught in Spanish. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 311. Advanced Writing in Spanish. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This requirement for the Spanish major provides additional language development for students early on in the major, emphasizing academic writing skills in Spanish. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 312. Spanish in the Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for heritage learners. Examines the role of Spanish in various forms of media such as television, Internet, and literature. Students practice advanced writing skills necessary to participate in argumentative writing and close textual readings. Prereq: SPAN 308 or any two from SPAN 301, SPAN 303, SPAN 305; SPAN 308 is recommended.

CourseID: P SPAN 320. Intensive Spanish Grammar Review. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review and development of the more complex aspects of Spanish grammar with special attention to idiomatic usage. Prereq: SPAN 203 or 228.

CourseID: P SPAN 322. Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Linguistic description of the Spanish language, including phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax, history, and social and geographical variation. Prereq: SPAN 308; one course from SPAN 301, SPAN 303, SPAN 305, SPAN 311, SPAN 312.

CourseID: P SPAN 324. Spanish Pronunciation and Phonetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of Spanish sounds, rhythms, and intonation; supervised pronunciation practice. Offered alternate years. Prereq: SPAN 308; one course from SPAN 301, SPAN 303, SPAN 305, SPAN 311, SPAN 312.

CourseID: P SPAN 341. Hispanic Cultures through Literature I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a variety of texts written in the Hispanic world in their literary, artistic, and historical contexts, from 1100 to 1600. Series with SPAN 342, 343, 344. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 342. Hispanic Cultures through Literature II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a variety of texts written in the Hispanic world in their literary, artistic, and historical contexts, from the 16th century to the Latin American independences. Series with SPAN 341, 343, 344. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 343. Hispanic Cultures through Literature III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a variety of texts written in the Hispanic world in their literary, artistic, and historical contexts, from the revolutionary wars to the Spanish Civil War. Series with SPAN 341, 342, 344. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 344. Hispanic Cultures through Literature IV. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to a variety of texts written in the Hispanic world in their literary, artistic, and historical contexts, from the 20th century into the 21st. Series with SPAN 341, 342, 343. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 348. United States Latino Literature and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to Hispanic literature written in the United States. Close reading and discussion of selected texts by Hispanic authors; emphasis on literary trends and themes. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 350. Introduction to Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores important aspects of Spanish poetry; reading poems from different periods of Spanish and Spanish American literature. Emphasizes formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 351. Introduction to Theater. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores important aspects of Spanish theater; reading plays from different periods of Spanish and Spanish American literature. Emphasizes formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 353. Introduction to Narrative. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores important aspects of Spanish narrative; reading texts from different periods of Spanish and Spanish American literature. Emphasizes formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: two from SPAN 301, 303, 305, 308.

CourseID: P SPAN 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Golden Age Theater, Latin American Film, Medieval Iberian, Mexican Literature and Culture, 19th-Century Spanish Decadence, Postwar Spain, Testimonial Literature. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Special on-campus activities in Spanish.

CourseID: P SPAN 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Literature and Democratic Transition, Race in Modern Los Angeles, Social Roots of Creativity.

CourseID: P SPAN 420. Spanish Linguistics: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Variable topics in Spanish linguistics, including advanced grammar, history of the Spanish language, the language of Iberia, Spanish sociolinguistics. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: Two from SPAN 320, 322, 324.

CourseID: P SPAN 424. History of the Spanish Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Linguistic changes and social-historical influences on the development of Spanish from its roots in Latin to the diversity of modern dialects. Offered alternate years. Prereq: Two from SPAN 320, 322, 324.

CourseID: P SPAN 425. Literary Translation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Variable topics include con textos, first issues, and cultural translationtransculturation in practice. Prereq: SPAN 311 or SPAN 312; one course from SPAN 320, SPAN 322, SPAN 324, SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 428. Spanish in the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The history and description of the linguistic characteristics of and narratives about the use of Spanish within the United States. Offered alternate years. Prereq: two from SPAN 320, SPAN 322, SPAN 324.

CourseID: P SPAN 431. Medieval Iberian Literature and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics on the literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula from the 12th through the 16th centuries. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Offered alternate years. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 432. Spanish Islamic Literature and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics on the Islamic literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula from the 12th through the 17th centuries. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 433. Sephardic Literature and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics on the literature and culture of the Sephardic Jews from the 12th through the 20th centuries. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SPAN 437. Contemporary Latin American Verse: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major aesthetic trends, authors, and works in contemporary Latin American poetry. Topics include avant-garde poetry, poetry and subjectivity, poetry and modernism. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 448. National Identities and Border Cultures in the Americas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines 19th and 21st century national formation and alternative forms of collective identity in the Americas through literary texts, historical documents and film. Offered alternate years. Prereq: SPAN 311 or 312; and two from SPAN 320, SPAN 322, SPAN 324, SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344, SPAN 348.

CourseID: P SPAN 450. Colonial Latin American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative works of Colonial Latin America. Recent topics include Mestizaje, Colonial Theater, Colonial Literature, Carlos Fuentes. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 451. Sor Juana and Her Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The debate on women and the woman intellectual; aesthetic definitions and the social meaning of Renaissance and baroque. Taught in Spanish. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 452. Renaissance and Baroque Poetry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Petrarchism of Garcilaso and Herrera; traditional forms, especially the romance; poetry of Fray Luis de Leon, San Juan de la Cruz, Santa Teresa, Gongora, Lope de Vega, and Quevedo. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 460. Don Quixote. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Careful reading of "Don Quixote" along with discussion of major critical topics and of its place and importance in literary history. Prereq: three from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 466. Introduction to Spanish Golden Age. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of major figures and cultural issues in the Spanish Golden Age, c. 1500s–1700s. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 480. 19th-Century Spanish American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include issue of literary periods, authors, narrative and nation, genres, and indigenismo. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344.

CourseID: P SPAN 490. 20th-Century Latin American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major literary trends, authors, and works. Recent topics are Avant-garde in the Mexican Revolution, Testimonial Literature, Latin American Theater. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: SPAN 311 or SPAN 312; and two from SPAN 341, SPAN 342, SPAN 343, SPAN 344

CourseID: P SPAN 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Golden Age Theater, Latin American Film, Medieval Iberian, Mexican Literature and Culture, 19th-Century Spanish Decadence, Postwar Spain, Testimonial Literature.

Descriptions: P SPAN 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Literature and Democratic Transition, Race in Modern Los Angeles, Social Roots of Creativity.

CourseID: P SPAN 520. Spanish Linguistics: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Variable topics in Spanish linguistics. Recent topics include Spanish Phonology, History of the Spanish Language. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P SPAN 524. History of the Spanish Language. 4 Credits.

Descriptions: P Variable topics include con textos, first issues, and cultural translationtransculturation in practice. Prereq: SPAN 420/520 recommended.

CourseID: P SPAN 528. Spanish in the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The history and description of the linguistic characteristics of and narratives about the use of Spanish within the United States. Offered alternate years.

Descriptions: P Selected topics on the literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula from the 12th through the 16th centuries. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Offered alternate years.

Descriptions: P Examines 19th and 21st century national formation and alternative forms of collective identity in the Americas through literary texts, historical documents and film. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SPAN 550. Colonial Latin American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative works of Colonial Latin America. Recent topics include Mestizaje, Colonial Theater, Colonial Literature, Carlos Fuentes. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 551. Sor Juana and Her Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The debate on women and the woman intellectual; aesthetic definitions and the social meaning of Renaissance and baroque. Taught in Spanish.

Descriptions: P Petrarchism of Garcilaso and Herrera; traditional forms, especially the romance; poetry of Fray Luis de Leon, San Juan de la Cruz, Santa Teresa, Gongora, Lope de Vega, and Quevedo.

CourseID: P SPAN 566. Introduction to Spanish Golden Age. 4 Credits.

Descriptions: P Topics include issue of literary periods, authors, narrative and nation, genres, and indigenismo. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 590. 20th-Century Latin American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major literary trends, authors, and works. Recent topics are Avant-garde in the Mexican Revolution, Latin American Theater. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 680. Advanced 19th-Century Spanish American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected Latin American topics from literary periods, authors, genres, and aesthetic trends. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SPAN 690. Advanced 20th-Century Latin American Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics from literary periods, authors, genres, and aesthetic trends. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 202. Second-Year Russian. 5 Credits.

Descriptions: P Analysis of short stories by important 19th and 20th century Russian writers in the context of social political and literary development. Readings in English. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P RUSS 334. Dostoevsky. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the novels and short stories of Dostoevsky. His literary, ethical, and political development. Readings and instruction in English.

CourseID: P RUSS 335. Tolstoy. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 351. Russian Literature and Film. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 2-4 Credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 534. Russian Literature: [Topic]. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P RUSS 540. Russian Phonology and Morphology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Russian phonology and morphology (sound system and word formation) Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P RUSS 545. Old Church Slavonic. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P WR 121 College Composition I
Descriptions: P SOC 204 Introduction to Sociology or SOC or Social Inequality 207

CourseID: P SOC 204 Introduction to Sociology or SOC or Social Inequality 207
Descriptions: P General-education course in arts and letters

CourseID: P SOC 204. Introduction to Sociology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The sociological perspective with emphasis on fundamental concepts, theories, and methods of research.

CourseID: P SOC 207. Social Inequality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of social inequality, cross-culturally and within the United States. Examines relationship of social inequality based on social class, race, and gender to social change, social institutions, and self-identity.

CourseID: P SOC 301. American Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected aspects of American culture and institutions and the ways in which they are changing. Prereq: SOC 204 recommended.

CourseID: P SOC 303. World Population. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to population studies. Comparative analysis of historical, contemporary, and anticipated demographic change. Emphasis on demographic transitions between and within developed and underdeveloped countries.

CourseID: P SOC 304. Community, Environment, and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interrelationship of social and environmental factors in human communities, processes of community change, impact of environmental change on human communities.

CourseID: P SOC 310. Social Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the major writers and ideas that have shaped contemporary sociology. Focus on recurrent concepts and issues that continue to challenge sociological inquiry.

CourseID: P SOC 311. Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The development of social research; the nature of scientific inquiry and basic methods and techniques; examination of representative sociological studies from the standpoint of methodology. Prereq: SOC 204 or SOC 207.

CourseID: P SOC 312. Statistical Analysis in Sociology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Construction and interpretation of tables and graphs, descriptive statistics, measures of association and contingency relationships, basic ideas of probability, and elementary statistical inference applied to nonexperimental research.

CourseID: P SOC 313. Social Issues and Movements. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contemporary social issues viewed in relation to the social structure of American society. Social movements and ideologies related to these issues.

CourseID: P SOC 317. Sociology of the Mass Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of media events: advertisements, news broadcasts, documentaries, popular music, and television. Perspectives include content analysis, semiotics, functionalist and structuralist paradigms, and power system analysis.

CourseID: P SOC 328. Self and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How the thought, feeling, and behavior of individuals influence and are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.

CourseID: P SOC 330. Sociology of the Family. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to and historical perspective of the family as a social institution and small-group association. Prereq: SOC 204 or 207.

CourseID: P SOC 345. Race and Ethnicity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the major racial and ethnic groups in the United States with special attention to social interactions and inequalities.

CourseID: P SOC 346. Work and Occupations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Characteristics of work and occupational careers in modern societies; relationships of those to family, the economy, bureaucracy, technology, and alienation.

CourseID: P SOC 347. Complex Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nature of organizations in modern societies (e.g., specialization, impersonality, formalization, authority, and power); relationship of organizations to work and careers, stratification, democracy, discrimination, and deviance.

CourseID: P SOC 355. Sociology of Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Position of women in contemporary society; women and work, politics, families, the economy; intersection of gender, race, and class; women's movements.

CourseID: P SOC 370. Urban Sociology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the growth of cities; urban inequalities, politics, and social movements; built environment, ecology, and sustainability of cities and identity; global cities and immigration.

CourseID: P SOC 380. Introduction: Deviance, Control, and Crime. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origins of rules and laws, patterns of reactions to their violation, emphasis on causal theories of deviance and of crime, data sources for study of crime.

CourseID: P SOC 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year depending on student needs and faculty interests. Prereq: SOC 204 or SOC 207.

CourseID: P SOC 412. Sociological Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Descriptive and inferential statistics, including multiple regression.

CourseID: P SOC 413. Sociological Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced statistical techniques focusing on generalized linear models. Prereq: SOC 412.

CourseID: P SOC 416. Issues in Environmental Sociology [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of selected topics in environmental sociology. Topics include environmental movement, impacts of technological change, environmental policy and the state, environmental values, attitudes, and behaviors. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 420. Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the fundamentals of political economy. Readings from Marxian and mainstream traditions introduce contemporary debates on socioeconomic crisis.

CourseID: P SOC 425. Issues in Sociology of Family: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of selected topics in the sociology of the family. Topics include the sociology of parenthood, feminist perspectives on the family, and the family in cross-cultural perspective. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when topic changes. Prereq: SOC 330.

CourseID: P SOC 442. Issues in Urban Sociology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Determinants and consequences of urbanization under different conditions; the city as a social and ecological system. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 445. Sociology of Race and Ethnicity: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced analysis of selected topics in sociology of race/ethnicity. Topics vary. Examples include Asian Americans, Latinos, mixed race, racial oppression, residential segregation, and the post-civil rights era. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: SOC 310, SOC 311.

CourseID: P SOC 446. Issues in Sociology of Work: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selected topics in sociology of work: occupational structures and careers, industrial democracy; technological change and work reform, politics of work. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 447. Issues in Sociology of Organizations: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of selected topics in the sociology of organizations. Topics include industrial sociology, organizational change; organizational democracy; corporate deviance; bureaucracy, power, and society. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 450. Sociology of Developing Areas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social and economic structures and processes promoting or inhibiting change in the developing nations of Africa, Asia, Latin America. Topics include urbanization, industrialization, cultural change, world poverty, and dependence.

CourseID: P SOC 451. Social Stratification. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The interrelations among class, race, and sex. Historical origins and development of class and class systems including slavery. Prereq: SOC 310, 311, 312.

CourseID: P SOC 452. Issues of Migration: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Sociological analysis of migration, including dynamics of race and ethnicity, social structure, and social policy. Examines assimilation, marginalization, multiculturalism, postcolonialism, and social cohesion. Repeatable twice when the topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits. Offered alternate years. Prereq: SOC 310.

CourseID: P SOC 455. Issues in Sociology of Gender: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced analysis of gender and social relations of power in contemporary society. Variable topics include Women and Health; Violence against Women. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 456. Feminist Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines major sociological theories that elucidate the position of women and gender as part of the configuration of social relations of power in contemporary societies.

CourseID: P SOC 457. Sex and Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines alternative sociological perspectives on sexual behavior, the social construction and regulation of sexuality, contemporary social and political issues pertaining to sexuality. Prereq: SOC 310.

CourseID: P SOC 464. Systems of War and Peace. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Violence and nonviolence as functions of social structures and as instruments of social change. Systems of international threat, their supporting institutions, and the ideology of nationalism.

CourseID: P SOC 465. Political Sociology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of political theory and behavior, social bases of power and policy determination, institutional interrelationships, intellectuals and ideologies, political trends and change, political participation and membership.

CourseID: P SOC 467. Economic Sociology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applies the sociological perspective to basic economic phenomena such as markets, exchange, prices, money and rationality. Prereq: SOC 310.

CourseID: P SOC 475. Marxist Sociological Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic concepts, theory, and social analysis in the works of Marx and Engels. Topics include dialectical and historical materialism, class, historical development, political economy, and imperialism.

CourseID: P SOC 480. Crime and Social Control. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes definitions of crimes, major substantive areas of crime, and control policies in the United States.

CourseID: P SOC 484. Issues in Deviance, Control, and Crime: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics vary. Examples are modern policing, juvenile delinquency, correction, emerging forms of social control. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year depending on student needs and faculty interests.

CourseID: P SOC 512. Sociological Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Descriptive and inferential statistics, including multiple regression.

CourseID: P SOC 513. Sociological Research Methods. 4 Credits.

Descriptions: P Topics vary. Examples are modern policing, juvenile delinquency, correction, emerging forms of social control. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Proseminar required for all incoming Sociology graduate students. Professional socialization and preparation for the discipline.

CourseID: P SOC 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A current topic is Master's Project.

CourseID: P SOC 612. Overview of Sociological Methods. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the research process--framing research questions, qualitative and quantitative design, relationships between methods and theory, deductive and inductive investigation logic, research ethics, sampling procedures, explanatory power.

CourseID: P SOC 613. Advanced Sociological Methods: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major methodological topics such as comparative, demographic, experimental, field, historical, and survey methods. Other possible topics include time-series analysis. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits. Prereq: SOC 612 or equivalent.

CourseID: P SOC 615. Advanced Sociological Theory: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major sociological theories such as modern functionalism, contemporary Marxism, phenomenology, postmodernism, feminist and organizational theory. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 616. Environment and Resource Issues: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores issues of environmental sociology and resource policy, including ecological crisis; environmental justice as it pertains to race, gender, class, and international inequality. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 617. Sociological Theory I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Sociological theories of the 19th century (especially Marx, Weber, and Durkheim) and 20th century (e.g., modern functionalism, feminist, neo-Marxism, neo-Weberian, poststructuralist theories).

CourseID: P SOC 618. Sociological Theory II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major themes and historical foundation of contemporary sociological theory. Prereq: SOC 617.

CourseID: P SOC 621. Teaching in the Social Sciences. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares graduate students to teach their own classes. Covers pedagogy and develops practical skills. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SOC 644. Race and Ethnicity Issues: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores current reseach and theoretical debates, such as Chicano-Chicana and Latino-Latina studies, in the sociology of race and ethnicity. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 656. Issues in Sociology of Gender: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines sociological theories of gender, focusing on a particular substantive area such as health, work, family, or sexuality. Explores gender in relation to race, ethnicity, and class. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P SOC 664. Political and Economic Sociology Issues: [Topic]. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between economic institutions and political processes. Sample topics include theories of modern capitalism, corporations and the state, development and underdevelopment, war and peace. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P TA 121. Scenery and Lighting Laboratory. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Building and painting scenery, hanging lights for productions. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P TA 122. Costume Laboratory. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Building costumes for productions. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P TA 124. Production. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Working backstage for productions. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P TA 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Freshman seminars.

CourseID: P TA 210. Introduction to Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the principles of design as applied to the arts of theater design, scenery, costumes, and lighting. Creative projects to develop concepts of visual imagery. Includes laboratory.

CourseID: P TA 211. Theater Production I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the mechanics of mounting a theatrical production including basic construction of scenery and props and use of lighting equipment. Includes laboratory.

CourseID: P TA 212. Theater Production II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to costumes and makeup. Costume construction includes basic hand and machine sewing techniques. Beginning makeup covers ingenue, beards, wounds, and fantasy. Includes laboratory.

CourseID: P TA 250. Acting I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of warm-ups, individual inventory, Stanislavski system, character analysis, and rehearsal procedure.

CourseID: P TA 251. Acting II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continuation of performance principles for contemporary realistic theater with addition of dramaturgical scene study.

CourseID: P TA 252. Acting III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of improvisational skills while establishing a working file of monologue material.

CourseID: P TA 271. Introduction to Theater Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Play and script structure, contemporary aesthetic attitudes, and the value of theater arts to society and the individual.

CourseID: P TA 321. Scenery Production. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Production or performance crew head for scenery. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: TA 211

CourseID: P TA 322. Costume Production. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Production or performance crew head for costumes. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: TA 212

CourseID: P TA 323. Lighting Production. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Production or performance crew head for lighting. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: TA 211

CourseID: P TA 324. Production. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Stage manager, assistant director, or dramaturgy position. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P TA 325. Performance. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Preparation, rehearsal, and performance of an acting role. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P TA 367. History of the Theater I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the theater from its origins to the present. Emphasizes the history of dramatic literature, criticism, theater architecture, design, and performance.

CourseID: P TA 368. History of the Theater II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the theater from its origins to the present. Emphasizes the history of dramatic literature, criticism, theater architecture, design, and performance.

CourseID: P TA 369. History of the Theater III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the theater from its origins to the present. Emphasizes the history of dramatic literature, criticism, theater architecture, design, and performance.

Descriptions: P Repeatable nine times when the topic changes for a maximum of 40 credits.

CourseID: P TA 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable nine times when the topic changes for a maximum of 40 credits.

CourseID: P TA 406. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for a maximum of 48 credits.

CourseID: P TA 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P TA 411. Costume History I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Egyptian to Renaissance.

CourseID: P TA 412. Costume History II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Mid-Renaissance to romanticism.

CourseID: P TA 413. Costume History III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Victorian to the present.

CourseID: P TA 416. Costume Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Beginning design concepts and various artistic media as applicable to costume design and rendering techniques. Prereq: TA 210.

CourseID: P TA 417. Advanced Costume Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and interpretation of scripts for costume design. Continuation of development of rendering techniques. Prereq: TA 416.

CourseID: P TA 418. Costume Pattern Drafting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing patterns through flat patterning and draping techniques. Practical experience in pattern development and execution. Prereq: TA 212.

CourseID: P TA 419. Costume Construction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical problems encountered in building and decorating costumes for the stage. Prereq: TA 212.

CourseID: P TA 420. Return and Review for Actors. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Review foundational concepts and technique by participating, demonstrating, and coaching in Acting I or II. Repeatable for Acting I (TA 250) only once; for Acting II (TA 251) only once. Prereq: TA 250, 251, 252. Coreq: TA 409.

CourseID: P TA 441. Scene Design: Single Set. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elements of scene design; the scene designer's role. Creating a ground plan, measured perspective techniques, elevations, design styles. Design process and procedures related to the proscenium stage only. Prereq: TA 210.

CourseID: P TA 445. Advanced Projects in Theater Technology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Specialized areas of theater technology, one topic per term. Topics include scene painting, stage management, props, and computer drafting. Repeatable seven times when topic changes for maximum of 32 credits.

CourseID: P TA 452. Advanced Acting: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in the performance of a specific genre or authors, or in specific performance technique, including voice, movement, and musical skills. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: TA 252, 271; one from TA 210, 211, 212.

CourseID: P TA 467. Lighting for the Stage. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing lighting for the stage; technical and aesthetic problems.

CourseID: P TA 470. Majors Seminar. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Capstone seminar for junior theater majors; readings and research in new theater trends, aesthetics, professional and higher academic opportunities.

CourseID: P TA 471. Studies in Theater and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dramatic literature and historical cultural concepts. Establishes a cultural context for periods of drama, using arts materials and socioeconomic factors to clarify aesthetic attitudes and practices of theater. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits.

CourseID: P TA 472. Multicultural Theater: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origins and development of contributions in theater and drama by various cultures including Latino, Chicano, African American, Asian American, and Native American. Repeatable four times when topic changes for maximum of 20 credits.

CourseID: P TA 490. Theater Capstone: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Required for the major and may be fulfilled by successful completion of any one of four topics: Play Direction, Playwriting, Dramaturgy, Devising. Prereq: TA 210, TA 211, TA 212, TA 250, TA 271, and one from the theatre history series: TA 367, TA 368, TA 369.

CourseID: P TA 511. Costume History I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Egyptian to Renaissance.

CourseID: P TA 512. Costume History II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Mid-Renaissance to romanticism.

CourseID: P TA 513. Costume History III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History of Western clothing in cultural context. Victorian to the present.

CourseID: P TA 516. Costume Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Beginning design concepts and various artistic media as applicable to costume design and rendering techniques.

CourseID: P TA 517. Advanced Costume Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and interpretation of scripts for costume design. Continuation of development of rendering techniques. Prereq: TA 416/516.

CourseID: P TA 518. Costume Pattern Drafting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing patterns through flat patterning and draping techniques. Practical experience in pattern development and execution.

CourseID: P TA 519. Costume Construction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Practical problems encountered in building and decorating costumes for the stage.

CourseID: P TA 541. Scene Design: Single Set. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elements of scene design; the scene designer's role. Creating a ground plan, measured perspective techniques, elevations, design styles. Design process and procedures related to the proscenium stage only.

CourseID: P TA 545. Advanced Projects in Theater Technology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Specialized areas of theater technology, one topic per term. Topics include scene painting, stage management, props, and computer drafting. Repeatable seven times when topic changes for maximum of 32 credits.

CourseID: P TA 552. Advanced Acting: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics in the performance of a specific genre or authors, or in specific performance technique, including voice, movement, and musical skills. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P TA 567. Lighting for the Stage. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing lighting for the stage; technical and aesthetic problems.

CourseID: P TA 571. Studies in Theater and Culture: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dramatic literature and historical cultural concepts. Establishes a cultural context for periods of drama, using arts materials and socioeconomic factors to clarify aesthetic attitudes and practices of theater. Repeatable thrice when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits.

CourseID: P TA 572. Multicultural Theater: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Origins and development of contributions in theater and drama by various cultures including Latino, Chicano, African American, Asian American, and Native American. Repeatable four times when topic changes for maximum of 20 credits.

CourseID: P TA 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rehearsal and Performance is a current topic. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 18 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 101 Introduction to Women's and Gender 4 Studies WR 121 College Composition I
Descriptions: P 4 PEMA 116 Women's Self Defense 2

CourseID: P WGS 303 Women and Gender in American
Descriptions: P 4 General-education course in social science

CourseID: P WGS 511 Feminist Praxis WGS 522 Sexuality Studies: [Topic] WGS 532 Gender, Environment, and Development WGS 551 Global Perspectives on Gender [Topic] WGS 605
Descriptions: P Reading and Conference: [Topic] 1 WGS 607 Seminar: [Topic] WGS 609

CourseID: P WGS 101. Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interdisciplinary examination of the diverse experiences, status, and contributions of women in the United States. Topics include social construction of gender, race, sexualities, work, class, violence, and health.

CourseID: P WGS 201. Introduction to Queer Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the study of sexuality and society from a queer studies interdisciplinary perspective.

CourseID: P WGS 221. Bodies and Power. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on gender, the body, and dis/ability as a particular nexus of experience and social meaning, influenced as well by race, sexuality, age and class. This course considers bodies and how we understand them within contexts shaped by social relations and systems of power.

CourseID: P WGS 250. Gender, Literature, and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines literary and other cultural representations of gendered experiences using novels, short stories, poetry, plays, and visual cultural production.

CourseID: P WGS 251. Transnational and Indigenous Feminisms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory survey of transnational and Indigenous feminist scholarship, two intersecting strains of feminism that address the workings of culture, nationalism, and gender in multiple contexts. Explores cross-section of key issues and perspectives using interdisciplinary lenses and methodologies employed by scholars in transnational and Indigenous studies.

CourseID: P WGS 303. Women and Gender in American History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on women and gender in America, highlighting how diverse women have experienced gender roles and sexism since the 17th century.

CourseID: P WGS 315. History and Development of Feminist Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Feminist theory from the Enlightenment through the Second Wave, with special emphasis on the diverse theories of the 1960s to the present. Prereq: WGS 101.

CourseID: P WGS 321. Feminist Perspectives: Identity, Race, Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines intersections of race and ethnicity, class, sexuality, and gender in the history and lives of United States women of color. Explores definitions of community, culture, and identity. Prereq: one course WGS or ES 101.

CourseID: P WGS 322. Queer Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys key terms and texts of the interdisciplinary fields that constitute queer theory; recent debates in scholarship and popular culture on gender, sexuality, race, disability, and other identities.

CourseID: P WGS 331. Science, Technology, and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include the role of gender in the practice of science and the impact of sexism and racism on the development of science and technology. Prereq: WGS 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P WGS 341. Women, Work, and Class. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores contexts and cultural attitudes shaping the women's market and domestic labor including race, sexuality, age, and class as well as occupational segregation and control.

CourseID: P WGS 350. Literature as Feminist Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analyzes literary and media texts while considering questions and intersections of race, gender, sexuality, ability, class, nation, culture, and power central to the field of women and gender studies, and demonstrates how these intersections within literary texts are sites of knowledge production in feminist theory. Prereq: one 200 level WGS course.

CourseID: P WGS 351. Decolonial Feminisms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of feminist activism and women’s movements globally, organizing to challenge the state, civil society, international agencies, and corporations for a more just world. Prereq: one 200-level WGS course.

CourseID: P WGS 361. Gender, Film, and the Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students read, view, examine, discuss, and write about film and media in terms of gender and feminist and queer theory. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P WGS 403. Thesis. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable with program director's and thesis adviser's consent for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 406. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P A current topic is Feminist Research Issues. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P WGS 411. Feminist Praxis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Combined internship and seminar explores the history and politics of community agencies and the relationship of feminist theory to practice. Prereq: one course WGS or equivalent.

CourseID: P WGS 421. Bodies and Embodiment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the complex relationships between gender, bodies, and society from theoretical and empirical perspectives. Theories examine the body through an intersectional lens to understand social construction, cultural symbolism, and political struggles, especially within institutional contexts like the media, medicine, and the market. Prereq: one 300-level WGS course.

CourseID: P WGS 422. Sexuality Studies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Various topics in sexuality studies, including the relationship between gender and sexuality and between queer studies and women's and gender studies. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: WGS 101 or 201.

CourseID: P WGS 432. Gender, Environment, and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys gender and political, economic, and cultural strategies for development and environmental change around the world. Pre- or coreq: WGS 101.

CourseID: P WGS 450. Literature and Feminist World-Making. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines feminist world-making in literary texts as a form of political theory, a strategy for thinking critically about the present, imagining the world under different circumstances, and building an alternative world from a feminist perspective. Prereq: one 300-level WGS course.

CourseID: P WGS 451. Global Perspectives on Gender [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed to deepen understanding of diverse global issues and perspectives related to women’s and gender studies. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P A current topic is Feminist Research Issues. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P WGS 511. Feminist Praxis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Combined internship and seminar explores the history and politics of community agencies and the relationship of feminist theory to practice. Prereq: one course WGS or equivalent.

CourseID: P WGS 521. Bodies and Embodiment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the complex relationships between gender, bodies, and society from theoretical and empirical perspectives. Theories examine the body through an intersectional lens to understand social construction, cultural symbolism, and political struggles, especially within institutional contexts like the media, medicine, and the market.

CourseID: P WGS 522. Sexuality Studies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Various topics in sexuality studies, including the relationship between gender and sexuality and between queer studies and women's and gender studies. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 532. Gender, Environment, and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys gender and political, economic, and cultural strategies for development and environmental change around the world.

CourseID: P WGS 550. Literature and Feminist World-Making. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines feminist world-making in literary texts as a form of political theory, a strategy for thinking critically about the present, imagining the world under different circumstances, and building an alternative world from a feminist perspective.

CourseID: P WGS 551. Global Perspectives on Gender [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed to deepen understanding of diverse global issues and perspectives related to women’s and gender studies. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P WGS 615. Contemporary Feminist Theory. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P This interdisciplinary graduate seminar covers foundational texts as well as critical cutting-edge developments in feminist theory. The course centers intersectional, transnational, and de-colonial theoretical frameworks.
