CourseID: P BA 101. Introduction to Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical, social, political, economic, and legal environments within which business operates. Interrelationships of the functional areas of management, finance, marketing, accounting, and international studies.

CourseID: P BA 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P BA 215. Accounting: Language of Business Decisions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How the accounting model reflects business transactions or events. Interpretation and analysis of financial statements. Understanding cost and revenue information, organization, and decisions. Prereq: BA 101.

CourseID: P BA 240. Managing Business Information. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Data-oriented approaches for structuring and analyzing information, with applications in the traditional functional areas of business, emphasizing modern techniques for developing fact-based decision models. Sophomore standing required.

CourseID: P BA 308. Leadership and Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Personal leadership and communication skills. Focuses on self-awareness for leading, persuading, and working with others; effective business writing and speaking; and team development. Students may not receive credit both BA 308 and BA 308H. Sophomore standing required. Prereq: C- or better in BA 101, WR 121; WR 122 or WR 123.

CourseID: P BA 308H. Leadership and Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Personal leadership and communication skills. Focuses on self-awareness for leading, persuading, and working with others; effective business writing and speaking; and team development. Students may not receive credit both BA 308 and BA 308H. Open only to students in the LCB Honors Program. Prereq: C- or better in BA 101, WR 121; WR 122 or WR 123.

CourseID: P BA 315. Economy, Industry, and Competitive Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Free enterprise capitalism and market competition. Economic value added, product cost, and product pricing. Organizational arrangements and the control of economic activity. Prereq: BA 101.

CourseID: P BA 316. Management: Creating Value through People. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Management systems for planning, controlling, organizing, and leading; how they influence human behavior in organizations. Selecting, training, retaining, and motivating the human resource in organization. Prereq: BA 101.

CourseID: P BA 317. Marketing: Creating Value for Customers. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Market analysis, target customer identification, and development of marketing-mix strategies to deliver superior customer value and contribute to the performance of the organization. Prereq: BA 101.

CourseID: P BA 318. Finance: Creating Value through Capital. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Financial statement analysis, pro forma statements and capital budgeting, time value of money, net present-value analysis, risk and cost of capital. Prereq: BA 101; BA 215 or ACTG 211.

CourseID: P BA 352. Leadership and Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Personal leadership and communication skills. Focuses on self-awareness for leading, persuading, and working with others; effective business writing and speaking; and team development. Students may not receive credit both BA 352 and BA 352H. Prereq: accounting and business administration majors only.

CourseID: P BA 352H. Leadership and Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops essential business leadership behaviors, including self-awareness, critical thinking, supportive communication, creative problem solving, building power, and influence. Students may not receive credit both BA 352 and BA 352H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P BA 361. Cross-Cultural Business Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical and practical approach to value dimensions across cultures and their impact on communication in business and professional contexts. Develops intercultural business communication skills. Prereq: WR 121 recommended.

CourseID: P BA 362. Effective Business Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and practice of writing effectively for U.S. and international business audiences; use of rhetorical, cultural, and organizational analysis to create persuasive business documents. Designed for nonnative speakers of English. Prereq: WR 121 recommended.

CourseID: P BA 363. Effective Business Presentations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contrastive rhetoric approach to business presentations in U.S. and international settings. Students research and learn to present effectively for different purposes and global audiences. Designed for nonnative speakers of English. Prereq: WR 121 recommended.

CourseID: P BA 364. International Business Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P International, cross-cultural perspective to communicating information. Presents language, concepts, and strategies needed to conduct international business research and guidelines for communicating research findings.

CourseID: P BA 365. Cross-Cultural Negotiation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and practice of negotiating effectively across cultures. Research and analysis of culturally specific models for negotiating and experience using those models in cross-cultural simulations. Prereq: WR 121 recommended.

CourseID: P BA 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P BA 406. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.

CourseID: P BA 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P BA 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.

CourseID: P BA 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P BA 453. Business Strategy and Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Capstone course focusing on strategy formulation and decisional processes. Includes writing a business plan that applies knowledge and develops course of action to accomplish organizational objectives. Students cannot receive credit for both BA 453 and BA 453H. Prereq: completion of 300-level business core courses, senior standing.

CourseID: P BA 453H. Business Strategy and Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides conceptual tools for in-depth strategic analysis and interactive discussions from sources relevant to the challenge of developing and implementing strategy. Students cannot receive credit for both BA 453 and BA 453H. Prereq: completion of 300-level business core courses, senior standing. Open only to students in the LCB honors program;

CourseID: P BA 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P BA 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P BA 661. Oregon Advanced Strategy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines advanced strategic analysis in corporate setting and integrates multidisciplinary values such as sustainability, product-service excellence, cultural values, financial strength, advanced marketing, entrepreneurial thinking, customer relationship management, big data analytics. This course is taught through the C-level practitioner’s perspective. Prereq: MGMT 614.

CourseID: P BA 711. Legal Environment of Business. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of government policy and the legal environment in which business operates; the effects of law, government policy, and social forces on the formulation of business strategy and decision-making.

CourseID: P BA 712. Financial Accounting and Reporting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Preparation, interpretation, and use of external financial statements and reports. Covers basic accounting principles, recording and reporting techniques underlying valuation and income determination. Series with BA 714.

CourseID: P BA 713. Applied Statistics for Managers. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exposure to descriptive statistics, decision analysis, regression analysis, and forecasting. Emphasis on when and how to use statistics. Integrates statistical tools used to analyze business data with microcomputers.

CourseID: P BA 714. Managerial Accounting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to cost accounting terminology; costing strategies, nontraditional costing systems, activity-based costing and product-service costing applications. Series with BA 712.

CourseID: P BA 715. Managerial Economics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers micro- and macroeconomic analyses and the concepts of cost, demand, profit, and competition. Examines monetary and fiscal policy, the Federal Reserve System, and money and capital markets.

CourseID: P BA 716. Managing Organizations. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Organizations as complex social systems; leadership; managing individuals, groups, and teams; formal and informal processes and systems.

CourseID: P BA 717. Marketing Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines marketing analysis and planning necessary to develop marketing plans and strategies for a product-line. Includes basic marketing concepts and philosophies and brief exposure to macromarketing strategies. Series with BA 719.

CourseID: P BA 718. Financial Analysis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers objectives, tools, methods, and problems of financial management. Includes fund acquisitions, dividend policy, capital acquisitions, taxes, mergers, and investment banking. Series with BA

CourseID: P BA 719. Marketing Strategy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Marketing strategies for product-service introduction, growth, maturity, and decline; managing product-service innovation and development; brand equity, relationship marketing. Series with BA 717.

CourseID: P BA 720. Corporate Financial Strategy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in firm evaluation (e.g., acquisitions, restructuring) and financial risk management (e.g., hedging, derivatives, foreign projects) as related to global and domestic corporate strategies. Series with BA 718.

CourseID: P BA 722. Leadership and Motivation. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on elements of motivation and leadership that affect management decision-making and problem-solving.

CourseID: P BA 723. Formulating Corporate Strategy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on how corporations choose to compete. Covers the analytical techniques and planning models appropriate for making this fundamental decision.

CourseID: P BA 725. Implementing Corporate Strategy. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Uses problems and cases to examine the implementation of corporate strategy, the strategy process and cycle, and implementation methods.

CourseID: P BA 726. Global Business. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines global competition and strategy, regional economic integration, cross-cultural challenges, foreign market entry, international joint ventures and strategic alliances, international dimensions in functional areas of business.

CourseID: P BA 727. Operations Management. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines methods and processes for providing a competitive advantage through continuous quality and process improvements, supplier management, and efficient production of goods and services.

CourseID: P BA 729. Negotiation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the major theories and concepts of negotiation. Opportunities to practice deal-making and conflict resolution. Encourages improvement in communication and persuasion.

CourseID: P BA 730. Business Ethics. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Studies the derivation of values and the application of those values to individual choices. Emphasizes the conflict manager's experience when choosing between two alternatives.

CourseID: P BA 734. Supply-Chain Strategy. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines strategic and tactical issues pertaining to the distribution and delivery of products and services.

CourseID: P BA 735. Opportunity Recognition. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with techniques and models to identify and develop new opportunities and manage innovation processes.

CourseID: P BA 736. Alliances and Acquisitions. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Using alliances and acquisitions as a strategic tool; emphasis on value creation. Includes deal valuation, deal-making, due diligence, integration, and ecosystem development. Builds on negotiation, strategy, and finance courses.

CourseID: P BA 740. Capstone Business Project. 1-9 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Focuses on integration of functional areas of business. Includes writing a plan that applies knowledge and develops a course of action to accomplish organizational objectives. Repeatable thrice for a maximum of 9 credits. Prereq: offered only to students in the second year of the Oregon Executive M.B.A. program.

CourseID: P BE 325. Global, Legal, Social Environment of Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Legal and ethical regulations of business organizations--including their human resource, finance, production, marketing, and environmental functions--in the United States and internationally. Prereq: BA 101, WR 121.

CourseID: P BE 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Law for Managers.

CourseID: P BE 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Law for Managers.

CourseID: P BE 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Global Business Environments.

CourseID: P BE 625. Business Law and Ethics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the legal and ethical facets of real-life business cases and develops the core knowledge and critical thinking skills around law and ethics for today's successful business leaders.

Descriptions: P The accounting model and financial statements for external users. Prereq: sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ACTG 213. Introduction to Accounting II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reporting of assets, equities, revenues, and expenses. Cost information and uses in management planning and control. Budgeting, manufacturing cost flows, and product costs. Prereq: ACTG 211, C- or better; sophomore standing.

CourseID: P ACTG 340. Accounting for Entrepreneurs. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Sources and uses of cash in the context of start-up and small firms. Emphasis on cash generated by operations and used for operations and growth. Secondary emphasis on external sources of cash. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 213, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, EC 202, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121. Coreq: MATH 242; WR 122 or WR 123.

CourseID: P ACTG 350. Intermediate Accounting I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts and principles of financial accounting, including U.S. and international financial reporting standards; analysis of alternatives for income measurement and asset and liability valuation. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 213, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, EC 202, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121. Coreq: MATH 242; WR 122 or WR 123.

CourseID: P ACTG 351. Intermediate Accounting II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts and principles of financial accounting, including U.S. and international financial reporting standards. Analysis of alternatives for income measurement and asset and liability valuation. Prereq: ACTG 350.

CourseID: P ACTG 352. Intermediate Accounting III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts and principles of financial accounting, including U.S. and international financial reporting standards; analysis of alternatives for income measurement and asset and liability valuation. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 351, FIN 316.

CourseID: P ACTG 360. Cost Accounting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development and communication of cost information to assist in planning, motivating managers, controlling costs, and evaluating performance.

CourseID: P ACTG 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. A recent topic is Accounting Information Systems. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 213, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, EC 202, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121.

CourseID: P ACTG 440. Auditing and Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The audit environment, examinations of financial statements, and the audit process. The role of information in modern organizations; systems concepts; accounting controls; auditing systems. Prereq: C– or better in ACTG 350.

CourseID: P ACTG 450. Advanced Financial Accounting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Accounting for equity; financial accounting and reporting for corporate consolidation. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 352.

CourseID: P ACTG 470. Introduction to Federal Taxation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Federal income tax law covering primarily the taxation of individuals. Introduction to tax planning. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 213, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, EC 202, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121.

CourseID: P ACTG 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. A recent topic is Accounting Information Systems.

CourseID: P ACTG 540. Auditing and Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The audit environment, examinations of financial statements, and the audit process. Includes professional standards, audit sampling, and the audit profession.

CourseID: P ACTG 550. Advanced Financial Accounting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Accounting for equity; financial accounting and reporting for corporate consolidation.

CourseID: P ACTG 570. Introduction to Federal Taxation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Federal income tax law covering primarily the taxation of individuals. Introduction to tax planning.

CourseID: P ACTG 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current Research in Accounting is a recent topic.

CourseID: P ACTG 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Developing the Business Professional, International Accounting, Tax Pass-Through Entities.

CourseID: P ACTG 612. Financial Accounting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the accounting model and financial statements for external users. Emphasizes the use of accounting information in valuation and performance evaluation. Prereq: ACTG 211 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ACTG 617. Taxation of Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Taxation of business entities (C corporations, partnerships, S corporations, and limited liability companies) as they form, operate, and dissolve.

CourseID: P ACTG 618. Taxes and Business Strategy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How to use economic analysis as a tax planning tool, thereby incorporating tax factors in economic decisions. Prereq: ACTG 617.

CourseID: P ACTG 620. Entrepreneurial Accounting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Coverage includes selection of a company's legal organizational structure; compensation strategies for small business owners; cash flow budgeting, management and forecasting; and financial statement analysis. Prereq: MBA core or the equivalent.

CourseID: P ACTG 625. Financial Reporting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth coverage of the measurement and disclosure principles used to prepare generally accepted accounting principle-based financial statements. Prereq: MBA core introduction to accounting courses or equivalent.

CourseID: P ACTG 630. Accounting Measurement and Disclosure. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent Financial Accounting Standings Board decisions; current measurement and disclosure conflicts facing the accounting profession. Includes exposure to governmental and not-for-profit accounting issues.

CourseID: P ACTG 631. Financial Statement Analysis and Valuation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the role of accounting information in financial decisions. Highlights valuation's relationship to accounting earnings and book value.

CourseID: P ACTG 642. Advanced Assurance Services. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Knowledge and application of generally accepted accounting principles and generally accepted auditing standards systems, design and flow charting, work paper preparation and review, oral and written presentation, and application of judgment. Prereq: ACTG 440/540.

CourseID: P ACTG 662. Strategic Cost Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and application of management accounting techniques to decisions made under uncertainty in complex business environments.

CourseID: P FIN 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P FIN 240. Survey of Real Estate. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basics of buying, selling, and leasing real estate. Overview of real estate law, commercial and residential brokerage, real estate financing, and real estate administration. Not open to LCB majors or prebusiness majors with junior standing or above.

CourseID: P FIN 281. Personal Finance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of lifetime personal financial strategies. Topics include financial goals and building net worth, major purchasing decisions, credit use, tax planning, retirement, and estate planning. Not open to LCB majors, prebusiness majors with junior standing or above.

CourseID: P FIN 283. The Stock Market and Investing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investments and the stock market, securities and approaches to security selection, portfolio composition and structure. Not open to LCB majors, prebusiness majors with junior standing or above, or students who have credit for FIN 380.

CourseID: P FIN 311. Economic Foundations of Competitive Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of market competition and its relation to product cost and pricing decisions by the firm. Students may receive credit for only one of EC 311, FIN 311, or FIN 311H. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 211, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, WR 121. Coreq: ACTG 213, MATH 242.

CourseID: P FIN 311H. Economic Foundations of Competitive Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analyzes the competitive structure of markets and industries. Focuses on the relationships among cost, pricing strategy and economic profit in competitive environments. Students may receive credit for only one of EC 311, FIN 311, or FIN 311H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P FIN 316. Financial Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Corporate financial planning, selection among alternative investment opportunities, analysis of risk, funds acquisition, and long-term financing. Students cannot receive credit for both FIN 316 and FIN 316H. Prereq: C- or better in ACTG 211, BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, WR 121. Coreq: ACTG 213, MATH 242.

CourseID: P FIN 316H. Financial Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the fundamental tools and concepts of finance, including the evaluation of investment opportunities and the relation between risk and return Students cannot receive credit for both FIN 316 and FIN 316H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P FIN 380. Financial Markets and Investments. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Financial markets and security investment decisions, analysis of risk and return, portfolio policies for individual and institutional investors, financial instruments. Prereq: FlN 316, OBA 330.

CourseID: P FIN 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Prereq: C- or better FIN 316 or FIN 316H.

CourseID: P FIN 462. Derivative Markets and Financial Institutions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Valuation of financial derivatives, methodologies for identifying firms' risk exposures, the role of risk management and financial derivatives in corporate strategy, and analysis of financial institutions. Prereq: FIN 316.

CourseID: P FIN 463. International Finance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of currency exchange rates, balance of payments; management of foreign exchange risk; risk and return in international investment. Prereq: FIN 316.

CourseID: P FIN 464. Commercial Banking. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Operation and pricing policies of a commercial bank, concentrating on management of institutions that take deposits and make loans and investments through the use of computer-simulated banking operations. Prereq: FIN 316.

CourseID: P FIN 473. Financial Analysis and Valuation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include working capital management, advanced capital budgeting, dividend policy, financing policy, business valuation, and corporate acquisitions. Prereq: FIN 380.

CourseID: P FIN 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P FIN 562. Derivative Markets and Financial Institutions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Valuation of financial derivatives, methodologies for identifying firms' risk exposures, the role of risk management and financial derivatives in corporate strategy, and analysis of financial institutions. Prereq: FIN 380 or FIN 612.

CourseID: P FIN 564. Commercial Banking. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Operation and pricing policies of a commercial bank, concentrating on management of institutions that take deposits and make loans and investments through the use of computer-simulated banking operations.

CourseID: P FIN 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P FIN 612. Fundamentals of Finance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the fundamental theories and tools of financial analysis. Topics include valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return, market efficiency, and financial policies. Sequence with FIN 613.

CourseID: P FIN 613. Managerial Economics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the fundamental theories and tools of economic and strategic analysis. Topics include demand and supply, pricing strategies, and perfect and imperfect competition. Sequence with FIN 612. Prereq: FIN 612.

CourseID: P FIN 615. Quantitative Methods for Finance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mathematical and statistical tools fundamental to financial analysis; measuring returns and risk, probability models, statistical inference, regression analysis, all with applications to finance.

CourseID: P FIN 663. International Financial Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P International monetary system and its implications for exchange rate determination. Determinants of foreign investments, characteristics of international financial institutions, and the relationship between international and domestic markets. Prereq: completion of first-year M.B.A. core.

CourseID: P FIN 671. Corporate Finance and Valuation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of financial principles to problems of valuation, capital budgeting, and financial policy. Prereq: FIN 612.

CourseID: P FIN 673. Advanced Topics in Corporate Finance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Cases dealing with financial analysis, working-capital management, valuation, and firm investment and financing decisions. Prereq: completion of first-year M.B.A. core.

CourseID: P FIN 675. Fixed Income Securities. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical, empirical, and institutional aspects of fixed-income securities and their derivatives; application of these tools to managerial decisions in other contexts. Prereq: completion of first-year MBA core.

CourseID: P FIN 683. Concepts of Investments. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Securities markets; risk-return characteristics of investment media; concepts of security analysis; investment and portfolio strategies of individual and institutional investors. Prereq: completion of first-year M.B.A. core.

CourseID: P FIN 687. Hedge Funds. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Institutional features and trading strategies of the hedge fund industry; developing trading ideas, evaluating based on historical data or financial statements, and analyzing risk-return tradeoff. Prereq: FIN 683.

CourseID: P MGMT 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P MGMT 321. Managing Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Roles of managers in planning, organizing, leading, and controlling organizations in a competitive global environment. Students cannot receive credit for both MGMT 321 and MGMT 321H. Prereq: BA 308, MATH 241.

CourseID: P MGMT 321H. Managing Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores principles of management in the context of current management practice. Nature of the manager's job in dynamic and complex environment. Cases, group project and intensive class interaction. Students cannot receive credit for both MGMT 321 and MGMT 321H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P MGMT 335. Launching New Ventures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Skills, behaviors, and knowledge necessary for creating and growing new ventures. Evaluating opportunities, developing growth strategies, obtaining venture financing, intellectual property, and building a management team. Prereq: MGMT 321.

CourseID: P MGMT 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Strategic Environmental Management, Technology and Innovation Management. Prereq: MGMT 321 or MGMT 321H.

CourseID: P MGMT 415. Human Resources Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Management of employee relations by an organization. Hiring and developing a productive work force in the context of the legal and competitive environment. Prereq: MGMT 321.

CourseID: P MGMT 416. Organizational Development and Change Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Organizational leaders face an accelerating pace of change in information technology, markets, and consumers. Focuses on how leaders create and sustain these organizational changes. Prereq: BA 352, MGMT 321.

CourseID: P MGMT 417. Negotiation Strategies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to negotiation theory, distributive and integrative bargaining techniques, and alternative dispute resolution. Uses workshop format for in-class negotiation simulations. Prereq: MGMT 321.

CourseID: P MGMT 420. Managing in a Global Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Economic, political and cultural challenges facing international managers. Topics include developing competitive global strategies and organizations, international negotiations, building strategic alliances, cross-cultural teams, and international staffing. Prereq: MGMT 321 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MGMT 455. Implementing Entrepreneurial Strategies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on turning an idea into a serious business venture. Students research new business opportunities and become skilled in developing business tools and processes to carry out venture launch strategies. Prereq: ACTG 340, MGMT 335, MKTG 445.

CourseID: P MGMT 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Strategic Environmental Management, Technology and Innovation Management.

CourseID: P MGMT 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. A recent topic is Sustainable Business Development.

CourseID: P MGMT 612. Managing Individuals and Organizations. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design of high-performance organizations and internal systems. Analysis of team dynamics and group decision-making. Study of individual cognitive and leadership styles.

CourseID: P MGMT 614. Strategic Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of industries and companies, development of competitive and cooperative strategies, analysis of the special demands of alternative social, technological, and international contexts.

CourseID: P MGMT 615. Leadership. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills managers need to be effective leaders in organizations, including communicating, problem-solving, influencing, motivating, delegating, and resolving conflict.

CourseID: P MGMT 620. Managing Global Business. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the problems of operating across multiple political and cultural boundaries. Possible topics include corporate strategy, the role of multinational corporations, and international joint ventures.

CourseID: P MGMT 623. Negotiation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Negotiation theory including distributive and integrative bargaining techniques, economic complements, game theory, and alternative dispute resolution. Extensive in-class negotiation simulations.

CourseID: P MGMT 625. New Venture Planning. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students identify and research a business opportunity; develop and present a professional start-up business plan that includes market, competitor, cash flow, and financial analyses.

CourseID: P MGMT 635. Opportunity Recognition. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the fundamentals of entrepreneurship, providing the tools necessary to successfully identify a true opportunity and to start and develop a new organization. Open only to MBA and MActg majors.

CourseID: P MGMT 640. Sustainable Business Development. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on corporate environmental management, drawing on economic and policy models, strategic analysis, and use of business cases. Issues facing small and mid-sized companies stressed.

CourseID: P MGMT 641. Industrial Ecology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Takes a systems approach to the design and manufacture of products and delivery of services with minimized ecological impact.

CourseID: P MGMT 690. Management Proseminar. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Contemporary issues in management research. Includes visiting speakers, resident faculty members, and doctoral students discussing their research.

CourseID: P MKTG 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P MKTG 311. Marketing Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Product, price, promotion, and distribution decisions in consumer and industrial markets. Market segmentation, product positioning for goods and services. Marketing strategy and management. Product life cycles. Students cannot receive credit for both MKTG 311 and MKTG 311H. Prereq: BA 240, BA 308.

CourseID: P MKTG 311H. Marketing Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores marketing strategy and tactics for profit and nonprofit organizations including start-ups and global firms. Uses cases and projects; requires intense student participation. Students cannot receive credit for both MKTG 311 and MKTG 311H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P MKTG 390. Marketing Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design, implementation, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of research for marketing decisions. Hands-on experience with techniques for data collection, statistical data analysis, and communication of results. Prereq: MKTG 311.

CourseID: P MKTG 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Marketing and Sustainability, Sales Management and Personal Selling.

CourseID: P MKTG 420. Marketing Communications. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advertising, sales promotions, public relations, and personal selling. Emerging communication media. Legal regulations and ethical considerations in mass media advertising. Media planning and promotional budgets. Prereq: MKTG 311.

CourseID: P MKTG 435. Consumer Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applications of social science concepts to the understanding of consumers and to the optimal delivery of products and services. Prereq: MKTG 311.

CourseID: P MKTG 445. Entrepreneurial Marketing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques for analyzing and developing new markets. Pricing, communicating, and distributing new products or services with limited resources. Developing marketing plans for new ventures. Prereq: MKTG 311.

CourseID: P MKTG 470. International Marketing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and development of marketing strategy and tactics for multinational and global markets. Prereq: one from BA 317, MKTG 311, 311H.

CourseID: P MKTG 490. Marketing Strategy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Capstone marketing course. Primary focus on developing and implementing marketing strategies and determining their impact on customer satisfaction and profitability. Prereq: MKTG 390; MKTG 420 or SBUS 452.

CourseID: P MKTG 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. A recent topic includes Marketing and Sustainability.

CourseID: P MKTG 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include New Product Development, Brand Strategy.

CourseID: P MKTG 612. Marketing Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Marketing Management addresses market analysis and segmentation, targeting, and positioning. Emphasis is on marketing strategies designed to deliver superior customer value and achieve organizational objectives.

CourseID: P MKTG 660. Marketing Research. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Marketing research as a tool for decision-making. Planning research projects; design, measurement, experimental and nonexperimental techniques, analysis and interpretation of data; reporting research results. Prereq: completion of first-year MBA core.

CourseID: P MKTG 665. Marketing Strategy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Relationship between marketing and other functional areas of a business. Emphasis on case analysis as a means of acquiring both planning and operational skills. Prereq: completion of first-year MBA core.

CourseID: P MKTG 687. Theory and Research in Marketing Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of marketing concepts and of economics, management science, and behavioral science to the management of the product, price, promotion, and distribution variables. Prereq: doctoral standing.

CourseID: P MKTG 689. Theory and Research in Consumer Behavior. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P The applicability of behavioral theories and methodologies to the understanding of the consumption process. Prereq: doctoral standing.

CourseID: P SBUS 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Sports, Business, and Society.

CourseID: P SBUS 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: one course from BA 317, MKTG 311, MKTG 311H.

CourseID: P SBUS 450. Sports Marketing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Essentials of effective sports marketing. Includes research, segmentation, product development, pricing, licensing, and communication channels such as advertising, sales promotion, and publicity. Prereq: MKTG 311.

CourseID: P SBUS 452. Sports Sponsorship. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Detailed consideration of the relationship between sports and corporate sponsorship programs. Focuses on alignment marketing, sponsor value, and sponsorship evaluation. Prereq: MKTG 311 or 311H.

CourseID: P SBUS 453. Law and Sports Marketing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Law and sports marketing, including contracts, legal aspects of licensing, relations with agents, intellectual properties law. Public policy issues. Prereq: MKTG 311 or 311H.

CourseID: P SBUS 455. Financing Sports Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Revenue sources for sports organizations. Includes conventional sources (e.g., tax support, bonds, ticket, media, concession sales) and innovations (e.g, initial public offerings, seat licenses, naming rights). Prereq: MKTG 311 or 311H.

CourseID: P SBUS 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Sports Product Branding, Product Line Management.

CourseID: P SBUS 645. Sports Product. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the companies and organizations of the international sports product industry: manufacturing innovation, company management, branding, retail and wholesale.

CourseID: P SBUS 650. Marketing Sports Properties. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines essentials of effective sports marketing. Includes product or property development, legal aspects, segmentation, pricing, and communication channels (e.g., broadcast media). Prereq: completion of first-year M.B.A. core.

CourseID: P SBUS 652. Sports Sponsorship Alliances. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Detailed consideration of the relation between sports, law, and corporate sponsorship programs. Focuses on alignment marketing issues, strategic communication through sponsorship, sponsor value, and sponsorship valuation. Prereq: completion of first-year MBA core.

CourseID: P SBUS 653. Legal Aspects of Sports Business. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines social responsibility and legal concepts in sports management including constitutional regulatory powers, individual participation rights, drug testing, antitrust, labor rights, intellectual property rights, sponsorships, product and event liability.

CourseID: P SBUS 655. Economic Aspects of Sports. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive coverage of traditional and innovative revenue methods available to sports organizations from public and private sources. Detailed consideration of venue-based income sources (e.g., premium seating, permanent seat licenses). Prereq: completion of first-year MBA core.

CourseID: P BA 453

CourseID: P OBA 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes.

CourseID: P OBA 330. Business Statistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Computer-aided business applications of hypothesis testing, simple linear regression. Introduction to multiple regression andnonparametric techniques. Blocked and completely randomized one- and two-factor experimental designs. Students cannot receivecredit for both OBA 330 and OBA 330H. Prereq: C- or better in BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121.

CourseID: P OBA 330H. Business Statistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. Regression analysis: computer-aided model formulation and diagnostic testing. Making decisions under uncertainty. Students cannot receive credit for both OBA 330 and OBA 330H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P OBA 335. Operations Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts and applications of operations management. Use of information technology in operations. Topics include forecasting, quality, supply chain management, information systems in operations management, and planning and scheduling. Students cannot receive credit for both OBA 335 and OBA 335H. Prereq: C- or better in BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121.

CourseID: P OBA 335H. Operations Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planning and control of manufacturing and service operations with an emphasis on supply chain management. Students cannot receivecredit for both OBA 335 and OBA 335H. Pre/coreq: OBA 330 or OBA 330H. Open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P OBA 340. Business Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores standard protocols for describing and modeling business information and processes; techniques for designing management information systems; criteria for analyzing firms' implementations of information technology. Students cannot receive credit for both OBA 340 and OBA 340H. Prereq: C- or better in BA 101, BA 240, EC 201, MATH 241, MATH 243, WR 121.

CourseID: P OBA 340H. Business Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores standard protocols for describing and modeling business information and processes; techniques for designing management information systems; criteria for analyzing firms' implementations of information technology. Students may not receive credit for both OBA 340 and OBA 340H. Prereq: open only to students in the LCB honors program.

CourseID: P OBA 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Service Operations, Business Analytics, Analyzing Big Data. Prereq: OBA 330/OBA 330H, OBA 335/OBA 335H, OBA 340/OBA 340H.

CourseID: P OBA 433. Information Analysis for Managerial Decisions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Leveraging information to manage risk and improve decisions; data-driven approaches for discovering business trends and strategic opportunities, including techniques for data-mining and analyzing empirical data. Prereq: OBA 330.

CourseID: P OBA 444. Business Database Management Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques for structuring and storing business data; primary focus on relational database theory, with applied skills for business users, including data warehouses, reporting, and normalization. Prereq: OBA 340 or OBA 340H.

CourseID: P OBA 466. Project and Operations Management Models. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Frameworks and solutions for managing complex projects and operations; implementing optimal strategies for producing profitable new products and services in the competitive global business environment. Prereq: OBA 335 or 335H.

CourseID: P OBA 477. Supply-Chain Operations and Information. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Strategic and tactical issues pertaining to the distribution and delivery of products and services. Methodologies and systems for designing, tracking, and managing complex global operations. Prereq: OBA 335 or 335H.

CourseID: P OBA 488. E-Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of electronic business; effect of e-business on business strategies, processes, customers, and suppliers; assessing the impact of e-business technologies on firm performance. Prereq: OBA 340 or 340H or CIT 382.

CourseID: P OBA 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Service Operations, Business Analytics, Analyzing Big Data.

CourseID: P OBA 533. Information Analysis for Managerial Decisions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Leveraging information to manage risk and improve decisions; data-driven approaches for discovering business trends and strategic opportunities, including techniques for data-mining and analyzing empirical data. Prereq: all MBA core courses.

CourseID: P OBA 544. Business Database Management Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques for structuring and storing business data; primary focus on relational database theory, with applied skills for business users, including data warehouses, reporting, and normalization. Prereq: all MBA core courses.

CourseID: P OBA 566. Project and Operations Management Models. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Frameworks and solutions for managing complex projects and operations; implementing optimal strategies for producing profitable new products and services in the competitive global business environment. Prereq: all MBA core courses.

CourseID: P OBA 577. Supply-Chain Operations and Information. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Strategic and tactical issues pertaining to the distribution and delivery of products and services. Methodologies and systems for designing, tracking, and managing complex global operations. Prereq: all MBA core courses.

CourseID: P OBA 588. E-Business. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamental principles of electronic business; effect of e-business on business strategies, processes, customers, and suppliers; assessing the impact of e-business technologies on firm performance. Prereq: all MBA core courses.

CourseID: P OBA 612. Quantitative Methods for Managers. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts and techniques of analytic decision making, sampling and statistical inference, and regression analysis.

CourseID: P OBA 613. Operations Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the managerial issues associated with production and delivery of goods and services. Includes the use of quantitative modeling and several case studies in operations.

Descriptions: P Use of research in developing professional vision statements, portfolios, and synthesis papers that reflect on academic, internship, practicum, or field experiences. Identifies possibilities for future professional trajectories.

CourseID: P ARCH 283–284 Architectural Design I-II 12 ARCH 383–384 Architectural Design III-IV 12
Descriptions: P Intermediate Architectural Design Studios

CourseID: P ARCH 201. Introduction to Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offers a structure of principles for making places for people. Examines places, design procedures, and the use of archtiectural principles in general.

CourseID: P ARCH 202. Design Skills. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to basic design processes, methods, and media. Prereq: ARCH 201 or IARC 204; coreq: ARCH 283.

CourseID: P ARCH 222. Introduction to Architectural Computer Graphics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces basic skills and literacy with the computer for architectural illustration, drafting, and design. Prereq: ARCH 202.

CourseID: P ARCH 283. Architectural Design I. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design studio projects and exercises introducing fundamental concepts and considerations in environmental design. Teaches knowledge and skills needed in subsequent studios and professional course work. Sequence with ARCH 284. Prereq: ARCH 201 or IARC 204; coreq: ARCH 202.

CourseID: P ARCH 284. Architectural Design II. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design studio projects and exercises introducing fundamental concepts and considerations in environmental design. Teaches knowledge and skills needed in subsequent studios and professional course work. Sequence with ARCH 283. Prereq: ARCH 202, 283; coreq: ARCH 222.

CourseID: P ARCH 383. Architectural Design III. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio projects. Integration of issues of context, activity support, spatial order, construction, structure, and environmental control. Emphasis on schematic concept formation and subsequent architectural development. Sequence with ARCH 384. Prereq: ARCH 284.

CourseID: P ARCH 384. Architectural Design IV. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio projects. Integration of issues of context, activity support, spatial order, construction, structure, and environmental control. Emphasis on schematic concept formation and subsequent architectural development. Sequence with ARCH 383. Prereq: ARCH 383 and 222.

CourseID: P ARCH 417. Context of the Architectural Profession. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the professional practice of architecture and related careers. Examines the professional, legal, and regulatory environment; firm organization and management; marketing; contractual issues; and the construction process. Prereq: ARCH 484 or IARC 484 or LA 489.

CourseID: P ARCH 423. Media for Design Development: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Instruction in media for design process. Techniques for problem and context analysis, generating concepts, developing form, and testing proposals. Subject emphasis varies with instructor. Repeatable. Prereq: ARCH 202.

CourseID: P ARCH 424. Advanced Design-Development Media: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced instruction in specific media techniques for architectural analysis and design. Subject emphasis varies with instructor. Repeatable. Prereq: ARCH 423.

CourseID: P ARCH 430. Architectural Contexts: Place and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How the design of buildings interacts with physical and cultural contexts of human traditions, landscape, settlements, cities, and suburbs. Historical and contemporary examples. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architectural minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 431. Community Design. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Multidisciplinary examination of the history, theory, and practice in the design and development of meaningful and sustainable neighborhoods. Special focus selected by faculty. Open to all majors. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 435. Principles of Urban Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of urban design, comparative studies of neighborhood conservation, central city regeneration, growth policies and prospects for restructuring cities, metropolitan regions. ARCH 284 or architecture minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 436. Theory of Urban Design I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the cultural and formal ideas that underlie American and European urban design. Ancient Greek to 1700. Prereq: ARCH 430.

CourseID: P ARCH 437. Theory of Urban Design II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the cultural and formal ideas that underlie American and European urban design. 1700 to the present.

CourseID: P ARCH 438. Housing Prototypes. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P An examination of modern housing prototypes (1920s to the present) with an emphasis on understanding the many and varied factors involved in the production of quality housing. Open to all majors. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 439. Minimal Dwelling. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the design of small dwelling units for a variety of users. Offered alternate years. Prereq: junior standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 440. Human Context of Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical principles, case studies, and technical skills for assessing user needs, developing building programs, applying research findings to design, and evaluating performance of the built environment. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architectural minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 450. Spatial Composition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Architectural space as a means to measure existence and expand awareness. Focus on compositional principles in architecture and methods for analyzing and generating spatial organizations. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architectural minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 457. The Facade. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ideas related to facade as primary surface of architectural representation. Emphasizes the facade as a mediator between internal and external building needs. Prereq: ARCH 450.

CourseID: P ARCH 458. Types and Typology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical introduction to theory of typology that categorizes urban and architectural forms by formal characteristics and cultural meaning. Lectures cover basic concepts, historical development, and case studies. Prereq: ARCH 384, 450.

CourseID: P ARCH 461. Structural Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops a basic understanding of structural systems or elements and their implications for architectural form. Lectures, laboratories, and case studies investigate structure in historical and contemporary buildings. Prereq: PHYS 201, 202; passing score on diagnostic examination.

CourseID: P ARCH 462. Wood and Steel Building Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of materials. Analyzes elements, connections, and systems of wood, steel, and concrete structures from the perspective of construction process, spatial and structural design. Prereq: ARCH 461.

CourseID: P ARCH 470. Building Construction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provide an understanding of the basic materials and methods of architecture with emphasis on the design, construction and performance of primary structure. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architectural minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 471. Building Enclosure. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selection, design, detailing, and performance evaluation of building envelopes: wood, metals, glass, concrete, and masonry veneers and roofing. Prereq: ARCH 462, 470, 491.

CourseID: P ARCH 480. Supervised Design Teaching. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised assistance with desk critiques and tasks related to studio teaching. Written application required. Repeatable for a maximum of 3 credits. Prereq: ARCH 384.

CourseID: P ARCH 484. Architectural Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design projects requiring comprehensive and integrative study over a wide range of project options. Individual criticism, group discussions, lectures and seminars by visiting specialists, public review of projects. Repeatable. Prereq: ARCH 384.

CourseID: P ARCH 485. Advanced Architectural Design I. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth work on complex design projects and design development beyond that normally possible in intermediate studios. Sequence. Prereq: 24 credits in ARCH 484.

CourseID: P ARCH 486. Advanced Architectural Design II. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth work on complex design projects and design development beyond that normally possible in intermediate studios. Prereq: ARCH 485.

CourseID: P ARCH 491. Environmental Control Systems I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influence of energy source, climate, heating, cooling, lighting, acoustics, and water and waste systems on design of buildings and sites. Architectural and mechanical means to manipulate thermal environment. Sequence. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architecture minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 492. Environmental Control Systems II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influence of energy source, climate, heating, cooling, lighting, acoustics, and water and waste systems on design of buildings and sites. Implications of lighting, acoustics, and water and waste for architectural design. Prereq: ARCH 284 or architecture minor status.

CourseID: P ARCH 495. Daylighting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P "Daylighting"—increasing the energy efficiency of a building by maximizing the amount of daylight versus electric light—as an element in architectural design. Models and photography used to study behavior of light. Case studies and prediction techniques. Prereq: ARCH 492.

CourseID: P ARCH 517. Context of the Architectural Profession. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the professional practice of architecture and related careers. Examines the professional, legal, and regulatory environment; firm organization and management; marketing; contractual issues; and the construction process.

CourseID: P ARCH 523. Media for Design Development: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Instruction in media for design process. Techniques for problem and context analysis, generating concepts, developing form, and testing proposals. Subject emphasis varies with instructor. Repeatable. Prereq: ARCH 611.

CourseID: P ARCH 524. Advanced Design-Development Media: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced instruction in specific media techniques for architectural analysis and design. Subject emphasis varies with instructor. Repeatable. Prereq: ARCH 423/523.

CourseID: P ARCH 530. Architectural Contexts: Place and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How the design of buildings interacts with physical and cultural contexts of human traditions, landscape, settlements, cities, and suburbs. Historical and contemporary examples. Prereq: ARCH 680 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 531. Community Design. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Multidisciplinary examination of the history, theory, and practice in the design and development of meaningful and sustainable neighborhoods. Special focus selected by faculty. Open to all majors. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ARCH 535. Principles of Urban Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of urban design, comparative studies of neighborhood conservation, central city regeneration, growth policies and prospects for restructuring cities, metropolitan regions. ARCH 680.

CourseID: P ARCH 536. Theory of Urban Design I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the cultural and formal ideas that underlie American and European urban design. Ancient Greek to 1700.

CourseID: P ARCH 537. Theory of Urban Design II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the cultural and formal ideas that underlie American and European urban design. 1700 to the present.

CourseID: P ARCH 538. Housing Prototypes. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P An examination of modern housing prototypes (1920s to the present) with an emphasis on understanding the many and varied factors involved in the production of quality housing. Open to all majors.

CourseID: P ARCH 539. Minimal Dwelling. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the design of small dwelling units for a variety of users. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P ARCH 540. Human Context of Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theoretical principles, case studies, and technical skills for assessing user needs, developing building programs, applying research findings to design, and evaluating performance of the built environment. Prereq: ARCH 680 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 550. Spatial Composition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Architectural space as a means to measure existence and expand awareness. Focus on compositional principles in architecture and methods for analyzing and generating spatial organizations. Prereq: ARCH 680.

CourseID: P ARCH 557. The Facade. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ideas related to facade as primary surface of architectural representation. Emphasizes the facade as a mediator between internal and external building needs. Prereq: ARCH 450/550.

CourseID: P ARCH 558. Types and Typology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical introduction to theory of typology that categorizes urban and architectural forms by formal characteristics and cultural meaning. Lectures cover basic concepts, historical development, and case studies. Prereq: ARCH 550 and 682 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 561. Structural Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Developes basic understanding of structural systems or elements and their implications for architectural form. Lectures, laboratories, and case studies investigate structure in historical and contemporary buildings. Prereq: passing score on diagnostic examination.

CourseID: P ARCH 562. Wood and Steel Building Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of materials. Analyzes elements, connections, and systems of wood, steel, and concrete structures from the perspective of construction process, spatial and structural design. Prereq: ARCH 461 or 561.

CourseID: P ARCH 570. Building Construction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provide an understanding of the basic materials and methods of architecture with emphasis on the design, construction and performance of primary structure. Prereq: ARCH 680.

CourseID: P ARCH 571. Building Enclosure. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selection, design, detailing, and performance evaluation of building envelopes: wood, metals, glass, concrete, and masonry veneers and roofing. ARCH 562, 570, 591.

CourseID: P ARCH 580. Supervised Design Teaching. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised assistance with desk critiques and tasks related to studio teaching. Written application required. Repeatable for a maximum of 3 credits. Prereq: ARCH 681 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 584. Architectural Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Design projects requiring comprehensive and integrative study over a wide range of project options. Individual criticism, group discussions, lectures and seminars by visiting specialists, public review of projects. Prereq: ARCH 682 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 585. Advanced Architectural Design I. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth work on complex design projects and design development beyond that normally possible in intermediate studios. Sequence. Prereq: 30 credits in ARCH 484/584.

CourseID: P ARCH 586. Advanced Architectural Design II. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth work on complex design projects and design development beyond that normally possible in intermediate studios. Prereq: ARCH 485/585.

CourseID: P ARCH 591. Environmental Control Systems I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influence of energy source, climate, heating, cooling, lighting, acoustics, and water and waste systems on design of buildings and sites. Architectural and mechanical means to manipulate thermal environment. Sequence. ARCH 680 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 592. Environmental Control Systems II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influence of energy source, climate, heating, cooling, lighting, acoustics, and water and waste systems on design of buildings and sites. Implications of lighting, acoustics, and water and waste for architectural design. ARCH 680 or 683.

CourseID: P ARCH 595. Daylighting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P "Daylighting"—increasing the energy efficiency of a building by maximizing the amount of daylight versus electric light—as an element in architectural design. Models and photography used to study behavior of light. Case studies and prediction techniques. Prereq: ARCH 492 or 592.

CourseID: P ARCH 611. Graduate Design Process. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foundation knowledge, concepts, and skills fundamental to design process and media subject areas.

CourseID: P ARCH 617. Built Environment Design and Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigation of design processes, planning, and construction of buildings and communities. Prereq: conditional MArch or PhD standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 620. Research Methods in Sustainable Design. 2-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research methods to assess the design of buildings and communities; discussions include defining research themes, hypotheses, and developing thesis proposals. Prereq: conditional MArch or PhD standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 633. History of Sustainable Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History and theory of sustainable design practices; the evolution of codes and standards related to building design; perspectives and implementation strategies by leading ecological practitioners. Prereq: conditional MArch or PhD standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 661. Teaching Technical Subjects in Architecture. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers techniques for effective teaching. Focuses on one or more standard building-technology courses in architecture and interior architecture. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P ARCH 678. Advanced Research in Sustainable Design. 2-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Quantitative and qualitative techniques used in validating the design practice and research covering analytic approaches, including research design, surveys,case-study research, measurement, evaluation, and data presentation. Prereq: conditional MArch or PhD standing.

CourseID: P ARCH 680. Introductory Graduate Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design projects and exercises intended to familiarize the student with fundamental concepts of environmental design. Emphasis on developing graphic skills and the capability for visual thinking that are essential to advanced studios. Sequence.

CourseID: P ARCH 681. Introductory Graduate Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design projects and exercises intended to familiarize the student with fundamental concepts of environmental design. Emphasis on developing graphic skills and the capability for visual thinking that are essential to advanced studios. Sequence. Prereq: ARCH 680.

CourseID: P ARCH 682. Introductory Graduate Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design projects and exercises intended to familiarize the student with fundamental concepts of environmental design. Emphasis on developing graphic skills and the capability for visual thinking that are essential to advanced studios. Prereq: ARCH 681.

CourseID: P ARCH 683. Graduate Architectural Design: Track II. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design to expand perception and response to issues in architectural design. Design as exploration of fundamental theoretical ideas. Studio projects require comprehensiveness and integrative study. Repeatable.

CourseID: P ARCH 695. Advanced Dissertation Proposal Development. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Directed study for the development of dissertation proposals. Approval of faculty advisor required. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 18 credits based on development of proposal for dissertation. Prereq: PhD standing.
