CourseID: P ART 101. Understanding Contemporary Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical exploration of concepts surrounding and defining the experience of understanding contemporary art. Students are guided by instructors through issues relating to their work and disciplines.

CourseID: P ART 111. The Artist Experience. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical exploration of concepts surrounding and defining contemporary art through the examination of the individual studio practice of members of the art faculty.

CourseID: P ART 115. Surface, Space, and Time. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces interdisciplinary media processes, critical theory, formal communication design, color theory, skills in objective evaluation and critique, and how materials, processes, and context establish meaning.

CourseID: P ART 116. Core Interdisciplinary Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rigorous studio projects in the core studio sequence stressing interdisciplinary media transitions and the interrelatedness of conceptual and formal concerns. Prereq: ART 115.

CourseID: P ART 198. Technical Workshop: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Possible topics include Beginning Woodworking, Book Arts, Professional Practices. Repeatable when change of topic for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P ART 233. Drawing I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to basic drawing concepts and practices.

CourseID: P ART 333. Drawing II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes synthesis of ideas and approaches, complex subjects, investigation, and expression while building on previous drawing skills. Sequence with ART 233. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ART 381. Letterpress. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experiments with lead and wooden type as related to graphic composition and communication. Repeatable ten times for a maximum of 44 credits. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ART 412. BFA Critique. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Interdisciplinary critique and discussion course for B.F.A. students. Prereq: B.F.A. standing. Repeatable with change of subject.

CourseID: P ART 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics change every term. If link to syllabus is not available, contact instructor by e-mail.

CourseID: P ART 612. Graduate Critique. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Interdisciplinary critique and discussion course for MFA students. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 18 credits.

CourseID: P ART 614. Graduate Studio. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Students engage in a rigorous studio practice through independent production, experimentation, and research. Faculty mentors instruct in rotation. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits.

CourseID: P ARTC 255. Introduction to Ceramics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Specific skills focus each term. Subjects includes processes related to design development, forming and fabrication, firing methods, glazing. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ARTC 354. Industrial Ceramics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level course focusing on skill development pertinent to ceramics industry. Emphasis on material, tools, techniques, and history. Repeatable three times for a maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116; one from ART 233, PD 223.

CourseID: P ARTC 355. Intermediate Ceramics: [Topic]. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced processes and concepts. Areas of technical focus include slip casting, glaze and decorator surface embellishment, architectural ceramic, low fire, and raku.Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ARTC 255.

CourseID: P ARTC 455. Advanced Ceramics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students will be exposed to a range of ceramic histories, technical processes, conceptual frameworks, and professional practices to develop an artistic practice. Repeatable ten times for a maximum of 44 credits. Prereq: ARTC 255, ARTC 354, ARTC 355.

CourseID: P ARTC 490. Issues and Practices in Ceramics. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTC 555. Advanced Ceramics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students will be exposed to a range of ceramic histories, technical processes, conceptual frameworks, and professional practices to develop an artistic practice. Repeatable ten times for a maximum of 44 credits.

CourseID: P ARTC 590. Issues and Practices in Ceramics. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations.

CourseID: P ARTD 198. Technical Workshop: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Possible topics include DreamWeaver, InDesign, PhotoShop. Repeatable when change of topic for maximum of 15 credits.

CourseID: P ARTD 250. Print Media Digital Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines application of print media in contemporary visual culture; explores its use in a fine art context. Introduces digital drawing, digital photo editing, and typographic layout to visually communicate expressive concepts. Laboratories, lectures.

CourseID: P ARTD 251. Time-Based Digital Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the notion of time as a medium in relation to contemporary art through which concepts of sequence, narration, scoring, and motion are expressed. Laboratories, lectures.

CourseID: P ARTD 252. Interactive Digital Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces resources that the computer offers the artist. Concentrates on animation, interaction, and the web as expressive mediums. Laboratories, lectures.

CourseID: P ARTD 256. Introduction to Production. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traditional camera, sound, and lighting techniques in production; nonlinear editing; and key theoretical, historical, and aesthetic approaches to video art. Prereq: J 201, ENG 260; two from ENG 265, 266, 267.

CourseID: P ARTD 350. Digital Drawing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applies technology as a drawing medium to communicate concepts visually. The entire creative process is researched in an experimental studio environment. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233, ARTD 250.

CourseID: P ARTD 360. Digital Imaging. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate-level focus on the proper preparation and presentation of digital images for use in print and on screen. Covers color theory. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233, ARTD 250.

CourseID: P ARTD 361. Introduction to Animation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to principles of animation, timing, sequence; key frames, in-betweens, and metamorphosis. Uses various methods to record and edit animation tests. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233 & ARTD 251 or ENG 260, J 201; two from ENG 265, 266, 267; one from ARTD 256, CINE 270, J 208.

CourseID: P ARTD 362. Digital Letterform. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts in the history, use, and appreciation of digital typography. Considers issues in communicative power of type and situations where it functions as message. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233, ARTD 250, 251, 252, 360.

CourseID: P ARTD 370. Digital Interactivity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students will learn programming to interactive artworks. This class will include how to program microcontrollers and use electronics to create responsive and expressive interactive systems. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTD 252, ART 115, ART 116, ART 233.

CourseID: P ARTD 378. Computational Aesthetics. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces screen-based programming and data navigation; use of motion, duration, and time-based interaction as a means of artistic expression. Students build navigational structures and explore stochastic principles in developing an individual approach to interactivity. Repeatable once for a maximum of 10 credits. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116, ART 233, ARTD 252.

CourseID: P ARTD 379. Introduction to Video Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate video-audio production and nonlinear editing, including camera, sound, and lighting techniques. Key theoretical, historical, and aesthetic approaches to time-based art in video and sound are surveyed. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233 & ARTD 251 or ENG 260, J 201; two from ENG 265, 266, 267; one from ARTD 256, CINE 270, J 208.

CourseID: P ARTD 412. Experimental Animation. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate to advanced students explore personal creative practice and experiment with film, video, and computer animation techniques. Integrates readings, screening, and discussion with production. Prereq: ARTD 361.

CourseID: P ARTD 413. Emerging Technologies. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores use of emerging technologies in art. Create works using emerging technologies and techniques and explore contemporary artworks, philosophies, and cultural trends. Prereq: ARTD 378 or 416.

CourseID: P ARTD 415. Video Art: Experimental Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Video and sound art practices, from conceptual deconstructions of the film-video apparatus to self-reflexive socio-political and/or cultural critique, are examined through short format and video installation. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTD 416. Programming for Artists. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the basics of computer programming within an art context. Topics include interaction design, web development, and physical computing programming. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116, ART 233, ARTD 252.

CourseID: P ARTD 463. Communication Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores the communication of ideas and information through visual means. Introduces design process and principles, visual language, and the art of problem solving in visual communication. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTD 350.

CourseID: P ARTD 471. 3-D Computer Imaging. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduces 3-D computer graphic arts: 3-D digital space and form, model building, scene composition, surface properties, lighting, and rendering 3-D images. Repeatable once for maximum of 10 credits. Prereq: ARTD 350 or 361.

CourseID: P ARTD 472. 3-D Computer Animation. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduces 3-D computer animation arts. Includes time and space in the digital 3-D environment, animation concepts and techniques in 3-D space, production techniques for various multimedia applications. Repeatable once for maximum of 10 credits. Prereq: ARTD 471.

CourseID: P ARTD 490. Issues and Practices in Digital Arts. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing.

CourseID: P ARTD 512. Experimental Animation. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate to advanced students explore personal creative practice and experiment with film, video, and computer animation techniques. Integrates readings, screening, and discussion with production. Prereq: ARTD 361, 395 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ARTD 513. Emerging Technologies. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores use of emerging technologies in art. Create works using emerging technologies and techniques and explore contemporary artworks, philosophies, and cultural trends. Prereq: ARTD 378 or 4/516.

CourseID: P ARTD 515. Video Art: Experimental Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Video and sound art practices, from conceptual deconstructions of the film-video apparatus to self-reflexive socio-political and/or cultural critique, are examined through short format and video installation. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTD 516. Programming for Artists. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the basics of computer programming within an art context. Topics include interaction design, web development, and physical computing programming. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTD 563. Communciation Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores the communication of ideas and information through visual means. Introduces design process and principles, visual language, and the art of problem solving in visual communication. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTD 362, 394 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ARTD 571. 3-D Computer Imaging. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduces 3-D computer graphic arts: 3-D digital space and form, model building, scene composition, surface properties, lighting, and rendering 3-D images. Repeatable once for maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P ARTD 572. 3-D Computer Animation. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduces 3-D computer animation arts. Includes time and space in the digital 3-D environment, animation concepts and techniques in 3-D space, production techniques for various multimedia applications. Repeatable once for maximum of 10 credits. Prereq: ARTD 4/571.

CourseID: P ARTF 270. Introduction to Fibers: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Skills and conceptual concerns of fibers, pertaining to structural textile forms and embellished or manipulated surfaces. Introduces historical and contemporary work through slides and lectures. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116, ART 233.

CourseID: P ARTF 368. Textile Printing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to screen-printing process for fabric and alternative substrates. Textile history, the relevance of printing, and related ideas of decoration, repetition, and appropriation are explored. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: ARTF 270.

CourseID: P ARTF 369. Woven Structures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to floor-loom hand weaving. Traditional and experimental use of materials, techniques, and structures are used to understand weaving as a cross-disciplinary practice. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: ARTF 270.

CourseID: P ARTF 370. Stitchwork Strategies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of stitch techniques, including embroidery, beading, applique, collage, piecing, and quilting. Topics include public versus private, language and narrative, and dimensional forms. Repeatable three times for a maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: ARTF 270.

CourseID: P ARTF 456. Advanced Fibers: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Develops individual studio practice through exploration of contemporary issues in textile-based processes and expansion of the rhetoric of craft. Prereq: one course from ARTF 267, 268, 269, 270; ARTF 368 or 369.

CourseID: P ARTF 556. Advanced Fibers: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Develops individual studio practice through exploration of contemporary issues in textile-based processes and expansion of the rhetoric of craft.

CourseID: P ARTM 257. Introduction to Jewelry and Metalsmithing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores developing and constructing jewelry and objects rooted in material culture. Introduces historical and contemporary work through image presentations, lectures, and independent research. Repeatable with change of course content. Prereq: Art 115, 116, 233

CourseID: P ARTM 357. Metalsmithing and Jewelry: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Further exploration of techniques related to conceptual problems. Content varies by term with a focus on individual processes: hollowware, forging, connections, casting, aluminum anodizing, enameling, stone setting. Prereq: ARTM 257.

CourseID: P ARTM 457. Metalsmithing and Jewelry: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Emphasis on creative work. Advanced investigation of techniques and process. Content varies by term related to process focus. Includes hollow-ware, forging, connections, casting, aluminum anodizing, enameling, stone setting. Prereq: ARTM 357.

CourseID: P ARTM 459. Advanced Metalsmithing and Jewelry. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Emphasis on individual creative development. Various conceptual problems. Prereq: ARTM 357.

CourseID: P ARTM 490. Issues and Practices in Metals. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTM 557. Metalsmithing and Jewelry: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Emphasis on creative work. Advanced investigation of techniques and process. Content varies by term related to process focus. Includes hollow-ware, forging, connections, casting, aluminum anodizing, enameling, stone setting. Prereq: ARTM 357 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ARTM 559. Advanced Metalsmithing and Jewelry. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Emphasis on individual creative development. Various conceptual problems. Prereq: ARTM 357.

CourseID: P ARTM 590. Issues and Practices in Metals. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: M.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTP 281. Introductory Painting I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic visual elements and their application to painting as a means of expression. Incorporates traditional subject matter: still life, landscape, figure. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ARTP 381. Introductory Painting II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Integrates concepts and approaches introduced in Introductory Painting I (ARTP 281) to develop more individual and complex strategies of form and meaning. Sequence with ARTP 281. Prereq: ARTP 281.

CourseID: P ARTP 390. Intermediate and Advanced Painting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Advanced painting concepts and technical processes. Independent initiative is encouraged. Repeatable twice for a total of 12 credits. Prereq: ARTP 381.

CourseID: P ARTP 391. Intermediate and Advanced Drawing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Continued study in observation related to visual and spatial phenomena. Repeatable twice for a total of 12 credits. Prereq: ART 333.

CourseID: P ARTP 481. Advanced Painting Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Pursuit of individual creative practice and forming the critical intelligence necessary to develop as an artist. Sequence: ARTP 281, 381, 390. Prereq: two terms ARTP 390.

CourseID: P ARTP 490. Issues and Practices in Painting. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations for B.F.A. and M.F.A. students. Prereq: B.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTP 491. Advanced Drawing. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores drawing in the expanded field, an experimental practice applicable to a broad range of media and ideas. Intended for students engaged in advanced, independent work.

CourseID: P ARTP 590. Issues and Practices in Painting. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations for B.F.A. and M.F.A. students. Prereq: M.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTP 591. Advanced Drawing. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores drawing in the expanded field, an experimental practice applicable to a broad range of media and ideas. Intended for students engaged in advanced, independent work.

CourseID: P ARTO 250. Introduction to Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers basic elements of photography using a DSLR camera and provides a broad-based understanding of photographic practice in a fine art context. Sequence with ARTO 350. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116, ART 233.

CourseID: P ARTO 350. Film and Darkroom. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Technical and aesthetic consideration of black-and-white analog photography. Basics of camera, film development, and photographic print controls in the darkroom. Sequence with ARTO 250. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 250.

CourseID: P ARTO 351. Constructed Image Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Explores processes and concepts extending beyond the single photographic image. Narrative and formal strategies in manipulation and sequencing, exploring the materiality of the photograph. Studio course. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTO 352. Creative Large-Format Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduces large-format cameras and their aesthetic possibilities. Four-by-five and eight-by-ten view cameras provided. Includes camera use, film and development, printing skills. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 350.

CourseID: P ARTO 450. Digital Photography II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Addresses advanced methods in a digital workflow and the role of photography in contemporary art practice through various constructed, aesthetic, and conceptual approaches. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 250.

CourseID: P ARTO 455. Conceptual Strategies in Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Studies the 1960s conceptual art movement and its influence on contemporary photography practice: open-ended projects respond to various conceptual frameworks. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 250.

CourseID: P ARTO 476. Alternative Photographic Processes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Combines painterly concerns with printmaking ideas and photographic principles in a mixed-media approach to contemporary image-making through historic and antiquated processes. Studio course. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 350; one course from ARTO 351, ARTO 352.

CourseID: P ARTO 484. Advanced Photography: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Investigates photographic practice and philosophy through readings and discussion; students engage in personal studio practice and class critiques. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 450.

CourseID: P ARTO 490. Issues and Practices in Photography. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTO 550. Digital Photography II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Addresses advanced methods in a digital workflow and the role of photography in contemporary art practice through various constructed, aesthetic, and conceptual approaches. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTO 555. Conceptual Strategies in Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Studies the 1960s conceptual art movement and its influence on contemporary photography practice: open-ended projects respond to various conceptual frameworks. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTO 576. Alternative Photographic Processes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Combines painterly concerns with printmaking ideas and photographic principles in a mixed-media approach to contemporary image-making through historic and antiquated processes. Studio course. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARTO 584. Advanced Photography: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Investigates photographic practice and philosophy through readings and discussion; students engage in personal studio practice and class critiques. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTO 352; ARTO 353 or 4/554.

CourseID: P ARTO 590. Issues and Practices in Photography. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: M.F.A. standing only

CourseID: P ARTR 245. Introduction to Printmaking. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to printmaking methodologies. Explores the unique print, multiples, and variable edition; techniques may include monotype, linocut, collagraph, etching, and screen print. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ARTR 346. Relief. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creative exploration of graphic and conceptual possibilities through woodcut and related relief printing methods; techniques include block cutting, registration, single and multicolor printing. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTR 245.

CourseID: P ARTR 347. Intaglio. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques of etching, drypoint, engraving, aquatint, soft ground, lift ground, white ground, embossment, relief plate printing. Emphasizes personal imagery development. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTR 245.

CourseID: P ARTR 348. Screen Printing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creative exploration of graphic and conceptual possibilities through screen printing; techniques include registration, color, edition printing, and stencil-making using hand-drawn, photographic, and digital methods. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTR 245.

CourseID: P ARTR 446. Intermediate and Advanced Printmaking. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Further exploration of printmaking techniques and concepts with an emphasis on creating a body of work; includes research, discussion, readings, and critiques. Prereq: two terms from ARTR 245, 346, 347, 348, 349.

CourseID: P ARTR 490. Issues and Practices in Printmaking. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing.

CourseID: P ARTR 546. Intermediate and Advanced Printmaking. 4-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Further exploration of techniques and concepts with emphasis on discussion and creative work. Content varies by term and may include color methods, chine collé, monoprints. Repeatable. Prereq: ARTR 346 or 347 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ARTR 590. Issues and Practices in Printmaking. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: M.F.A. standing.

CourseID: P ARTS 288. Sculpture I: Mixed Media. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigation of 3-D forms in space using a range of processes. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: ART 115, 116, 233.

CourseID: P ARTS 393. Sculpture II: [Topic]. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Integration of concepts and materials in sculpture; investigation of individual methodology. Topics vary by term: wood, moldmaking, steel. Reading, presentation on issues and artists. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: ARTS 288.

CourseID: P ARTS 490. Issues and Practices in Sculpture. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: B.F.A. standing.

CourseID: P ARTS 491. Methodologies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores conceptually driven topics in sculpture such as formless, assemblage, and new landscapes. Sequence with ARTS 288, 393, 493. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: ARTS 393.

CourseID: P ARTS 493. Advanced Sculpture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for students who have completed several upper-division sculpture courses. Individual and group critiques; development and articulation of individual voice. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ARTS 288, ARTS 393.

CourseID: P ARTS 590. Issues and Practices in Sculpture. 3-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive critique, discussion, readings, and presentations. Prereq: M.F.A. standing.

CourseID: P ARTS 591. Methodologies: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores conceptually driven topics in sculpture such as formless, assemblage, and new landscapes. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P AAD 250. Art and Human Values. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses fundamental aesthetic theory and practice questions resulting from viewing art as a powerful communicator of social and cultural values. Values, rights, and responsibilities of the contemporary visual environment.

CourseID: P AAD 251. The Arts and Visual Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores ways in which physical, perceptual, affective, and cognitive modes of learning interact when viewing, interpreting, and assessing designed visual information within sociocultural contexts.

CourseID: P AAD 252. Art and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses sociocultural factors influencing roles of women and men in arts disciplines. Examines underlying social structures that affect how we define art and artists.

CourseID: P AAD 301. Understanding Arts and Creative Sectors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Mapping the concepts of "art world" and "creative sector" as they relate to each other and to the practice of arts administration.

CourseID: P AAD 312. Arts Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the field of professional management of arts organizations such as museums, galleries, community arts centers, and performing arts centers.

CourseID: P AAD 315. Funding the Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the marketing and fundraising management functions in arts organizations such as museums, galleries, community arts centers, and performing arts organizations.

CourseID: P AAD 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current topics are The Cultural Museum, The History Museum, Performing Arts Policy and Administration.

CourseID: P AAD 420. Event Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines management practices and trends of special events, festival, celebrations, and fundraisers sponsored by organizations.

CourseID: P AAD 421. Cultural Programming. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the practice and theory related to arts and cultural programming in the public sector.

CourseID: P AAD 422. Arts Program Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores program theory, principles, and practices associated with comprehensive arts programs.

CourseID: P AAD 425. Ethics in the Arts and Museums. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces current ethical concerns relevant to museums and the audiences they serve and focuses on the philosophical and practical dilemmas faced by exhibiting institutions.

CourseID: P AAD 429. Museum Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines theory and practice of museum education. Analyzes program-development approaches for university and community audiences; creates educational materials for campus and local museums.

CourseID: P AAD 430. Youth Arts Curriculum and Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teachers in training are provided introductory knowledge and skills necessary for implementing arts instruction as an integral part of the core curriculum for younger learners.

CourseID: P AAD 434. Entrepreneurship and the Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides exploration into the evolution of entrepreneurship in the arts; instructs emerging artists to assess their entrepreneurial potential and develop strategic planning skills in finance, legal issues, and cultural leadership.

CourseID: P AAD 435. Arts Business Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Integrating the entrepreneurial startup process with business skills; developing the strategies needed to transform creative ideas into successful ventures.

CourseID: P AAD 450. Art in Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts derived from anthropology, philosophy, sociology, and art education are used to examine fine, popular, folk, industrial, and environmental art forms in contemporary society.

CourseID: P AAD 451. Community Cultural Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of services that art and art educators perform in the community. Explores settings, constituencies, philosophical approaches, methodologies, planning, and funding of community art programs.

CourseID: P AAD 462. Cultural Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the impact of cultural policies and institutions on opportunities of the artistic community, on what art forms are made accessible, and on the general aesthetic welfare of the public.

CourseID: P AAD 471. Performing Arts Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines development of cultural-policy institutions and processes worldwide; emphasis on understanding contemporary American cultural-policy issues. Governance and strategic planning; executive leadership; management; revenue; developing audiences; cross-cultural interactions.

CourseID: P AAD 472. Artistic Administration in the Performing Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on developing leadership and management skills for professional nonprofit performing arts administration (e.g., theater, music, opera, dance). Topics in artistic administration, programming, artist management, and operations and production management.

CourseID: P AAD 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current topics are The Cultural Museum, The History Museum, Performing Arts Policy and Administration.

CourseID: P AAD 520. Event Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines management practices and trends of special events, festival, celebrations, and fundraisers sponsored by organizations.

CourseID: P AAD 521. Cultural Programming. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the practice and theory related to arts and cultural programming in the public sector.

CourseID: P AAD 522. Arts Program Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores program theory, principles, and practices associated with comprehensive arts programs.

CourseID: P AAD 525. Ethics in the Arts and Museums. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces current ethical concerns relevant to museums and the audiences they serve and focuses on the philosophical and practical dilemmas faced by exhibiting institutions.

CourseID: P AAD 529. Museum Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines theory and practice of museum education. Analyzes program-development approaches for university and community audiences; creates educational materials for campus and local museums.

CourseID: P AAD 530. Youth Arts Curriculum and Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teachers in training are provided introductory knowledge and skills necessary for implementing arts instruction as an integral part of the core curriculum for younger learners.

CourseID: P AAD 550. Art in Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concepts derived from anthropology, philosophy, sociology, and art education are used to examine fine, popular, folk, industrial, and environmental art forms in contemporary society.

CourseID: P AAD 551. Community Cultural Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of services that art and art educators perform in the community. Explores settings, constituencies, philosophical approaches, methodologies, planning, and funding of community art programs.

CourseID: P AAD 562. Cultural Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the impact of cultural policies and institutions on opportunities of the artistic community, on what art forms are made accessible, and on the general aesthetic welfare of the public.

CourseID: P AAD 571. Performing Arts Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines development of cultural-policy institutions and processes worldwide; emphasis on understanding contemporary American cultural-policy issues. Governance and strategic planning; executive leadership; management; revenue; developing audiences; cross-cultural interactions.

CourseID: P AAD 572. Artistic Administration in the Performing Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on developing leadership and management skills for professional nonprofit performing arts administration (e.g., theater, music, opera, dance). Topics in artistic administration, programming, artist management, and operations and production management.

CourseID: P AAD 612. Cultural Administration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a grounded foundation for course work in the Arts and Administration Program.

CourseID: P AAD 616. Arts Marketing, Media & Communication I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This class is the first part of a two-course sequence introducing students to issues shaping relationships between marketing, media, and communication in arts and culture sector work.

CourseID: P AAD 617. Arts Marketing, Media & Communication II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This class is the second part of a two-course sequence introducing students to issues shaping relationships between marketing, media, and communication in arts and culture sector work. Prereq: AAD 616.

CourseID: P AAD 630. Research Methodology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Scientific bases and classification of research; methodologies used in descriptive, analytical, and experimental research. Development of research proposals and critique of research reports.

Descriptions: P Conceptualize, research, and develop proposal for graduate thesis or project. Prereq: AAD 630

CourseID: P AAAP 531. National Register Nomination. 3 Credits.

CourseID: P AAAP 535. Historical Archaeology in Preservation. 3 Credits.

CourseID: P AAAP 541. Legal Issues in Historic Preservation. 3 Credits.

CourseID: P AAAP 551. Historic Survey and Inventory Methodology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how historic inventories help communities plan for wise use of historic resources. Includes complete reconnaissance and survey documentation for historic properties and development of historic context statement.

CourseID: P ARH 101. Global Masterpieces: Monuments in Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to art and architectural history through examination of thirteen key sites from around the world. Themes include religion, politics, domesticity, and modernity.

CourseID: P ARH 204. History of Western Art I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of visual arts. Selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts studied in relation to the ancient cultures producing them.

CourseID: P ARH 205. History of Western Art II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of visual arts. Selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts studied in relation to the medieval to early Renaissance cultures producing them.

CourseID: P ARH 206. History of Western Art III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of visual arts. Selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts studied in relation to the Renaissance to modern cultures producing them.

CourseID: P ARH 208. History of Chinese Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of the visual arts of China. Selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts studied in relation to the culture in which they were produced.

CourseID: P ARH 209. History of Japanese Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical survey of the visual arts of Japan. Selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts studied in relation to the culture in which they were produced.

CourseID: P ARH 210. Contemporary Asian Art and Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Broad survey of modern and contemporary Asian art, architecture, and film.

CourseID: P ARH 211. Survey of Latin American Arts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the rich tradition of visual arts within Latin America from the pre-Columbian period, through the art of the Spanish viceroyalties, to the contemporary artistic landscape.

CourseID: P ARH 300. Critical Approaches to Art-Historical Study. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methodologies used to study art history (historic, iconographic, formal). Materials drawn from Asian and Western artistic traditions; bibliography, oral presentations, and papers. Prereq: junior standing, major status.

CourseID: P ARH 314. History of World Architecture I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of global architectural developments from prehistory to the Middle Ages. Series with ARH 315.

CourseID: P ARH 315. History of World Architecture II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of global architectural developments from c. 1400 to the present. Series with ARH 314.

CourseID: P ARH 317. Romanesque Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines Romanesque architecture through the lens of pilgrimage, a major cultural force in the Middle Ages.

CourseID: P ARH 322. Art of Ancient Greece. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major traditions, functions, and styles of Greek art from the Bronze Age through the Archaic to the Classical and Hellenistic periods.

CourseID: P ARH 323. Art of Ancient Rome. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major traditions, functions, and styles of the art of ancient Italy and the Roman Empire, from the Etruscans through the Republic to the art of Constantine the Great.

CourseID: P ARH 324. Art and Politics in the Ancient World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of art and architecture by leading figures and states to shape and express the political environment and ideologies of the ancient world. Propagandistic art from Egypt to Rome.

CourseID: P ARH 326. The Acropolis of Athens. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The principal architectural and sculptural monuments of the Athenian Acropolis. Emphasis on works from the Age of Pericles. Selected literary texts read in translation.

CourseID: P ARH 327. Medieval Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the most important monuments of the Middle Ages, spanning the fourth through the 15th centuries with the primary focus on Western Europe and Byzantium.

CourseID: P ARH 341. Italian Renaissance Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Painting and sculpture of the Renaissance and mannerist periods analyzed in terms of style, iconography, theory, patronage, and social context.

CourseID: P ARH 343. Northern Renaissance Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Painting and graphic arts in the Netherlands, Germany, and France in the 15th and 16th centuries. Van Eyck, Durer, Holbein, other leading artists. Harper.

CourseID: P ARH 348. Rome in Age of Bernini. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Painting, sculpture, architecture, urbanism in 17th-century Rome with special reference to Bernini, the dominant figure. Patronage and society in the city of the popes.

CourseID: P ARH 350. History of Manga. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the history of Manga (Japanese comics) from the 19th Century to the present.

CourseID: P ARH 351. 19th-Century Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to artistic movements in Europe from 1780 to the 1880s including neoclassicism, romanticism, realism, and impressionism.

CourseID: P ARH 352. Art of the Enlightenment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores European art of the 18th century. Lectures cover major movements—rococo, chinoiserie, neoclassicism, early romanticism —in the context of changing social values, the scientific revolution, secularization, and globalization.

CourseID: P ARH 353. Modern Art, 1880–1950. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Modern art from postimpressionism to abstract expressionism in relation to intellectual and historical developments. Series with ARH 354.

CourseID: P ARH 354. Contemporary Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of contemporary art in the West from 1945 to the present in relation to historical, social, cultural, and political concerns.

CourseID: P ARH 358. History of Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design from the late 18th century to the present--considered in relation to social, political, and technological developments.

CourseID: P ARH 359. History of Photography. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Photography from the early 19th-century to the present, aesthetics of the medium, its relationship to painting and the graphic arts, and its social role.

CourseID: P ARH 373. 20th Century Latin American Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines art and architecture across 20th-century Latin America, with special emphasis on the formation and expression of ethnic, cultural, regional, and national identity through them.

CourseID: P ARH 387. Chinese Buddhist Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to selective aspects of the history of Buddhist art in China. Emphasis on sculpture and painting.

CourseID: P ARH 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year and reflect the interests of faculty members.

CourseID: P ARH 403. Thesis. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Prereq: ARH 401; major standing.

CourseID: P ARH 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year and reflect the interests of faculty members.

CourseID: P ARH 424. Classical Greek Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Greek art in the 5th and 4th centuries BC. Emphasizes major artistic programs of Olympia and Athens and classical attitudes toward the representation of the human form. Prereq: ARH 204 or ARH 322.

CourseID: P ARH 451. Studies in 19th-Century Art: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on a specific area, movement, period or issue in visual art of the long 19th century (c. 1770–1914). Repeatable once for a total of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARH 457. Contemporary Art: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics are unified by their emphasis on the historical, socio-cultural, political, and theoretical conditions associated with art since 1945. Offerings vary from year to year and reflect the interests of faculty members. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P ARH 462. Modern Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines modern architecture from 1885 to 1965, and the discourse surrounding it. Emphasis on the meanings and manifestations of modernity as these evolved in Europe, the US, and around the world. Series with ARH 461. Prereq: ARH 206, ARH 315.

CourseID: P ARH 465. American Architecture II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major developments in American architecture, 1800–1900. Includes the rediscovery of national symbols, the impact of industry, and the national focus on the single-family residence. Prereq: ARH 206 or ARH 315.

CourseID: P ARH 466. American Architecture III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Major developments in American architecture, 1885 to the present. Emphasizes academicism, the impact of international modernism, and the rediscovery of eclectic symbolism. Prereq: ARH 206 or ARH 315.

CourseID: P ARH 488. Japanese Prints. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The woodblock print in Japan as part of the cultural, social, and political conditions.

CourseID: P ARH 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Offerings vary from year to year and reflect the interests of faculty members.

CourseID: P ARH 524. Classical Greek Art. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Greek art in the 5th and 4th centuries BC. Emphasizes major artistic programs of Olympia and Athens and classical attitudes toward the representation of the human form.

CourseID: P ARH 551. Studies in 19th-Century Art: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on a specific area, movement, period or issue in visual art of the long 19th century (c. 1770–1914). Repeatable once for a total of 8 credits.

CourseID: P ARH 566. American Architecture III. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ARH 588. Japanese Prints. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P ARH 611. Graduate Studies in Art History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to bibliographic resources research methodology, and critical issues in art history. Prereq: major standing.

Introduction to structure, construction, and construction installation drawings. PD 323 or ARCH 484 or IARC 484 or interior architecture minor status.

Descriptions: P Formulation of individual design projects for IARC 488/588, 489/589. Development of project issues and documentation of context, site, and building information; includes research, case studies, and programming. Prereq: IARC 473, 484.

CourseID: P IARC 447. Color Theory and Application for the Built Environment. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of color in the built environment including principal color systems, methods of color harmony, effects of visual phenomena, and various psychological, cultural, and historic implications. Prereq: PD 350 or ARCH 484 or IARC 484 or interior architecture minor status.

CourseID: P IARC 471. Interior Construction Elements. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P The properties and detailing of materials used in interior design construction. Code issues that affect interior construction field trips to supply sources and projects. ARCH 470.

CourseID: P IARC 472. Interior Finishes and Design Application. 3 Credits.

Descriptions: P Focuses on the design of a small, sustainable interior architecture design project and the production of a set of working drawings. Prereq: ARCH 462, 484 or IARC 471, 472, 484; coreq: IARC 473.

Descriptions: P Student-initiated studies in interior design for the terminal project. Emphasis on comprehensive and integrative study. Prereq: IARC 445.

CourseID: P IARC 489. Interior Design Comprehensive Project II. 8 Credits.

Descriptions: P Principles of lighting with focus on integration of electric illumination and space. Design for lighting, calculations, and available systems and sources tested through models and drawings. Prereq: ARCH 484/584 or IARC 484/584; ARCH 492/592.

CourseID: P IARC 572. Interior Finishes and Design Application. 3 Credits.

Descriptions: P Projects in design and construction of custom furniture, preparation of detailed shop drawings, shop procedure. Prereq: IARC 444/544; ARCH 484/584 or IARC 484/584.

CourseID: P IARC 587. Working Drawings. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the design of a small, sustainable interior architecture design project and the production of a set of working drawings. Prereq: ARCH 562, 584 or IARC 571, 572, 584; coreq: IARC 573.

CourseID: P IARC 588. Interior Design Comprehensive Project I. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Student-initiated studies in interior design for the terminal project. Emphasis on comprehensive and integrative study. Prereq: 36 credits in IARC design studios.

CourseID: P IARC 589. Interior Design Comprehensive Project II. 8 Credits.

CourseID: P LA 196. Field Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P LA 227. Introduction to Landscape Architecture. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploring the background and scope of the profession: its history, ethics, goals, skills, topics, achievements, and evolving challenges in making healthy, functional, and beautiful places.

CourseID: P LA 260. Understanding Landscapes. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Perception, description, and explanation of landscapes as environmental sets, as biophysical processes, and as cultural values.

CourseID: P LA 289. Landscape Architectural Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of places, their use, and how they evolve. Fundamentals of environmental awareness, social factors, and small-scale site design; abstract design and elementary graphic techniques. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 326. Plants: Fall. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Characteristics, identification, and design uses of deciduous trees, shrubs, vines, and ground covers. Emphasis on identification and appropriate use in landscape design.

CourseID: P LA 327. Plants: Winter. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Characteristics, identification, and design uses of ornamental conifers and broad-leaved evergreen trees, shrubs, and ground covers. Prereq: LA 326.

CourseID: P LA 328. Spring Plants. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on flowering plants, their identification, design use, and ecosystem services they provide. Plant identification focuses on flowering trees and shrubs, groundcovers and perennials, with the intention of understanding how flowering plants may be used in design to support both human needs and ecosystem functions.

CourseID: P LA 333. Photography and Environmental Values. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores major movements in landscape photography through the lens of cultural perceptions and policies about landscape and environment.

CourseID: P LA 337. Landscape Field Work: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Direct examination and appraisal of the function, form, content, and composition of example landscapes in relation to ecological, cultural, legal, technical, aesthetic, and economic objectives. Repeatable twice for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P LA 350. Landscape Media. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of freehand drawing and visualization skills; exercises on line, tone, texture, and color for plan, section, and perspective drawings. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 352. Digital Landscape Media. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introductory survey and skill development in a range of basic computer graphic tools used in landscape architecture. Includes image processing, computer drawing, modeling, and drafting. Repeatable once for maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: LA 350.

CourseID: P LA 362. Landscape Technologies I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops understanding of contours, contour manipulation, and site engineering methodologies in the design of places; fundamentals of inclusive design, stormwater management, earthwork, and design development.

CourseID: P LA 366. Landscape Technologies II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Consideration of aesthetic and engineering properties of materials and processes of landscape construction; communication of design intent through documentation including sources and costs. Prereq: LA 362.

CourseID: P LA 375. Contemporary American Landscape. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of the contemporary American land-scape as an expression of American culture.

CourseID: P LA 390. Urban Farm. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experimentation with food production in the city; rebuilding urban soils; farm animal-plant relationships; nutrient cycles. Cooperative food production and distribution; use of appropriate technologies. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Concentrated programs of study on special topics. Regular offerings include Fire Ecology and Management, Landscape Design.

CourseID: P LA 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised field laboratory work; clinical or in-service educational experience. Planned programs of activities and study with assured provisions for adequate supervision. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 413. Analyzing Landscape Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops skills for collecting data and understanding how landscapes function in space and time to inform good decision-making in planning and design. Prereq: one course in geography or biology or environmental studies.

CourseID: P LA 415. Computers in Landscape Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Development, application, and evaluation of computer systems for land use and site planning (e.g., geographic information systems); encoding of data, cell storage, and analysis systems.

CourseID: P LA 417. Computer-Aided Landscape Design. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding and use of computer-aided drafting and design technology for executing landscape design development, evaluation, and presentation tasks.

CourseID: P LA 423. Drawing The Landscape. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of the varied ways to represent and understand the form, cultural meaning, social content, history, natural dynamics, regional context, spiritual intentions, and technical functions of urban and rural landscapes.

CourseID: P LA 433. Japanese Garden. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the art, form, meaning, and experience of Japanese gardens. Special emphasis on their heartland in the valley of Nara and Kyoto.

CourseID: P LA 439. Landscape Architectural Design and Process. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate problems in landscape architecture design. Relations among problem concepts, goals, design theory, communication media, and technical analysis. Repeatable four times for a total of 30 credits. Prereq: LA 289.

CourseID: P LA 440. Introduction to Landscape Planning Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of designing land- and waterscapes for human use and settlement. Ecological, social, and economic analyses of landscapes, resources, and patterns of occupancy in the Eugene-Springfield area. Prereq: LA 413.

CourseID: P LA 441. Principles of Applied Ecology. 2-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of ecological concepts to landscape design, planning, and management. Emphasis on spatially explicit problem-solving over a range of spatial and temporal scales. Prereq: one course in ecology.

CourseID: P LA 450. Advanced Landscape Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The role of media in design inquiry; development of hard-line drawing skills, diagramming, and principles of graphic design. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 459. Landscape Technology Topics. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of topics in landscape construction and maintenance. Topics include irrigation, lighting, special structures, water management, and road design. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P LA 462. Professional Practice of Landscape Architecture. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to key aspects of professional practice, fundamental professional skills, and professional career planning. Includes licensure, legal aspects of landscape architecture, career options, business management, and project management.

CourseID: P LA 474. History of Landscape Architecture I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First in a sequence covering the history of landscape architecture. Explores the history and theory of the designed landscape from the beginnings of human settlement to the 19th century.

CourseID: P LA 484. Landscape Perception. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the human-environment relationship as it relates to landscape perception, landscape archetypes, and the development of a theoretical base for contemporary landscape design.

CourseID: P LA 489. Site Planning and Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced problems in landscape architecture, cultural determinants of site planning and design, design development and natural systems and processes as indicators of carrying capacity. Repeatable. Prereq: LA 362, LA 366, LA 439.

CourseID: P LA 490. Comprehensive Project Preparation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Finding, describing, programming, and probing environmental opportunities and problems.

CourseID: P LA 494. Land Planning and Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Problems in landscape architecture of increased cultural complexity. Land use planning, computer-aided ecological analysis of land, environmental impact, urban and new community design. Prereq: LA 489; fifth-year standing for undergraduates.

CourseID: P LA 499. Comprehensive Project. 8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced planning and design projects in landscape architecture. Studio development of individually selected projects. Prereq: LA 490.

CourseID: P LA 508. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Concentrated programs of study on special topics. Regular offerings include Fire Ecology and Management, Landscape Design.

CourseID: P LA 513. Analyzing Landscape Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops skills for collecting data and understanding how landscapes function in space and time to inform good decision-making in planning and design.

CourseID: P LA 515. Computers in Landscape Architecture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development, application, and evaluation of computer systems for land use and site planning (e.g., geographic information systems); encoding of data, cell storage, and analysis systems. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 517. Computer-Aided Landscape Design. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding and use of computer-aided drafting and design technology for executing landscape design development, evaluation, and presentation tasks.

CourseID: P LA 523. Drawing The Landscape. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of the varied ways to represent and understand the form, cultural meaning, social content, history, natural dynamics, regional context, spiritual intentions, and technical functions of urban and rural landscapes.

CourseID: P LA 533. Japanese Garden. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the art, form, meaning, and experience of Japanese gardens. Special emphasis on their heartland in the valley of Nara and Kyoto.

CourseID: P LA 539. Landscape Architectural Design and Process. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intermediate problems in landscape architecture design. Relations among problem concepts, goals, design theory, communication media, and technical analysis. Repeatable four times for a total of 30 credits.

CourseID: P LA 540. Introduction to Landscape Planning Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of designing land- and waterscapes for human use and settlement. Ecological, social, and economic analyses of landscapes, resources, and patterns of occupancy in the Eugene-Springfield area. Prereq: LA 513.

CourseID: P LA 541. Principles of Applied Ecology. 2-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of ecological concepts to landscape design, planning, and management. Emphasis on spatially explicit problem-solving over a range of spatial and temporal scales. Prereq: one course in the natural sciences.

CourseID: P LA 550. Advanced Landscape Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The role of media in design inquiry; development of hard-line drawing skills, diagramming, and principles of graphic design. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LA 559. Landscape Technology Topics. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of topics in landscape construction and maintenance. Topics include irrigation, lighting, special structures, water management, and road design. Repeatable thrice for maximum of 10 credits.

CourseID: P LA 562. Professional Practice of Landscape Archtecture. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to key aspects of professional practice, fundamental professional skills, and professional career planning. Includes licensure, legal aspects of landscape architecture, career options, business management, and project management.

CourseID: P LA 574. History of Landscape Architecture I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P First in a sequence covering the history of landscape architecture. Explores the history and theory of the designed landscape from the beginnings of human settlement to the 19th century.

CourseID: P LA 584. Landscape Perception. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of the human-environment relationship as it relates to landscape perception, landscape archetypes, and the development of a theoretical base for contemporary landscape design.

CourseID: P LA 589. Site Planning and Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced problems in landscape architecture, cultural determinants of site planning and design, design development and natural systems and processes as indicators of carrying capacity. Repeatable. Prereq: LA 539.

CourseID: P LA 594. Land Planning and Design. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Problems in landscape architecture of increased cultural complexity. Land-use planning, computer-aided ecological analysis of land, environmental impact, urban and new community design. Prereq: LA 489/589.

CourseID: P LA 603. Dissertation. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P LA 605. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.

CourseID: P LA 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Introduction to Landscape Literature.

CourseID: P LA 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Intensive study combining practical projects with instruction on special topics related to landscape problems.

CourseID: P LA 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Supervised field laboratory work; clinical or in-service educational experience. Planned programs of activities and study with assured provisions for adequate supervision.

CourseID: P LA 617. Introduction to Landscape Architecture Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey and critique of the theoretical frameworks for landscape architecture.

CourseID: P LA 620. Landscape Research Methods I. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contemporary research issues and strategies. Theories, approaches, and techniques applicable to topics and problems in landscape architecture. Sequence with LA 621.

CourseID: P LA 621. Landscape Research Methods II. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Contemporary research issues and strategies. Theories, approaches, and techniques applicable to topics and problems in landscape architecture. Sequence with LA 620. Prereq: LA 620.

CourseID: P LA 699. Master's Project. 2-10 Credits.
Descriptions: P Student-directed and executed performance and communication of original research or project work to demonstrate advanced mastery of landscape architecture. Repeatable.

CourseID: P PPPM 205 Introduction to City Planning Maintain 4
Descriptions: P 3.00 GPA for admission into PPPM major. PPPM majors must take core courses for letter grades and pass them with a C– or better. Apply to the PPPM major. Applications are due by Monday of the fifth week of spring term.

CourseID: P WR 122 College Composition II
Descriptions: P Mathematics course General-education arts and letters group-satisfying course

CourseID: P PPPM 201. Introduction to Public Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of professional public service and the planning and management of public issues. Focuses on the goals of public services within their economic, social, and political contexts.

CourseID: P PPPM 202. Healthy Communities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical relationships of public policy, planning, and public health; how public policies can promote health; relationship of planning and policies to inequalities in health outcomes.

CourseID: P PPPM 205. Introduction to City Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to planning, using urban issues as lenses to explore transportation, housing, environment, and social equity as critical elements shaping where and how people live.

CourseID: P PPPM 280. Introduction to the Nonprofit Sector. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the nonprofit sector includes its origin, growth, oversight, and varied elements. Examines theory and research into the effectiveness of nonprofit strategies and structures.

CourseID: P PPPM 325. Community Leadership and Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores sustainable change at the community level by examining local systems and institutions: transportation, social influences, environment, housing, and the economy.

CourseID: P PPPM 327. Global Leadership and Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the role of leadership in global social, economic, and ecological sustainability. Considers population, consumption, technology, diversity, scale, nonviolent change, and community.

CourseID: P PPPM 331. Environmental Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to environmental management. Focuses on solutions to problems in managing population, pollution, and resources.

CourseID: P PPPM 340. Climate-Change Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of climate-change policy; topics include cap and trade, carbon tax, fuel efficiency standards, biofuel standards, and renewable portfolio standards.

CourseID: P PPPM 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised work experience that offers students opportunities to explore and clarify career goals, apply academic learning, enhance and learn new skills, gain experience, and network with professionals. Repeatable. Prereq: PPPM 412.

CourseID: P PPPM 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P PPPM 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.

CourseID: P PPPM 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Trial courses are taught under these numbers. See the online class schedule for current titles.

CourseID: P PPPM 412. Internship and Professional Development. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the department’s internship program and career development. Includes overview of professionalism and effective communication, resume and cover letter writing, and interviewing and networking skills.

CourseID: P PPPM 413. Quantitative Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the use of quantitative techniques to answer planning, public policy and management related questions.

CourseID: P PPPM 415. Policy and Planning Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applied problem-solving in the public policy and planning process. Examines the theoretical and methodological underpinnings of policy and planning analysis. Prereq: EC 201.

CourseID: P PPPM 418. Introduction to Public Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Administrative law, including introduction to legal research, for public administrators. Administrative procedures, implementation of policy through administrative law, judicial review, and practical applications in public agencies.

CourseID: P PPPM 422. Grant Proposal Writing. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the process of preparing grant applications and material for funded research.

CourseID: P PPPM 425. Project Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of specific techniques that lead to projects being completed on time, within budget, and with appropriate quality.

CourseID: P PPPM 426. Strategic Planning for Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Process of strategic planning for communities, government agencies, and nonprofit organizations.

CourseID: P PPPM 432. Justice and Urban Revitalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political, economic, institutional and social forces that affect the long-term vitality of cities and communities and how those factors relate to community redevelopment. Emphasis is given on how to revitalize low-income multicultural communities.

CourseID: P PPPM 434. Urban Geographic Information Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to geographic information systems in areas of environmental, demographic, suitability, and transportation-related research.

CourseID: P PPPM 438. Transportation Issues in Planning: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the social implications of various transportation-related policies and practices. Repeatable for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P PPPM 440. Land-Use Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planning in urban, rural, and connecting environments. Functions, distribution, relationships of land uses; social, economic, fiscal, physical consequences of alternative land use development patterns.

CourseID: P PPPM 441. Growth Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines motivations for managing growth. Surveys regulatory and incentive-based approaches to growth management at the state, regional, and local level. Prereq: PPPM 205.

CourseID: P PPPM 442. Sustainable Urban Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces issues revolving around cities as the nexus for environmental challenges, including land-use planning, transportation planning, community and neighborhood design, and green buildings.

CourseID: P PPPM 443. Natural Resource Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aspects of population and resource systems. Poses questions about population trends, policy, and optimum size; analyzes methods for determining resource availability and flows.

CourseID: P PPPM 444. Environmental Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of policies related to the environment: examines the design and effectiveness of specific policies.

CourseID: P PPPM 445. Green Cities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the history and future of the interface between urban growth and environmental concerns, and the technological, social, and political forces that continue to shape it.

CourseID: P PPPM 446. Socioeconomic Development Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planning for responsible economic and social development. Policy problems and issues in providing a stable economic base and social and economic well-being while avoiding environmental degradation.

CourseID: P PPPM 448. Collaboration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores theory and practice of collaboration. Presents a variety of collaboration settings with a focus on environmental and natural resource management.

CourseID: P PPPM 452. Public Participation in Diverse Communities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of community engagement strategies and tools for encouraging public participation in low income and ethnically diverse communities. Prereq: PPPM 432.

CourseID: P PPPM 455. Social Planning and Policy: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include health, crime, youth, inequality, international development, or terrorism. Repeatable twice for a total of 12 credits.

CourseID: P PPPM 460. Health Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the key health policy issues of access, cost, quality, and racial and ethnic disparities.

CourseID: P PPPM 465. Program Evaluation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the design and implementation of program evaluations.

CourseID: P PPPM 480. Nonprofit Management I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P How to manage nonprofit organizations for superior performance in a humane, responsive, and responsible manner. Distinctive characteristics of nonprofit organizations. Prereq: PPPM 280.

CourseID: P PPPM 481. Fundraising for Nonprofit Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to fundraising for nonprofit organizations. Annual giving, major gifts, planned giving, and campaigns.

CourseID: P PPPM 484. Public and Nonprofit Financial Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to financial management for public agencies and nonprofit organizations. Topics include budget processes, financial statements, financial resource management (taxes, donations, grants), expenditure systems, and capital project analysis.

CourseID: P PPPM 486. Philanthropy and Grant Making. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, economics, and practice of philanthropy and grant making in the United States. Students study philanthropy from a multidisciplinary perspective and finish the quarter by awarding a $15,000 grant to a nonprofit organization of their choice.

CourseID: P PPPM 487. Impact Philanthropy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to impact philanthropy and related topics. Evidence-based philanthropy, venture philanthropy, impact investing, social impact bonds, impact measurement, and policy environment.

CourseID: P PPPM 494. Practice of Leadership and Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the principles and practices of leadership and change in communities and organizations through discussions with community leaders and personal reflection. Prereq: major status, senior standing preferred.

CourseID: P PPPM 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Trial courses are taught under these numbers. See the online class schedule for current titles.

CourseID: P PPPM 518. Introduction to Public Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Administrative law, including introduction to legal research, for public administrators. Administrative procedures, implementation of policy through administrative law, judicial review, and practical applications in public agencies.

CourseID: P PPPM 522. Grant Proposal Writing. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the process of preparing grant applications and material for funded research.

CourseID: P PPPM 525. Project Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of specific techniques that lead to projects being completed on time, within budget, and with appropriate quality.

CourseID: P PPPM 526. Strategic Planning for Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Process of strategic planning for communities, government agencies, and nonprofit organizations.

CourseID: P PPPM 532. Justice and Urban Revitalization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the political, economic, institutional and social forces that affect the long-term vitality of cities and communities and how those factors relate to community redevelopment. Emphasis is given on how to revitalize low-income multicultural communities.
