Descriptions: P Introduction to geographic information systems in areas of environmental, demographic, suitability, and transportation-related research.

CourseID: P PPPM 538. Transportation Issues in Planning: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the social implications of various transportation-related policies and practices. Repeatable for a maximum of 8 credits.

CourseID: P PPPM 541. Growth Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines motivations for managing growth. Surveys regulatory and incentive-based approaches to growth management at the state, regional, and local level.

CourseID: P PPPM 542. Sustainable Urban Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces issues evolving around cities as the nexus for environmental challenges, including land-use planning, transportation planning, community and neighborhood design, and green buildings.

CourseID: P PPPM 543. Natural Resource Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Aspects of population and resource systems. Poses questions about population trends, policy, and optimum size; analyzes methods for determining resource availability and flows.

CourseID: P PPPM 544. Environmental Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of policies related to the environment: examines the design and effectiveness of specific policies.

CourseID: P PPPM 546. Socioeconomic Development Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planning for responsible economic and social development. Policy problems and issues in providing a stable economic base and social and economic well-being while avoiding environmental degradation.

CourseID: P PPPM 548. Collaboration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores theory and practice of collaboration. Presents a variety of collaboration settings with a focus on environmental and natural resource management.

CourseID: P PPPM 552. Public Participation in Diverse Communities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of community engagement strategies and tools for encouraging public participation in low income and ethnically diverse communities. Prereq: PPPM 532.

CourseID: P PPPM 555. Social Planning and Policy: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include health, crime, youth, inequality, international development, or terrorism. Repeatable twice for a total of 12 credits.

CourseID: P PPPM 560. Health Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the key health policy issues of access, cost, quality, and racial and ethnic disparities.

CourseID: P PPPM 565. Program Evaluation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the design and implementation of program evaluations.

CourseID: P PPPM 581. Fundraising for Nonprofit Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to fundraising for nonprofit organizations. Annual giving, major gifts, planned giving, and campaigns.

CourseID: P PPPM 586. Philanthropy and Grant Making. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, economics, and practice of philanthropy and grant making in the United States. Students study philanthropy from a multidisciplinary perspective and finish the quarter by awarding a $15,000 grant to a nonprofit organization of their choice.

CourseID: P PPPM 587. Impact Philanthropy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to impact philanthropy and related topics. Evidence-based philanthropy, venture philanthropy, impact investing, social impact bonds, impact measurement, and policy environment.

CourseID: P PPPM 604. Internship: [Topic]. 1-10 Credits.
Descriptions: P Supervised work experience that offers students opportunities to explore and clarify career goals, apply academic learning, enhance and learn new skills, gain experience, and network with professionals. Repeatable.

CourseID: P PPPM 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Community Planning.

CourseID: P PPPM 611. Introduction to Planning Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the concepts and functions of the planning process as they relate to the social, economic, political, and environmental aspects of communities and regions.

CourseID: P PPPM 612. Legal Issues in Planning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Federal and state legal relationships, the role of the courts in reviewing public sector decision-making, sources of the law, issues in land-use regulation, and basic legal research skills.

CourseID: P PPPM 613. Planning Analysis I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Data sources and methods of data collection including surveys; descriptive and multivariate analysis; computer applications; selected analytic models, population projections, cost-benefit analysis.

CourseID: P PPPM 616. Planning Theory and Ethics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Logic of the planning process; the relationship of planning to the political process and to rational decision making in governance.

CourseID: P PPPM 617. Human Settlements. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical development of cities and the ways in which city and regional contexts influence economic, social, and political processes.

CourseID: P PPPM 618. Public Sector Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the core concepts, theories, and practices that provide the foundation for the field of public policy and management.

CourseID: P PPPM 620. Research Methods in Planning I. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Communicate, execute, and evaluate research in the public sector. Students conduct original research projects from problem formulation through data analysis.

CourseID: P PPPM 621. Research Methods in Planning II. 3-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students explore research topics and develop proposals for terminal project. Sequence with PPPM 620.

CourseID: P PPPM 623. Professional Development. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Articulating preliminary career goals and mapping the necessary steps to accomplish these goals.

CourseID: P PPPM 625. Community Planning Workshop. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P First in a two-term sequence of planning and problem-solving courses. Students working in teams conduct research and develop solutions to planning problems for a client community. Sequence with PPPM 626.

CourseID: P PPPM 626. Community Planning Workshop. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Last in a two-term sequence of planning and problem-solving courses. Students working in teams conduct research and develop solutions to planning problems for a client community. Sequence with PPPM 625. Prereq: PPPM 625.

CourseID: P PPPM 628. Public Sector Economics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reasons for governmental intervention and analysis of revenue sources available to governments. Includes discussion of various taxes, intergovernmental transfer policies, and user fees.

CourseID: P PPPM 629. Public Budget Administration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Resource allocation through the budget process. Analysis of budget systems, service costing, and citizen participation in the budget process.

CourseID: P PPPM 633. Public Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and practice of public service managment; leadership and organizational capacity building, including key management activities for developing effective public service organizations.

CourseID: P PPPM 636. Public Policy Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques in the policymaking process. Determining the impact of policies, comparing alternatives, determining the likelihood that a policy will be adopted and effectively implemented. Prereq: PPPM 628 or equivalent.

CourseID: P PPPM 637. MPA Policy Analysis Project. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Students team to produce a professionally oriented policy analysis memorandum and presentation on an assigned topic in a 48-hour period. Prereq: PPPM 636.

CourseID: P PPPM 638. MPA Capstone Applied Research Project I. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Team prepare applied research projects for client organizations using analytical and managerial skills to solve problems in public policy analysis or public management. Sequence with PPPM 639. Prereq: PPPM 618, 629, 633, 636, 657, 684.

CourseID: P PPPM 639. MPA Capstone Applied Research Project II. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teams prepare applied research projects for client organizations using analytical and management skills to solve problems in public policy analysis or public management. Sequence with PPPM 638. Prereq: PPPM 638.

CourseID: P PPPM 656. Quantitative Methods. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops skills in quantitative analysis. Emphasizes selecting appropriate analysis procedures and properly interpreting and reporting results.

CourseID: P PPPM 657. Research Methods in Public Policy and Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of research methods used in the analysis of public policy issues. Emphasis is on determining the appropriate methodology for a given research question. Prereq: PPPM 656.

CourseID: P PPPM 680. Managing Nonprofit Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles of effective management of nonprofit organizations. Governance, strategy, legal structure and standards, and volunteer administration.

CourseID: P PPPM 684. Public and Nonprofit Financial Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Financial management overview for public agencies and nonprofits, including budget processes, financial statements, resource management, expenditure systems, capital project analysis, and internal management control processes.

CourseID: P PPPM 685. Social Enterprise. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to social enterprises and their ecosystem. Earned revenue and social business models, social performance management, balancing financial and social objectives, funding landscape, policy environment, and taking social enterprises to scale.

CourseID: P PPPM 686. Nonprofit 48-Hour Charrette. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Requires students to complete a management memo on an assigned topic. Work is completed within a 48-hour period, mimicking the high-stakes, deadline-intensive schedule characterizing professional work in the nonprofit sector.

CourseID: P PPPM 687. Nonprofit Board Governance. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Students serve on governing boards of nonprofit organizations for one year: fall, winter, and spring terms.

CourseID: P PPPM 688. Nonprofit Consultancy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Student teams complete projects for nonprofit organizations, assessing organizational needs and capacity, evaluating alternative strategies, and recommending solutions for organizational success.

CourseID: P PD 101. Introduction to Product Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how designers invent things that help people through lectures from designers, drawing assignments, photo documentation, model-making, storytelling, and computer-aided design; product innovation, creation, and sales; and protfolio creation. Laborabory, lecture.

CourseID: P PD 223. Beginning Design Drawing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on perspective, line weight, construction with primary shapes, and shading in the creation of three-dimensional objects.

CourseID: P PD 240. Designers' Tools. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Quick model-making and additive, subtractive, and mold-using fabrication methods are applied in the creation of products in three separate projects. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116.

CourseID: P PD 301. Introduction to Design Studio. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students observe and design solutions for problems on campus in three team-based projects. Pre- or coreq: PD 370.

CourseID: P PD 323. Design Drawing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces specific techniques in drawing and modeling objects and their spatial context; the demonstration and implementation of various media and types of drawing. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits. Prereq: ART 115, PD 223.

CourseID: P PD 340. Design for Use. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides the basic theoretical underpinnings for considering the sociocultural background and design of products. Lectures and readings present main issues; discussions complete conceptual principals. Prereq: PD 350.

CourseID: P PD 350. Objects and Impacts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how design influences and is influenced by materials and manufacturing processes. Lectures, readings, and discussions present sustainability, aesthetic, and functional aspects of product design. Prereq: PD 370.

CourseID: P PD 360. Object Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Promotes a greater understanding of the material world and how everyday objects define culture.

CourseID: P PD 370. Design Process. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces design processes, from theoretical to professional, using readings, guest lectures, and experimental new structures.

CourseID: P PD 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.

CourseID: P PD 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable with change of topic. Prereq: instructor's permission.

CourseID: P PD 406. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-8 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable with change of topic. Prereq: instructor's permission.

CourseID: P PD 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P PD 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.

CourseID: P PD 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable with change of topic.

CourseID: P PD 430. Computer-Assisted Design and Production. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Meshes virtual design and physical design as students work on projects using shop tools and computer-aided design and manufacturing software and equipment. Prereq: ART 115, ART 116, PD 223.

CourseID: P PD 440. Advanced Designers’ Tools. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing a production line for twenty identical items. Prereq: PD 340.

CourseID: P PD 483. Senior Studio I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design studio focuses on personal questions that are explored through active design development. Questions may relate to issues of user interface, sustainability, or societal problems. Sequence with PD 484, PD

CourseID: P PD 484. Senior Studio II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design studio focuses on global questions explored through active development. Questions may relate to issues of user interface, sustainability, or societal problems. Only for seniors with declared major status in architecture, art, interior architecture, or product design. Sequence with PD 483, 485. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits. Pre- or coreq: PD 240, PD 323, PD 340, PD 350, PD 370, PD 430, PD 483; senior standing in product design.

CourseID: P PD 485. Senior Studio III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design studio focuses on corporate questions that are explored through active design development. Questions may relate to issues of user interface, sustainability, or societal problems. Sequence with PD 483,

CourseID: P PD 486. BFA Studio I. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores problems that stress design development through innovation and the responsibility to solve complex societal, functional, and aesthetic issues. Seminar component fosters theoretical, professional, and creative discussion. Prereq: BFA standing.

CourseID: P PD 487. BFA Studio II. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second course in series of interactive studios in which students engage in independent project-based learning. Sequence with PD 486, PD 488. Prereq: PD 486, BFA standing.

CourseID: P PD 488. BFA Studio III. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third course in series of interactive studio in which students engage in independent project-based learning. Sequence with PD 486, PD 487. Prereq: PD 487, BFA standing.

CourseID: P SPD 650. Sports Product Materials and Manufacturing. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the materials science, manufacturing, and sustainability theories applied in sports product design. Prereq: SPD 684.

CourseID: P SPD 684. Research Methodology and Innovation Process Studio. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the design theories and methodologies used to design innovative sports products.

CourseID: P SPD 685. Sports Product Design Studio I. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theories and creative problem-solving methods used to design solutions for sports soft goods. Theories of human thermoregulation, hydroprotection, support, aerodynamics, wearable technology, and kinematics. Prereq: SPD 684.

CourseID: P SPD 686. Sports Product Design Studio II. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theories and creative problem-solving methods used to design solutions for sports footwear. Mechanical theories of cushioning, stability, support, traction, and slipping-sliding. Prereq: SPD 650, SPD 685.

CourseID: P SPD 687. Sports Product Design Studio III. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theories and creative problem-solving methods used to design solutions for sports hard goods. Performance theories are considered to generate creative solutions. Prereq: SPD 650, SPD 686.

CourseID: P SPD 688. Innovative Project Strategy Development Studio. 6 Credits.
Descriptions: P First of a two-term capstone studio that critically examines the alignment of design, materials, science, sustainability, research, and business theories to create an innovative sports product design opportunity. Prereq: SPD 650, SPD 687.

CourseID: P SPD 689. Collaborative Creation and Launch Studio. 9 Credits.
Descriptions: P Second of a two-term capstone studio that critically examines the alignment of design, materials, science, research, and business theories to create an innovative sports product design opportunity. Prereq: SPD 688.

CourseID: P EDUC 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Exploring Careers in Education.

CourseID: P EDUC 406. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Peer Advising Experience.

CourseID: P EDUC 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Advanced Professional Practices.

CourseID: P EDUC 611. Survey of Educational Research Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of qualitative, quantitative, and single-subject research methods. Students develop competence in using published research to inform decision-making in various settings.

CourseID: P EDUC 612. Social Science Research Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of qualitative, quantitative, and single-subject research methods. Emphasis on introducing students to considerations, issues, and techniques of social science research design.

CourseID: P EDUC 614. Educational Statistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foundations of statistical methods for research producers. Covers sampling methods, descriptive statistics, standard scores, distributions, estimation, statisticalsignificance testing, T tests, correlation, Pearson’s chi-square test, power, effect size. Prereq: EDUC 612.

CourseID: P EDUC 620. Program Evaluation I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on small-scale evaluations, particularly in the field of education and human services. Students plan and design an evaluation. Prereq: EDUC 640.

CourseID: P EDUC 621. Program Evaluation II. 3-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Implementation and completion of the evaluation design defined in Program Evaluation I. Prereq: EDUC 620.

CourseID: P EDUC 630. Qualitative Methodology I: Interpretivist Inquiry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the history of qualitative research in the study of human experience, emphasizing interpretive approaches to qualitative research that retain the regulative ideal of objectivity.

CourseID: P EDUC 632. Qualitative Methodology II: Postcritical Inquiry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the epistemic limits of representing human experience, and the political and ethical implications for researchers beginning with Marx. Pre- or coreq: EDUC 630.

CourseID: P EDUC 634. Qualitative Methodology III: Posthumanist Inquiry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines theoretical influences on qualitative research beginning with those associated with the linguistic turn, then critiquing the linguistic turn, and ending with the ontological turn. Pre- or coreq: EDUC 630, EDUC 632.

CourseID: P EDUC 636. Advanced Qualitative Methodology: New Materialisms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines contemporary theoretical explorations prompted by “the new materialisms” and how questions of ontology and materiality produce considerations of agency, data, subjectivity, voice, and analysis. Pre- or coreq: EDUC 630, EDUC 632, EDUC 634

CourseID: P EDUC 640. Applied Statistical Design and Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Factor analysis of variance, planned comparisons, post hoc tests, trend analysis, effect size and strength of association measures, repeated measures designs. Prereq: EDUC 614.

CourseID: P EDUC 642. Multiple Regression in Educational Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application and use of multiple regression in educational research. Topics include bivariate regression, multiple regression with continuous and categorical independent variables. Prereq: EDUC 640.

CourseID: P EDUC 644. Applied Multivariate Statistics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced statistical techniques including covariance analyses, discriminant function analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, principal components analysis, exploratory factor analysis. Prereq: EDUC 640.

CourseID: P EDUC 646. Advanced Research Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a deeper understanding of educational research with an emphasis on principles of research designs and their use in applied research. Offered alternate years. Prereq: EDUC 640.

CourseID: P EDUC 650. Single-Subject Research Methods I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic single-subject design strategies and general procedures as well as issues related to conducting and analyzing single-subject research in applied settings. Prereq: EDUC 614.

CourseID: P EDUC 652. Single-Subject Research Methods II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical evaluation of single-subject and group-analysis research designs; elaboration on critical topics in single-subject methodology. Prereq: EDUC 650.

CourseID: P EDUC 654. Advanced Applied Behavior Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Doctoral-level seminar designed to provide skills, practice, and knowledge in advanced methods and theory of applied behavior analysis. Prereq: EDUC 652.

CourseID: P EDUC 656. Advanced Analysis of Single-Case Research. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on application of statistical and meta-analytic strategies for analyzing single-case research. Sequence with EDUC 650, 652, 654. Offered alternate years. Prereq: EDUC 650. One course in structural equation modeling or hierarchical linear modeling is recommended preparation.

CourseID: P FHS 331 Group and Community Interventions 3 FHS 406 Special Problems: [Topic] 2 FHS 407 Seminar: [Topic]

CourseID: P FHS 406 Special Problems: [Topic] 2 FHS 407 Seminar: [Topic]
Descriptions: P 1 Upper-division elective courses

CourseID: P CPSY 217. Foundations of Student Health and Well-Being. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents the risks and protective factors for college students during the developmental stage of emerging adulthood, and strategies for reducing risk and enhancing well-being.

CourseID: P CPSY 417. Introduction to Counseling Psychology Profession. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P An examination of counseling psychology as a specialty that emphasizes multicultural approaches to serving individuals, families, and groups through clinical practice and research.

CourseID: P CPSY 420. Positive Psychology. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the field of positive psychology, the scientific study of human strengths and virtues that contribute to meaning and well-being.

CourseID: P CPSY 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Ecological Bases of Behavior is a current topic.

CourseID: P CPSY 611. Ethics Discussion for Counseling Psychology. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Focuses on current ethical standards of professional practice for psychologists and Oregon’s legal requirements, applied to roles and settings of counseling psychologists.

CourseID: P CPSY 612. Professional Ethics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ethical and legal concerns in the professional practice of psychology. Ethical theory and decision-making processes; legal aspects of client-psychologist relationships.

CourseID: P CPSY 613. Introduction to Counseling Psychology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical foundations of counseling psychology. Major theories and theorists. Counseling as an ecological and context-sensitive interactive process. Settings and roles of the profession.

CourseID: P CPSY 614. Theories of Counseling. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of selected historical and current counseling theories.

CourseID: P CPSY 615. Counseling Diverse Populations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influence of gender, race, ethnicity, and other factors related to diverse populations on the identity-formation process in contemporary society. Applications to counseling psychology.

CourseID: P CPSY 617. Theories of Career Development. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses life-span career development including issues, concepts, and definitions; theories of career development and choice; intervention in strategies; and career resources in the context of a multicultural society.

CourseID: P CPSY 621. Lifespan Developmental Psychology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding continuity and change in human development and the ways in which the development of children, adolescents, and adults can be enhanced. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P CPSY 622. Psychological Assessment II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Selection and administration of instruments and procedures for generating personality and career assessment reports. Emphasizes the integration of assessment into the intervention planning process. Includes laboratory.

CourseID: P CPSY 626. Psychological Services for Latinos. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provide graduate students with content specific to carrying out human services work and research with those who are Latino and/or Spanish-speaking.

CourseID: P CPSY 635. Social Aspects of Behavior. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course introduces research and concepts related to social influences on human behavior, including prejudice, conformity, aggression, prosocial behavior, internalized social norms, and social cognition.

CourseID: P CPSY 642. Child-Family Interventions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Empirically oriented interventions with children and families, ranging from early childhood through adolescence. Integrates developmental and intervention sciences.

CourseID: P CPSY 643. Community and Preventive Interventions. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and practice in community intervention designed to prevent mental and physical health problems. Includes health promotion, work-site interventions, school and community prevention programs.

CourseID: P CPSY 645. Health Promotion and Equity. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course introduces theoretical and empirical work in prevention-focused health psychology, integrating cultural, developmental, and community psychology concepts as they pertain to health related behaviors.

CourseID: P CPSY 651. Advanced Individual Counseling Intervention. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on applying interpersonal process and problem-management approaches to individual counseling and psychotherapy; using assessment information in treatment planning.

CourseID: P CPSY 654. Supervision and Consultation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on didactic knowledge of supervision theory, research, models of practice, and evidence-based practices in supervision and consultation and acquisition of supervision and consultation skills. Students refine their knowledge of supervision theory, research, and techniques and integrate these into supervision and consultation activities.

CourseID: P CFT 412. Healthy Relationships. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses the knowledge, skills, and behaviors associated with engaging in healthy relationships.

CourseID: P CFT 512. Healthy Relationships. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses the knowledge, skills, and behaviors associated with engaging in healthy relationships.

CourseID: P CFT 612. Parenting Interventions. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines evidence-based practices for parenting children and adolescents, including trauma-focused parenting strategies.

CourseID: P CFT 614. Child Mental Health and Diagnosis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes the etiology, nosology, phenomenology, and diagnosis of mental health disorders in children. Examines social and cultural assumptions about "normal"versus "pathological" behavior, cognition, and emotion.

CourseID: P CFT 615. Introduction to Marriage Family Therapy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the distinct disciplines of marriage and family therapy.

CourseID: P CFT 616. Systems Theory Foundations. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys macro theories and their relationship to families and family therapy with emphasis on systems, communications, and ecological theories.

CourseID: P CFT 620. Mental Health and Diagnosis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of maladaptive behavior, treatment, and prevention emphasizing the integrative contributions of biological, behavior, cognitive, psychodynamic, humanist-existential, and community perspectives, including the "Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders."

CourseID: P CFT 621. Ethics Discussion. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides an opportunity to more fully examine and discuss ethical and legal considerations for couples and family therapists with emphasis on relational-systemic elements of ethical decision-making.

CourseID: P CFT 622. Relational Assessment. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines evidence-based practices for assessment in couples therapy. Integrates systems and communication theory with emerging contextual and behavior-assessment models.

CourseID: P CFT 624. Group Psychotherapy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents basic elements of group process; includes introduction to group work, guidelines for multicultural practice, ethical and professional issues in group practice, and group leadership.

CourseID: P CFT 625. Violence, Trauma, and Healing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories and research on the acceleration and cessation of violence in the family and assessment of responses to violent family behaviors and to perpetrators, survivors, and families.

CourseID: P CFT 626. Human Sexuality in Counseling. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Increases understanding and clinical abilities for working with couples; special emphasis on the role of intimacy and sexual relationships.

CourseID: P CFT 627. Advanced Theories in Relational Therapy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studies theories and models of couples and family therapy; self-evaluation of clinical work. Examines integration, specifically the "metaframeworks" model,solution-focused therapy, and emotionally focused therapy.

CourseID: P CFT 628. Addiction and Recovery. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Increases the conceptual understanding and skills of family therapists working with contemporary issues; emphasis on addictions and addiction recovery.

CourseID: P CFT 629. Intimate Partner Therapy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of systems theory to problems within relationships and their resolution. Includes research findings, assessment, motivation, change, content and process, ethics, and social-macro considerations.

CourseID: P CFT 630. Wellness and Spirituality. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an understanding of existential issues, spirituality, and wellness. Working with clients' life-cycle stages and health-stress issues; resources to promote wellness.

CourseID: P CFT 632. Medical Family Therapy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the theory, fundamentals, and practical applications of medical family therapy.

CourseID: P FHS 199. . 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P FHS 213. Issues for Children and Families. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P FHS 213. Issues for Children and Families. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and problems confronting children and families in modern society. Issues such as disability, poverty, health care, addictions, racism, and violence are addressed.

CourseID: P FHS 215. Exploring Family and Human Services. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the historic basis and current design of family and human services. Emphasizes services to children, youth, adults, and families.

CourseID: P FHS 216. Diversity in Human Services. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides glimpses into various social groups and the rudimentary knowledge, awareness, and skills required to function effectively as a social-service worker within diverse populations.

CourseID: P FHS 320. Instructional Methods in Early Childhood I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Explores an array of knowledge- and evidenced-based practices that ensure excellence in teaching young children.

CourseID: P FHS 321. Instructional Methods in Early Childhood II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Explores communication, language, and social emotional development in young children. Teaching strategies for infants, toddlers, and preschoolers in early childhood settings that promote social communication.

CourseID: P FHS 322. Instructional Methods in Early Childhood III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Explores early literacy, print awareness, group reading, evaluation of children’s books, and literacy for dual-language learners.

CourseID: P FHS 327. Organizational Issues in Human Services. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories and policies on the organization of human services. Emphasizes the evaluation of outcomes of services for children, youth, adults, and families. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 328. Human Development in the Family Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines human development within the context of the family from an evidence-based perspective. Integration of contemporary family issues experienced across the lifespan within the context of the human service profession. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 329. Youth Psychopathology in Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents child and adolescent psychopathology and problems within a diagnostic framework. Topics address psychosocial issues for youth in family and cultural contexts. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 330. Individual Interventions in Ecological Contexts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the concept of individual interventions within an ecological model. Provides knowledge and development of basic listening skills and how to apply these skills to individuals in diverse contexts. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 331. Group and Community Interventions. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the concept of group intervention within the context of group theory and community development. Provides knowledge and development of group interventions, including group facilitation skills and curriculum development. Prereq: FHS 330.

CourseID: P FHS 404. . 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P FHS 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

CourseID: P FHS 420. Research in Human Services. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of research to reform practice in human services. Trends and issues in assessment and evaluation in human services are provided.

CourseID: P FHS 430. Foundations in Early Childhood Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the history and theories of early education with a focus on societal factors that affect development.

CourseID: P FHS 431. Early Childhood and Human Services Curriculum. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theoretical and historical context of primary curriculum models used in early childhood education and human service settings that serve at-risk children and families.

CourseID: P FHS 432. Assessment in Early Childhood Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores educational, environmental, and family assessments in early childhood education and human service settings.

CourseID: P FHS 482. Prevention of Youth Violence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and practice in community interventions designed to prevent youth violence. Includes home, school, and community-based interventions.

CourseID: P FHS 483. Prevention of Interpersonal Violence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines interpersonal violence and community-based prevention using ecological, multicultural, international frameworks. Emphasizes assessment, prevention, intervention, and simultaneous occurrence of adult violence and child maltreatment.

CourseID: P FHS 491. Junior Professional Practices and Issues I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and behaviors associated with being a community service professional. Includes ethical standards for professional practice. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 492. Junior Professional Practices and Issues II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and behaviors associated with being a community service professional. Includes ethical standards for professional practice. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 493. Junior Professional Practices and Issues III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and behaviors associated with being a community service professional. Includes ethical standards for professional practice. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 494. Senior Professional Practices and Issues. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and behaviors associated with being a community service professional. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 495. Senior Professional Practices and Issues. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues and behaviors associated with being a community service professional. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 496. Senior Project Proposal. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Students create a written proposal outlining rationale, project description, and timelines for completing the senior project. Prereq: major status.

CourseID: P FHS 497. Senior Project. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students develop a written product or project in conjunction with faculty members and field site personnel. Prereq: FHS 496.

CourseID: P FHS 582. Prevention of Youth Violence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and practice in community interventions designed to prevent youth violence. Includes home, school, and community-based interventions.

CourseID: P FHS 583. Prevention of Interpersonal Violence. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines interpersonal violence and community-based prevention using ecological, multicultural, international frameworks. Emphasizes assessment, prevention, intervention, and simultaneous occurrence of adult violence and child maltreatment.

CourseID: P PREV 631. Introduction to Prevention Science. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of theory, research, and practice in prevention science and health promotion, including foundational concepts, translation of theory into intervention, methodology, and implementation.

CourseID: P PREV 632. Risk and Resilience in Adolescents. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and theory related to risk and resiliency processes during adolescence and young adulthood. Focuses on populations at elevated risk for adverse outcomes.

CourseID: P PREV 633. Contemporary Issues in Public Health. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course introduces approaches, concepts, methods, and perspectives of epidemiology as applied to current public health issues and prevention science research and practice.

CourseID: P PREV 634. Implementation Science. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a framework for examining implementation science and its application to clinical and community-based research. Prereq: CPSY 631 or CPSY 643; a graduate-level statistics course.

CourseID: P EDLD 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include 21st-Century Leadership, Peer Mentoring.

CourseID: P EDLD 211. Exploring Leadership. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding the context of leadership for the common good and for change in educational and social systems; establishing basic skill-building in project management fundamentals to promote effective leadership.

CourseID: P EDLD 311. Equity Leadership and Social Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides foundational exposure to current scholarship and practice in approaches that promote equity and inclusion within professional educational and social service settings. Prereq: EDLD 211.

CourseID: P EDLD 312. Effective Leadership Decision-Making. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces basic concepts of evidence-based decision-making. Addresses theoretical frameworks for decision-making, statistical applications, common decision-making errors, and ways to involve diverse individuals and groups in making decisions. Prereq: EDLD 211.

CourseID: P EDLD 313. Program Evaluation for Future Leaders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to evaluation theory and evaluation research design; potential uses and limitations of program evaluation in the public and private sector through study, discussion, and application of course materials. Prereq: EDLD 211.

CourseID: P EDLD 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Human Services, Peer Health Education.

CourseID: P EDLD 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Advanced Peer Support, International Educational Leadership.

CourseID: P EDLD 411. Examining Leadership Effectiveness. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed for students who enroll in a proposed minor program yet to be named. Focuses on analysis of personal commitments and goals in the context of leadership for social change. Prereq: EDLD 211.

CourseID: P EDLD 412. Leading Change in Organizations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills for leading change within an organization: planning, managing, enacting, surviving, and evaluating personal and organizational change. Prereq: EDLD 211.

CourseID: P EDLD 422. Globalization and Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the implications of globalization on education and educational systems around the world.

CourseID: P EDLD 450. Data and Information Retrieval. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Presents multimedia information search and organization procedures for use with public libraries, websites, and institutional and governmental clearinghouses.

CourseID: P EDLD 460. Measurement and Assessment. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers foundational knowledge in measurement and assessment.

CourseID: P EDLD 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Human Services, Peer Health Education.

CourseID: P EDLD 522. Globalization and Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the implications of globalization on education and educational systems around the world.

CourseID: P EDLD 530. Comparative Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Graduate-level seminar focusing on major educational issues of concern to scholars in the field of comparative education.

CourseID: P EDLD 560. Measurement and Assessment. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers foundational knowledge in measurement and assessment.

CourseID: P EDLD 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Administrator Licensure, International Higher Education, Superintendent.

CourseID: P EDLD 610. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Advanced Measurement and Assessment, Equity and Achievement, Foundations of Educational Research, Hierarchical Linear Modeling, Master's Research Writing.

CourseID: P EDLD 612. Reading Interventions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on providing research-based reading interventions to school-age struggling readers. Includes field experience tutoring a child at the Center on Teaching and Learning Reading Clinic on campus.

CourseID: P EDLD 613. Reading Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the empirical research that serves as the scientific basis for advancing reading pedagogy and practice.

CourseID: P EDLD 614. Literacy for Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on instructional strategies for designing and delivering effective literacy instruction and content area supports for intermediate and middle school students with diverse learning and/or linguistic abilities. Prereq: EDLD 612.

CourseID: P EDLD 618. Data-Based Decisions in Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines data-based decision-making in the context of reading development and instruction from kindergarten through twelfth grade.

CourseID: P EDLD 620. Educational Leadership. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaches leadership concepts through simulations and exercises. Covers group expectations, basic communication skills, participative decision-making, ethics, goal setting, power, and styles of influence.

CourseID: P EDLD 621. Equity and Achievement. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides basics of data analysis and interpretations regarding achievement gaps, as well as applications of multiculturally competent practices in educational administrative settings.

CourseID: P EDLD 622. Leading Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines leadership through a systems-thinking lens. Students experience how adaptive leadership sustains change and why traditional operational change fails in education.

CourseID: P EDLD 623. Cultural Adaptation of Evidence-Based Practices. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course is designed to provide an advanced foundation in models and methods for the cultural adaptation of evidenced-based prevention and treatment practices in school, community, and family settings.

CourseID: P EDLD 624. Leading for Equity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course is designed to provide advanced exposure to current research and practice in leading for equity and inclusion within professional educational settings and a strong conceptual foundation in leadership.

CourseID: P EDLD 625. Survey and Questionnaire Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students gain practical experience in the collection and analysis of social science information through the design of surveys and questionnaires.

CourseID: P EDLD 626. Social-Cultural Foundations of Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines education in US society from sociological, cultural, and structural perspectives with a focus on inequity and the intersecting roles of race, language, class, gender, and ability-disability.

CourseID: P EDLD 628. Hierarchical Linear Models I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to multilevel modeling and hierarchical data structures, random and fixed effects, intercepts and slopes as outcomes models, estimation, centering, and two-level models. Sequence with EDLD 629. Prereq: EDUC 642.

CourseID: P EDLD 629. Hierarchical Linear Models II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced topics in multilevel modeling and hierarchical data structures including three-level models with random and fixed effects, longitudinal models, and multilevel models. Sequence with EDLD 628. Offered alternate years. Prereq: EDLD 628.

CourseID: P EDLD 630. Comparative Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of higher education in selected developing countries; comparison with American higher education; relation to economic development; major problems.

CourseID: P EDLD 631. Meeting the Needs of English Learners. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reviews historical and current approaches to meeting the needs of English learners in the US. Focuses on federal, state, and local policies supporting acquisition of English.

CourseID: P EDLD 632. Educational Policy Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Systematic interpretation and analysis of issues in educational policy using techniques such as cost-benefit, competing values, impact, and effects analysis.

CourseID: P EDLD 633. Structural Equation Modeling I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory, application, and interpretation of structural equation modeling techniques. Includes covariance structures, path diagrams, path analysis, model identification, estimation, and testing. Sequence with EDLD 634. Prereq: EDUC 642.

CourseID: P EDLD 634. Structural Equation Modeling II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on structural and latent variable models, including cross-validation, mean structures, comparing groups and models, latent growth-curve analyses. Sequence with EDLD 633. Offered alternate years. Prereq: EDLD 633.

CourseID: P EDLD 638. Advanced School Law. 2-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of legal issues in school board–superintendent relations, media relations, personnel evaluation practices, student and employee rights, collective bargaining, contract management, and official complaints.

CourseID: P EDLD 641. Standards and Accountability Systems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rationale for standards and accountability systems. Reviews national, state, and local systems and ways to improve these systems. Associated policy and implementation.

CourseID: P EDLD 643. Data-Based Decision Making. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces basic concepts of evidence-based decision-making. Prereq: EDLD 560, EDUC 611, EDUC 614.

CourseID: P EDLD 644. Learning Organization. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Three facets of learning organization are integrated: structural components, informational systems, and leadership processes.

CourseID: P EDLD 646. Action Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing and implementing quasi-experimental studies in classrooms; using outcomes to enhance educational programs and provide professional development for teachers.

CourseID: P EDLD 647. Professional Issues in Education I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between scholarship, planned programs of study, preparation for comprehensive exams, master's project, and dissertation.

CourseID: P EDLD 648. Professional Issues in Education II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between scholarship, planned programs of study, preparation for comprehensive exams, master's project, and dissertation. Prereq: EDLD 647.

CourseID: P EDLD 649. Professional Issues in Education III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between scholarship, planned programs of study, preparation for comprehensive exams, master's project, and dissertation. Prereq: EDLD 648.

CourseID: P EDLD 650. Advanced Seminar Educational Research Methods. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines special issues in the use and application of educational statistics and research design in a discussion-seminar format. Prereq: EDUC 640.

CourseID: P EDLD 655. Analysis of Teaching and Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Increases understanding of theories of learning and methodologies of teaching through analysis of relationship between teaching and learning.

CourseID: P EDLD 657. Information Technology for Curriculum Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses integration of classroom educational technology. Participants explore and evaluate best practices on how, when, and why technology might be introduced into education.

CourseID: P EDLD 659. Scholarly Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops proficiency in preparing technical reports, dissertations, grant applications, and literature syntheses to communicate educational programs, processes, and results.

CourseID: P EDLD 661. Item Response Theory I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory and application of item response measurement models. Participation outcomes include knowledge of IRT models, terminology, and resources. Emphasis on popular models and underlying assumptions.

CourseID: P EDLD 663. Measurement & Assessment: Research. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers applied knowledge in measurement and assessment with an emphasis on use of measures for research purposes. Coreq: EDLD 560.

CourseID: P EDLD 665. Measurement & Assessment: Literacy. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers applied knowledge in measurement and assessment with emphasis on use of reading, writing, and language assessments for instructional and intervention purposes. Coreq: EDLD 560.

CourseID: P EDLD 667. Advanced Measurement Assessment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced foundation in educational measurement and assessment; emphasis on scale development and psychometric evaluation techniques. Introduction to methodological approaches to develop and evaluate scales designed for educational and applied research settings. Prereq: EDLD 560, EDLD 663.

CourseID: P EDLD 675. School Finance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of school finance concepts, Oregon's school financing system, political and legal considerations, taxation, state distribution formulas, school finance reform, the federal role in education.

CourseID: P EDLD 681. Program Evaluation for Educational Managers I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P A comprehensive survey of formative and summative evaluations of educational programs at schools and colleges.

CourseID: P EDLD 683. State and Local Policy Development in Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the social, economic, political, and technological forces that shape educational policy at the national, state, and local levels. Developing school district policies and assessing their consequences.

CourseID: P EDLD 684. Master's Project Proposal. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Clarifying research topics and identifying data sources and interpretation for the master's project for initial administrator licensure under the guidance of faculty advisor.

CourseID: P EDLD 685. Master's Project. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Culminating activity for students seeking initial administrator licensure master's degree. Working under the guidance of assigned faculty advisor to complete the master's project.

CourseID: P EDLD 691. Research Writing I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P First in a course sequence providing students in the doctor of education degree (DEd) program with a structured, guided opportunity to complete dissertation proposals. Sequence with EDLD 692, EDLD 693.

CourseID: P EDLD 692. Research Writing II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Second in a course sequence providing students in the doctor of education degree (DEd) program with a structured, guided opportunity to complete dissertation proposals. Sequence with EDLD 691, EDLD 693. Prereq: EDLD 691.

CourseID: P EDLD 693. Research Writing III. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Third in a course sequence providing students in the doctor of education degree (DEd) program with a structured, guided opportunity to complete dissertation proposals. Sequence with EDLD 691, EDLD 692. Prereq: EDLD 692.

CourseID: P EDLD 696. Professional Writing I: Foundations in Professional Writing. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers foundational knowledge of the American Psychological Association’s (APA) writing style as well as how to synthesize research for academic purposes. Sequence with EDLD 697, EDLD 698.

CourseID: P EDLD 697. Professional Writing II: Organization. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the types of writing required of the three doctor of education (DEd) dissertation options: scholarly article, policy analysis, and grant proposal. Sequence with EDLD 696, EDLD 698. Prereq: EDLD 696.

CourseID: P EDLD 698. Professional Writing III: Literature Review. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students write a review of research manuscripts on a professional topic and continue to learn the nuances of APA writing style. Sequence with EDLD 696, EDLD 697. Prereq: EDLD 697.

CourseID: P EDLD 699. Dissertation Methods Apprenticeship. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides doctoral students in the DEd program a structured opportunity to complete their dissertation proposal and a PowerPoint presentation on their respective proposals.

Descriptions: P 1 Assessment II EDST 440 Physical Education for Diverse

Descriptions: P Third term of second-year second-language sequence 4

Descriptions: P 4 or EDST or Equal Opportunity: Homophobia General-education course in arts and letters

Descriptions: P Assessment II EDST 422 Technology Education EDST 440 Physical Education for Diverse

CourseID: P EDST 343 EDST 464 EDST 451
Descriptions: P EDST 458 or EDST 455 Total Credits

CourseID: P EDST 111. Educational Issues and Problems. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines specific issues and problems confronting educators. Compares and contrasts different approaches to the ways in which society defines and deals with educational issues and problems.

CourseID: P EDST 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A recent topic is Exploring Educational Studies.

CourseID: P EDST 220. Beginning Applications in Educational Technology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills and exploration of computer applications useful for communicating in an educational setting.

CourseID: P EDST 225. School and Representation in Film. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines popular culture’s influence on schools and teachers along with the various mediating factors such as race, ethnicity, social class, gender, sexuality, religion, and nationality.

CourseID: P EDST 231. Teaching in the 21st Century. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of who teachers are and what teachers do in urban, suburban, and rural school settings.

CourseID: P EDST 331. Autobiography of Schooling. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Through critical autobiographies, case studies, readings and application activities, students examine and reflect on life in classrooms.

CourseID: P EDST 332. Learning, Teaching, and Assessment I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students move beyond their own critical autobiographies of life in classrooms into various disciplinary literatures on learning, teaching, and assessment. Prereq: EDST 331; coreq: EDST 338.

CourseID: P EDST 333. Learning, Teaching, and Assessment II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focus on specific school subjects that provide a context for examining the basic assumptions underlying teaching, learning, and assessment. Prereq: EDST 332; coreq: EDST 339.

CourseID: P EDST 338. Observation: Learning, Teaching, Assessment I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Students focus on listening to children to better understand how they make sense of school subjects. Pre- or coreq: EDST 332.

CourseID: P EDST 339. Observation: Learning, Teaching, Assessment II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Focuses on developing skills in observation of learning, teaching, and assessments. Coreq: EDST 333.

CourseID: P EDST 342. Curriculum Studies I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines basic assumptions underlying curriculum in specific subject areas.

CourseID: P EDST 343. Curriculum Studies II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines basic assumptions underlying curriculum development in K-12 schools. Prereq: EDST 342.

CourseID: P EDST 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Exploring Educational Studies, IDEA Reading.

CourseID: P EDST 406. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Educational Foundations.

CourseID: P EDST 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Professional Practices, Education for Minority Students, Reading in the Upper Elementary Grades.

CourseID: P EDST 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-18 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Integrated Licensure I, II, III.

CourseID: P EDST 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Foundations of Education, Science and Health Methods, Social Studies and Language Arts Methods.

CourseID: P EDST 411. Childhood Studies. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines child development from within the context of specific development and ecological theories.

CourseID: P EDST 420. Living in a Stratified Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the stratification of wealth, status, and opportunity for advancement in our society.

CourseID: P EDST 422. Technology Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines educational technology, including the theoretical, methodological, practical, and policy issues that influence the field. Prereq: EDST 220.

CourseID: P EDST 440. Physical Education for Diverse Learners. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a variety of physical education and fitness activities appropriate for children with diverse abilities.

CourseID: P EDST 451. Equal Opportunity: Ecojustice and Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines ways that schools, implicitly and explicitly, teach about the environment and human relationships to the environment. Prereq: EDST 420; coreq: EDST 458.

CourseID: P EDST 452. Equal Opportunity: Poverty. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way poverty structures and mediates educational experiences and influences the educational achievement of students. Prereq: EDST 420.

CourseID: P EDST 453. Equal Opportunity: Racism. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical development of the concept of race and its role in legitimizing colonization, genocide, and extreme maldistributions of wealth. Prereq: EDST 420.

CourseID: P EDST 454. Equal Opportunity: Patriarchy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way gender affects educational experiences and influences the educational achievement of students. Prereq: EDST 420.

CourseID: P EDST 455. Equal Opportunity: Homophobia. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way sexuality and sexual identity influence the educational experiences of students. Prereq: EDST 420. Coreq: EDST 458.

CourseID: P EDST 456. Equal Opportunity: Colonization and Genocide. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines educational institutions and their continuing part in larger social processes of colonization and cultural genocide. Prereq: EDST 420.

CourseID: P EDST 457. Equal Opportunity: Diaspora and Immigration. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way educational institutions have responded to human migration generally and to immigrant students specifically. Prereq: EDST 420

CourseID: P EDST 458. Observation: Equal Opportunity I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Engages students in the analysis of specific dimensions of educational opportunity in the field. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 3 credits. Prereq: EDST 420; coreq: one from EDST 451, 452, 453, 454, 455, 456,

CourseID: P EDST 463. Foundations of Reading. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to the various theoretical dimensions of reading and writing that form the foundation for understanding and teaching the complex texts children encounter today.

CourseID: P EDST 464. Multicultural Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces preservice teachers to literature written from ethnic, linguistic, social, and cultural perspectives and draws connections to broader cultural, social, historical, economic, and political contexts.

CourseID: P EDST 471. Foundations of Algebra Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the principles underlying the teaching and learning of algebra. Sequence with EDST 472.

CourseID: P EDST 472. Foundations of Geometry Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the principles underlying the teaching and learning of geometry. Sequence with EDST 471. Prereq: EDST 471.

CourseID: P EDST 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Professional Practices, Education for Minority Students, Reading in the Upper Elementary Grades.

CourseID: P EDST 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Foundations of Education, Science and Health Methods, Social Studies and Language Arts Methods.

CourseID: P EDST 522. Technology Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines educational technology, including the theoretical, methodological, practical, and policy issues that influence the field.

CourseID: P EDST 551. Equal Opportunity: Ecojustice and Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines ways that schools, implicitly and explicitly, teach about the environment and human relationships to the environment. Coreq: EDST 558.

CourseID: P EDST 552. Equal Opportunity: Poverty. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way poverty structures and mediates educational experiences and influences the educational achievement of students.

CourseID: P EDST 553. Equal Opportunity: Racism. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical development of the concept of race and its role in legitimizing colonization, genocide, and extreme maldistributions of wealth.

CourseID: P EDST 554. Equal Opportunity: Patriarchy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way gender affects educational experiences and influences the educational achievement of students.

CourseID: P EDST 555. Equal Opportunity: Homophobia. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way sexuality and sexual identity influence the educational experiences of students.

CourseID: P EDST 556. Equal Opportunity: Colonization and Genocide. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines educational institutions and their continuing part in larger social processes of colonization and cultural genocide.

CourseID: P EDST 557. Equal Opportunity: Diaspora and Immigration. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way educational institutions have responded to human migration generally and to immigrant students specifically.

CourseID: P EDST 558. Observation: Equal Opportunity I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Engages students in the analysis of specific dimensions of educational opportunity in the field.

CourseID: P EDST 571. Foundations of Algebra Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the principles underlying the teaching and learning of algebra. Sequence with EDST 572.

CourseID: P EDST 572. Foundations of Geometry Learning. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the principles underlying the teaching and learning of geometry. Sequence with EDST 571. Prereq: EDST 571.

CourseID: P EDST 611. The Scholarship of Teaching. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the recent emergence of a focus on teachers as reflective practitioners, inquirers, action researchers, and scholars of pedagogical understanding.

CourseID: P EDST 612. Foundations of Teaching and Learning. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with the psychological foundations of teaching and learning.

CourseID: P EDST 614. Cultural Context of Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the cultural foundations of educational practice through a critical review of four decades of ethnographic research on school and student culture.

CourseID: P EDST 615. Technology and Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to major contemporary issues affecting education in the digital age.

CourseID: P EDST 616. Language, Power, and Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the politics, policies, and practical realities associated with language and literacy in educational settings and how these issues affect all students to some degree.

CourseID: P EDST 618. Teaching English Language Development, K–12. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines best practices of delivering English-language development in light of federal and state standards, including teaching methods, technology, and parental involvement.

CourseID: P EDST 619. Teaching for Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares middle and high school teachers who are expected to teach specific content areas and literacy strategies as part of a reading endorsement. Offered as needed.

CourseID: P EDST 620. Evolution and the Math Wars. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the debates that influence, and in some cases overshadow, the teaching of mathematics and science from kindergarten to grade 12. Sequence with EDST 621, 622 (or 623, 624); 625, 626.

CourseID: P EDST 621. Representing Mathematical Concepts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students deepen their content knowledge, widen their understanding of student conceptualizations of mathematics, and reflect on their own mathematics instructional practices. Sequence with EDST 620, 622, 625,

CourseID: P EDST 622. Mathematical Problem-Solving Curriculum. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares students to view mathematics as a problem-solving field rather than a set of discrete skills and operational rules. Sequence with EDST 620, 621, 625, 626. Prereq: EDST 621.

CourseID: P EDST 623. Representing Science Concepts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines why science is taught, what science subjects need to be taught, and how science is learned. Sequence with EDST 620, 624, 625,

CourseID: P EDST 624. Scientific Problem-Solving Curriculum. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents science as a problem-solving field rather than a set of discrete facts and concepts. Introduces scientific literacy as the aim of science teaching. Sequence with EDST 620, 623, 625, 626. Prereq: EDST 623.

CourseID: P EDST 627. Introduction to Supportive Learning Communities. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Introduces the teacher candidate to the necessary components for creating supportive and successful classroom communities, including interaction between motivation, “classroom management,” and teacher-student relationships. Sequence with EDST 628.

CourseID: P EDST 628. Creating Supportive Classroom Communities. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Builds on EDST 627 by providing specific research, experience, and strategies for developing classroom environments where student behaviors are focused on learning. Sequence with EDST 627. Prereq: EDST 627.

CourseID: P EDST 630. Humanities Curriculum and Cultural Conflict. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the epistemology and conceptions of education that underlie the humanities curriculum at the secondary level. Sequence with EDST 631, 632 (or 633, 634 or 635, 636); 637; 638.

CourseID: P EDST 631. Representing Literature to Young People. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines why literature is taught and the way teachers represent literary works to students. Sequence with EDST 630, 632, 637, 638.

CourseID: P EDST 632. Engaging Students in Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of strategies and tools for engaging students in the writing process. Emphasis on genres of writing and use of technology to enhance student writing. Sequence with EDST 630, 631, 637, 638. Prereq: EDST 631.

CourseID: P EDST 633. Representing Second-Language Concepts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a research-based foundation for planning, teaching, assessing, and managing second-language learning for the great diversity of students encountered in middle and high school. Sequence with EDST 630, 634, 637, 638.

CourseID: P EDST 634. Second-Language Conversation and Composition. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced teaching methodologies, techniques, and skills to effectively promote proficiency and fluency in second languages. Sequence with EDST 630, 633, 637, 638. Prereq: EDST 633.

CourseID: P EDST 635. Representing Social Studies Concepts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines why social studies is taught and the way teachers represent social studies concepts to students. Sequence with EDST 630, 636, 637,

CourseID: P EDST 636. Social Studies Inquiry and Analysis. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the theory and practice of teaching social studies as a specialized form of inquiry. Sequence with EDST 630, 635, 637, 638. Prereq: EDST 635.

CourseID: P EDST 638. English Language Learners Pedagogy for Humanities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines a variety of research-based instructional and assessment strategies that support English language learners in meeting the curricular mandates of mainstream language arts and social studies courses. Sequence with EDST 630; 631, 632 (or 633, 634 or 635, 636);

CourseID: P EDST 640. Constructing Meaning through Literacy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides concepts and strategies used in teaching children to read. Focuses in particular on instruction for beginning and intermediate readers and writers. Sequence with EDST 641.

CourseID: P EDST 641. Developing Thoughtful Literary Practices. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the teaching of reading as a practice filled with cultural meaning, placing reading education in its wider social and cultural context.

CourseID: P EDST 642. Pedagogical Methods in the Humanities. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the application of language arts and social studies methods and strategies for future elementary school practitioners.

CourseID: P EDST 643. Teaching Mathematics: Facts and Inquiry. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on four areas of instruction crucial to becoming a skillful beginning teacher of mathematics. Sequence with EDST 644.

CourseID: P EDST 644. Teaching Mathematics: Inquiry in Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates techniques and strategies used to effectively teach mathematics and assess students. Sequence with EDST 643. Prereq: EDST 643.

CourseID: P EDST 645. Teaching Science: Detail and Discovery. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes science as a process of contemplating, exploring, and raising questions about the world in elementary classrooms.

CourseID: P EDST 646. English Language Learners Pedagogy for Elementary Classrooms. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines a variety of research-based instructional and assessment strategies that support English language learners in meeting the mandates of elementary-level curriculum.

CourseID: P EDST 650. Teacher Education: Policy and Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the work of contemporary scholars who are attempting to bridge the division between policy and practice in teacher education. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 652. Teacher Education: Analyzing Foundational Concepts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines foundational concepts that shape research and practice in teacher education. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 654. Learning and Motivational Sciences. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the learning and motivational sciences for advanced graduate students. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 660. Urban Schools: History and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical, economic, political, legal, and social context of contemporary urban schooling systems. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 661. Sociology: From Reproduction to Resistance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the ways schools reproduce, reinforce, and challenge prevailing social, economic, and political relationships. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 662. Curriculum Theory: Contesting Educational Content. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of the history of curriculum theory, the subfield that asks the fundamental question, what is worth teaching? Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 663. Education and Immigration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the way educational institutions have responded to human migration generally and to immigrant students, with an emphasis onbilingual education policy. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P EDST 666. Thesis Writing. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Seminar for doctoral students who have advanced to candidacy. Emphasis is on support through the dissertation proposal writing process. Repeatable as needed.

CourseID: P EDST 667. Grant Writing: Finding Funders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides graduate students with the knowledge and skills needed to write successful grant proposals for research, professional development, and curriculum development projects.

CourseID: P EDST 670. Philosophy of Research. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the philosophical assumptions that underlie various research methodologies in the human and social sciences.

CourseID: P EDST 673. Advanced Qualitative Methodology: Arts-Based Approaches. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines contemporary reflexive social science research writing, focusing on experimentations with the form used by researchers to communicate insights about human affairs. Pre- or coreq: EDUC 630, EDUC 632, EDUC 634.
