CourseID: P ASL 101. First-Year American Sign Language. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of basic grammatical structure and vocabulary of American Sign Language, expressive and receptive finger-spelling, and introduction to American deaf culture. Prereq: WR 122 or WR 123 or HC 221H or HC 231H.

CourseID: P ASL 102. First-Year American Sign Language. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Increased receptive and expressive communication skills in ASL, and study of cultural values and behavioral rules of the deaf community. Prereq: C- or better or P in ASL 101 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ASL 103. First-Year American Sign Language. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concentration on understanding and acquiring advanced conversational proficiency. Emphasis on ASL classifiers. Continued study of deaf culture as a linguistic minority. Prereq: C- or better or P in ASL 102 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ASL 201. Second-Year American Sign Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applied conversational use of ASL through literature, narratives, poetry, and plays. Explores various underlying metaphors found in ASL literature. Prereq: C- or better or P in ASL 103 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ASL 202. Second-Year American Sign Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasis on more abstract and challenging conversational and narrative ranges. Lab and readings cover historical aspects of deaf community and culture. Prereq: C- or better or P in ASL 201 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ASL 203. Second-Year American Sign Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Further emphasis on more abstract and challenging conversational and narrative ranges. Explores broader political and social activities of international deaf community. Prereq: C- or better or P in ASL 202 or equivalent.

CourseID: P ASL 301. American Deaf Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the relationship between small groups and dominant culture in the United States. Explore issues of language, culture, self-representation, identity, and social structure.

CourseID: P CDS 201. Communication Disorders in Society and Media. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of communication disorders and differences, comparing individual and social-cultural perspectives through popular media and real case examples. Prereq: WR 121.

CourseID: P CDS 430. Speech Pathology-Audiology as Professions. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the broad dimensions of the speech-language pathology and audiology professions. Begins undergraduate process of acquiring observation hours required for graduate school. Sequence with CDS 431.

CourseID: P CDS 431. Beginning Clinical Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on basic methods for assessment and intervention within an evidence-based framework. Includes fifteen hours of guided observation. Sequence with CDS 430. Prereq: CDS 430.

CourseID: P CDS 442. Anatomy and Physiology of Speech Mechanism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of anatomy, physiology, and neurology of speech and language processes.

CourseID: P CDS 443. Acoustics of Speech. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Acoustic measurement and analysis of sound production and reception in human communication.

CourseID: P CDS 444. Clinical Phonetics and Phonology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on sounds and symbols of American English, foreign accents, and dialects using broad and narrow transcription methods. Presents speech production, distinctive features, and basics of phonology. Prereq: CDS 442, 450.

CourseID: P CDS 446. Services for Deaf Students. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides understanding of deaf and hard-of-hearing students’ educational experiences and includes the cultural, linguistic, social, and pedagogical factors contributing to successful service provision.

CourseID: P CDS 450. Introduction to Language Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Primary focus on the development of phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, pragmatics, and literacy. Prereq: LING 150 and WR 122 or 123.

CourseID: P CDS 451. Later Language Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed to promote an in-depth study of language development in school-age children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 6–20 years). Prereq: CDS 450.

CourseID: P CDS 455. Child and Adolescent Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers theories, norms, and concepts related to child and adolescent development. Geared toward allied health professionals and educators working in a variety of settings.

CourseID: P CDS 457. Fundamentals of Audiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy and physiology of hearing and vestibular systems; causes, types, and symptomatologies of hearing impairment.

CourseID: P CDS 458. Audiology Disorders and Treatment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Pure tone, speech and impedance audiometry. Special tests, difficult-to-test populations, and central auditory processing. Audiogram interpretation and report writing. Prereq: CDS 457/557.

CourseID: P CDS 460. Developmental Disorders in Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores growth and developmental disorders that cause or contribute to child and adult speech, language, and fluency impairments. Prereq: CDS 450.

CourseID: P CDS 462. Acquired Disorders of Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores neurologic disorders that cause or contribute to child and adult speech, language, and voice impairments. Prereq: CDS 470.

CourseID: P CDS 470. Neuroscience of Speech and Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foundation in normal neuroanatomy and neurophysiology and the clinical signs observed with nervous-system damage. Prereq: CDS 442.

CourseID: P CDS 542. Anatomy and Physiology of Speech Mechanism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of anatomy, physiology, and neurology of speech and language processes.

CourseID: P CDS 543. Acoustics of Speech. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Acoustic measurement and analysis of sound production and reception in human communication.

CourseID: P CDS 544. Clinical Phonetics and Phonology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on sounds and symbols of American English, foreign accents, and dialects using broad and narrow transcription methods. Presents speech production, distinctive features, and basics of phonology.

CourseID: P CDS 550. Introduction to Language Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Primary focus on the development of phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, pragmatics, and literacy.

CourseID: P CDS 551. Later Language Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed to promote an in-depth study of language development in school-age children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 6–20 years).

CourseID: P CDS 557. Fundamentals of Audiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy and physiology of hearing and vestibular systems; causes, types, and symptomatologies of hearing impairment.

CourseID: P CDS 558. Audiology Disorders and Treatment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Pure tone, speech and impedance audiometry. Special tests, difficult-to-test populations, and central auditory processing. Audiogram interpretation and report writing.

CourseID: P CDS 560. Developmental Disorders in Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores growth and developmental disorders that cause or contribute to child and adult speech, language, and fluency impairments.

CourseID: P CDS 562. Acquired Disorders of Communication. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores neurologic disorders that cause or contribute to child and adult speech, language, and voice impairments.

CourseID: P CDS 570. Neuroscience of Speech and Language. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Foundation in normal neuroanatomy and neurophysiology and the clinical signs observed with nervous-system damage. Prereq: CDS 542.

CourseID: P CDS 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Multicultural Issues in Communication Disorders and Sciences, Dysphagia, Professional Ethics.

CourseID: P CDS 611. Clinical Methods. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides methodology behind the sound clinical practices and fundamentals of the UO Speech-Language-Hearing Center operations. Prepares students to begin working with clients.

CourseID: P CDS 625. Final Full-Time Practicum. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Diagnostic and treatment experience in the public school setting. Repeatable once for maximum of 30 credits.

CourseID: P CDS 626. Professional Practices in the Schools. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Helps students critically assess and integrate their fieldwork and course work in the broader context of the school experience. Coreq: CDS 625.

CourseID: P CDS 649. Assessment and Treatment of Feeding and Swallowing Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nature and characteristics of feeding and swallowing; methods of evaluation and management of feeding and swallowing in adults and children.

CourseID: P CDS 651. School-Age Language Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents normal language development and language disorders in school-age children and adolescents. Emphasizes contributions from linguistics, psychology, education, and learning theory.

CourseID: P CDS 652. Speech Sound Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Causes and consequences of phonological disorders; principles and procedures for assessment and intervention.

CourseID: P CDS 654. Management of Adult Language Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a foundation in diagnosis and treatment of adult neurogenic language disorders, concentrating on aphasia and the cognitive-linguistic changes associated with dementia.

CourseID: P CDS 655. Stuttering. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on contemporary issues in stuttering. Discusses and critically evaluates current theories and research findings.

CourseID: P CDS 656. Voice Science and Disorders. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Anatomy and physiology of vocal mechanism; diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for various voice disorders.

CourseID: P CDS 657. Augmentative Procedures for Communication Disorders. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Recent advancements in design, development, and use of systems supplemental to vocal speech and language.

CourseID: P CDS 660. Motor Speech Disorders. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of speech disorders associated with lesions of central and peripheral nervous systems.

CourseID: P CDS 663. Management of Acquired Cognitive Disorders. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines current theory and practice in cognitive rehabilitation. Reviews models and tools for treating attention, memory, and dysexecutive syndromes. Prereq: CDS 662.

CourseID: P CDS 665. Language Disorders in Children. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Child language disorders and related topics, including principles of assessment and intervention, cultural awareness and sensitivity, clinical application, and working with families.

CourseID: P SPSY 617. Tests and Measurements in Education. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to measurement. Provides a theoretical and practical basis for evaluating and using the wide range of test and measurement data in educational research. Prereq: undergraduate statistics or educational psychology course or equivalent.

CourseID: P SPSY 626. Final Supervised Field Experience. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Limited to students in school psychology program for basic endorsement for an Oregon license.

CourseID: P SPSY 630. Introduction to Consultation. 3-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with basic knowledge and skills in the area of school-based consultation.

CourseID: P SPSY 632. Advanced Consultation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops and refines competencies in school-based consultation, and provides opportunities for students to practice consultation skills.

CourseID: P SPSY 650. Developmental Psychopathology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of developmental psychopathology, with emphasis on childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood. Covers phenomenology, etiology, development, classification systems, and prognosis of major psychological disorders.

CourseID: P SPSY 651. Cognitive-Affective Aspects of Behavior. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of cognitive and affective foundations of human behavior. Emphasis on reciprocal influences of cognition and emotion. Selected topics in attention,language, memory, thinking, reasoning. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P SPSY 652. Biological Aspects of Behavior. 4-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides the appropriate background for students to meet biological psychology course work requirement for board licensure as a psychologist.

CourseID: P SPSY 661. Principles and Practices in School Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theory, role, and function of school psychology in its relation to learning and the school setting.

CourseID: P SPSY 662. Foundations of Clinical Supervision. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of clinical supervision. Overview of supervision models, factors affecting the supervision relationship, supervision and evaluation techniques, legal and ethical considerations.

CourseID: P SPSY 663. Professional Ethics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the study of current ethical standards of professional practice for school psychologists and behavior analysts.

CourseID: P SPSY 671. Behavioral Assessment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles, techniques, and conceptual and practical issues in behavioral assessment; applied aspects include data gathering and interpretation as well as report writing.

CourseID: P SPSY 672. Intellectual Assessment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers individual assessment of learning aptitude. Includes administering, scoring, and interpreting intelligence tests as well as report writing. Reviews theories of intelligence.

CourseID: P SPSY 674. Educational Assessment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of educational assessment designed to develop and evaluate instructional interventions; topics include systematic observations, curriculum-based assessment, and teacher interviews.

CourseID: P SPED 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Collaborative Team, Introduction to Talented and Gifted, Introduction to Developmental Disabilities.

CourseID: P SPED 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Special Education, Talented and Gifted.

CourseID: P SPED 411. Foundations of Disability I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Categorical and cross-categorical survey of information about exceptional children and youths. Topics include history, etiology, identification, classification, legislation, alternate program delivery systems.

CourseID: P SPED 412. Foundations of Disability II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of special education and disability studies; social construction of disability; personal perspectives; societal imagery concerning disability.

CourseID: P SPED 422. Special Education Mathematics Instruction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Systematic instruction of mathematics skills for students with disabilities: assessment, planning, curriculum modification, diagnosis and remediation of persistent error patterns, evaluation.

CourseID: P SPED 426. Behavior and Classroom Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides behavior management procedures for a variety of educational environments. Emphasizes functional assessment-based behavior support planning, classroom management, and principles of applied behavior analysis.

CourseID: P SPED 431. Introduction to Learning Disabilities. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces major topics, issues, and trends in learning disabilities. Addresses the history, definitions, etiologies, theories, characteristics, instructional interventions, and service-delivery models.

CourseID: P SPED 432. Introduction to Behavioral Disorders. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the characteristics and education of children and youth who have emotional and behavioral disorders. Prereq: SPED 411.

CourseID: P SPED 436. Advanced Behavior and Classroom Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes functional assessment-based behavior support planning, individual education plans (IEPs), and effective behavior support systems for a variety of educational environments. Prereq: SPED 426.

CourseID: P SPED 440. Early Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for preschool- to early elementary-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 441, 442, 443.

CourseID: P SPED 441. Intermediate Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for late elementary- to middle school-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 440, 442, 443. Prereq: SPED 440.

CourseID: P SPED 442. Adolescent Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for middle school- and high school-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 440, 441, 443. Prereq: SPED 441.

CourseID: P SPED 443. Supporting Students with Low-Incidence Disability. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides skills on how to plan, coordinate, deliver, and evaluate evidence-based instruction for students with low-incidence disabilities. Sequence with SPED 440, 441, 442. Prereq: SPED 442.

CourseID: P SPED 488. Professional Practices: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Helps students critically assess their fieldwork and integrate fieldwork and course work in the wider context of the school experience. Repeatable twice. Coreq: SPED 406 or 409.

CourseID: P SPED 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Collaborative Team, Introduction to Talented and Gifted, Introduction to Developmental Disabilities.

CourseID: P SPED 511. Foundations of Disability I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Categorical and cross-categorical survey of information about exceptional children and youths. Topics include history, etiology, identification, classification, legislation, alternate program delivery systems.

CourseID: P SPED 512. Foundations of Disability II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of special education and disability studies; social construction of disability; personal perspectives; societal imagery concerning disability.

CourseID: P SPED 522. Special Education Mathematics Instruction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Systematic instruction of mathematics skills for students with disabilities: assessment, planning, curriculum modification, diagnosis and remediation of persistent error patterns, evaluation.

CourseID: P SPED 526. Behavior and Classroom Management. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides behavior management procedures for a variety of educational environments. Emphasizes functional assessment-based behavior support planning, classroom management, and principles of applied behavior analysis.

CourseID: P SPED 531. Introduction to Learning Disabilities. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces major topics, issues, and trends in learning disabilities. Addresses the history, definitions, etiologies, theories, characteristics, instructional interventions, and service-delivery models.

CourseID: P SPED 532. Introduction to Behavioral Disorders. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the characteristics and education of children and youth who have emotional and behavioral disorders. Prereq: SPED 411/511.

CourseID: P SPED 536. Advanced Behavior and Classroom Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes functional assessment-based behavior support planning, individual education plans (IEPs), and effective behavior support systems for a variety of educational environments. Prereq: SPED 426/526.

CourseID: P SPED 540. Early Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for preschool- to early elementary-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 541, 542, 543.

CourseID: P SPED 541. Intermediate Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for late elementary- to middle school-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 540, 542, 543. Prereq: SPED 540.

CourseID: P SPED 542. Adolescent Literacy for Diverse Learners. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on designing and evaluating instruction in the areas of reading and writing for middle school- and high school-aged students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 540, 541, 543. Prereq: SPED 541.

CourseID: P SPED 543. Supporting Students with Low-Incidence Disability. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides skills on how to plan, coordinate, deliver, and evaluate evidence-based instruction for students with low-incidence disabilities. Sequence with SPED 540, 541, 542. Prereq: SPED 542.

CourseID: P SPED 588. Professional Practices: [Topic]. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Helps students critically assess their fieldwork and integrate fieldwork and course work in the wider context of the school experience. Repeatable. Coreq: SPED 606 or 609.

CourseID: P SPED 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Advanced Applied Behavioral Analysis, Doctoral Orientation, Program Evaluation, Project Aim.

CourseID: P SPED 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Classroom Consultation; College Teaching; Elementary I,II; Program Evaluation; Research.

CourseID: P SPED 622. History of Special Education and Disability. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical context for contemporary issues in understanding and supporting the lives of people with disabilities and their families.

CourseID: P SPED 625. Final Supervised Field Experience. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P SPED 626. Grant Writing. 1-3 Credits.

CourseID: P SPED 626. Grant Writing. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides structure and guidance in developing a grant proposal.

CourseID: P SPED 628. Law and Special Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Knowledge of current case law and legislation, sensitivity to legal issues, application to legal principles related to special education services in school settings.

CourseID: P SPED 632. Collaborative Educational Planning. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Collaborating to identify unique needs of individuals with disabilities and establish legally correct, educationally useful IEPs, and to use knowledge of effective interventions to meet needs. Prereq: SPED 628 or equivalent.

CourseID: P SPED 633. Transition Planning and Instruction I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on preparing youth for postsecondary education and training. Development of skills for using assessment-planning and content-instruction strategies to assist students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 634.

CourseID: P SPED 634. . 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on strategies for improving employment and independent-living skills; using individualized assessment and planning strategies, curriculum and instructional strategies, and program delivery to assist students with disabilities. Sequence with SPED 633.

CourseID: P SPED 655. Supervised Field Experience. 5-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Provides practical experience in teaching students with disabilities in a public-school setting under the direction of cooperating teachers and university supervisors.

CourseID: P SPED 660. Design of Instruction. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Design, development, and evaluation of instructional materials for children with disabilities. Emphasis on analysis and construction of instructional sequences for various learning tasks.

CourseID: P SPED 680. Foundations in Early Childhood and Early Intervention. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conceptual underpinnings and practical application of an approach to early intervention that links assessment, intervention, and evaluation.

CourseID: P SPED 681. Family-Guided Early Intervention. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers procedures for family assessment, intervention, and evaluation. Addresses adult communication and management strategies.

CourseID: P SPED 682. Assessment and Evaluation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents assessment and evaluation materials used in early intervention programs and provides methods for using these materials.

CourseID: P SPED 683. Curriculum in Early Childhood and Early Intervention. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents curricular materials covering development from birth to six years. Discusses procedures for use and modification.

CourseID: P SPED 684. Applications of a Linked System I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides opportunities for students to implement activities in a linked approach to early intervention services; foundation for an understanding of the components of a linked system. Sequence with SPED 685.

CourseID: P SPED 685. Applications of a Linked System II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines the components of a linked system, how they influence one another, and how they are implemented within a best-practices model for early intervention–early childhood special education. Sequence with SPED 684. Prereq: SPED 684.

CourseID: P SPED 686. Autism in Early Intervention. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Information is given regarding the etiology of autism, diagnostic/ evaluation procedures and current evidence-based strategies for supporting young children with autism spectrum disorder and their families.

CourseID: P SPED 687. Early Intervention Methods I. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides practical information for conducting program-relevant assessments using curriculum-based assessment tools and for developing individualized family service plans.

CourseID: P SPED 688. Early Intervention Methods II. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides opportunity to develop effective intervention skills to use with young children who are at risk and disabled and with their families.

CourseID: P SPED 689. Early Intervention Methods III. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on advanced methods in early intervention, including special handling and management techniques.

CourseID: P SPED 690. Early Intervention Methods IV. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops advanced intervention skills to use with young children who are at risk and disabled and with their families.

CourseID: P LAW 780 LLM Seminar: Writing 2 LAW 781 LLM Seminar: In Practice 2 Core courses (JD degree holders) 11-15 Core courses (non-JD degree holders) 12-17 Elective courses in environmental and natural resources law 5-10
Descriptions: P (JD degree holders) higher education are required to take a 2-credit introductory course

CourseID: P CRES 101. Introduction to Conflict Resolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores up-to-date conflict management theories and practical steps to communicate effectively in sensitive situations.

CourseID: P CRES 351. Roles of a Diplomat. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students learn about diplomats and diplomatic practice in international conflict situations.

CourseID: P CRES 404. . 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P CRES 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.

CourseID: P CRES 415. Conflict and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the multiple relationships among conflict, violence, and gender in situations of warfare, militarization, and peacemaking.

CourseID: P CRES 420. Restorative Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a critical introduction to the principles and practices of restorative justice.

CourseID: P CRES 435. Israel and Palestine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the Palestinian and Israeli conflict. Evolution of the political struggle with a broad look at the human side of conflict, and examination of critical negotiation issues.

CourseID: P CRES 440. Dialogue across Differences. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to processes and facilitation of discourse and dialogue, with special emphasis on participation.

CourseID: P CRES 445. Conflicts of Incarceration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Issues of crime, incarceration, and justice within the Western context.

CourseID: P CRES 515. Conflict and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the multiple relationships among conflict, violence, and gender in situations of warfare, militarization, and peacemaking.

CourseID: P CRES 520. Restorative Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a critical introduction to the principles and practices of restorative justice.

CourseID: P CRES 535. Israel and Palestine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination of the Palestinian and Israeli conflict. Evolution of the political struggle with a broad look at the human side of conflict, and examination of critical negotiation issues.

CourseID: P CRES 540. Dialogue Across Differences. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to processes and facilitation of discourse and dialogue, with special emphasis on participation.

CourseID: P CRES 545. Conflicts of Incarceration. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Issues of crime, incarceration, and justice within the Western context.

CourseID: P CRES 612. Philosophy of Conflict Resolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of how philosophical and theoretical frameworks influence current views and practices of conflict resolution.

CourseID: P CRES 613. Perspectives on Conflict Resolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to interdisciplinary perspectives on conflict and conflict resolution. Various disciplines (including economies, psychology, and communication) views of conflict and conflict resolution.

CourseID: P CRES 614. Negotiation, Bargaining and Persuasion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines issues that pervade negotiations, including framing arguments, analyzing bargaining conditions, and crafting deals. Basic skills in negotiation, bargaining and persuasion developed through simulated negotiations.

CourseID: P CRES 615. Cross-Cultural Dynamics in Conflict Resolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with an opportunity to build or enhance necessary theoretical knowledge, awareness, understanding, practical skills, and strategies for effectiveness in cross-cultural conflict resolution.

CourseID: P CRES 616. Mediation Skills. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develop mediation skills such as problem framing, listening, and issue identification and sequencing. Learn to diagnose problems, clarify facts and craft interventions.

CourseID: P CRES 617. Professionalism in Practice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the legal and professional ethical constraints in the practice of conflict resolution.

CourseID: P CRES 618. Adjudication and Courts. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designed to familiarize students with litigation and formal legal alternatives such as arbitration. Court processes and regulations are explained.

CourseID: P CRES 620. Facilitation. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of facilitating group discussions and decision-making.

CourseID: P CRES 625. Psychology of Conflict. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the psychological sources, nature, and functions of conflict, covering multiple levels of analysis relevant to intrapersonal, interpersonal, intragroup, and intergroup conflict.

CourseID: P CRES 629. Arbitration Survey. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Exploring arbitration as a form of dispute resolution with particular relevance to employment, consumer, commercial, and large-scale disputes.

CourseID: P CRES 631. Managing Conflict in Organizations. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Prepares students to assist in managing disputes within organization. Covers sources of conflict, common organizational processes, and analyzing and resolving organizational disputes.

CourseID: P CRES 632. Research Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores questions that research may encounter or raise, and how to resolve them. Considers both qualitative and quantitative research methods.

CourseID: P CRES 633. Professional Development Seminar. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides incoming students with tools to be successful in the graduate program and the professional world.

CourseID: P CRES 650. Capstone Seminar. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides student with opportunities to systemically consider lessons from their practicum experiences. Class sessions based on student fieldwork.

CourseID: P CRES 651. Academic Capstone: Course Concentration. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Fulfills the course component of the course concentration final project for conflict resolution students. Prereq: students must have completed 50 percent or more of their course concentration credits prior to the term in which they enroll in this course.

CourseID: P CRES 660. Environmental Conflict Resolution. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students learn and critically examine methods of environmental conflict resolution, including conflict assessment, negotiation, decision-making, adaptive management, collaboration, and public participation.

CourseID: P CRES 665. Family Mediation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Preparation for work-related experiences in family mediation, specifically domestic relations involving custody and parenting time.

CourseID: P LAW 101. Introduction to American Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys United States legal system: presents structure and methods of the legal system and fundamentals of several substantive areas of law.

CourseID: P LAW 102. Introduction to Criminal Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores criminal law and statutes using primary and secondary sources.

CourseID: P LAW 103. Introduction to Criminal Investigation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the constitutional limitations on police officers’ authority to detain suspects, search them and their property, and interrogate them.

CourseID: P LAW 104. Introduction to Business Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the context of everyday commerce, shaped by contract, tort, business entity, and securities law, to uncover how the law both affects and is affected by business.

CourseID: P LAW 201. Introduction to Environmental Law and Policy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to environmental policy and law, with an overview of major themes and the regulatory framework. Focuses on community resilience.

CourseID: P LAW 202. Introduction to Public International Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to the origins, application, and main actors in international law, international institutions, and international legal processes.

CourseID: P LAW 203. Controversies in Constitutional Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth examination of five to seven landmark Supreme Court cases over the course of the term, spending three to four class sessions on each case.

CourseID: P LAW 204. Immigration and Citizenship. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Interdisciplinary study of the way in which the American legal order has constituted citizenship.

CourseID: P LAW 250. Introduction to Legal Research. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students investigate sources of law and sharpen analytical skills using issues arising in everyday life and scenarios requiring legal information to develop critical legal information literacy skills.

CourseID: P LAW 301. Youth and Social Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explore how adults act on youth through law, mass media, policy, and social science, while investigating youth as agents of change, acting on their own perspective of law and justice.

CourseID: P LAW 304. American Law and Families. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the family through a legal lens: the rules that affect legal relationships among family members and laws related to family property.

CourseID: P LAW 305. Contracts in Society. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines business deals as tools that shape personal and social realities, including related power dynamics and the nuances and limits of language.

CourseID: P LAW 310. Environmental Regulation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with an understanding of laws regulating activities that affect the environment as well as the skills to analyze and apply these laws to current issues.

CourseID: P LAW 415. Human Rights, Law, and Culture. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P The history, theory, and practice of human rights from a global perspective.

CourseID: P LAW 416. Transitional Justice. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Historical and theoretical overview of the conflicts and international mechanisms, with a focus on cultural, historical, and legal forces that shape postconflict peace-building efforts.

CourseID: P LAW 600. Law Courses for Nonlaw Students. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Generic course number for translating 600-level School of Law semester credits to term credits on academic records for nonlaw students.

CourseID: P LAW 607. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Accounting for Lawyers, Alternative Dispute Resolution, American Legal Biography, Immigration Law, Litigation Practice and Procedure, Mediation, Negotiation, Nonprofit Organizations, Postconviction Remedies, White-Collar Crime.

CourseID: P LAW 611. Contracts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines contractual relationships from formation through interpretation and breach to remedies and potential third-party rights. Covers the common law of contracts and Uniform Commercial Code, Article 2, which governs contracts for the sale of goods.

CourseID: P LAW 613. Torts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Liability for intentional and negligently caused injuries to person and property, strict liability, vicarious liability, abnormally dangerous activities, products liability, nuisance, invasion of privacy, defamation, defenses and immunities, the impact of insurance and risk distribution upon liability, accident compensation plans, damages, losses.

CourseID: P LAW 615. Civil Procedure. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of federal court organization and jurisdiction and of systems of civil procedure.

CourseID: P LAW 617. Property. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Nature and function of private property rights. Topics may include the common law classification of estates in land; forms of concurrent ownership; landlord and tenant; adverse possession; incorporeal interests in land, easements, covenants, and servitudes; title; introduction to land use issues and judicial legislative developments in law.

CourseID: P LAW 618. Criminal Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Administration of criminal law and the definition of crimes as a technique of social order with primary basic elements of criminal liability. Emphasis on sources of definitions, limitations of culpability, and defenses.

CourseID: P LAW 619. White-Collar Crime. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P For students interested in the practice of criminal law. Assists business lawyers who advise clients on the business practices that constitute criminal activity.

CourseID: P LAW 620. Business Associations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys business relationships between the people who own, invest in, and manage businesses and the third parties who interact with or are affected by them. Starting with sole proprietorships, then turning to partnerships, corporations, and hybrids of the two, presents the structure, operation, and salient characteristics of each business form.

CourseID: P LAW 621. Advanced Business Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents topics not covered in Business Associations I. Includes special corporate fiduciary duties that are implicated in friendly and unfriendly merger transactions as well as the federal securities laws that affect corporate governance. Prereq: LAW 620.

CourseID: P LAW 622. Legal Research and Writing I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Integrated instruction in legal research, analysis, and writing of legal memoranda emphasizes research strategies, problem solving, and the relationship between research strategies and analysis. Writing assignments, each progressively more difficult, are evaluated by faculty members. Offered in small sections. Includes library workshops and individual conferences.

CourseID: P LAW 623. Legal Research and Writing II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Building on the research, writing, and analytical skills of Legal Research and Writing I, students focus on persuasive writing as they produce trial memoranda and appellate briefs. Students present final oral arguments in a courtroom setting before a panel of three judges.

CourseID: P LAW 624. Advanced Legal Research. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills in formulating efficient research strategies online and in print; exposure to research methods in particular areas of law.

CourseID: P LAW 625. Business Bankruptcy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the law governing business bankruptcy; examines tools for restructuring and rehabilitating a business under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. Topics include operating a business in bankruptcy, reshaping the estate, and negotiating and confirming a plan of reorganization. Prereq: LAW 648.

CourseID: P LAW 626. Mergers and Acquisitions. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Participants develop an understanding of how to analyze a potential acquiree and how that analysis informs and governs the drafting of the acquisition agreement and the disclosure document. Presents the germination of a transaction from financial need to executed documentation. Prereq: LAW 620.

CourseID: P LAW 627. Accounting for Lawyers. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the accounting cycle, generally accepted accounting principles, financial statements, and common legal and accounting topics.

CourseID: P LAW 628. Nonprofit Organizations. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides an overview of the theory, purposes, and regulation of nonprofit organizations. Practical skills are developed through drafting assignments.

CourseID: P LAW 629. Fundamentals of Loans. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Covers the rights of borrowers and lenders in unsecured and secured loans in less depth than the Secured Transactions course.

CourseID: P LAW 630. Tax Policy. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores tax policy issues including how taxes are used to create social equality. Evaluates the current tax system using the three classic goals: equity, efficiency, and simplification. Prereq: LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 631. Real Estate Planning. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the planning and documentation of real estate development, financing and leasing transactions, with special emphasis on tax aspects of real estate transactions. Taught from a practical skills perspective that will appeal to practicing lawyers and other employers. Pre- or co-req: LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 632. Sales. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers contracts for the sale of goods as codified in Uniform Commercial Code Article 2; international contracts, regulation of consumer warranties, leases of goods under Article 2A.

CourseID: P LAW 633. Business Planning. 2,3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of business life cycle from its initial organization and operation to its eventual sale and dissolution. Students draft documents for use in hypothetical transactions, compare the way partnerships and corporations deal with similar problems, and analyze the impact taxes have on business decisions. Prereq: LAW 620, LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 634. Contract Drafting. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P The principles of contemporary commercial drafting, introduction to documents typically used in a variety of transactions.

CourseID: P LAW 635. Real Estate Transactions. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of real estate transactions, with a focus on secured land and finance.

CourseID: P LAW 636. Secured Transactions. 3-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the rules that govern borrowing and lending with collateral; buying and selling promissory notes and other debt; and related transactions that are essential to large and small transactions.

CourseID: P LAW 637. Trusts and Estates I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basics of estate planning law--intestate succession, wills, will substitutes, and trusts. Prereq: LAW 617.

CourseID: P LAW 638. Workers' Compensation Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Fundamentals of workers’ compensation law in Oregon and other states.

CourseID: P LAW 639. Employment Discrimination. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines theory and law of race, sex, age, disability, and other prohibited employment discrimination, including harassment. Focuses on federal statutes and relevant constitutional provisions, and applies law and theory to practice.

CourseID: P LAW 640. Children and the Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include the constitutional framework for allocating the power to make decisions about children among parents, children, and state agents; control of education; parental support duties; establishing paternity; the child welfare system; legal solutions to conflict between adolescents and their parents; and juvenile delinquency and the juvenile justice system.

CourseID: P LAW 641. Legislation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers theories of the legislative process, normative theories of statutory interpretation, and the main judicial doctrines of statutory interpretation.

CourseID: P LAW 642. International Business Transactions. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines legal issues affecting international business activity; includes forms of doing business, trading of goods, commercial terms, the UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods, financing, technology, transfers, foreign investment, and dispute resolution.

CourseID: P LAW 643. Constitutional Law I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Government structure and individual rights are examined in the context of the authority of courts to declare legislative acts unconstitutional. Includes congressional regulatory power under the Commerce Clause, implied limits on state regulatory power, and the substantive dimensions of due process.

CourseID: P LAW 644. Constitutional Law II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Guarantees of individual rights against government, especially freedom of expression and equal protection of the law. Prereq: LAW 643.

CourseID: P LAW 645. Oregon Practice and Procedure. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Intensive study of civil procedure in Oregon courts, and the critical evaluation of Oregon civil procedure in light of the purposes and values of a procedural system and in comparison with federal rules.

CourseID: P LAW 646. Federal Jurisdiction. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses the role of federal courts in the operation of the federal system. Includes analysis of constitutional and legislative foundations of the judicial power of the United States; jurisdiction--diversity of citizenship, federal question, jurisdictional amount, and removal; venue; federal and state court relationships; the law applied to federal courts; procedure in the federal district courts; appellate jurisdiction and procedure in courts of appeals and the Supreme Court.

CourseID: P LAW 647. Conflict of Laws. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students learn to evolve techniques for choosing or selecting the governing law from among the states or nations involved in a private event. Presents some aspects of federalism; jurisdiction; and the recognition, enforcement, and modification of judgments.

CourseID: P LAW 648. Bankruptcy. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to bankruptcy law; focuses on consumer bankruptcy and contrasting creditor's rights and debtor's protections under the federal Bankruptcy Code with those under state collection law. Recommended preparation: Commercial Law (LAW 636).

CourseID: P LAW 649. Legal Profession. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses the Model Code of Professional Responsibility, the Code of Judicial Ethics, roles and functions of lawyers in society, organization and functions of the bar, provision of legal service, responsibilities in representing clients, and the future of the legal profession. It may include the review and analysis of videotaped ethical problems.

CourseID: P LAW 650. Interview and Counsel. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the client-centered approach to interviewing and counseling through readings, discussions, participatory exercises, and role-playing.

CourseID: P LAW 651. Trial Practice. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces the essential techniques and theory necessary to conduct a trial in court. Prereq: LAW 652.

CourseID: P LAW 652. Evidence. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers the structure of the adversary system; roles of judge, jury, and attorney in the fact-finding process; sufficiency of evidence; order of proof; presumptions; relevancy; judicial notice; real and documentary evidence; form and elicitation of oral testimony; impeachment and rehabilitation of witnesses; the hearsay rule and its exceptions; privileges. Addresses practical problems in the introduction of evidence and trial tactics and methods. Courtroom observations, movies, and videotapes of effective trial techniques present realistic situations.

CourseID: P LAW 655. Family Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Marriage and its legal consequences, divorce and its financial consequences; establishing the parent-child relationship; child custody and child support; jurisdiction and choice of law issues at divorce; legal regulation of marriage; rights of unmarried cohabitants.

CourseID: P LAW 656. Elder Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics include social security and pensions; health care decision-making, including the right to die, living wills, and durable powers of attorney for health care; planning for health care financing, including alternate living arrangements and financing through private resources, Medicare and Medicaid; regulation of retirement facilities and nursing homes; and protection of disabled adults through guardianships, conservator-ships, and related mechanisms. Covers the basic and comprehensive writing requirements.

CourseID: P LAW 658. Local Government Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Uses DeTocqueville and Madison to frame the issue of decentralization versus centralization in governmental structure. Course materials are divided into three sections: 1) vertical governmental organization--the relationships between cities and state governments and the relation of both to the federal government; 2) horizontal governmental relations-how neighboring cities deal with one another on public school funding, exclusionary zoning, regional planning, and other areas; 3) internal relationship between cities and their citizens--voting systems, when citizens can sue a city, referenda, and initiatives.

CourseID: P LAW 659. Labor Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the National Labor Relations Act and the Oregon Labor Relations Act; the right of self-organization; selection of the representative by election and by other means; unit determination; bargaining in good faith; remedies for unfair labor practices; judicial review; strikes, boycotts, and lockouts under various labor relations acts; concerted activities; and roles of courts and labor agencies.

CourseID: P LAW 660. Employment Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines individual rights in the workplace, including federal and state statutes. Use of questionnaires, polygraph legislation, drug and other medical tests; employment discrimination (Title 7); disability discrimination; family leave statutes; and a variety of working conditions are covered, including harassment, workplace privacy, and free speech as well as the Occupational Safety and Health Act. The doctrine of at-will discharge and whistle-blower legislation are included.

CourseID: P LAW 661. Remedies. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Remedies available for prevention of redress of civil wrongs; includes monetary damages; restitutionary remedies such as tracing, constructive trusts, equitable liens, and injunctions.

CourseID: P LAW 662. Jurisprudence. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Topics may include examination of important conceptual theories of law--legal positivism, natural law, legal realism; the relation of law and morality; theories of justice: economic, Kantian, utlitarian; the Critical Legal Studies movement; philosophical aspects of legal issues; abortion and punishment; feminist theories of law; and moral constraints of the practice of law.

CourseID: P LAW 664. Administrative Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of judicial review of administrative action, including presumptions, standing, ripeness, exhaustion, and questions of fact and law; the process of proof in adjudicatory hearings, including official notice, evidentiary considerations, and investigation; the process of decision in adjudicatory hearings, including separation of function, bias, and ex parte communication; procedural distinctions between rule making and adjudication.

CourseID: P LAW 665. Securities Regulation. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the federal statutes and regulations that affect the initial and secondary distribution of securities. Emphasis is placed on the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and the integrated disclosure system now largely in place.

CourseID: P LAW 667. Copyrights. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Virtually any creative product (other than inventions) that originates with the author can be protected by copyright. Comprehensive federal copyright statute is built upon extensive judicial interpretations through case law. Considers creations, ownership, and transfer of copyright interests and the rights accorded to copyright owners to make copies and derivative works and to distribute, perform, and display the work. Addresses the basic principles of trademark law.

CourseID: P LAW 668. Land Use Law. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the function, operation, and legal impact of state and local public planning and land-use control laws, ordinances, and administrative growth-control techniques; transfer of developmental rights; zoning; variances; conditional-use permits; and nonconforming uses. Considers newer state-level land-use control devices, such as state environmental impact assessment acts (e.g., in California) and statewide land-use planning laws (e.g., in Oregon).

CourseID: P LAW 669. Water Resources Law. 2,3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reparian and appropriation water law systems, federal and state power over water resources, transfer of water rights, groundwater management, public water rights, including the public trust doctrine, and enviornmental constraints on water use.

CourseID: P LAW 670. Public Land Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Reviews the historical development of public land law and an analysis of the interrelated roles of Congres, the executive branch, the courts, and state governments in determining the use of public lands. Examines management of specific resources found on public lands: wilderness, timber, water, wildlife, grazing, minerals with attention to the growing tension between resource development and preservation of the public lands.

CourseID: P LAW 671. International Law. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Justification for state actions labeled rules of law; sources and evidence of a law between states; statehood; treaties; state responsibility and authority; individuals in transnational situations; international cooperation; protection of human rights; and use of military force.

CourseID: P LAW 673. Patent Law and Policy. 2,3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Developments in patent law including patentable subject matter; requirements for patentability and infringement; the process of obtaining and enforcing a patent; and contemporary controversies in patent law, such as ethical and economic objections to biotechnology and software patents.

CourseID: P LAW 675. Legal Writing. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research and writing supervised by a faculty member. Typically 2 credits, but never more than 3, are awarded for a writing project in one semester.

CourseID: P LAW 676. International Tax. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses the United States taxation of international transactions, including trade, investment, and labor, covering both out-bound (US to foreign) and inbound (foreign to US) transactions. Prereq: LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 678. Indian Law. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with an understanding and overview of the fundamental principles of American Indian law.

CourseID: P LAW 679. Ocean and Coastal Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys federal, state, and international laws governing the use and protection of ocean and coastal resources including relevant judicial decisions, administrative regulations, and management plans.

CourseID: P LAW 680. Federal Income Tax I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Statutory, judicial, and administrative material related to individual income tax—concepts of income, deductions, credits, tax accounting, basis, and capital gains and losses.

CourseID: P LAW 681. Federal Income Tax II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Tax treatment of partners and partnerships, corporations, and shareholders. Prereq: LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 682. Estate and Gift Taxes. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis of the federal estate and gift tax system and its application to gratuitous transfers. Prereq: LAW 637, LAW 680.

CourseID: P LAW 683. Estate Planning. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents problems in estate analysis, planning, and execution; planning an estate from the interview stage to the drafting of wills and trusts to implement the estate plan. Prereq: LAW 637.

CourseID: P LAW 684. Criminal Investigation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the regulation of law enforcement investigatory practices-searches and seizures, the eliciting of confessions, and lineups and other idenfication procedures. Course materials analyze various constitutional and statutory constraints on law enforcement practices, and deal extensively with landmark federal constitutional cases such as Miranda v. Arizona.

CourseID: P LAW 685. Criminal Adjudication. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the adjudicative part of criminal procedure; covers the decision to charge, bail and pretrial release, grand juries and preliminary hearings, discovery, pretrial motions, plea bargaining, jury trials, appeals, and former jeopardy.

CourseID: P LAW 686. Environment and Pollution. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Taught whenever possible as a seminar; class preparation is essential. Emphasizes air and water pollution law. Legal questions address federal laws, enforcement techniques, proper and improper roles of courts, and the concept of forcing technology. Context includes primarily Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act.

CourseID: P LAW 687. Wildlife Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of the treatment of wildlife; international regulation; federal regulation; the national wildlife refuge system; wildlife management on

CourseID: P LAW 688. Hazardous Waste Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hazardous waste liability and regulation is moving to the forefront of environmental law as industries, governmental agencies, and citizen groups struggle with the problems of remedying contamination caused by past disposal practices and seek to prevent unsafe disposal in the future. Emphasizes the attorney's roles in compliance counseling, in environmental audits, and in negotiation between governmental agencies and regulated parties.

CourseID: P LAW 689. Animal Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the debate between animal rights and animal welfare, and considers legal issues concerning companion animals, farm animals, laboratory animals, wild animals, feral animals, and service animals.

CourseID: P LAW 690. International Environmental Law. 2,3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Investigates treaty and customary principles of international law regarding environmental protection. Covers problems of protecting the international environmental commons, transboundary pollution, and international interest in national environmental resources.

CourseID: P LAW 691. Comparative Environmental Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Includes readings and classroom discussions; participation by U.S. staff members of the Environmental Law Alliance Worldwide; participation by international lawyers visiting Eugene under E-LAW U.S.'s "working exchange" program; pairing of students with lawyers in other countries for legal research; making legal material available to others using the web. Research paper required.

CourseID: P LAW 692. International Trade and Investment Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines U.S. and international regulatory structures, policies, and rules governing trade and investment that cross national boundaries. Emphasizes history, philosophy, and practices that characterize the World Trade Organization and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Considers regional economic arrangements and the European Union.

CourseID: P LAW 693. Human Rights and Environment. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Environmental rights, increasingly recognized as a new category of human rights as well as an application of existing rights, are both substantive and procedural. Presents recent developments in international law and national law in various countries in Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas. Examines international instruments, national constitutions, and legislation. Discussion includes novel international court cases that interpret and apply these rights.

CourseID: P LAW 694. Professional Sports Law. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Is the NFL an illegal cartel? What rights do players and unions have? Explores the regulation of professional leagues, players, teams, coaches, and agents.

CourseID: P LAW 695. Amateur Sports Law. 2-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Are student athletes pampered or victimized? What has Title IX accomplished? What’s next for the National Collegiate Athletic Association? Explores the regulation of intercollegiate and interscholastic sports.

CourseID: P LAW 696. Sports Licensing. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P A practical look into the world of sports licensing. The focus will be on examining real-world contracts and the contexts in which they were negotiated.

CourseID: P LAW 699. Antitrust Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of antitrust law in the United states, with an emphasis on current antitrust practice; recognizing, analyzing, and solving problems involving antitrust issues.

CourseID: P LAW 704. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Hollywood Externship, Federal Judicial Internship.

CourseID: P LAW 707. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics are Advanced Appellate Advocacy; Interviewing and Counseling; Journal of Environmental Law and Litigation; Legislative Issues Workshop; Moot Court Board; Moot Court Competition; Law Review; Oregon Review of International Law, Trial Practice.

CourseID: P LAW 712. Business Law Clinic. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Replicates the environment of a small law firm. Students represent small companies and entrepreneurs who need legal assistance in forming and operating their businesses. Each student assists several clients during the course of the semester under the supervision of an attorney. Includes a weekly seminar. Prereq: LAW 620, 680.

CourseID: P LAW 714. Judicial Externship [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Externship at the Lane County Circuit Court. Students conduct research, write legal memoranda, draft opinions and generally participate in the daily operation of the court. Repeatable.

CourseID: P LAW 720. Disability Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the major federal special education and disability nondiscrimination laws from a disability rights perspective.

CourseID: P LAW 721. Introduction to State Administrative Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines Oregon’s Administrative Procedure Act and Model State Administrative Procedure Act, with the added context of relevant case law.

CourseID: P LAW 722. Alternative Dispute Resolution Litigation Strategy. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides knowledge, tools and skills for lawyers to settle cases, help clients make an informed decision about settlement, and identify appropriate processes.

CourseID: P LAW 723. Oregon Constitutional Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P This course covers provisions of the Oregon Constitution that differ from, and usually provide more rights than, the US Constitution, including equal protection, free speech, search and seizure, guaranteed remedy. Prereq: LAW 643, LAW 644.

CourseID: P LAW 729. Legal Writing for the Bar. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Offers a head start on bar preparation by helping students to develop and solidify the fundamental skills needed to pass the bar.

CourseID: P LAW 730. Intensive Writing. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to ways in which lawyers communicate and gives students the opportunity to more extensively study the mechanics of effectively communicating legal analysis.

CourseID: P LAW 731. Writing in Law Practice. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides students with opportunities to develop practice-oriented writing skills in a variety of contexts.

CourseID: P LAW 732. Intensive Legal Writing. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students produce documents in a wide variety of practice settings, including office memoranda, contracts, and client letters. Students receive extensive feedback and opportunities to revise their work. Offered summer only.

CourseID: P LAW 740. Innovations in Criminal Justice. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Focuses on advanced approaches to the reduction of recidivism in the federal criminal justice system. Discussion centers on the use of therapeutic jurisprudence grounded in evidence-based practice.

CourseID: P LAW 741. Child Development and the Law. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Provides students with an overview of child development with applications for the law. Course topics span the developmental spectrum from prenatal influences through childhood.

CourseID: P LAW 742. Leadership Practices for Professional Success. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Examines leadership theories and models. Through intensive readings, exercises, introspection, and open discussion, participants develop workable insights into their own leadership styles and how to improve them.

CourseID: P LAW 743. Law of Settlement. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Survey of legal issues and lawyering practices associated with the private resolution of litigated cases, including confidentiality, economic incentives, and enforcement.

CourseID: P LAW 744. Art Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of law related to the visual arts. Analyzes laws related to the creation, purchase, sale, transfer, import and export of art; protection of artist rights.

CourseID: P LAW 750. Forensic Science in Criminal Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to forensic science and criminal law. Topics include crime scene investigation, trace evidence, serology, DNA analysis, fingerprints, firearms, documents, and pathology. Prereq: LAW 652, LAW 685.

CourseID: P LAW 760. Negotiation. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how negotiations work, what makes negotiators effective, and why negotiations fail. Focuses on analyzing and improving negotiation skills.

CourseID: P LAW 780. LLM Seminar: Writing. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Master of laws students will explore the United States legal system and legal profession through in-class workshops, legal research and writing, and oral presentations.

CourseID: P LAW 781. LLM Seminar: In Practice. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students studying for a master of laws (LLM) degree explore professional development topics and develop practice skills through in-class workshops, legal writing, a simulated symposium, and negotiation exercises.

CourseID: P LAW 790. Tribal Courts and Tribal Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines Indian law from the tribal perspective and focuses on the role of tribal lawmaking and tribal courts.

CourseID: P LAW 791. Contemporary Issues in American Indian Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides in-depth study of current issues in American Indian law and US public policy regarding Native Americans.

CourseID: P LAW 792. Comparative Law of Indigenous Peoples. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the historical and contemporary legal and policy treatment of indigenous peoples in select countries with significant indigenous populations.

CourseID: P LAW 793. Environmental Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of environmental law and policy, common-law doctrines, administrative rulemaking, environmental federalism, National Environmental Policy Act, Endangered Species Act, the regulation of hazardous waste, air and water pollution.

CourseID: P LAW 794. Natural Resources Law. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Provides a foundation in environmental law. Spans international, federal, state, and local jurisdiction, interfacing with classic environmental law (pollution statutes).

CourseID: P LAW 795. Public Trust Law. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores public trust law, which originated as judge-made law and has been enshrined in many statutes and constitutions in the United States and abroad.

CourseID: P LAW 796. Food, Farming, and Sustainability. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines how laws structure processes of food production, distribution, and consumption; surveys food and agricultural laws in review of broader questions of ecological sustainability and commerce.

CourseID: P DANC 170. Modern I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 171. Contact Improvisation. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 172. Ballet I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 175. Jazz I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 184. Ballroom I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 185. African Dance. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Tango, Hip-Hop, Salsa, Drumming, and Swing.

CourseID: P DANC 270. Modern II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 271. Dance Improvisation. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 272. Ballet II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 275. Jazz II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 372. Ballet III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 375. Jazz III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits.

CourseID: P DANC 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Tango, Hip-Hop, Salsa, Drumming, and Swing.

CourseID: P DAN 198. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Performance, Production Experience, Repertory.

CourseID: P DAN 251. Looking at Dance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of dance as a cultural and aesthetic experience. Examines its meaning and impact on contemporary United States society.

CourseID: P DAN 252. Fundamentals of Rhythm. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Essential topics in rhythm and dance; how rhythm and dance relate in various cultures with an emphasis on concert modern dance choreography; introduction to the communication of personally created movement to other dancers.

CourseID: P DAN 255. Dance Production I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to production planning, management, lighting, design, costuming, and publicity for the dance concert. Practical experience in Dougherty Dance Theatre.

CourseID: P DAN 256. Dance Somatics. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Exploration of patterning in movement. Various body therapies— Bartenieff Fundamentals, ideokinesis, and body-mind centering—provide a framework for experiential investigations.

CourseID: P DAN 260. Anatomy of Human Movement. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P An introduction to scientific reasoning focusing on methodology and current research in dance anatomy and kinesiology.

CourseID: P DAN 294. Modern Dance Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Rigorous training in modern dance as a performing art form emphasizing use of the body as an instrument, elements of movement, and performance skills. Repeatable for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 301. African Dance Aesthetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Using the field of dance studies to examine African dance aesthetics in popular culture, daily media landscapes, and expressive cultures in Africa and the diaspora.

CourseID: P DAN 351. Dance Composition I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to creation of dance movement as a communication tool. How to select, develop, vary, and phrase dance movement. Choreography of short dance studies. Prereq: DAN 252; DANC 271, 370 or above.

CourseID: P DAN 352. Dance Composition II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Compositional forms in dance. Crafting of movements into studies. Prereq: DAN 351.

CourseID: P DAN 355. Dance Production II. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Extended application of skills and procedures used in producing a concert. Practical backstage work; pre- and postconcert sessions. Repeatable eleven times for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: DAN 255.

CourseID: P DAN 360. Dance Kinesiology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Applications of anatomical, muscular, and motor control information to dance training and injury prevention.

CourseID: P DAN 394. Modern Dance Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the modern idiom. Repeatable for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 396. Ballet Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the ballet idiom. Repeatable for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Apprenticeship under the guidance of a supervising teacher in areas such as teaching, arts management, administration, and dance production. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits. Prereq: Junior standing.

CourseID: P DAN 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent topics include Choreographic Analysis, Contemporary Issues. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P DAN 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include rehearsal and performance for department-sponsored events. Prereq: Audition for performance experiences.

CourseID: P DAN 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current topics are Choreography, Production Design, and Management.

CourseID: P DAN 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current topics include Neuromuscular Bases of Dance, Topics in Technique, Composition III.

CourseID: P DAN 411. Senior Project. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P DAN 412. Student Dance Concert. 1-6 Credits.

CourseID: P DAN 412. Student Dance Concert. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students apply ideas learned about concert choreography, production, and management. In a cooperative venture, students produce dance works in Dougherty Dance Theatre. Repeatable for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: DAN 255, 352.

CourseID: P DAN 452. Dance Composition III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced skills in dance composition to engage critical creative processes for the development of substantial choreographies. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Sequence with DAN 351, DAN 352. Prereq: DAN 352.

CourseID: P DAN 453. Ballet from the Courts to Balanchine. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social and theater dance forms of Western cultures from the Middle Ages through 18th-century ballet into the era of contemporary art. Offered alternate years. Prereq: DAN 251.

CourseID: P DAN 454. Evolution of Modern Dance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Influences of leading dance artists; directions in concert and theater forms in the 20th century; emphasis on dance in the United States. Offered alternate years. Prereq: DAN 251.

CourseID: P DAN 458. Music for Dancers. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys musical form, style, and expressive content as it relates to dance. Examines the interrelationship of elements of music and dance in significant works from around the world. Prereq: DAN 252.

CourseID: P DAN 480. Dance Repertory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio course for learning dances, excerpts, or works created or reconstructed by faculty. Informal performance at end of term. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 10 credits. Coreq: DANC 300 level or above in both ballet and modern.

CourseID: P DAN 481. Repertory Dance Company: Rehearsal. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creating and rehearsing new or existing material in preparation for the spring tour. Repeatable four times. Prereq: audition or application; coreq: DANC 300 level or above in ballet and modern.

CourseID: P DAN 482. Repertory Dance Company: Touring. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lecture-demonstrations and formal performances of repertory learned in winter rehearsals. Repeatable four times. Prereq: DAN 481; coreq: DANC 300 level or above in either ballet or modern.

CourseID: P DAN 491. Teaching Dance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of teaching theories, course planning methods, teaching resources and techniques. Emphasis on teaching in university situation. Repeatable. Prereq: DAN 252, 394; DANC 271; coreq: DAN 490.

CourseID: P DAN 494. Modern Dance Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the modern idiom. Repeatable for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 496. Ballet Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the ballet idiom. Repeatable for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

Descriptions: P Recent topics include Choreographic Analysis, Contemporary Issues. Repeatable when topic changes.
