Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include rehearsal and performance for department-sponsored events. Prereq: Audition for performance experiences.

CourseID: P DAN 510. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Current topics include Neuromuscular Bases of Dance, Topics in Technique, Composition III.

CourseID: P DAN 512. Student Dance Concert. 1-6 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students apply ideas learned about concert choreography, production, and management. In a cooperative venture, students produce dance works in Dougherty Dance Theatre. Repeatable for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: DAN 255, 352 or equivalent.

CourseID: P DAN 552. Dance Composition III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced skills in dance composition to engage critical creative processes for the development of substantial choreographies. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Sequence with DAN 351, DAN 352.

CourseID: P DAN 558. Music for Dancers. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys musical form, style, and expressive content as it relates to dance. Examines the interrelationship of elements of music and dance in significant works from around the world.

CourseID: P DAN 580. Dance Repertory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio course for learning dances, excerpts, or works created or reconstructed by faculty. Informal performance at end of term. Repeatable four times for a maximum of 10 credits. Coreq: DANC 300 level or above in both ballet and modern.

CourseID: P DAN 581. Repertory Dance Company: Rehearsal. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Creating and rehearsing new or existing material in preparation for the spring tour. Repeatable four times. Prereq: audition or application; coreq: DANC 300 level or above in ballet and modern.

CourseID: P DAN 582. Repertory Dance Company: Touring. 1-12 Credits.
Descriptions: P Lecture-demonstrations and formal performances of repertory learned in winter rehearsals. Repeatable four times. Prereq: DAN 4/581; coreq: DANC 300 level or above in either ballet or modern.

CourseID: P DAN 591. Teaching Dance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of teaching theories, course planning methods, teaching resources and techniques. Emphasis on teaching in university situation. Prereq: DAN 252, 394; DANC 271; coreq: DAN 590.

CourseID: P DAN 594. Modern Dance Laboratory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the modern idiom. Repeatable for maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 596. Ballet Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Dance technique in the ballet idiom. Repeatable for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: placement audition.

CourseID: P DAN 606. Special Problems: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Formal Compositional Structure, Solo Composition, and student-initiated topics. Limited by faculty workload and availability.

CourseID: P DAN 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-16 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include Performance, Production, Rehearsal.

CourseID: P DAN 611. Research Methods in Dance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review and evaluation of written and creative research in dance and allied fields. Culminating project is a written proposal for original research in dance.

CourseID: P DAN 690. Music in the Dance Studio. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Explores issues in using music—live and recorded—in the dance technique studio. Open to graduate dance students only. Prereq: DAN 591.

CourseID: P DAN 692. Dance Literature. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to graduate studies in dance through critical reading of literature of theory and practice. Prereq: admission to graduate program in dance.

CourseID: P DAN 693. Aesthetic Bases for Dance in Art and Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories of dance as an art form; function of the dance in the changing social milieu; elements of dance criticism.

CourseID: P MUE 326. Foundations of Music Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Professional orientation for prospective school music teachers; curricular, historical, philosophical, and social foundation of music education; ethical, professional, and social aspects of teaching; comprehensive field experience. Extra fee.

CourseID: P MUE 386. Teaching Laboratory I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Practice in teaching using microteaching techniques and music education methods in a laboratory setting. Prereq: admission to music education. Coreq: MUE 442.

CourseID: P MUE 387. Teaching Laboratory I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Practice in teaching using microteaching techniques and music education methods in a laboratory setting. Prereq: admission to music education. Coreq: MUS 484 or MUS 486.

CourseID: P MUE 388. Teaching Laboratory I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Practice in teaching using microteaching techniques and music education methods in a laboratory setting. Prereq: admission to music education. Coreq: MUE 411 or MUE 413.

CourseID: P MUE 392. Instrumental Techniques: [Topic]. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Elementary instruction in pedagogy and performance of various instruments. Sections in violin and cello, low brass, high brass, percussion, flute and clarinet, saxophone, oboe and bassoon, and voice. Instrument rental fee. Prereq: admission to music education.

CourseID: P MUE 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Individual study of topics at a level above that available in the standard curriculum. Prereq: completion of all regularly scheduled courses related to the topic or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUE 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Various advanced topics offered periodically according to student and faculty interest and availability.

CourseID: P MUE 408. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-21 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Various topics at a level above that available in the standard curriculum.

CourseID: P MUE 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Practical experience in guiding learning activities.

CourseID: P MUE 411. Band Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Concerns of band teachers in secondary and elementary schools. Observations, procedures, and instructional materials; planning and teaching lessons for analysis and criticism. Sequence. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits; admission to the MUP 300 level in primary instrument required. Prereq: admission to music education major; admission to the MUP 300 level on primary instrument; MUE 392, MUS 486; coreq: MUE 388 or MUE 406.

CourseID: P MUE 412. Elementary Music Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to a variety of skills and techniques necessary for successful music teaching in elementary school settings. Laboratory fee. Prereq: admission to music education; admission to the MUP 300 level; MUE 411, MUE 413; coreq: MUE 406, MUE 486.

CourseID: P MUE 413. Secondary Choral Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Secondary choral music curriculum, teaching methods, sight singing and music literacy, developing independent musicianship, philosophical and social foundation of vocal music education in the public schools. Prereq: admission to music education major; admission to the MUP 300 level in voice or piano; MUS 484; coreq: MUE 388 or MUE 488.

CourseID: P MUE 420. Contemporary Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of contemporary methodologies used in planning and implementation of musical experiences for children in elementary school, including Dalcroze, Kodaly, Orff, and comprehensive musicianship. Laboratory fee. Prereq: MUE 412, MUS 484.

CourseID: P MUE 428. Music for Early Childhood. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Musical characteristics and abilities of preschool children. Suitable materials and musical experiences; techniques involving parents and children in a laboratory setting. Laboratory fee. Repeatable once for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MUE 429. Music in Special Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Music for disabled or gifted learners. Educational and therapeutic uses of music for mentally, physically, and emotionally disabled as well as gifted learners.

CourseID: P MUE 430. Music Classroom Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques in classroom management; crises prevention and intervention; techniques for providing a safe and positive classroom environment; professional ethics and legal expectations. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits.

CourseID: P MUE 432. Music in School and Society. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary and secondary school music programs, past and present, and their relationships to the communities they serve.

CourseID: P MUE 438. Curricular Strategies in Music Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Procedures for developing music courses for today’s schools; determination of goals, content, instructional materials, and evaluative criteria; exploration of significant curriculum development projects in music education.

CourseID: P MUE 442. Teaching Singing in the Classroom. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods for teaching group vocal technique in the classroom with emphasis on elementary, mid-level, and emerging adult voices. Concentration on development of the adolescent changing voice. Prereq: admission to music education; coreq: MUE 387.

CourseID: P MUE 455. Marching Band Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaching methods for secondary school marching bands.

CourseID: P MUE 456. String Methods. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaching methods for the beginning string class in elementary and middle schools. Development of technique sequences for string groups in secondary schools.

CourseID: P MUE 459. Suzuki Pedagogy I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills for teaching beginning violin students and their parents using the Suzuki method, its philosophies, and Book I repertoire. Required observation and teaching assignment with Community Music Institute.

CourseID: P MUE 460. Suzuki Pedagogy II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills for teaching beginning violin students using the Suzuki method, its philosophies, and Book II repertoire; methods for introducing music-reading and basic ensemble skills. Prereq: MUE 459.

CourseID: P MUE 461. Suzuki Pedagogy III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills for teaching intermediate violin students using the Suzuki method, its philosophies, and Book III repertoire, as well as supplementary repertoire, etudes, and scale studies. Prereq: MUE 460.

CourseID: P MUE 462. Suzuki Pedagogy IV. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Development of skills for teaching advanced intermediate violin students using the Suzuki method, its philosophies, and Book IV repertoire, as well as supplementary repertoire, etudes, and scale studies. Prereq: MUE 461.

CourseID: P MUE 463. Pedagogy Methods: Violin and Viola. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Principles and techniques of violin and viola teaching selected from the pedagogical approaches of Flesch, Galamian, Dounis, Rolland.

CourseID: P MUE 471. Piano Pedagogy I: Teaching Beginners. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P In-depth study of beginning methods and materials for children and adults. Individual teaching experience. Offered alternating years.

CourseID: P MUE 472. Piano Pedagogy II: Teaching Groups. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods and materials for group instruction of all ages and levels. Survey of learning theories and new technologies. Individual and group teaching experience. Offered alternating years. Prereq: MUE 471; coreq: MUE 409.

CourseID: P MUE 473. Piano Pedagogy III: Teaching Intermediate Levels. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of repertoire, technique, and teaching methods appropriate for intermediate-level piano students. Individual and master-class teaching experience. Offered alternating years. Prereq: MUE 472; coreq MUE 409.

Descriptions: P Practice in teaching using microteaching techniques and music education methods in a laboratory setting. Prereq: admission to music education.

CourseID: P MUE 555. Marching Band Methods. 3 Credits.

CourseID: P MUE 556. String Methods. 3 Credits.

CourseID: P MUE 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Professionally related experience, on campus or elsewhere, supervised by a qualified expert both in planning and in carrying out the project. Prereq: knowledge and competence in the substance of the activity and in curricular planning.

CourseID: P MUE 613. Research Methods in Music Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Experimental research including problem identification, research design, influencing variables, research tools, and the interpretation of data in relation to the teaching of music.

CourseID: P MUE 632. Music in School and Society. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Musical experiences and responses in contemporary society; standards for musical quality. Elementary and secondary school music programs, past and present, and their relationships to the communities they serve.

CourseID: P MUE 638. Curricular Strategies in Music Education. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Procedures for developing music courses for today's schools; determination of goals, content, instructional materials, and evaluative criteria; exploration of significant curriculum development projects in music education.

CourseID: P MUE 639. Pedagogy and Practicum: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaching strategies and practical application. Topics include composition, conducting, ethnomusicology, jazz studies, music education, music history, music technology, music theory, performance practice, instrumental conducting, voice, keyboard, strings, woodwinds, brass, and percussion. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 9 credits.

CourseID: P MUE 641. College Music Teaching. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Developing knowledge, skills, and attitudes useful for teaching music; current principles of educational psychology at the college level, instructional techniques, tests and measurements.

CourseID: P MUE 647. Psychology of Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of psychological, physiological, and neurological aspects of musical behavior and experience, including acoustics, human hearing, perception and cognition, development and expertise, affective response and preference, unusual abilities.

CourseID: P MUJ 180. Jazz Performance Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Drills and practical application of scales, chords, harmonic progressions, rhythmic patterns, and approach-note groups for development of skills in small jazz ensembles.

CourseID: P MUJ 181. Jazz Performance Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Drills and practical application of scales, chords, harmonic progressions, rhythmic patterns, and approach-note groups for development of skills in small jazz ensembles. Prereq: MUJ 180

CourseID: P MUJ 182. Jazz Performance Laboratory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Drills and practical application of scales, chords, harmonic progressions, rhythmic patterns, and approach-note groups for development of skills in small jazz ensembles. Prereq: MUJ 181

CourseID: P MUJ 270. Jazz Theory. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to jazz harmony: chord symbols, chord voicing practices, analysis, reharmonization practices, scale choices for improvisation, creation of bass lines.

CourseID: P MUJ 271. Functional Jazz Piano I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Performance of one- and two-handed comping style including common voice-leading practices, scales, and harmonic formulas. Reading from chord symbols and lead sheets. Sequence. Prereq: MUJ 270.

CourseID: P MUJ 272. Functional Jazz Piano II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Performance of one- and two-handed comping style including common voice-leading practices, scales, and harmonic formulas. Reading from chord symbols and lead sheets. Sequence. Prereq: MUJ 271.

CourseID: P MUJ 273. Jazz Improvisation I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Task-oriented performance of selected standard jazz repertoire. Chord and scale study, solo transcription, analysis, pattern practice, simple compositional forms. Prereq: MUJ 270.

CourseID: P MUJ 274. Jazz Improvisation II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Task-oriented performance of selected standard jazz repertoire. Chord alteration, chord substitution, reharmonization and chromaticism. Prereq: MUJ 273.

CourseID: P MUJ 350. History of Jazz, 1900–1950. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, biography, multiculturalism, and racism in early jazz and swing through modern jazz. Includes Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis.

CourseID: P MUJ 351. History of Jazz, 1940 to Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P History, biography, multiculturalism, and racism in modern jazz and free jazz to present. Includes Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Ornette Coleman.

CourseID: P MUJ 390. Jazz Laboratory Band III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 7 credits. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUJ 391. Jazz Laboratory Band II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 7 credits. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUJ 392. Oregon Jazz Ensemble. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Ensemble fee. Prereq: audition.

CourseID: P MUJ 395. Small Jazz Ensemble: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Improvisation group. Study current and past small-group jazz performances. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 14 credits. Ensemble fee. Prereq: audition.

Descriptions: P Composition, arranging, and performance of works for large and chamber jazz ensembles. Preparation of works for graduate degree recitals. Sequence. Prereq: MUJ 483/MUJ 583.

Descriptions: P Composition, arranging, and performance of works for large and chamber jazz ensembles. Preparation of works for graduate degree recitals. Sequence. Prereq: MUJ 484/MUJ 584.

CourseID: P MUJ 660. Survey of Jazz Composition. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Overview of important developments and historically significant figures in jazz composition and arranging. Analysis of their music and stylistic traits.

CourseID: P MUJ 661. Jazz Program Planning and Development. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Designing and nurturing a successful jazz program. Jazz curriculum, grant writing, budgets, resources, organizing student support, setting and reaching program goals.

CourseID: P MUJ 690. Jazz Laboratory Band III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 7 credits. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUJ 691. Jazz Laboratory Band II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 7 credits. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUJ 692. Oregon Jazz Ensemble. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Large ensembles performing repertoire associated with the jazz idiom. Performances on campus, in the community, and at jazz festivals. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUJ 695. Small Jazz Ensemble: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Improvisation group. Study current and past small-group jazz performances. Repeatable six times for a maximum of 14 credits. Ensemble fee.

CourseID: P MUP 100. Beginning Class Piano. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Beginning-level group instruction for students with little or no previous training. Repeatable once for maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 125. Understanding Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents the basic elements of music, historical style periods of Western art music, development of jazz and popular music.

CourseID: P MUS 131. Music Theory I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Coreq: MUS 134, MUS 137.

CourseID: P MUS 132. Music Theory II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 131, MUS 134, MUS 137.

CourseID: P MUS 133. Music Theory III. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 132, MUS 135, MUS 138.

CourseID: P MUS 134. Aural Skills I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Coreq: MUS 131, MUS 137.

CourseID: P MUS 135. Aural Skills II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 131, MUS 134, MUS 137.

CourseID: P MUS 136. Aural Skills III. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Elementary ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 132, MUS 135, MUS 138.

CourseID: P MUS 137. Keyboard Skills I. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Coreq MUS 131, MUS 134.

CourseID: P MUS 138. Keyboard Skills II. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Prereq: MUS 131, MUS 134, MUS 137.

CourseID: P MUS 139. Keyboard Skills III. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Prereq: MUS 132, MUS 135, MUS 138.

CourseID: P MUS 141. Popular Piano and Musicianship I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding general musicianship—what it is and how it relates to genre and culture—in popular music. Sequence with MUS 142, MUS 143.

CourseID: P MUS 142. Popular Piano and Musicianship II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continuing study of musicianship—integrated music theory, ear training, and piano—through piano instruction in popular music styles. Sequence with MUS 141, MUS 143. Prereq: MUS 141.

CourseID: P MUS 143. Popular Piano and Musicianship III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Continuing study of musicianship—integrated music theory, ear training, and piano—through piano instruction in popular music styles. Sequence with MUS 141, MUS 142. Prereq: MUS 142.

CourseID: P MUS 151. Popular Songwriting. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composing and producing songs using software applications and studying historical examples to understand how musical techniques reflect societal trends and express ideas. Music background optional. Laboratory fee.

CourseID: P MUS 155. Introduction to Lyric Diction. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to pronunciation of standard languages for students pursuing careers related to singing. The International Phonetic Alphabet is applied to the texts of simple repertoire. English, Italian, Spanish. Sequence. Coreq: MUP 174 or above, Voice.

CourseID: P MUS 156. Introduction to Lyric Diction. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to pronunciation of standard languages for students pursuing careers related to singing. The International Phonetic Alphabet is applied to the texts of simple repertoire. German, French. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 155; coreq: MUP 174 or above, Voice.

CourseID: P MUS 227. Elements of Electronic Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to experimental and popular electronic music. Topics include fundamental elements of musical construction, history, technology, composers, musicians, copyright law, sampling, styles, and aesthetics.

CourseID: P MUS 231. Music Theory IV. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 133, MUS 136, MUS 139 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 232. Music Theory V. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 231.

CourseID: P MUS 233. Music Theory VI. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of musical structure, emphasizing the acquisition of descriptive, notational, compositional, and analytical capacity. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 232.

CourseID: P MUS 234. Aural Skills IV. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 133, MUS 136, MUS 139 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 235. Aural Skills V. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 234.

CourseID: P MUS 236. Aural Skills VI. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Ear training through sight singing, dictation, and related activities. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 235.

CourseID: P MUS 237. Keyboard Skills IV. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Prereq: MUS 133, MUS 136, MUS 139 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 238. Keyboard Skills V. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Prereq: MUS 237.

CourseID: P MUS 239. Keyboard Skills VI. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Performance of rhythmic patterns, scales, intervals, and chord progressions. Harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and figured bass on the keyboard. Sequence. Keyboard lab fee. Prereq: MUS 238.

CourseID: P MUS 240. Composition I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to musical composition. Problems of notation, scoring for instruments, basic concepts of form; contemporary techniques; emphasis on student's own beginning creative work. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 133, MUS 136, MUS 139 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 241. Composition I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to musical composition. Problems of notation, scoring for instruments, basic concepts of form; contemporary techniques; emphasis on student's own beginning creative work. Sequence. Prereg: MUS 240.

CourseID: P MUS 242. Composition I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to musical composition. Problems of notation, scoring for instruments, basic concepts of form; contemporary techniques; emphasis on student's own beginning creative work. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 241.

CourseID: P MUS 250. Popular Musics in Global Context. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Surveys the global popular music landscape of the 20th and 21st centuries, with an emphasis on identity and cultural mixture.

CourseID: P MUS 264. Rock History, 1950–70. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of rock emphasizing musical style and social context. Roots of rock through the British Invasion.

CourseID: P MUS 265. Rock History, 1965 to Present. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evolution of rock emphasizing musical style and social context. Psychedelic rock to early rap music.

CourseID: P MUS 267. Survey of Music History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the history and evolution of music, principally Western art music, from the early Middle Ages to the present. Prereq: WR 121.

CourseID: P MUS 268. Survey of Music History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the history and evolution of music, principally Western art music, from the early Middle Ages to the present. Prereq: WR 121.

CourseID: P MUS 269. Survey of Music History. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of the history and evolution of music, principally Western art music, from the early Middle Ages to the present. Prereq: WR 121.

CourseID: P MUS 270. History of the Blues. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traces blues music from its African and African American roots through its 20th-century history and its influence on the values of jazz, rhythm and blues, and country music.

CourseID: P MUS 281. Music of the Woodstock Generation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the relationship between popular music and social upheavals in the United States during the 1960s.

CourseID: P MUS 322. Music Fundamentals. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Music notation and terminology; learning musical rudiments through singing simple songs; introduction to simple melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic instruments. Laboratory fee. Educational foundations majors only.

CourseID: P MUS 327. Analysis: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques of analysis in various types of music. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: MUS 233, MUS 236, MUS 239.

CourseID: P MUS 340. Composition II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of small works for piano, voice, and small ensembles. Prereq: MUS 242 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 341. Composition II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of small works for piano, voice, and small ensembles. Prereq: MUS 340.

CourseID: P MUS 342. Composition II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of small works for piano, voice, and small ensembles. Prereq: MUS 341.

CourseID: P MUS 345M. Music, Politics, and Race. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines a variety of musical forms and their relationship to histories of racial and social justice, inequality, and political movements. Offered alternate years. Multilisted with ES 345M.

CourseID: P MUS 346. Music, Money, and the Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores theory and history of relationship between money and music, and corresponding laws that govern and shape that relationship. Topics include copyright, contract rights, media distribution technology, marketing, unions.

CourseID: P MUS 347. Music, Gender, Sexuality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the intersections of gender, sexuality, race, and identity in popular music and the Western classical canon.

CourseID: P MUS 349. American Ethnic and Protest Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Social change and ethnicity reflected by music of and about Native Americans, African Americans, and women as well as songs of protest and Spanish-speaking groups.

CourseID: P MUS 351. The Music of Bach and Handel. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Compositions by Bach and Handel such as organ chorales, cantatas, oratorios, operas, and masses; cultural context in Germany, France, Italy, and England for the development of their styles.

CourseID: P MUS 356. Innovative Jazz Musicians: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Covers one or two innovative and influential jazz musicians per term. Examines issues of history, biography, multiculturalism, racism, and critical reception. Repeatable twice when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 358. Music in World Cultures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the music of three world regions in their sociocultural context. Emphasis on listening skills, relationships between music and culture, aesthetics, styles, genres, music structures and forms, and participatory music making.

CourseID: P MUS 359. Music of the Americas. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P African American, Latin American, and Native American music in sociocultural context. Includes listening skills, music-culture relationship, aesthetics, styles, genres, music structures and forms, and participatory music making.

CourseID: P MUS 360. Hip-Hop Music: History, Culture, Aesthetics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the history and evolution of hip-hop and rap music in the late 20th and early 21st centuries.

CourseID: P MUS 363. The Beatles and Their Times. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents and examines the music of the Beatles in the context of post– World War II English and United States cultures and 1960s Western youth cultures.

CourseID: P MUS 365. Regional Ethnomusicology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students analyze the music and dance of a specified geographic region in relation to its culture. Covers local performance and genres, social constructions. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits when geographic region changes.

CourseID: P MUS 367. Survey of African Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students analyze musical expression—including traditional, neotraditional, and contemporary mass mediated popular music (Afropop)—in Africa and the diaspora.

CourseID: P MUS 380. Film: Drama, Photography, Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Understanding the manner in which drama, photography, and music combine to form the whole through extensive viewing and analysis.

CourseID: P MUS 382. American Musical Theater. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Students analyze selected American musicals in relation to social conditions and events at different junctures in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 384. Introduction to Conducting. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to conducting with emphasis on the art and study of conducting, baton and left-hand technique, nonverbal communication, leadership, terminology, transpositions, and score reading. Prereq: MUS 233, MUS 236, MUS 239.

CourseID: P MUS 391. Collegium Musicum. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of music repertoire of the medieval, Renaissance, and baroque periods through rehearsals and extensive sight-reading; vocal and instrumental repertoire. Ensemble fee. Prereq: audition.

CourseID: P MUS 393. Oregon Electronic Device Orchestra. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Performance ensemble that uses data-driven musical instruments in combination with software and hardware to perform music and intermedia compositions. Prereq: MUS 447 or MUS 448.

CourseID: P MUS 394. Chamber Ensemble: [Topic]. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Accompanying, Brass Choir, Brass Ensemble, Chamber Ensemble, Trombone Ensemble, Tuba and Euphonium Ensemble, Studio Guitar Ensemble, Jazz Guitar Ensemble, Oregon Percussion Ensemble. Repeatable. Prereq: audition (except chamber ensemble).

CourseID: P MUS 395. Band: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Green Garter Band, Oregon Basketball Band, Oregon Marching Band, Oregon Wind Ensemble, UO Campus Band, UO Symphonic Band, Yellow Garter Band. Ensemble fee for Oregon Wind Ensemble, UO Symphonic Band, UO Campus Band. Prereq: audition (except UO Campus Band and Oregon Marching Band).

CourseID: P MUS 396. Orchestra: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. University Symphony Orchestra, Campus Orchestra. Ensemble fee. Prereq: audition (except Campus Orchestra).

CourseID: P MUS 397. Chorus: [Topic]. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chamber Choir, Concert Choir, Gospel Singers, Repertoire Singers, University Gospel Choir, University Gospel Ensemble, University Singers, Women's Choir. Ensemble fee. Repeatable. Prereq: audition or voice screening (except Concert Choir and Gospel Choir).

CourseID: P MUS 398. Opera Workshop. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Traditional and contemporary repertory for musical theater through analysis, rehearsal, and performance of complete and excerpted works; training in stage movement, diction, and rehearsal techniques. Prereq: audition.

CourseID: P MUS 405. Reading and Conference: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Individual study of topics agreed upon by the student and faculty adviser. Prereq: completion of all regularly scheduled courses related to the topic or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Various topics at an advanced level, offered periodically according to student and faculty interest and availability.

CourseID: P MUS 410. Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Recent courses include Meditation for Performers and Andean Music Ensemble.

CourseID: P MUS 412. Music Theory Review. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of tonal theory. Graduate entrance examination required.

CourseID: P MUS 413. Music History Review. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of music history from the medieval period to the present. Graduate entrance examination required.

CourseID: P MUS 414. Aural Skills Review. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Review of aural skills and sight singing. Graduate entrance examination required.

CourseID: P MUS 416. Post-Tonal Theory I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and analysis of post-tonal music. Concepts of pitch-class set analysis and practical applications. Sequence. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 327.

CourseID: P MUS 417. Post-Tonal Theory II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and analysis of post-tonal music. Concepts of pitch-class set analysis and practical applications. Sequence. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 416.

CourseID: P MUS 421. The Collaborative Pianist. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive study of techniques and literature for artistic ensemble performance by pianists. Includes chamber music, art song, opera arias, accompaniment, sight-reading, and orchestral reduction skills. Sequence. Repeatable once each for maximum of 4 credits per course. Prereq: MUP 271 or above.

CourseID: P MUS 422. The Collaborative Pianist. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive study of techniques and literature for artistic ensemble performance by pianists. Includes chamber music, art song, opera arias, accompaniment, sight-reading, and orchestral reduction skills. Sequence. Repeatable once each for maximum of 4 credits per course. Prereq: MUS 421.

CourseID: P MUS 423. The Collaborative Pianist. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Comprehensive study of techniques and literature for artistic ensemble performance by pianists. Includes chamber music, art song, opera arias, accompaniment, sight-reading, and orchestral reduction skills. Sequence. Repeatable once each for maximum of 4 credits per course. Prereq: MUS 422.

CourseID: P MUS 430. Schenkerian Analysis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analytical techniques, developed by Heinrich Schenker, studied through application to music of all periods and styles. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 327.

CourseID: P MUS 431. Schenkerian Analysis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analytical techniques, developed by Heinrich Schenker, studied through application to music of all periods and styles. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 430.

CourseID: P MUS 433. Counterpoint. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of modal and tonal counterpoint through analysis and composition: 16th-century sacred polyphony. Prereq: MUS 233, MUS 236.

CourseID: P MUS 434. Counterpoint. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of modal and tonal counterpoint through analysis and composition: baroque imitative counterpoint. Prereq: MUS 433.

CourseID: P MUS 435. Counterpoint. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of modal and tonal counterpoint through analysis and composition: varies—typically devoted to more advanced fugal writing, 20th-century counterpoint, or other modal composition. Prereq: MUS 434.

CourseID: P MUS 438. Composers Forum. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Formulation of a two- or three-concert series of student compositions; sessions with visiting composers and UO performers and listening projects related to these residencies. Repeatable eleven times for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 439. Scoring for Voices and Instruments. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Techniques of arranging and scoring for various types of choral and instrumental groups. Prereq: MUS 233, MUS 236, MUS 239.

CourseID: P MUS 440. Composition III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of works including large or chamber ensembles. Preparation of works for senior recital. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits. Prereq: MUS 342.

CourseID: P MUS 441. Composition III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of works including large or chamber ensembles. Preparation of works for senior recital. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: MUS 440.

CourseID: P MUS 442. Composition III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Composition and public performance of works including large or chamber ensembles. Preparation of works for senior recital. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: MUS 441.

CourseID: P MUS 445. Electronic Composition. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Develops an elementary understanding about how computers and software are used to process digital audio and create musical compositions. Laboratory fee. Repeatable twenty-four times for maximum of 75 credits. Prereq: MUS 447, MUS 448, MUS 476.

CourseID: P MUS 446. Computer Music Applications: [Topic]. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Use of computers for music notation, education, analysis, performance, research, and other applications. Repeatable three times when topic changes for maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 447. Digital Audio and Sound Design. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines concepts of digital audio representation, sampling, and processing; considers audio mixing, basic synthesis, and sound modification techniques and fundamentals of electroacoustic composition. Laboratory fee.

CourseID: P MUS 448. Interactive Media Performance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines concepts of interactive performance using MIDI, digital audio, and video processing, and considers issues related to designing performance algorithms in software. Laboratory fee.

CourseID: P MUS 450. SensorMusik. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Examines the fundamental principles for microprocessors and sensor interface design within the context of musical performance, composition, and improvisation. Repeatable thrice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 451. Introduction to Ethnomusicology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P World musics studied in their social and cultural contexts. Compares the varied approaches, ideas, and methods of selected American and European researchers since 1980.

CourseID: P MUS 452. Musical Instruments of the World. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines instruments of the world in their cultural contexts. Covers cross-cultural issues and focuses on particular geographic areas. Includes films, recordings, live demonstrations.

CourseID: P MUS 455. Lyric Diction. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and International Phonetic Alphabet transcription of song and opera texts with emphasis on the singer's approach to performance. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 156.

CourseID: P MUS 456. Lyric Diction. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analysis and International Phonetic Alphabet transcription of song and opera texts with emphasis on the singer's approach to performance. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 156.

CourseID: P MUS 460. Music and Gender. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the role of gender in shaping the music that is created, performed, taught, and listened to in representative cultures of the world, including the West.

CourseID: P MUS 462. Popular Musics in the African Diaspora. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines social and historical contexts of popular musics in the African diaspora from the 20th century forward. Geographic focus is North America, the Caribbean, and Africa.

CourseID: P MUS 463. Popular Music Studies. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores current research and foundational texts in the interdisciplinary field of popular music studies.

CourseID: P MUS 467. Solo Vocal Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Solo songs with accompaniment; the lute air and Purcell; 19th-century art songs in Germany and France; 20th-century British, American, and Continental song literature; development of bases for artistic performance and sound critical judgment through study of text, voice, and accompaniment. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 269 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 468. Solo Vocal Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Solo songs with accompaniment; the lute air and Purcell; 19th-century art songs in Germany and France; 20th-century British, American, and Continental song literature; development of bases for artistic performance and sound critical judgment through study of text, voice, and accompaniment. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 269 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 470. History of Electroacoustic Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines the development of aesthetic movements, styles, media, instruments, and performance practice related to electroacoustic music. Repeatable once with no conditions. Prereq: Standing as a music technology major or meeting the prerequisites for history survey courses.

CourseID: P MUS 471. Musical Performance Networks. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines various types of network architectures and data-processing and mapping strategies that can be applied to real-time musical outcomes. Repeatable with no conditions.

CourseID: P MUS 474. History of Opera. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical study of the musical and dramatic content of operas forming the standard international repertoire, from Monteverdi to Mozart. Prereq: MUS 269 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 475. History of Opera. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Critical study of the musical and dramatic content of operas forming the standard international repertoire, from Mozart to the present. Prereq: MUS 269 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 476. Digital Audio Workstation Tech I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores how MIDI (musical instrument digital interface) is used to compose, edit, and record using a personal computer. Sequence with MUS 477 and MUS 478. Basic Mac skills recommended. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Laboratory fee.

CourseID: P MUS 477. Digital Audio Workstation Tech II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores the principles and techniques used in recording audio with a computer. Sequence with MUS 476 and MUS 478. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Laboratory fee. Prereq: MUS 476.

CourseID: P MUS 478. Digital Audio Workstation Tech III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Explores advanced uses of plug-ins, mixing, and editing using a computer. Sequence with MUS 476 and MUS 477. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Laboratory fee. Prereq: MUS 477.

CourseID: P MUS 480. Audio Recording Techniques I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Hardware and software techniques for use in a recording studio environment, including microphone usage, recording techniques, and digital production. Sequence with MUS 481, MUS 482. Laboratory fee.

CourseID: P MUS 481. Audio Recording Techniques II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Application of advanced recording techniques. Sequence with MUS 480, MUS 482. Laboratory fee. Pre- or coreq: MUS 480.

CourseID: P MUS 482. Audio Recording Techniques III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Focuses on the production concepts and techniques necessary to produce a full-length, professional-quality compact disc. Sequence with MUS 480, MUS 481. Laboratory fee. Prereq: MUS 481.

CourseID: P MUS 484. Choral Conducting and Literature. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Choral conducting, gesture and communication, rehearsal technique, and choral literature appropriate for secondary school choral music programs (grades 6–12), community youth choirs, and collegiate ensembles. Repeatable once for maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: MUP 140 or higher. Coreq: MUE 387, MUE 406 Fld Prac Public School.

CourseID: P MUS 486. Instrumental Conducting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Conducting techniques as applied to band and orchestral music with emphasis on various styles and periods of music; study of 20th-century rhythms and related conducting problems. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Prereq: major standing. Coreq: MUE 387.

CourseID: P MUS 490. Balinese Gamelan. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Pacific Rim Gamelan ensemble. Performance of original compositions and traditional music for gamelan. Limited to twelve performers. Three public performances a year.

CourseID: P MUS 499. Senior Project. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Projects in music history, analysis, theory, composition, performance, or related disciplines designed by the student in consultation with the instructor. Repeatable twice for maximum of 9 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Various topics at an advanced level, offered periodically according to student and faculty interest and availability.

CourseID: P MUS 516. Post-Tonal Theory I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and analysis of post-tonal music. Concepts of pitch-class set analysis and practical applications. Sequence. Offered alternate years.

Descriptions: P Use of reference, research, and bibliographical sources in music. Sequence.

CourseID: P MUS 614. Introduction to Musicology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces musicology and several of its subfields; includes current and recent arguments. Prereq: major standing.

CourseID: P MUS 620. Bibliography in Instrumental Conducting. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of research in conducting. Discussion of rehearsal strategies and psychology.

CourseID: P MUS 621. Wind Repertoire. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey and analysis of music composed for large wind groups, from 1500 to the present. Sequence.

CourseID: P MUS 622. Wind Repertoire. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey and analysis of music composed for large wind groups, from 1500 to the present. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 621.

Descriptions: P Survey and analysis of music composed for large wind groups, from 1500 to the present. Sequence. Prereq: MUS 622.

Descriptions: P Study, preparation, and conducting of works for instrumental ensembles in rehearsals and performances. Repeatable twice for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MUS 625. Orchestral Music: Bach to Beethoven. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of orchestral music from Bach to Beethoven. Sequence with MUS

CourseID: P MUS 626. Orchestral Music: 1825 to Modern. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Survey of orchestral music from 1825 to the modern era. Sequence with MUS 625. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 629. Repertoire and Analysis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analytical interpretations of musical works in a context that focuses on repertoire rather than on particular analytical methodologies. The pieces studied vary each time the course is offered. Repeatable with varying repertoire.

CourseID: P MUS 630. History of Theory I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination and evaluation of theories of music from ancient times to the 16th century, including Aristides Quintilianus, Boethius, Hucbald, Guido, Franco, Tinctoris, Ramis, and Aron. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 631. History of Theory II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examination and evaluation of theories of music from the 16th to 19th centuries, including Glarean, Zarlino, Descartes, Rameau, Tartini, Kirnberger, C. P. E. Bach, Fetis, Sechter, and Helmholtz. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 632. History of Theory III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Theories of harmony and structure ranging from the mid-19th century to the present, including Hauptmann, Riemann, Schenker, Schoenberg, Hindemith, Babbitt, Forte, Lewin, Straus, and Lerdahl. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 633. Advanced Schenkerian Analysis. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced analytical techniques developed by Heinrich Schenker. Pre- or coreq: MUS 431/531 or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 634. Advanced Post-Tonal Theory. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Analytic approaches to twelve-tone music.

CourseID: P MUS 640. Advanced Composition Studies. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio instruction in composition. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits. Prereq: MUS 442/MUS 542; coreq: MUS 538.

CourseID: P MUS 641. Advanced Composition Studies. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio instruction in composition. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits. Prereq: MUS 640; coreq: MUS 538.

CourseID: P MUS 642. Advanced Composition Studies. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Studio instruction in composition. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits. Prereq: MUS 641; coreq MUS 538.

CourseID: P MUS 643. Notation of Medieval and Renaissance Music. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Representative examples of notational systems and practices in Western European polyphony from 900 to 1600. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 645. Advanced Electronic Composition. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Develops an advanced understanding of computers and software and how they are used to process digital audio and create musical and mediacompositions. Repeatable with instructor’s consent. Laboratory fee. Prereq: MUS 547, MUS 548, MUS 576; or equivalent.

CourseID: P MUS 650. Piano Literature. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of solo piano literature from Bach to the present. Sequence with MUS 650, MUS 651, MUS 652. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 651. Piano Literature. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of solo piano literature from Bach to the present. Sequence with MUS 650, MUS 651, MUS 652. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 650.

CourseID: P MUS 652. Piano Literature. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Advanced study of solo piano literature from Bach to the present. Sequence with MUS 650, MUS 651, MUS 652. Offered alternate years. Prereq: MUS 651.

CourseID: P MUS 660. Music in the Middle Ages. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Sources of Western European music in classical antiquity and the Near East; sacred monophony, secular monophony; development of polyphony. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 661. Music in the Renaissance. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P The central Renaissance style in 15th-century France and Italy; high Renaissance music; late Renaissance music; developments in England and Germany; instrumental music; Renaissance music theory. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 662. Music in the Baroque Era. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Musical genres in Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Britain, the Netherlands, Spain, Mexico, and South America in historical, social, political, and cultural contexts—early 17th century through Bach and Handel. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 663. Music in the Classical Period. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of galant, Emfindsamer, and classical styles from c. 1730 to Boccherini, Haydn, and Mozart. Focus on instrumental and sacred music, and on opera before Mozart. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 664. Music in the Romantic Era. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Virtuosic and lyric extremes in instrumental and vocal styles. Literary romanticism, descriptive music, and the Lied; opera in France and Italy; Wagner's music drama as Gesamtkunstwerk. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 665. Music in the 20th Century. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Crisis of romanticism and tonality: transition of Debussy, Mahler, and others; new styles of Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Bartok; developments in the United States; implications of recent trends. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: P MUS 680. Historical Performance Practices I. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of sound production, rhetoric, pronunciation, instrumentation, pitch, temperament, and ornamentation in period vocal and instrumental solo and ensemble music, from the 12th through 16th centuries. Offered once every third year.

CourseID: P MUS 681. Historical Performance Practices II. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of sound production, rhetoric, pronunciation, instrumentation, pitch, temperament, and ornamentation in period vocal and instrumental solo and ensemble music in the 17th and early 18th centuries. Offered once every third year.

CourseID: P MUS 682. Historical Performance Practices III. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduction to theory and practice of sound production, rhetoric, pronunciation, instrumentation, pitch, temperament, and ornamentation in period vocal and instrumental solo and ensemble music in the late 18th and 19th centuries. Offered once every third year.

CourseID: P MUS 691. Collegium Musicum. 1-3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of music repertoire of the medieval, Renaissance, and baroque periods through rehearsals and extensive sight-reading; vocal and instrumental repertoire. Ensemble fee. Prereq: audition.

CourseID: P MUS 693. Oregon Electronic Device Orchestra. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Performance ensemble that uses data-driven musical instruments in combination with software and hardware to perform music and intermedia compositions. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: MUS 547, MUS 548.

CourseID: P MUS 694. Chamber Ensemble: [Topic]. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Accompanying, Brass Choir, Brass Ensemble, Chamber Ensemble, Trombone Ensemble, Tuba and Euphonium Ensemble, Studio Guitar Ensemble, Jazz Guitar Ensemble, Latin Jazz Ensemble, Oregon Percussion Ensemble. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: audition (except chamber ensemble).

CourseID: P MUS 695. Band: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Green Garter Band, Oregon Basketball Band, Oregon Marching Band, Oregon Wind Ensemble, UO Campus Band, UO Symphonic Band, Yellow Garter Band. Ensemble fee for Oregon Wind Ensemble, UO Symphonic Band, UO Campus Band. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: audition (except UO Campus Band and Oregon Marching Band).

CourseID: P MUS 696. Orchestra: [Topic]. 1-2 Credits.
Descriptions: P University Symphony Orchestra, Campus Orchestra. Ensemble fee. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: audition (except Campus Orchestra).

CourseID: P MUS 697. Chorus: [Topic]. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Chamber Choir, Concert Choir, Gospel Singers, Repertoire Singers, University Gospel Choir, University Gospel Ensemble, University Singers, Women's Choir. Ensemble fee. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: audition or voice screening (except Concert Choir and Gospel Choir).

CourseID: P MUS 698. Opera Workshop. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Traditional and contemporary repertory for musical theater through analysis, rehearsal, and performance of complete and excerpted works; training in stage movement, diction, and rehearsal techniques. Repeatable 11 times. Prereq: audition.

CourseID: P AIM 642. Managing Organizations in Technological Environments. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines critical issues in business and provides a framework for redesigning organizations in response to change. Topics include market trends, work force changes, and environmental conditions.

CourseID: P AIM 646. Creating Business Solutions with Technology. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Methods of aligning information technology planning with corporate goals and objectives. Topics include strategic planning, design and evaluation of techology projects.

CourseID: P AIM 654. Information Design and Communication. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses concepts, vocabulary, tools and technologies related to the design and preservation of electronically processed and print information that increases attention and understanding.

CourseID: P AIM 656. Information Design Trends. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Examines information design trends, as they affect standards and website implementation, from a project manager's perspective.

CourseID: P AIM 665. Project Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Presents theoretical and practical applications of scheduling and project management. Topics include planning, budgeting, and evaluation using project management tools.

CourseID: P AIM 668. Information Systems and Management. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Information systems, how they change, the role of management, and the structure of organizations. Topics include the strategic role of information, managing systems implementation, and end-user computing.

CourseID: P JC 610. Joint Campus Experimental Course: [Topic]. 1-15 Credits.
Descriptions: P Research Centers and Institutes

CourseID: P UGST 100. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P UGST 111. Academic Residential Community—Arts and Letters: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.

CourseID: P UGST 111. Academic Residential Community—Arts and Letters: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the academic and social aspects of university life and to the discipline of Arts and Letters with a small group environment with Arts and Letters faculty. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P UGST 112. Academic Residential Community—Social Science: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the academic and social aspects of university life and the study of social science within a small group environment. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P UGST 113. Academic Residential Community—Science: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Introduces students to the academic and social aspects of university life and to the discipline of Science with a small group environment with Sciences faculty. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 4 credits.

CourseID: P UGST 200M. Temporary Multilisted Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P UGST 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P UGST 298. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P UGST 300. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.

CourseID: P UGST 300. Temporary Group-Satisfying Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P UGST 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.

CourseID: P UGST 400M. Temporary Multilisted Course. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P UGST 404. Internship: [Topic]. 1-12 Credits.

CourseID: P TLC 101. Introduction to University Study. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Helps students learn, adapt, and apply effective study skills, including strategies for time management, note taking, critical reading, writing, and test preparation.

CourseID: P TLC 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Addresses specific topics such as time management, reading, writing, testing, presentation skills, and math strategies. Repeatable twice per topic for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P TLC 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics include grammar and style, research skills, critical thinking, communication, and speed reading.

CourseID: P TLC 409. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P TLC 508. . 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P TLC 608. Workshop: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.

CourseID: P TLC 609. Practicum: [Topic]. 1-4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 121. Military Science I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Constitutional beginnings, organization, and role of today's army; physical fitness; introduction to equipment and small-unit operations.

CourseID: P MIL 122. Military Science I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Operational and survival skills, topographic map reading and land navigation, first-aid, small-unit tactics, and practical exercises with Army weapons and equipment.

CourseID: P MIL 123. Military Science I. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Characteristics and methods of successful leadership--building trust, understanding, cooperation, and communication; responsibilities of leadership including personal motivation and ethics.

CourseID: P MIL 131. Physical Training. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Participatory physical training program that follows the U.S. Army's physical fitness program. Prepares students for the rigors of military activities through a systematic physical conditioning process. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 141. Ranger Challenge. 3 Credits.
Descriptions: P Course training focuses on basic infantry individual and team skills. Course culminates in squad-sized teams competing against other schools in the region. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 191. Leadership Laboratory. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Laboratory for practical experience. Assesses cadet leadership potential, communication, problem-solving, and decision-making skills. One field-training exercise a term. Repeatable five times for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. A current topic is Physical Fitness Training. Repeatable six times for maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 221. Military Science II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Basic leadership and technical military skills--map reading, first aid, and communication skills. Focus is individual abilities and building effective teams.

CourseID: P MIL 222. Military Science II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Purpose, roles, and obligations of commissioned officers; organizational values and their application to the decision-making process; military tactics in small-unit operations.

CourseID: P MIL 223. Military Science II. 2 Credits.
Descriptions: P Self and team development in Army operations; comprehension and use of the five-paragraph Operations Order; tactics; land navigation.

CourseID: P MIL 321. Military Science III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Teaches the sixteen leadership dimensions and application to infantry tactics, operation orders, and orienteering. Lectures, laboratory, field training exercises. Prereq or coreq: MIL 223

CourseID: P MIL 322. Military Science III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Strengthens individual abilities with experience in marksmanship, drill, and tactics. Lectures, laboratory, field training exercises. Prereq: MIL 223

CourseID: P MIL 323. Military Science III. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Evaluates leadership abilities in tactical and nontactical settings. Lectures, laboratory, field training exercises. Prereq: MIL 223

CourseID: P MIL 331. Physical Training. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: P Emphasizes physical fitness and overall good health. Focus is on the intensity, duration, and frequency of fitness training, resulting in improved health and physical fitness. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 6 credits.

CourseID: P MIL 421. Military Science IV. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Planning, evaluating, and conducting unit training and practical exercises. Lectures, laboratory, and field training exercises. Prereq: MIL 323.

CourseID: P MIL 422. Military Science IV. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Study of judicial and nonjudicial proceedings and administrative actions available to commanders. Lectures, laboratory, and field training exercises. Prereq: MIL 323.

CourseID: P MIL 423. Military Science IV. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: P Duties and responsibilities of a lieutenant; ethical decision making, counseling subordinates, evaluation reports, transition to active duty. Lectures, laboratory, and field training exercises. Prereq: MIL 323.

CourseID: P LIB 199. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to general library resources and to subject-related library resources. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P LIB 399. Special Studies: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Introduction to general library resources and to subject-related library resources. Repeatable when topic changes.

CourseID: P LIB 407. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are Library Resources, Bibliography.

CourseID: P LIB 507. Seminar: [Topic]. 1-5 Credits.
Descriptions: P Repeatable. Topics are Library Resources, Bibliography.
